<p>For screenshotting a page, we can use a library such as <a href="https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas" class="uri">https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas</a>. What it does is just walks the page and draws it on <code>&lt;canvas&gt;</code>. Then we can get a <code>Blob</code> of it the same way as above.</p>
<h2 id="from-blob-to-arraybuffer">From Blob to ArrayBuffer</h2>
<p>The <code>Blob</code> constructor allows to create a blob from almost anything, including any <code>BufferSource</code>.</p>
<p>But if we need to perform low-level processing, we can get the lowest-level <code>ArrayBuffer</code> from it using <code>FileReader</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb38"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-1" title="1"><span class="co">// get arrayBuffer from blob</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> fileReader <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">FileReader</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-4" title="4"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-5" title="5"><span class="va">fileReader</span>.<span class="at">readAsArrayBuffer</span>(blob)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-6" title="6"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-8" title="8"><span class="ss">fileReader.onload = function</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">event</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-9" title="9"><span class="ss">  let arrayBuffer = fileReader.result;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb38-10" title="10"><span class="ss">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="summary-7">Summary</h2>
<p>While <code>ArrayBuffer</code>, <code>Uint8Array</code> and other <code>BufferSource</code> are ‚Äúbinary data‚Äù, a <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/FileAPI/#dfn-Blob">Blob</a> represents ‚Äúbinary data with type‚Äù.</p>
<p>That makes Blobs convenient for upload/download operations, that are so common in the browser.</p>
<p>Methods that perform web-requests, such as <a href="info:xmlhttprequest">XMLHttpRequest</a>, <a href="info:fetch">fetch</a> and so on, can work with <code>Blob</code> natively, as well as with other binary types.</p>
<p>We can easily convert between <code>Blob</code> and low-level binary data types:</p>
<ul>
<li>We can make a Blob from a typed array using <code>new Blob(...)</code> constructor.</li>
<li>We can get back <code>ArrayBuffer</code> from a Blob using <code>FileReader</code>, and then create a view over it for low-level binary processing. # File and FileReader</li>
</ul>
<p>A <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/FileAPI/#dfn-file">File</a> object inherits from <code>Blob</code> and is extended with filesystem-related capabilities.</p>
<p>There are two ways to obtain it.</p>
<p>First, there‚Äôs a constructor, similar to <code>Blob</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb39"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb39-1" title="1"><span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">File</span>(fileParts<span class="op">,</span> fileName<span class="op">,</span> [options])</a></code></pre></div>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>fileParts</code></strong> ‚Äì is an array of Blob/BufferSource/String values.</li>
<li><strong><code>fileName</code></strong> ‚Äì file name string.</li>
<li><strong><code>options</code></strong> ‚Äì optional object:
<ul>
<li><strong><code>lastModified</code></strong> ‚Äì the timestamp (integer date) of last modification.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<p>Second, more often we get a file from <code>&lt;input type="file"&gt;</code> or drag‚Äôn‚Äôdrop or other browser interfaces. In that case, the file gets this information from OS.</p>
<p>As <code>File</code> inherits from <code>Blob</code>, <code>File</code> objects have the same properties, plus: - <code>name</code> ‚Äì the file name, - <code>lastModified</code> ‚Äì the timestamp of last modification.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs how we can get a <code>File</code> object from <code>&lt;input type="file"&gt;</code>:</p>
<p>```html run <input type="file" onchange="showFile(this)"></p>
<script>
function showFile(input) {
  let file = input.files[0];

  alert(`File name: ${file.name}`); // e.g my.png
  alert(`Last modified: ${file.lastModified}`); // e.g 1552830408824
}
</script>
<p>```</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>The input may select multiple files, so `input.files` is an array-like object with them. Here we have only one file, so we just take `input.files[0]`.</code></pre>
<h2 id="filereader">FileReader</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/FileAPI/#dfn-filereader">FileReader</a> is an object with the sole purpose of reading data from <code>Blob</code> (and hence <code>File</code> too) objects.</p>
<p>It delivers the data using events, as reading from disk may take time.</p>
<p>The constructor:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb41"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb41-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> reader <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">FileReader</span>()<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// no arguments</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The main methods:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>readAsArrayBuffer(blob)</code></strong> ‚Äì read the data in binary format <code>ArrayBuffer</code>.</li>
<li><strong><code>readAsText(blob, [encoding])</code></strong> ‚Äì read the data as a text string with the given encoding (<code>utf-8</code> by default).</li>
<li><strong><code>readAsDataURL(blob)</code></strong> ‚Äì read the binary data and encode it as base64 data url.</li>
<li><strong><code>abort()</code></strong> ‚Äì cancel the operation.</li>
</ul>
<p>The choice of <code>read*</code> method depends on which format we prefer, how we‚Äôre going to use the data.</p>
<ul>
<li><code>readAsArrayBuffer</code> ‚Äì for binary files, to do low-level binary operations. For high-level operations, like slicing, <code>File</code> inherits from <code>Blob</code>, so we can call them directly, without reading.</li>
<li><code>readAsText</code> ‚Äì for text files, when we‚Äôd like to get a string.</li>
<li><code>readAsDataURL</code> ‚Äì when we‚Äôd like to use this data in <code>src</code> for <code>img</code> or another tag. There‚Äôs an alternative to reading a file for that, as discussed in chapter <a href="info:blob" class="uri">info:blob</a>: <code>URL.createObjectURL(file)</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>As the reading proceeds, there are events: - <code>loadstart</code> ‚Äì loading started. - <code>progress</code> ‚Äì occurs during reading. - <code>load</code> ‚Äì no errors, reading complete. - <code>abort</code> ‚Äì <code>abort()</code> called. - <code>error</code> ‚Äì error has occurred. - <code>loadend</code> ‚Äì reading finished with either success or failure.</p>
<p>When the reading is finished, we can access the result as: - <code>reader.result</code> is the result (if successful) - <code>reader.error</code> is the error (if failed).</p>
<p>The most widely used events are for sure <code>load</code> and <code>error</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example of reading a file:</p>
<p>```html run <input type="file" onchange="readFile(this)"></p>
<script>
function readFile(input) {
  let file = input.files[0];

  let reader = new FileReader();

  reader.readAsText(file);

  reader.onload = function() {
    console.log(reader.result);
  };

  reader.onerror = function() {
    console.log(reader.error);
  };

}
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="</code>FileReader<code>for blobs" As mentioned in the chapter &lt;info:blob&gt;,</code>FileReader` can read not just files, but any blobs.</p>
<p>We can use it to convert a blob to another format: - <code>readAsArrayBuffer(blob)</code> ‚Äì to <code>ArrayBuffer</code>, - <code>readAsText(blob, [encoding])</code> ‚Äì to string (an alternative to <code>TextDecoder</code>), - <code>readAsDataURL(blob)</code> ‚Äì to base64 data url. ```</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="</code>FileReaderSync<code>is available inside Web Workers" For Web Workers, there also exists a synchronous variant of</code>FileReader`, called <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/FileAPI/#FileReaderSync">FileReaderSync</a>.</p>
<p>Its reading methods <code>read*</code> do not generate events, but rather return a result, as regular functions do.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs only inside a Web Worker though, because delays in synchronous calls, that are possible while reading from files, in Web Workers are less important. They do not affect the page. ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-8">Summary</h2>
<p><code>File</code> objects inherit from <code>Blob</code>.</p>
<p>In addition to <code>Blob</code> methods and properties, <code>File</code> objects also have <code>name</code> and <code>lastModified</code> properties, plus the internal ability to read from filesystem. We usually get <code>File</code> objects from user input, like <code>&lt;input&gt;</code> or Drag‚Äôn‚ÄôDrop events (<code>ondragend</code>).</p>
<p><code>FileReader</code> objects can read from a file or a blob, in one of three formats: - String (<code>readAsText</code>). - <code>ArrayBuffer</code> (<code>readAsArrayBuffer</code>). - Data url, base-64 encoded (<code>readAsDataURL</code>).</p>
<p>In many cases though, we don‚Äôt have to read the file contents. Just as we did with blobs, we can create a short url with <code>URL.createObjectURL(file)</code> and assign it to <code>&lt;a&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;img&gt;</code>. This way the file can be downloaded or shown up as an image, as a part of canvas etc.</p>
<p>And if we‚Äôre going to send a <code>File</code> over a network, that‚Äôs also easy: network API like <code>XMLHttpRequest</code> or <code>fetch</code> natively accepts <code>File</code> objects.</p>
<h1 id="fetch">Fetch</h1>
<p>JavaScript can send network requests to the server and load new information whenever it‚Äôs needed.</p>
<p>For example, we can use a network request to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Submit an order,</li>
<li>Load user information,</li>
<li>Receive latest updates from the server,</li>
<li>‚Ä¶etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>‚Ä¶And all of that without reloading the page!</p>
<p>There‚Äôs an umbrella term ‚ÄúAJAX‚Äù (abbreviated <b>A</b>synchronous <b>J</b>avaScript <b>A</b>nd <b>X</b>ML) for network requests from JavaScript. We don‚Äôt have to use XML though: the term comes from old times, that‚Äôs why that word is there. You may have heard that term already.</p>
<p>There are multiple ways to send a network request and get information from the server.</p>
<p>The <code>fetch()</code> method is modern and versatile, so we‚Äôll start with it. It‚Äôs not supported by old browsers (can be polyfilled), but very well supported among the modern ones.</p>
<p>The basic syntax is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb42"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb42-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> promise <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> [options])</a></code></pre></div>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>url</code></strong> ‚Äì the URL to access.</li>
<li><strong><code>options</code></strong> ‚Äì optional parameters: method, headers etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>Without <code>options</code>, this is a simple GET request, downloading the contents of the <code>url</code>.</p>
<p>The browser starts the request right away and returns a promise that the calling code should use to get the result.</p>
<p>Getting a response is usually a two-stage process.</p>
<p><strong>First, the <code>promise</code>, returned by <code>fetch</code>, resolves with an object of the built-in <a href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#response-class">Response</a> class as soon as the server responds with headers.</strong></p>
<p>At this stage we can check HTTP status, to see whether it is successful or not, check headers, but don‚Äôt have the body yet.</p>
<p>The promise rejects if the <code>fetch</code> was unable to make HTTP-request, e.g.¬†network problems, or there‚Äôs no such site. Abnormal HTTP-statuses, such as 404 or 500 do not cause an error.</p>
<p>We can see HTTP-status in response properties:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>status</code></strong> ‚Äì HTTP status code, e.g.¬†200.</li>
<li><strong><code>ok</code></strong> ‚Äì boolean, <code>true</code> if the HTTP status code is 200-299.</li>
</ul>
<p>For example:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb43"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> response <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(url)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-3" title="3"><span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">ok</span>) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// if HTTP-status is 200-299</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-4" title="4">  <span class="co">// get the response body (the method explained below)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">let</span> json <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">json</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-6" title="6"><span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-7" title="7">  <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="st">&quot;HTTP-Error: &quot;</span> <span class="op">+</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">status</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb43-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><strong>Second, to get the response body, we need to use an additional method call.</strong></p>
<p><code>Response</code> provides multiple promise-based methods to access the body in various formats:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>response.text()</code></strong> ‚Äì read the response and return as text,</li>
<li><strong><code>response.json()</code></strong> ‚Äì parse the response as JSON,</li>
<li><strong><code>response.formData()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as <code>FormData</code> object (explained in the <a href="info:formdata">next chapter</a>),</li>
<li><strong><code>response.blob()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as <a href="info:blob">Blob</a> (binary data with type),</li>
<li><strong><code>response.arrayBuffer()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as <a href="info:arraybuffer-binary-arrays">ArrayBuffer</a> (low-level representation of binary data),</li>
<li>additionally, <code>response.body</code> is a <a href="https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#rs-class">ReadableStream</a> object, it allows you to read the body chunk-by-chunk, we‚Äôll see an example later.</li>
</ul>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs get a JSON-object with latest commits from GitHub:</p>
<p>```js run async let url = ‚Äòhttps://api.github.com/repos/javascript-tutorial/en.javascript.info/commits‚Äô; let response = await fetch(url);</p>
<p><em>!</em> let commits = await response.json(); // read response body and parse as JSON <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert(commits[0].author.login); ```</p>
<p>Or, the same without <code>await</code>, using pure promises syntax:</p>
<p><code>js run fetch('https://api.github.com/repos/javascript-tutorial/en.javascript.info/commits')   .then(response =&gt; response.json())   .then(commits =&gt; alert(commits[0].author.login));</code></p>
<p>To get the response text, <code>await response.text()</code> instead of <code>.json()</code>:</p>
<p>```js run async let response = await fetch(‚Äòhttps://api.github.com/repos/javascript-tutorial/en.javascript.info/commits‚Äô);</p>
<p>let text = await response.text(); // read response body as text</p>
<p>alert(text.slice(0, 80) + ‚Äò‚Ä¶‚Äô); ```</p>
<p>As a show-case for reading in binary format, let‚Äôs fetch and show a logo image of <a href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org">‚Äúfetch‚Äù specification</a> (see chapter <a href="info:blob">Blob</a> for details about operations on <code>Blob</code>):</p>
<p>```js async run let response = await fetch(‚Äò/article/fetch/logo-fetch.svg‚Äô);</p>
<p><em>!</em> let blob = await response.blob(); // download as Blob object <em>/!</em></p>
<p>// create <img> for it let img = document.createElement(‚Äòimg‚Äô); img.style = ‚Äòposition:fixed;top:10px;left:10px;width:100px‚Äô; document.body.append(img);</p>
<p>// show it img.src = URL.createObjectURL(blob);</p>
<p>setTimeout(() =&gt; { // hide after three seconds img.remove(); URL.revokeObjectURL(img.src); }, 3000); ```</p>
<pre class="warn"><code>We can choose only one body-reading method.

If we&#39;ve already got the response with `response.text()`, then `response.json()` won&#39;t work, as the body content has already been processed.

```js
let text = await response.text(); // response body consumed
let parsed = await response.json(); // fails (already consumed)
```</code></pre>
<h2 id="response-headers">Response headers</h2>
<p>The response headers are available in a Map-like headers object in <code>response.headers</code>.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs not exactly a Map, but it has similar methods to get individual headers by name or iterate over them:</p>
<p>```js run async let response = await fetch(‚Äòhttps://api.github.com/repos/javascript-tutorial/en.javascript.info/commits‚Äô);</p>
<p>// get one header alert(response.headers.get(‚ÄòContent-Type‚Äô)); // application/json; charset=utf-8</p>
<p>// iterate over all headers for (let [key, value] of response.headers) { alert(<code>${key} = ${value}</code>); } ```</p>
<h2 id="request-headers">Request headers</h2>
<p>To set a request header in <code>fetch</code>, we can use the <code>headers</code> option. It has an object with outgoing headers, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb45"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb45-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> response <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(protectedUrl<span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb45-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">headers</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb45-3" title="3">    <span class="dt">Authentication</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;secret&#39;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb45-4" title="4">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb45-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶But there‚Äôs a list of <a href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#forbidden-header-name">forbidden HTTP headers</a> that we can‚Äôt set:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Accept-Charset</code>, <code>Accept-Encoding</code></li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Headers</code></li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Method</code></li>
<li><code>Connection</code></li>
<li><code>Content-Length</code></li>
<li><code>Cookie</code>, <code>Cookie2</code></li>
<li><code>Date</code></li>
<li><code>DNT</code></li>
<li><code>Expect</code></li>
<li><code>Host</code></li>
<li><code>Keep-Alive</code></li>
<li><code>Origin</code></li>
<li><code>Referer</code></li>
<li><code>TE</code></li>
<li><code>Trailer</code></li>
<li><code>Transfer-Encoding</code></li>
<li><code>Upgrade</code></li>
<li><code>Via</code></li>
<li><code>Proxy-*</code></li>
<li><code>Sec-*</code></li>
</ul>
<p>These headers ensure proper and safe HTTP, so they are controlled exclusively by the browser.</p>
<h2 id="post-requests">POST requests</h2>
<p>To make a <code>POST</code> request, or a request with another method, we need to use <code>fetch</code> options:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>method</code></strong> ‚Äì HTTP-method, e.g.¬†<code>POST</code>,</li>
<li><strong><code>body</code></strong> ‚Äì the request body, one of:
<ul>
<li>a string (e.g.¬†JSON-encoded),</li>
<li><code>FormData</code> object, to submit the data as <code>form/multipart</code>,</li>
<li><code>Blob</code>/<code>BufferSource</code> to send binary data,</li>
<li><a href="info:url">URLSearchParams</a>, to submit the data in <code>x-www-form-urlencoded</code> encoding, rarely used.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<p>The JSON format is used most of the time.</p>
<p>For example, this code submits <code>user</code> object as JSON:</p>
<p>```js run async let user = { name: ‚ÄòJohn‚Äô, surname: ‚ÄòSmith‚Äô };</p>
<p><em>!</em> let response = await fetch(‚Äò/article/fetch/post/user‚Äô, { method: ‚ÄòPOST‚Äô, headers: { ‚ÄòContent-Type‚Äô: ‚Äòapplication/json;charset=utf-8‚Äô }, body: JSON.stringify(user) }); <em>/!</em></p>
<p>let result = await response.json(); alert(result.message); ```</p>
<p>Please note, if the request <code>body</code> is a string, then <code>Content-Type</code> header is set to <code>text/plain;charset=UTF-8</code> by default.</p>
<p>But, as we‚Äôre going to send JSON, we use <code>headers</code> option to send <code>application/json</code> instead, the correct <code>Content-Type</code> for JSON-encoded data.</p>
<h2 id="sending-an-image">Sending an image</h2>
<p>We can also submit binary data with <code>fetch</code> using <code>Blob</code> or <code>BufferSource</code> objects.</p>
<p>In this example, there‚Äôs a <code>&lt;canvas&gt;</code> where we can draw by moving a mouse over it. A click on the ‚Äúsubmit‚Äù button sends the image to the server:</p>
```html run autorun height=‚Äú90‚Äù
<body style="margin:0">
<canvas id="canvasElem" width="100" height="80" style="border:1px solid">
</canvas>
<p><input type="button" value="Submit" onclick="submit()"></p>
<script>
    canvasElem.onmousemove = function(e) {
      let ctx = canvasElem.getContext('2d');
      ctx.lineTo(e.clientX, e.clientY);
      ctx.stroke();
    };

    async function submit() {
      let blob = await new Promise(resolve => canvasElem.toBlob(resolve, 'image/png'));
      let response = await fetch('/article/fetch/post/image', {
        method: 'POST',
        body: blob
      });

      // the server responds with confirmation and the image size
      let result = await response.json();
      alert(result.message);
    }

  </script>
</body>
<p>```</p>
<p>Please note, here we don‚Äôt set <code>Content-Type</code> header manually, because a <code>Blob</code> object has a built-in type (here <code>image/png</code>, as generated by <code>toBlob</code>). For <code>Blob</code> objects that type becomes the value of <code>Content-Type</code>.</p>
<p>The <code>submit()</code> function can be rewritten without <code>async/await</code> like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb46"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">submit</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-2" title="2">  <span class="va">canvasElem</span>.<span class="at">toBlob</span>(<span class="kw">function</span>(blob) <span class="op">{</span>        </a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-3" title="3">    <span class="at">fetch</span>(<span class="st">&#39;/article/fetch/post/image&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-4" title="4">      <span class="dt">method</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;POST&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-5" title="5">      <span class="dt">body</span><span class="op">:</span> blob</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-6" title="6">    <span class="op">}</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-7" title="7">      .<span class="at">then</span>(response <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">json</span>())</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-8" title="8">      .<span class="at">then</span>(result <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">JSON</span>.<span class="at">stringify</span>(result<span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">null</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">2</span>)))</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-9" title="9">  <span class="op">},</span> <span class="st">&#39;image/png&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb46-10" title="10"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="summary-9">Summary</h2>
<p>A typical fetch request consists of two <code>await</code> calls:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb47"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb47-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> response <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> options)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// resolves with response headers</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb47-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">json</span>()<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// read body as json</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Or, without <code>await</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb48"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb48-1" title="1"><span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> options)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb48-2" title="2">  .<span class="at">then</span>(response <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">json</span>())</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb48-3" title="3">  .<span class="at">then</span>(result <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="co">/* process result */</span>)</a></code></pre></div>
<p>Response properties: - <code>response.status</code> ‚Äì HTTP code of the response, - <code>response.ok</code> ‚Äì <code>true</code> is the status is 200-299. - <code>response.headers</code> ‚Äì Map-like object with HTTP headers.</p>
<p>Methods to get response body: - <strong><code>response.text()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as text, - <strong><code>response.json()</code></strong> ‚Äì parse the response as JSON object, - <strong><code>response.formData()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as <code>FormData</code> object (form/multipart encoding, see the next chapter), - <strong><code>response.blob()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as <a href="info:blob">Blob</a> (binary data with type), - <strong><code>response.arrayBuffer()</code></strong> ‚Äì return the response as <a href="info:arraybuffer-binary-arrays">ArrayBuffer</a> (low-level binary data),</p>
<p>Fetch options so far: - <code>method</code> ‚Äì HTTP-method, - <code>headers</code> ‚Äì an object with request headers (not any header is allowed), - <code>body</code> ‚Äì the data to send (request body) as <code>string</code>, <code>FormData</code>, <code>BufferSource</code>, <code>Blob</code> or <code>UrlSearchParams</code> object.</p>
<p>In the next chapters we‚Äôll see more options and use cases of <code>fetch</code>.</p>
<h1 id="formdata">FormData</h1>
<p>This chapter is about sending HTML forms: with or without files, with additional fields and so on.</p>
<p><a href="https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-formdata">FormData</a> objects can help with that. As you might have guessed, it‚Äôs the object to represent HTML form data.</p>
<p>The constructor is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb49"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb49-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> formData <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">FormData</span>([form])<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>If HTML <code>form</code> element is provided, it automatically captures its fields.</p>
<p>The special thing about <code>FormData</code> is that network methods, such as <code>fetch</code>, can accept a <code>FormData</code> object as a body. It‚Äôs encoded and sent out with <code>Content-Type: multipart/form-data</code>.</p>
<p>From the server point of view, that looks like a usual form submission.</p>
<h2 id="sending-a-simple-form">Sending a simple form</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs send a simple form first.</p>
<p>As you can see, that‚Äôs almost one-liner:</p>
```html run autorun
<form id="formElem">
<input type="text" name="name" value="John"> <input type="text" name="surname" value="Smith"> <input type="submit">
</form>
<script>
  formElem.onsubmit = async (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();

    let response = await fetch('/article/formdata/post/user', {
      method: 'POST',
*!*
      body: new FormData(formElem)
*/!*
    });

    let result = await response.json();

    alert(result.message);
  };
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>In this example, the server code is not presented, as it‚Äôs beyond our scope. The server accepts the POST request and replies ‚ÄúUser saved‚Äù.</p>
<h2 id="formdata-methods">FormData Methods</h2>
<p>We can modify fields in <code>FormData</code> with methods:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>formData.append(name, value)</code> - add a form field with the given <code>name</code> and <code>value</code>,</li>
<li><code>formData.append(name, blob, fileName)</code> - add a field as if it were <code>&lt;input type="file"&gt;</code>, the third argument <code>fileName</code> sets file name (not form field name), as it were a name of the file in user‚Äôs filesystem,</li>
<li><code>formData.delete(name)</code> - remove the field with the given <code>name</code>,</li>
<li><code>formData.get(name)</code> - get the value of the field with the given <code>name</code>,</li>
<li><code>formData.has(name)</code> - if there exists a field with the given <code>name</code>, returns <code>true</code>, otherwise <code>false</code></li>
</ul>
<p>A form is technically allowed to have many fields with the same <code>name</code>, so multiple calls to <code>append</code> add more same-named fields.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs also method <code>set</code>, with the same syntax as <code>append</code>. The difference is that <code>.set</code> removes all fields with the given <code>name</code>, and then appends a new field. So it makes sure there‚Äôs only one field with such <code>name</code>, the rest is just like <code>append</code>:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>formData.set(name, value)</code>,</li>
<li><code>formData.set(name, blob, fileName)</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Also we can iterate over formData fields using <code>for..of</code> loop:</p>
<p>```js run let formData = new FormData(); formData.append(‚Äòkey1‚Äô, ‚Äòvalue1‚Äô); formData.append(‚Äòkey2‚Äô, ‚Äòvalue2‚Äô);</p>
<p>// List key/value pairs for(let [name, value] of formData) { alert(<code>${name} = ${value}</code>); // key1 = value1, then key2 = value2 } ```</p>
<h2 id="sending-a-form-with-a-file">Sending a form with a file</h2>
<p>The form is always sent as <code>Content-Type: multipart/form-data</code>, this encoding allows to send files. So, <code>&lt;input type="file"&gt;</code> fields are sent also, similar to a usual form submission.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example with such form:</p>
```html run autorun
<form id="formElem">
<input type="text" name="firstName" value="John"> Picture: <input type="file" name="picture" accept="image/*"> <input type="submit">
</form>
<script>
  formElem.onsubmit = async (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();

    let response = await fetch('/article/formdata/post/user-avatar', {
      method: 'POST',
*!*
      body: new FormData(formElem)
*/!*
    });

    let result = await response.json();

    alert(result.message);
  };
</script>
<p>```</p>
<h2 id="sending-a-form-with-blob-data">Sending a form with Blob data</h2>
<p>As we‚Äôve seen in the chapter <a href="info:fetch" class="uri">info:fetch</a>, it‚Äôs easy to send dynamically generated binary data e.g.¬†an image, as <code>Blob</code>. We can supply it directly as <code>fetch</code> parameter <code>body</code>.</p>
<p>In practice though, it‚Äôs often convenient to send an image not separately, but as a part of the form, with additional fields, such as ‚Äúname‚Äù and other metadata.</p>
<p>Also, servers are usually more suited to accept multipart-encoded forms, rather than raw binary data.</p>
<p>This example submits an image from <code>&lt;canvas&gt;</code>, along with some other fields, as a form, using <code>FormData</code>:</p>
```html run autorun height=‚Äú90‚Äù
<body style="margin:0">
<canvas id="canvasElem" width="100" height="80" style="border:1px solid">
</canvas>
<p><input type="button" value="Submit" onclick="submit()"></p>
<script>
    canvasElem.onmousemove = function(e) {
      let ctx = canvasElem.getContext('2d');
      ctx.lineTo(e.clientX, e.clientY);
      ctx.stroke();
    };

    async function submit() {
      let imageBlob = await new Promise(resolve => canvasElem.toBlob(resolve, 'image/png'));

*!*
      let formData = new FormData();
      formData.append("firstName", "John");
      formData.append("image", imageBlob, "image.png");
*/!*    

      let response = await fetch('/article/formdata/post/image-form', {
        method: 'POST',
        body: formData
      });
      let result = await response.json();
      alert(result.message);
    }

  </script>
</body>
<p>```</p>
<p>Please note how the image <code>Blob</code> is added:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb50"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb50-1" title="1"><span class="va">formData</span>.<span class="at">append</span>(<span class="st">&quot;image&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> imageBlob<span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;image.png&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>That‚Äôs same as if there were <code>&lt;input type="file" name="image"&gt;</code> in the form, and the visitor submitted a file named <code>"image.png"</code> (3rd argument) with the data <code>imageBlob</code> (2nd argument) from their filesystem.</p>
<p>The server reads form data and the file, as if it were a regular form submission.</p>
<h2 id="summary-10">Summary</h2>
<p><a href="https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-formdata">FormData</a> objects are used to capture HTML form and submit it using <code>fetch</code> or another network method.</p>
<p>We can either create <code>new FormData(form)</code> from an HTML form, or create a object without a form at all, and then append fields with methods:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>formData.append(name, value)</code></li>
<li><code>formData.append(name, blob, fileName)</code></li>
<li><code>formData.set(name, value)</code></li>
<li><code>formData.set(name, blob, fileName)</code></li>
</ul>
<p>Let‚Äôs note two peculiarities here:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The <code>set</code> method removes fields with the same name, <code>append</code> doesn‚Äôt. That‚Äôs the only difference between them.</li>
<li>To send a file, 3-argument syntax is needed, the last argument is a file name, that normally is taken from user filesystem for <code>&lt;input type="file"&gt;</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>Other methods are:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>formData.delete(name)</code></li>
<li><code>formData.get(name)</code></li>
<li><code>formData.has(name)</code></li>
</ul>
<p>That‚Äôs it!</p>
<h1 id="fetch-download-progress">Fetch: Download progress</h1>
<p>The <code>fetch</code> method allows to track <em>download</em> progress.</p>
<p>Please note: there‚Äôs currently no way for <code>fetch</code> to track <em>upload</em> progress. For that purpose, please use <a href="info:xmlhttprequest">XMLHttpRequest</a>, we‚Äôll cover it later.</p>
<p>To track download progress, we can use <code>response.body</code> property. It‚Äôs <code>ReadableStream</code> ‚Äì a special object that provides body chunk-by-chunk, as it comes. Readable streams are described in the <a href="https://streams.spec.whatwg.org/#rs-class">Streams API</a> specification.</p>
<p>Unlike <code>response.text()</code>, <code>response.json()</code> and other methods, <code>response.body</code> gives full control over the reading process, and we can count how much is consumed at any moment.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the sketch of code that reads the response from <code>response.body</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb51"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-1" title="1"><span class="co">// instead of response.json() and other methods</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-2" title="2"><span class="kw">const</span> reader <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="va">body</span>.<span class="at">getReader</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-4" title="4"><span class="co">// infinite loop while the body is downloading</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-5" title="5"><span class="cf">while</span>(<span class="kw">true</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// done is true for the last chunk</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-7" title="7">  <span class="co">// value is Uint8Array of the chunk bytes</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-8" title="8">  <span class="kw">const</span> <span class="op">{</span>done<span class="op">,</span> value<span class="op">}</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">reader</span>.<span class="at">read</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-10" title="10">  <span class="cf">if</span> (done) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-11" title="11">    <span class="cf">break</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-12" title="12">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-13" title="13"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-14" title="14">  <span class="va">console</span>.<span class="at">log</span>(<span class="vs">`Received </span><span class="sc">${</span><span class="va">value</span>.<span class="at">length</span><span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs"> bytes`</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb51-15" title="15"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The result of <code>await reader.read()</code> call is an object with two properties: - <strong><code>done</code></strong> ‚Äì <code>true</code> when the reading is complete, otherwise <code>false</code>. - <strong><code>value</code></strong> ‚Äì a typed array of bytes: <code>Uint8Array</code>.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>Streams API also describes asynchronous iteration over `ReadableStream` with `for await..of` loop, but it&#39;s not yet widely supported (see [browser issues](https://github.com/whatwg/streams/issues/778#issuecomment-461341033)), so we use `while` loop.</code></pre>
<p>We receive response chunks in the loop, until the loading finishes, that is: until <code>done</code> becomes <code>true</code>.</p>
<p>To log the progress, we just need for every received fragment <code>value</code> to add its length to the counter.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full working example that gets the response and logs the progress in console, more explanations to follow:</p>
<p>```js run async // Step 1: start the fetch and obtain a reader let response = await fetch(‚Äòhttps://api.github.com/repos/javascript-tutorial/en.javascript.info/commits?per_page=100‚Äô);</p>
<p>const reader = response.body.getReader();</p>
<p>// Step 2: get total length const contentLength = +response.headers.get(‚ÄòContent-Length‚Äô);</p>
<p>// Step 3: read the data let receivedLength = 0; // received that many bytes at the moment let chunks = []; // array of received binary chunks (comprises the body) while(true) { const {done, value} = await reader.read();</p>
<p>if (done) { break; }</p>
<p>chunks.push(value); receivedLength += value.length;</p>
<p>console.log(<code>Received ${receivedLength} of ${contentLength}</code>) }</p>
<p>// Step 4: concatenate chunks into single Uint8Array let chunksAll = new Uint8Array(receivedLength); // (4.1) let position = 0; for(let chunk of chunks) { chunksAll.set(chunk, position); // (4.2) position += chunk.length; }</p>
<p>// Step 5: decode into a string let result = new TextDecoder(‚Äúutf-8‚Äù).decode(chunksAll);</p>
<p>// We‚Äôre done! let commits = JSON.parse(result); alert(commits[0].author.login); ```</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs explain that step-by-step:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>We perform <code>fetch</code> as usual, but instead of calling <code>response.json()</code>, we obtain a stream reader <code>response.body.getReader()</code>.</p>
Please note, we can‚Äôt use both these methods to read the same response: either use a reader or a response method to get the result.</li>
<li><p>Prior to reading, we can figure out the full response length from the <code>Content-Length</code> header.</p>
It may be absent for cross-origin requests (see chapter <a href="info:fetch-crossorigin" class="uri">info:fetch-crossorigin</a>) and, well, technically a server doesn‚Äôt have to set it. But usually it‚Äôs at place.</li>
<li><p>Call <code>await reader.read()</code> until it‚Äôs done.</p>
We gather response chunks in the array <code>chunks</code>. That‚Äôs important, because after the response is consumed, we won‚Äôt be able to ‚Äúre-read‚Äù it using <code>response.json()</code> or another way (you can try, there‚Äôll be an error).</li>
<li>At the end, we have <code>chunks</code> ‚Äì an array of <code>Uint8Array</code> byte chunks. We need to join them into a single result. Unfortunately, there‚Äôs no single method that concatenates those, so there‚Äôs some code to do that:
<ol type="1">
<li>We create <code>chunksAll = new Uint8Array(receivedLength)</code> ‚Äì a same-typed array with the combined length.</li>
<li>Then use <code>.set(chunk, position)</code> method to copy each <code>chunk</code> one after another in it.</li>
</ol></li>
<li><p>We have the result in <code>chunksAll</code>. It‚Äôs a byte array though, not a string.</p>
<p>To create a string, we need to interpret these bytes. The built-in <a href="info:text-decoder">TextDecoder</a> does exactly that. Then we can <code>JSON.parse</code> it, if necessary.</p>
<p>What if we need binary content instead of a string? That‚Äôs even simpler. Replace steps 4 and 5 with a single line that creates a <code>Blob</code> from all chunks: <code>js  let blob = new Blob(chunks);</code></p></li>
</ol>
<p>At the end we have the result (as a string or a blob, whatever is convenient), and progress-tracking in the process.</p>
<p>Once again, please note, that‚Äôs not for <em>upload</em> progress (no way now with <code>fetch</code>), only for <em>download</em> progress.</p>
<p>Also, if the size is unknown, we should check <code>receivedLength</code> in the loop and break it once it reaches a certain limit. So that the <code>chunks</code> won‚Äôt overflow the memory.</p>
<h1 id="fetch-abort">Fetch: Abort</h1>
<p>As we know, <code>fetch</code> returns a promise. And JavaScript generally has no concept of ‚Äúaborting‚Äù a promise. So how can we cancel an ongoing <code>fetch</code>? E.g. if the user actions on our site indicate that the <code>fetch</code> isn‚Äôt needed any more.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a special built-in object for such purposes: <code>AbortController</code>. It can be used to abort not only <code>fetch</code>, but other asynchronous tasks as well.</p>
<p>The usage is very straightforward:</p>
<h2 id="the-abortcontroller-object">The AbortController object</h2>
<p>Create a controller:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb53"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb53-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> controller <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">AbortController</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>A controller is an extremely simple object.</p>
<ul>
<li>It has a single method <code>abort()</code>,</li>
<li>And a single property <code>signal</code> that allows to set event listeners on it.</li>
</ul>
<p>When <code>abort()</code> is called: - <code>controller.signal</code> emits the <code>"abort"</code> event. - <code>controller.signal.aborted</code> property becomes <code>true</code>.</p>
<p>Generally, we have two parties in the process: 1. The one that performs a cancelable operation, it sets a listener on <code>controller.signal</code>. 2. The one that cancels: it calls <code>controller.abort()</code> when needed.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full example (without <code>fetch</code> yet):</p>
<p>```js run let controller = new AbortController(); let signal = controller.signal;</p>
<p>// The party that performs a cancelable operation // gets the ‚Äúsignal‚Äù object // and sets the listener to trigger when controller.abort() is called signal.addEventListener(‚Äòabort‚Äô, () =&gt; alert(‚Äúabort!‚Äù));</p>
<p>// The other party, that cancels (at any point later): controller.abort(); // abort!</p>
<p>// The event triggers and signal.aborted becomes true alert(signal.aborted); // true ```</p>
<p>As we can see, <code>AbortController</code> is just a mean to pass <code>abort</code> events when <code>abort()</code> is called on it.</p>
<p>We could implement the same kind of event listening in our code on our own, without the <code>AbortController</code> object.</p>
<p>But what‚Äôs valuable is that <code>fetch</code> knows how to work with the <code>AbortController</code> object. It‚Äôs integrated in it.</p>
<h2 id="using-with-fetch">Using with fetch</h2>
<p>To be able to cancel <code>fetch</code>, pass the <code>signal</code> property of an <code>AbortController</code> as a <code>fetch</code> option:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb54"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb54-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> controller <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">AbortController</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb54-2" title="2"><span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb54-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">signal</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="va">controller</span>.<span class="at">signal</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb54-4" title="4"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code>fetch</code> method knows how to work with <code>AbortController</code>. It will listen to <code>abort</code> events on <code>signal</code>.</p>
<p>Now, to abort, call <code>controller.abort()</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb55"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb55-1" title="1"><span class="va">controller</span>.<span class="at">abort</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>We‚Äôre done: <code>fetch</code> gets the event from <code>signal</code> and aborts the request.</p>
<p>When a fetch is aborted, its promise rejects with an error <code>AbortError</code>, so we should handle it, e.g.¬†in <code>try..catch</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full example with <code>fetch</code> aborted after 1 second:</p>
<p>```js run async // abort in 1 second let controller = new AbortController(); setTimeout(() =&gt; controller.abort(), 1000);</p>
<p>try { let response = await fetch(‚Äò/article/fetch-abort/demo/hang‚Äô, { signal: controller.signal }); } catch(err) { if (err.name == ‚ÄòAbortError‚Äô) { // handle abort() alert(‚ÄúAborted!‚Äù); } else { throw err; } } ```</p>
<h2 id="abortcontroller-is-scalable">AbortController is scalable</h2>
<p><code>AbortController</code> is scalable. It allows to cancel multiple fetches at once.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs a sketch of code that fetches many <code>urls</code> in parallel, and uses a single controller to abort them all:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb56"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> urls <span class="op">=</span> [...]<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// a list of urls to fetch in parallel</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> controller <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">AbortController</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-5" title="5"><span class="co">// an array of fetch promises</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-6" title="6"><span class="kw">let</span> fetchJobs <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">urls</span>.<span class="at">map</span>(url <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-7" title="7">  <span class="dt">signal</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="va">controller</span>.<span class="at">signal</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span>))<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-10" title="10"><span class="kw">let</span> results <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">Promise</span>.<span class="at">all</span>(fetchJobs)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-11" title="11"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-12" title="12"><span class="co">// if controller.abort() is called from anywhere,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb56-13" title="13"><span class="co">// it aborts all fetches</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>If we have our own asynchronous tasks, different from <code>fetch</code>, we can use a single <code>AbortController</code> to stop those, together with fetches.</p>
<p>We just need to listen to its <code>abort</code> event in our tasks:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb57"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> urls <span class="op">=</span> [...]<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> controller <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">AbortController</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-4" title="4"><span class="kw">let</span> ourJob <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Promise</span>((resolve<span class="op">,</span> reject) <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// our task</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-5" title="5">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-6" title="6">  <span class="va">controller</span>.<span class="va">signal</span>.<span class="at">addEventListener</span>(<span class="st">&#39;abort&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> reject)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-8" title="8"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-9" title="9"><span class="kw">let</span> fetchJobs <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">urls</span>.<span class="at">map</span>(url <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// fetches</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-10" title="10">  <span class="dt">signal</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="va">controller</span>.<span class="at">signal</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-11" title="11"><span class="op">}</span>))<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-12" title="12"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-13" title="13"><span class="co">// Wait for fetches and our task in parallel</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-14" title="14"><span class="kw">let</span> results <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">Promise</span>.<span class="at">all</span>([...<span class="at">fetchJobs</span><span class="op">,</span> ourJob])<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-15" title="15"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-16" title="16"><span class="co">// if controller.abort() is called from anywhere,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb57-17" title="17"><span class="co">// it aborts all fetches and ourJob</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="summary-11">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li><code>AbortController</code> is a simple object that generates an <code>abort</code> event on it‚Äôs <code>signal</code> property when the <code>abort()</code> method is called (and also sets <code>signal.aborted</code> to <code>true</code>).</li>
<li><code>fetch</code> integrates with it: we pass the <code>signal</code> property as the option, and then <code>fetch</code> listens to it, so it‚Äôs possible to abort the <code>fetch</code>.</li>
<li>We can use <code>AbortController</code> in our code. The ‚Äúcall <code>abort()</code>‚Äù -&gt; ‚Äúlisten to <code>abort</code> event‚Äù interaction is simple and universal. We can use it even without <code>fetch</code>. # Fetch: Cross-Origin Requests</li>
</ul>
<p>If we send a <code>fetch</code> request to another web-site, it will probably fail.</p>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs try fetching <code>http://example.com</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run async try {   await fetch('http://example.com'); } catch(err) {   alert(err); // Failed to fetch }</code></p>
<p>Fetch fails, as expected.</p>
<p>The core concept here is <em>origin</em> ‚Äì a domain/port/protocol triplet.</p>
<p>Cross-origin requests ‚Äì those sent to another domain (even a subdomain) or protocol or port ‚Äì require special headers from the remote side.</p>
<p>That policy is called ‚ÄúCORS‚Äù: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing.</p>
<h2 id="why-is-cors-needed-a-brief-history">Why is CORS needed? A brief history</h2>
<p>CORS exists to protect the internet from evil hackers.</p>
<p>Seriously. Let‚Äôs make a very brief historical digression.</p>
<p><strong>For many years a script from one site could not access the content of another site.</strong></p>
<p>That simple, yet powerful rule was a foundation of the internet security. E.g. an evil script from website <code>hacker.com</code> could not access the user‚Äôs mailbox at website <code>gmail.com</code>. People felt safe.</p>
<p>JavaScript also did not have any special methods to perform network requests at that time. It was a toy language to decorate a web page.</p>
<p>But web developers demanded more power. A variety of tricks were invented to work around the limitation and make requests to other websites.</p>
<h3 id="using-forms">Using forms</h3>
<p>One way to communicate with another server was to submit a <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> there. People submitted it into <code>&lt;iframe&gt;</code>, just to stay on the current page, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb58"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-1" title="1"><span class="co">&lt;!-- form target --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-2" title="2">*!*</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-3" title="3"><span class="kw">&lt;iframe</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;iframe&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-4" title="4">*/!*</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-6" title="6"><span class="co">&lt;!-- a form could be dynamically generated and submited by JavaScript --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-7" title="7">*!*</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-8" title="8"><span class="kw">&lt;form</span><span class="ot"> target=</span><span class="st">&quot;iframe&quot;</span><span class="ot"> method=</span><span class="st">&quot;POST&quot;</span><span class="ot"> action=</span><span class="st">&quot;http://another.com/‚Ä¶&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-9" title="9">*/!*</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-10" title="10">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb58-11" title="11"><span class="kw">&lt;/form&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So, it was possible to make a GET/POST request to another site, even without networking methods, as forms can send data anywhere. But as it‚Äôs forbidden to access the content of an <code>&lt;iframe&gt;</code> from another site, it wasn‚Äôt possible to read the response.</p>
<p>To be precise, there were actually tricks for that, they required special scripts at both the iframe and the page. So the communication with the iframe was technically possible. Right now there‚Äôs no point to go into details, let these dinosaurs rest in peace.</p>
<h3 id="using-scripts">Using scripts</h3>
<p>Another trick was to use a <code>script</code> tag. A script could have any <code>src</code>, with any domain, like <code>&lt;script src="http://another.com/‚Ä¶"&gt;</code>. It‚Äôs possible to execute a script from any website.</p>
<p>If a website, e.g.¬†<code>another.com</code> intended to expose data for this kind of access, then a so-called ‚ÄúJSONP (JSON with padding)‚Äù protocol was used.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs how it worked.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs say we, at our site, need to get the data from <code>http://another.com</code>, such as the weather:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>First, in advance, we declare a global function to accept the data, e.g.¬†<code>gotWeather</code>.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb59"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb59-1" title="1"><span class="co">// 1. Declare the function to process the weather data</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb59-2" title="2"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">gotWeather</span>(<span class="op">{</span> temperature<span class="op">,</span> humidity <span class="op">}</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb59-3" title="3">  <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="vs">`temperature: </span><span class="sc">${</span>temperature<span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">, humidity: </span><span class="sc">${</span>humidity<span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">`</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb59-4" title="4"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>Then we make a <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tag with <code>src="http://another.com/weather.json?callback=gotWeather"</code>, using the name of our function as the <code>callback</code> URL-parameter.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb60"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb60-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> script <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">createElement</span>(<span class="st">&#39;script&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb60-2" title="2"><span class="va">script</span>.<span class="at">src</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="vs">`http://another.com/weather.json?callback=gotWeather`</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb60-3" title="3"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="va">body</span>.<span class="at">append</span>(script)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li>The remote server <code>another.com</code> dynamically generates a script that calls <code>gotWeather(...)</code> with the data it wants us to receive. <code>js  // The expected answer from the server looks like this:  gotWeather({    temperature: 25,    humidity: 78  });</code></li>
<li><p>When the remote script loads and executes, <code>gotWeather</code> runs, and, as it‚Äôs our function, we have the data.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>That works, and doesn‚Äôt violate security, because both sides agreed to pass the data this way. And, when both sides agree, it‚Äôs definitely not a hack. There are still services that provide such access, as it works even for very old browsers.</p>
<p>After a while, networking methods appeared in browser JavaScript.</p>
<p>At first, cross-origin requests were forbidden. But as a result of long discussions, cross-origin requests were allowed, but with any new capabilities requiring an explicit allowance by the server, expressed in special headers.</p>
<h2 id="safe-requests">Safe requests</h2>
<p>There are two types of cross-origin requests:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Safe requests.</li>
<li>All the others.</li>
</ol>
<p>Safe Requests are simpler to make, so let‚Äôs start with them.</p>
<p>A request is safe if it satisfies two conditions:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><a href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#cors-safelisted-method">Safe method</a>: GET, POST or HEAD</li>
<li><a href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#cors-safelisted-request-header">Safe headers</a> ‚Äì the only allowed custom headers are:
<ul>
<li><code>Accept</code>,</li>
<li><code>Accept-Language</code>,</li>
<li><code>Content-Language</code>,</li>
<li><code>Content-Type</code> with the value <code>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</code>, <code>multipart/form-data</code> or <code>text/plain</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol>
<p>Any other request is considered ‚Äúunsafe‚Äù. For instance, a request with <code>PUT</code> method or with an <code>API-Key</code> HTTP-header does not fit the limitations.</p>
<p><strong>The essential difference is that a safe request can be made with a <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> or a <code>&lt;script&gt;</code>, without any special methods.</strong></p>
<p>So, even a very old server should be ready to accept a safe request.</p>
<p>Contrary to that, requests with non-standard headers or e.g.¬†method <code>DELETE</code> can‚Äôt be created this way. For a long time JavaScript was unable to do such requests. So an old server may assume that such requests come from a privileged source, ‚Äúbecause a webpage is unable to send them‚Äù.</p>
<p>When we try to make a unsafe request, the browser sends a special ‚Äúpreflight‚Äù request that asks the server ‚Äì does it agree to accept such cross-origin requests, or not?</p>
<p>And, unless the server explicitly confirms that with headers, an unsafe request is not sent.</p>
<p>Now we‚Äôll go into details.</p>
<h2 id="cors-for-safe-requests">CORS for safe requests</h2>
<p>If a request is cross-origin, the browser always adds the <code>Origin</code> header to it.</p>
<p>For instance, if we request <code>https://anywhere.com/request</code> from <code>https://javascript.info/page</code>, the headers will look like:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>GET /request
Host: anywhere.com
*!*
Origin: https://javascript.info
*/!*
...</code></pre>
<p>As you can see, the <code>Origin</code> header contains exactly the origin (domain/protocol/port), without a path.</p>
<p>The server can inspect the <code>Origin</code> and, if it agrees to accept such a request, add a special header <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> to the response. That header should contain the allowed origin (in our case <code>https://javascript.info</code>), or a star <code>*</code>. Then the response is successful, otherwise it‚Äôs an error.</p>
<p>The browser plays the role of a trusted mediator here: 1. It ensures that the correct <code>Origin</code> is sent with a cross-origin request. 2. It checks for permitting <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> in the response, if it exists, then JavaScript is allowed to access the response, otherwise it fails with an error.</p>
<p><img src="xhr-another-domain.svg" /></p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example of a permissive server response:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>200 OK
Content-Type:text/html; charset=UTF-8
*!*
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://javascript.info
*/!*</code></pre>
<h2 id="response-headers-1">Response headers</h2>
<p>For cross-origin request, by default JavaScript may only access so-called ‚Äúsafe‚Äù response headers:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Cache-Control</code></li>
<li><code>Content-Language</code></li>
<li><code>Content-Type</code></li>
<li><code>Expires</code></li>
<li><code>Last-Modified</code></li>
<li><code>Pragma</code></li>
</ul>
<p>Accessing any other response header causes an error.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>There&#39;s no `Content-Length` header in the list!

This header contains the full response length. So, if we&#39;re downloading something and would like to track the percentage of progress, then an additional permission is required to access that header (see below).</code></pre>
<p>To grant JavaScript access to any other response header, the server must send the <code>Access-Control-Expose-Headers</code> header. It contains a comma-separated list of unsafe header names that should be made accessible.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>200 OK
Content-Type:text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Length: 12345
API-Key: 2c9de507f2c54aa1
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://javascript.info
*!*
Access-Control-Expose-Headers: Content-Length,API-Key
*/!*</code></pre>
<p>With such an <code>Access-Control-Expose-Headers</code> header, the script is allowed to read the <code>Content-Length</code> and <code>API-Key</code> headers of the response.</p>
<h2 id="unsafe-requests">‚ÄúUnsafe‚Äù requests</h2>
<p>We can use any HTTP-method: not just <code>GET/POST</code>, but also <code>PATCH</code>, <code>DELETE</code> and others.</p>
<p>Some time ago no one could even imagine that a webpage could make such requests. So there may still exist webservices that treat a non-standard method as a signal: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not a browser‚Äù. They can take it into account when checking access rights.</p>
<p>So, to avoid misunderstandings, any ‚Äúunsafe‚Äù request ‚Äì that couldn‚Äôt be done in the old times, the browser does not make such requests right away. First, it sends a preliminary, so-called ‚Äúpreflight‚Äù request, to ask for permission.</p>
<p>A preflight request uses the method <code>OPTIONS</code>, no body and two headers:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Method</code> header has the method of the unsafe request.</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Headers</code> header provides a comma-separated list of its unsafe HTTP-headers.</li>
</ul>
<p>If the server agrees to serve the requests, then it should respond with empty body, status 200 and headers:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> must be either <code>*</code> or the requesting origin, such as <code>https://javascript.info</code>, to allow it.</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Methods</code> must have the allowed method.</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Headers</code> must have a list of allowed headers.</li>
<li>Additionally, the header <code>Access-Control-Max-Age</code> may specify a number of seconds to cache the permissions. So the browser won‚Äôt have to send a preflight for subsequent requests that satisfy given permissions.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="xhr-preflight.svg" /></p>
<p>Let‚Äôs see how it works step-by-step on the example of a cross-origin <code>PATCH</code> request (this method is often used to update data):</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb65"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> response <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(<span class="st">&#39;https://site.com/service.json&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">method</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;PATCH&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">headers</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-4" title="4">    <span class="st">&#39;Content-Type&#39;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;application/json&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-5" title="5">    <span class="st">&#39;API-Key&#39;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;secret&#39;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-6" title="6">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb65-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>There are three reasons why the request is unsafe (one is enough): - Method <code>PATCH</code> - <code>Content-Type</code> is not one of: <code>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</code>, <code>multipart/form-data</code>, <code>text/plain</code>. - ‚ÄúUnsafe‚Äù <code>API-Key</code> header.</p>
<h3 id="step-1-preflight-request">Step 1 (preflight request)</h3>
<p>Prior to sending such a request, the browser, on its own, sends a preflight request that looks like this:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>OPTIONS /service.json
Host: site.com
Origin: https://javascript.info
Access-Control-Request-Method: PATCH
Access-Control-Request-Headers: Content-Type,API-Key</code></pre>
<ul>
<li>Method: <code>OPTIONS</code>.</li>
<li>The path ‚Äì exactly the same as the main request: <code>/service.json</code>.</li>
<li>Cross-origin special headers:
<ul>
<li><code>Origin</code> ‚Äì the source origin.</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Method</code> ‚Äì requested method.</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Headers</code> ‚Äì a comma-separated list of ‚Äúunsafe‚Äù headers.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<h3 id="step-2-preflight-response">Step 2 (preflight response)</h3>
<p>The server should respond with status 200 and the headers: - <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://javascript.info</code> - <code>Access-Control-Allow-Methods: PATCH</code> - <code>Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type,API-Key</code>.</p>
<p>That allows future communication, otherwise an error is triggered.</p>
<p>If the server expects other methods and headers in the future, it makes sense to allow them in advance by adding them to the list.</p>
<p>For example, this response also allows <code>PUT</code>, <code>DELETE</code> and additional headers:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>200 OK
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://javascript.info
Access-Control-Allow-Methods: PUT,PATCH,DELETE
Access-Control-Allow-Headers: API-Key,Content-Type,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control
Access-Control-Max-Age: 86400</code></pre>
<p>Now the browser can see that <code>PATCH</code> is in <code>Access-Control-Allow-Methods</code> and <code>Content-Type,API-Key</code> are in the list <code>Access-Control-Allow-Headers</code>, so it sends out the main request.</p>
<p>If there‚Äôs the header <code>Access-Control-Max-Age</code> with a number of seconds, then the preflight permissions are cached for the given time. The response above will be cached for 86400 seconds (one day). Within this timeframe, subsequent requests will not cause a preflight. Assuming that they fit the cached allowances, they will be sent directly.</p>
<h3 id="step-3-actual-request">Step 3 (actual request)</h3>
<p>When the preflight is successful, the browser now makes the main request. The process here is the same as for safe requests.</p>
<p>The main request has the <code>Origin</code> header (because it‚Äôs cross-origin):</p>
<pre class="http"><code>PATCH /service.json
Host: site.com
Content-Type: application/json
API-Key: secret
Origin: https://javascript.info</code></pre>
<h3 id="step-4-actual-response">Step 4 (actual response)</h3>
<p>The server should not forget to add <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> to the main response. A successful preflight does not relieve from that:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://javascript.info</code></pre>
<p>Then JavaScript is able to read the main server response.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>Preflight request occurs &quot;behind the scenes&quot;, it&#39;s invisible to JavaScript.

JavaScript only gets the response to the main request or an error if there&#39;s no server permission.</code></pre>
<h2 id="credentials">Credentials</h2>
<p>A cross-origin request initiated by JavaScript code by default does not bring any credentials (cookies or HTTP authentication).</p>
<p>That‚Äôs uncommon for HTTP-requests. Usually, a request to <code>http://site.com</code> is accompanied by all cookies from that domain. Cross-origin requests made by JavaScript methods on the other hand are an exception.</p>
<p>For example, <code>fetch('http://another.com')</code> does not send any cookies, even those (!) that belong to <code>another.com</code> domain.</p>
<p>Why?</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because a request with credentials is much more powerful than without them. If allowed, it grants JavaScript the full power to act on behalf of the user and access sensitive information using their credentials.</p>
<p>Does the server really trust the script that much? Then it must explicitly allow requests with credentials with an additional header.</p>
<p>To send credentials in <code>fetch</code>, we need to add the option <code>credentials: "include"</code>, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb71"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb71-1" title="1"><span class="at">fetch</span>(<span class="st">&#39;http://another.com&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb71-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">credentials</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;include&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb71-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now <code>fetch</code> sends cookies originating from <code>another.com</code> with request to that site.</p>
<p>If the server agrees to accept the request <em>with credentials</em>, it should add a header <code>Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true</code> to the response, in addition to <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code>.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<pre class="http"><code>200 OK
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://javascript.info
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true</code></pre>
<p>Please note: <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> is prohibited from using a star <code>*</code> for requests with credentials. Like shown above, it must provide the exact origin there. That‚Äôs an additional safety measure, to ensure that the server really knows who it trusts to make such requests.</p>
<h2 id="summary-12">Summary</h2>
<p>From the browser point of view, there are two kinds of cross-origin requests: ‚Äúsafe‚Äù and all the others.</p>
<p>‚ÄúSafe‚Äù requests must satisfy the following conditions: - Method: GET, POST or HEAD. - Headers ‚Äì we can set only: - <code>Accept</code> - <code>Accept-Language</code> - <code>Content-Language</code> - <code>Content-Type</code> to the value <code>application/x-www-form-urlencoded</code>, <code>multipart/form-data</code> or <code>text/plain</code>.</p>
<p>The essential difference is that safe requests were doable since ancient times using <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tags, while unsafe were impossible for browsers for a long time.</p>
<p>So, the practical difference is that safe requests are sent right away, with the <code>Origin</code> header, while for the other ones the browser makes a preliminary ‚Äúpreflight‚Äù request, asking for permission.</p>
<p><strong>For safe requests:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>‚Üí The browser sends the <code>Origin</code> header with the origin.</li>
<li>‚Üê For requests without credentials (not sent by default), the server should set:
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> to <code>*</code> or same value as <code>Origin</code></li>
</ul></li>
<li>‚Üê For requests with credentials, the server should set:
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> to same value as <code>Origin</code></li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Credentials</code> to <code>true</code></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<p>Additionally, to grant JavaScript access to any response headers except <code>Cache-Control</code>, <code>Content-Language</code>, <code>Content-Type</code>, <code>Expires</code>, <code>Last-Modified</code> or <code>Pragma</code>, the server should list the allowed ones in <code>Access-Control-Expose-Headers</code> header.</p>
<p><strong>For unsafe requests, a preliminary ‚Äúpreflight‚Äù request is issued before the requested one:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>‚Üí The browser sends an <code>OPTIONS</code> request to the same URL, with the headers:
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Method</code> has requested method.</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Headers</code> lists unsafe requested headers.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>‚Üê The server should respond with status 200 and the headers:
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Methods</code> with a list of allowed methods,</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Headers</code> with a list of allowed headers,</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Max-Age</code> with a number of seconds to cache the permissions.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Then the actual request is sent, and the previous ‚Äúsafe‚Äù scheme is applied.</li>
</ul>
<h1 id="fetch-api">Fetch API</h1>
<p>So far, we know quite a bit about <code>fetch</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs see the rest of API, to cover all its abilities.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>Please note: most of these options are used rarely. You may skip this chapter and still use `fetch` well.

Still, it&#39;s good to know what `fetch` can do, so if the need arises, you can return and read the details.</code></pre>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full list of all possible <code>fetch</code> options with their default values (alternatives in comments):</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb74"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> promise <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">method</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;GET&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="co">// POST, PUT, DELETE, etc.</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">headers</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-4" title="4">    <span class="co">// the content type header value is usually auto-set</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-5" title="5">    <span class="co">// depending on the request body</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-6" title="6">    <span class="st">&quot;Content-Type&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;text/plain;charset=UTF-8&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-7" title="7">  <span class="op">},</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-8" title="8">  <span class="dt">body</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">undefined</span> <span class="co">// string, FormData, Blob, BufferSource, or URLSearchParams</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-9" title="9">  <span class="dt">referrer</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;about:client&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="co">// or &quot;&quot; to send no Referer header,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb74-10" title="10">  <span class="co">// or an url from the current origin</span></a>
