<li><p>Send a request to the server, asking how many bytes it already has, like this: ```js let response = await fetch(‚Äòstatus‚Äô, { headers: { ‚ÄòX-File-Id‚Äô: fileId } });</p>
<p>// The server has that many bytes let startByte = +await response.text(); ```</p>
<p>This assumes that the server tracks file uploads by <code>X-File-Id</code> header. Should be implemented at server-side.</p>
<p>If the file doesn‚Äôt yet exist at the server, then the server response should be <code>0</code></p></li>
<li><p>Then, we can use <code>Blob</code> method <code>slice</code> to send the file from <code>startByte</code>: ```js xhr.open(‚ÄúPOST‚Äù, ‚Äúupload‚Äù, true);</p>
<p>// File id, so that the server knows which file we upload xhr.setRequestHeader(‚ÄòX-File-Id‚Äô, fileId);</p>
<p>// The byte we‚Äôre resuming from, so the server knows we‚Äôre resuming xhr.setRequestHeader(‚ÄòX-Start-Byte‚Äô, startByte);</p>
<p>xhr.upload.onprogress = (e) =&gt; { console.log(<code>Uploaded ${startByte + e.loaded} of ${startByte + e.total}</code>); };</p>
<p>// file can be from input.files[0] or another source xhr.send(file.slice(startByte)); ```</p>
<p>Here we send the server both file id as <code>X-File-Id</code>, so it knows which file we‚Äôre uploading, and the starting byte as <code>X-Start-Byte</code>, so it knows we‚Äôre not uploading it initially, but resuming.</p>
<p>The server should check its records, and if there was an upload of that file, and the current uploaded size is exactly <code>X-Start-Byte</code>, then append the data to it.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Here‚Äôs the demo with both client and server code, written on Node.js.</p>
<p>It works only partially on this site, as Node.js is behind another server named Nginx, that buffers uploads, passing them to Node.js when fully complete.</p>
<p>But you can download it and run locally for the full demonstration:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúupload-resume‚Äù height=200]</p>
<p>As we can see, modern networking methods are close to file managers in their capabilities ‚Äì control over headers, progress indicator, sending file parts, etc.</p>
<p>We can implement resumable upload and much more. # Long polling</p>
<p>Long polling is the simplest way of having persistent connection with server, that doesn‚Äôt use any specific protocol like WebSocket or Server Side Events.</p>
<p>Being very easy to implement, it‚Äôs also good enough in a lot of cases.</p>
<h2 id="regular-polling">Regular Polling</h2>
<p>The simplest way to get new information from the server is periodic polling. That is, regular requests to the server: ‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm here, do you have any information for me?‚Äù. For example, once every 10 seconds.</p>
<p>In response, the server first takes a notice to itself that the client is online, and second - sends a packet of messages it got till that moment.</p>
<p>That works, but there are downsides: 1. Messages are passed with a delay up to 10 seconds (between requests). 2. Even if there are no messages, the server is bombed with requests every 10 seconds, even if the user switched somewhere else or is asleep. That‚Äôs quite a load to handle, speaking performance-wise.</p>
<p>So, if we‚Äôre talking about a very small service, the approach may be viable, but generally, it needs an improvement.</p>
<h2 id="long-polling">Long polling</h2>
<p>So-called ‚Äúlong polling‚Äù is a much better way to poll the server.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs also very easy to implement, and delivers messages without delays.</p>
<p>The flow:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>A request is sent to the server.</li>
<li>The server doesn‚Äôt close the connection until it has a message to send.</li>
<li>When a message appears - the server responds to the request with it.</li>
<li>The browser makes a new request immediately.</li>
</ol>
<p>The situation when the browser sent a request and has a pending connection with the server, is standard for this method. Only when a message is delivered, the connection is reestablished.</p>
<p><img src="long-polling.svg" /></p>
<p>If the connection is lost, because of, say, a network error, the browser immediately sends a new request.</p>
<p>A sketch of client-side <code>subscribe</code> function that makes long requests:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb112"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-1" title="1"><span class="kw">async</span> <span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">subscribe</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> response <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(<span class="st">&quot;/subscribe&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">status</span> <span class="op">==</span> <span class="dv">502</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-5" title="5">    <span class="co">// Status 502 is a connection timeout error,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-6" title="6">    <span class="co">// may happen when the connection was pending for too long,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-7" title="7">    <span class="co">// and the remote server or a proxy closed it</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-8" title="8">    <span class="co">// let&#39;s reconnect</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-9" title="9">    <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">subscribe</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-10" title="10">  <span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">status</span> <span class="op">!=</span> <span class="dv">200</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-11" title="11">    <span class="co">// An error - let&#39;s show it</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-12" title="12">    <span class="at">showMessage</span>(<span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">statusText</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-13" title="13">    <span class="co">// Reconnect in one second</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-14" title="14">    <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Promise</span>(resolve <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="at">setTimeout</span>(resolve<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">1000</span>))<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-15" title="15">    <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">subscribe</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-16" title="16">  <span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-17" title="17">    <span class="co">// Get and show the message</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-18" title="18">    <span class="kw">let</span> message <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">response</span>.<span class="at">text</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-19" title="19">    <span class="at">showMessage</span>(message)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-20" title="20">    <span class="co">// Call subscribe() again to get the next message</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-21" title="21">    <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">subscribe</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-22" title="22">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-23" title="23"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-24" title="24"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb112-25" title="25"><span class="at">subscribe</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>As you can see, <code>subscribe</code> function makes a fetch, then waits for the response, handles it and calls itself again.</p>
<p>```warn header=‚ÄúServer should be ok with many pending connections‚Äù The server architecture must be able to work with many pending connections.</p>
<p>Certain server architectures run one process per connection, resulting in there being as many processes as there are connections, while each process consumes quite a bit of memory. So, too many connections will just consume it all.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs often the case for backends written in languages like PHP and Ruby.</p>
<p>Servers written using Node.js usually don‚Äôt have such problems.</p>
<p>That said, it isn‚Äôt a programming language issue. Most modern languages, including PHP and Ruby allow to implement a proper backend. Just please make sure that your server architecture works fine with many simultaneous connections. ```</p>
<h2 id="demo-a-chat">Demo: a chat</h2>
<p>Here‚Äôs a demo chat, you can also download it and run locally (if you‚Äôre familiar with Node.js and can install modules):</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúlongpoll‚Äù height=500]</p>
<p>Browser code is in <code>browser.js</code>.</p>
<h2 id="area-of-usage">Area of usage</h2>
<p>Long polling works great in situations when messages are rare.</p>
<p>If messages come very often, then the chart of requesting-receiving messages, painted above, becomes saw-like.</p>
<p>Every message is a separate request, supplied with headers, authentication overhead, and so on.</p>
<p>So, in this case, another method is preferred, such as <a href="info:websocket">Websocket</a> or <a href="info:server-sent-events">Server Sent Events</a>. # WebSocket</p>
<p>The <code>WebSocket</code> protocol, described in the specification <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455">RFC 6455</a> provides a way to exchange data between browser and server via a persistent connection. The data can be passed in both directions as ‚Äúpackets‚Äù, without breaking the connection and additional HTTP-requests.</p>
<p>WebSocket is especially great for services that require continuous data exchange, e.g.¬†online games, real-time trading systems and so on.</p>
<h2 id="a-simple-example">A simple example</h2>
<p>To open a websocket connection, we need to create <code>new WebSocket</code> using the special protocol <code>ws</code> in the url:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb113"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb113-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> socket <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">WebSocket</span>(<span class="st">&quot;*!*ws*/!*://javascript.info&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>There‚Äôs also encrypted <code>wss://</code> protocol. It‚Äôs like HTTPS for websockets.</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Always prefer</code>wss://<code>" The</code>wss://` protocol is not only encrypted, but also more reliable.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because <code>ws://</code> data is not encrypted, visible for any intermediary. Old proxy servers do not know about WebSocket, they may see ‚Äústrange‚Äù headers and abort the connection.</p>
<p>On the other hand, <code>wss://</code> is WebSocket over TLS, (same as HTTPS is HTTP over TLS), the transport security layer encrypts the data at sender and decrypts at the receiver. So data packets are passed encrypted through proxies. They can‚Äôt see what‚Äôs inside and let them through. ```</p>
<p>Once the socket is created, we should listen to events on it. There are totally 4 events: - <strong><code>open</code></strong> ‚Äì connection established, - <strong><code>message</code></strong> ‚Äì data received, - <strong><code>error</code></strong> ‚Äì websocket error, - <strong><code>close</code></strong> ‚Äì connection closed.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶And if we‚Äôd like to send something, then <code>socket.send(data)</code> will do that.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example:</p>
<p>```js run let socket = new WebSocket(‚Äúwss://javascript.info/article/websocket/demo/hello‚Äù);</p>
<p>socket.onopen = function(e) { alert(‚Äú[open] Connection established‚Äù); alert(‚ÄúSending to server‚Äù); socket.send(‚ÄúMy name is John‚Äù); };</p>
<p>socket.onmessage = function(event) { alert(<code>[message] Data received from server: ${event.data}</code>); };</p>
<p>socket.onclose = function(event) { if (event.wasClean) {<br />
alert(<code>[close] Connection closed cleanly, code=${event.code} reason=${event.reason}</code>); } else { // e.g.¬†server process killed or network down // event.code is usually 1006 in this case alert(‚Äò[close] Connection died‚Äô); } };</p>
<p>socket.onerror = function(error) { alert(<code>[error] ${error.message}</code>); };</p>
<pre><code>
For demo purposes, there&#39;s a small server [server.js](demo/server.js) written in Node.js, for the example above, running. It responds with &quot;Hello from server, John&quot;, then waits 5 seconds and closes the connection.

So you&#39;ll see events `open` -&gt; `message` -&gt; `close`.

That&#39;s actually it, we can talk WebSocket already. Quite simple, isn&#39;t it?

Now let&#39;s talk more in-depth.

## Opening a websocket

When `new WebSocket(url)` is created, it starts connecting immediately.

During the connection the browser (using headers) asks the server: &quot;Do you support Websocket?&quot; And if the server replies &quot;yes&quot;, then the talk continues in WebSocket protocol, which is not HTTP at all.

![](websocket-handshake.svg)

Here&#39;s an example of browser headers for request made by `new WebSocket(&quot;wss://javascript.info/chat&quot;)`.
</code></pre>
<p>GET /chat Host: javascript.info Origin: https://javascript.info Connection: Upgrade Upgrade: websocket Sec-WebSocket-Key: Iv8io/9s+lYFgZWcXczP8Q== Sec-WebSocket-Version: 13 ```</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Origin</code> ‚Äì the origin of the client page, e.g.¬†<code>https://javascript.info</code>. WebSocket objects are cross-origin by nature. There are no special headers or other limitations. Old servers are unable to handle WebSocket anyway, so there are no compatibility issues. But <code>Origin</code> header is important, as it allows the server to decide whether or not to talk WebSocket with this website.</li>
<li><code>Connection: Upgrade</code> ‚Äì signals that the client would like to change the protocol.</li>
<li><code>Upgrade: websocket</code> ‚Äì the requested protocol is ‚Äúwebsocket‚Äù.</li>
<li><code>Sec-WebSocket-Key</code> ‚Äì a random browser-generated key for security.</li>
<li><code>Sec-WebSocket-Version</code> ‚Äì WebSocket protocol version, 13 is the current one.</li>
</ul>
<p><code>smart header="WebSocket handshake can't be emulated" We can't use `XMLHttpRequest` or `fetch` to make this kind of HTTP-request, because JavaScript is not allowed to set these headers.</code></p>
<p>If the server agrees to switch to WebSocket, it should send code 101 response:</p>
<pre><code>101 Switching Protocols
Upgrade: websocket
Connection: Upgrade
Sec-WebSocket-Accept: hsBlbuDTkk24srzEOTBUlZAlC2g=</code></pre>
<p>Here <code>Sec-WebSocket-Accept</code> is <code>Sec-WebSocket-Key</code>, recoded using a special algorithm. The browser uses it to make sure that the response corresponds to the request.</p>
<p>Afterwards, the data is transfered using WebSocket protocol, we‚Äôll see its structure (‚Äúframes‚Äù) soon. And that‚Äôs not HTTP at all.</p>
<h3 id="extensions-and-subprotocols">Extensions and subprotocols</h3>
<p>There may be additional headers <code>Sec-WebSocket-Extensions</code> and <code>Sec-WebSocket-Protocol</code> that describe extensions and subprotocols.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<ul>
<li><p><code>Sec-WebSocket-Extensions: deflate-frame</code> means that the browser supports data compression. An extension is something related to transferring the data, functionality that extends WebSocket protocol. The header <code>Sec-WebSocket-Extensions</code> is sent automatically by the browser, with the list of all extensions it supports.</p></li>
<li><p><code>Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: soap, wamp</code> means that we‚Äôd like to transfer not just any data, but the data in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SOAP">SOAP</a> or WAMP (‚ÄúThe WebSocket Application Messaging Protocol‚Äù) protocols. WebSocket subprotocols are registered in the <a href="http://www.iana.org/assignments/websocket/websocket.xml">IANA catalogue</a>. So, this header describes data formats that we‚Äôre going to use.</p>
<p>This optional header is set using the second parameter of <code>new WebSocket</code>. That‚Äôs the array of subprotocols, e.g.¬†if we‚Äôd like to use SOAP or WAMP:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb116"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb116-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> socket <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">WebSocket</span>(<span class="st">&quot;wss://javascript.info/chat&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> [<span class="st">&quot;soap&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;wamp&quot;</span>])<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
</ul>
<p>The server should respond with a list of protocols and extensions that it agrees to use.</p>
<p>For example, the request:</p>
<pre><code>GET /chat
Host: javascript.info
Upgrade: websocket
Connection: Upgrade
Origin: https://javascript.info
Sec-WebSocket-Key: Iv8io/9s+lYFgZWcXczP8Q==
Sec-WebSocket-Version: 13
*!*
Sec-WebSocket-Extensions: deflate-frame
Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: soap, wamp
*/!*</code></pre>
<p>Response:</p>
<pre><code>101 Switching Protocols
Upgrade: websocket
Connection: Upgrade
Sec-WebSocket-Accept: hsBlbuDTkk24srzEOTBUlZAlC2g=
*!*
Sec-WebSocket-Extensions: deflate-frame
Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: soap
*/!*</code></pre>
<p>Here the server responds that it supports the extension ‚Äúdeflate-frame‚Äù, and only SOAP of the requested subprotocols.</p>
<h2 id="data-transfer">Data transfer</h2>
<p>WebSocket communication consists of ‚Äúframes‚Äù ‚Äì data fragments, that can be sent from either side, and can be of several kinds:</p>
<ul>
<li>‚Äútext frames‚Äù ‚Äì contain text data that parties send to each other.</li>
<li>‚Äúbinary data frames‚Äù ‚Äì contain binary data that parties send to each other.</li>
<li>‚Äúping/pong frames‚Äù are used to check the connection, sent from the server, the browser responds to these automatically.</li>
<li>there‚Äôs also ‚Äúconnection close frame‚Äù and a few other service frames.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the browser, we directly work only with text or binary frames.</p>
<p><strong>WebSocket <code>.send()</code> method can send either text or binary data.</strong></p>
<p>A call <code>socket.send(body)</code> allows <code>body</code> in string or a binary format, including <code>Blob</code>, <code>ArrayBuffer</code>, etc. No settings required: just send it out in any format.</p>
<p><strong>When we receive the data, text always comes as string. And for binary data, we can choose between <code>Blob</code> and <code>ArrayBuffer</code> formats.</strong></p>
<p>That‚Äôs set by <code>socket.binaryType</code> property, it‚Äôs <code>"blob"</code> by default, so binary data comes as <code>Blob</code> objects.</p>
<p><a href="info:blob">Blob</a> is a high-level binary object, it directly integrates with <code>&lt;a&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;img&gt;</code> and other tags, so that‚Äôs a sane default. But for binary processing, to access individual data bytes, we can change it to <code>"arraybuffer"</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb119"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb119-1" title="1"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">binaryType</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;arraybuffer&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb119-2" title="2"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">onmessage</span> <span class="op">=</span> (event) <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb119-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// event.data is either a string (if text) or arraybuffer (if binary)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb119-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="rate-limiting">Rate limiting</h2>
<p>Imagine, our app is generating a lot of data to send. But the user has a slow network connection, maybe on a mobile internet, outside of a city.</p>
<p>We can call <code>socket.send(data)</code> again and again. But the data will be buffered (stored) in memory and sent out only as fast as network speed allows.</p>
<p>The <code>socket.bufferedAmount</code> property stores how many bytes remain buffered at this moment, waiting to be sent over the network.</p>
<p>We can examine it to see whether the socket is actually available for transmission.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb120"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-1" title="1"><span class="co">// every 100ms examine the socket and send more data  </span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-2" title="2"><span class="co">// only if all the existing data was sent out</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-3" title="3"><span class="at">setInterval</span>(() <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">bufferedAmount</span> <span class="op">==</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-5" title="5">    <span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">send</span>(<span class="at">moreData</span>())<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-6" title="6">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb120-7" title="7"><span class="op">},</span> <span class="dv">100</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="connection-close">Connection close</h2>
<p>Normally, when a party wants to close the connection (both browser and server have equal rights), they send a ‚Äúconnection close frame‚Äù with a numeric code and a textual reason.</p>
<p>The method for that is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb121"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb121-1" title="1"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">close</span>([code]<span class="op">,</span> [reason])<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<ul>
<li><code>code</code> is a special WebSocket closing code (optional)</li>
<li><code>reason</code> is a string that describes the reason of closing (optional)</li>
</ul>
<p>Then the other party in <code>close</code> event handler gets the code and the reason, e.g.:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb122"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-1" title="1"><span class="co">// closing party:</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-2" title="2"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">close</span>(<span class="dv">1000</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;Work complete&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-4" title="4"><span class="co">// the other party</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-5" title="5"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">onclose</span> <span class="op">=</span> event <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// event.code === 1000</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-7" title="7">  <span class="co">// event.reason === &quot;Work complete&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-8" title="8">  <span class="co">// event.wasClean === true (clean close)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb122-9" title="9"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Most common code values:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>1000</code> ‚Äì the default, normal closure (used if no <code>code</code> supplied),</li>
<li><code>1006</code> ‚Äì no way to set such code manually, indicates that the connection was lost (no close frame).</li>
</ul>
<p>There are other codes like:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>1001</code> ‚Äì the party is going away, e.g.¬†server is shutting down, or a browser leaves the page,</li>
<li><code>1009</code> ‚Äì the message is too big to process,</li>
<li><code>1011</code> ‚Äì unexpected error on server,</li>
<li>‚Ä¶and so on.</li>
</ul>
<p>The full list can be found in <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6455#section-7.4.1">RFC6455, ¬ß7.4.1</a>.</p>
<p>WebSocket codes are somewhat like HTTP codes, but different. In particular, any codes less than <code>1000</code> are reserved, there‚Äôll be an error if we try to set such a code.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb123"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb123-1" title="1"><span class="co">// in case connection is broken</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb123-2" title="2"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">onclose</span> <span class="op">=</span> event <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb123-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// event.code === 1006</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb123-4" title="4">  <span class="co">// event.reason === &quot;&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb123-5" title="5">  <span class="co">// event.wasClean === false (no closing frame)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb123-6" title="6"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="connection-state">Connection state</h2>
<p>To get connection state, additionally there‚Äôs <code>socket.readyState</code> property with values:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>0</code></strong> ‚Äì ‚ÄúCONNECTING‚Äù: the connection has not yet been established,</li>
<li><strong><code>1</code></strong> ‚Äì ‚ÄúOPEN‚Äù: communicating,</li>
<li><strong><code>2</code></strong> ‚Äì ‚ÄúCLOSING‚Äù: the connection is closing,</li>
<li><strong><code>3</code></strong> ‚Äì ‚ÄúCLOSED‚Äù: the connection is closed.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="chat-example">Chat example</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs review a chat example using browser WebSocket API and Node.js WebSocket module <a href="https://github.com/websockets/ws" class="uri">https://github.com/websockets/ws</a>. We‚Äôll pay the main attention to the client side, but the server is also simple.</p>
<p>HTML: we need a <code>&lt;form&gt;</code> to send messages and a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> for incoming messages:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb124"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-1" title="1"><span class="co">&lt;!-- message form --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-2" title="2"><span class="kw">&lt;form</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;publish&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">&lt;input</span><span class="ot"> type=</span><span class="st">&quot;text&quot;</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;message&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">&lt;input</span><span class="ot"> type=</span><span class="st">&quot;submit&quot;</span><span class="ot"> value=</span><span class="st">&quot;Send&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-5" title="5"><span class="kw">&lt;/form&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-7" title="7"><span class="co">&lt;!-- div with messages --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb124-8" title="8"><span class="kw">&lt;div</span><span class="ot"> id=</span><span class="st">&quot;messages&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>From JavaScript we want three things: 1. Open the connection. 2. On form submission ‚Äì <code>socket.send(message)</code> for the message. 3. On incoming message ‚Äì append it to <code>div#messages</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the code:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb125"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> socket <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">WebSocket</span>(<span class="st">&quot;wss://javascript.info/article/websocket/chat/ws&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-3" title="3"><span class="co">// send message from the form</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-4" title="4"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="va">forms</span>.<span class="va">publish</span>.<span class="at">onsubmit</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">let</span> outgoingMessage <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="va">message</span>.<span class="at">value</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-7" title="7">  <span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">send</span>(outgoingMessage)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-8" title="8">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="kw">false</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-9" title="9"><span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-11" title="11"><span class="co">// message received - show the message in div#messages</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-12" title="12"><span class="va">socket</span>.<span class="at">onmessage</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(event) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-13" title="13">  <span class="kw">let</span> message <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">data</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-15" title="15">  <span class="kw">let</span> messageElem <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">createElement</span>(<span class="st">&#39;div&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-16" title="16">  <span class="va">messageElem</span>.<span class="at">textContent</span> <span class="op">=</span> message<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-17" title="17">  <span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">getElementById</span>(<span class="st">&#39;messages&#39;</span>).<span class="at">prepend</span>(messageElem)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb125-18" title="18"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Server-side code is a little bit beyond our scope. Here we‚Äôll use Node.js, but you don‚Äôt have to. Other platforms also have their means to work with WebSocket.</p>
<p>The server-side algorithm will be:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Create <code>clients = new Set()</code> ‚Äì a set of sockets.</li>
<li>For each accepted websocket, add it to the set <code>clients.add(socket)</code> and setup <code>message</code> event listener to get its messages.</li>
<li>When a message received: iterate over clients and send it to everyone.</li>
<li>When a connection is closed: <code>clients.delete(socket)</code>.</li>
</ol>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb126"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-1" title="1"><span class="kw">const</span> ws <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">require</span>(<span class="st">&#39;ws&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-2" title="2"><span class="kw">const</span> wss <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="va">ws</span>.<span class="at">Server</span>(<span class="op">{</span><span class="dt">noServer</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-4" title="4"><span class="kw">const</span> clients <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Set</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-6" title="6"><span class="va">http</span>.<span class="at">createServer</span>((req<span class="op">,</span> res) <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-7" title="7">  <span class="co">// here we only handle websocket connections</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-8" title="8">  <span class="co">// in real project we&#39;d have some other code here to handle non-websocket requests</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-9" title="9">  <span class="va">wss</span>.<span class="at">handleUpgrade</span>(req<span class="op">,</span> <span class="va">req</span>.<span class="at">socket</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="va">Buffer</span>.<span class="at">alloc</span>(<span class="dv">0</span>)<span class="op">,</span> onSocketConnect)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-10" title="10"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-11" title="11"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-12" title="12"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">onSocketConnect</span>(ws) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-13" title="13">  <span class="va">clients</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(ws)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-15" title="15">  <span class="va">ws</span>.<span class="at">on</span>(<span class="st">&#39;message&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(message) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-16" title="16">    message <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">message</span>.<span class="at">slice</span>(<span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">50</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// max message length will be 50</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-17" title="17"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-18" title="18">    <span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="kw">let</span> client <span class="kw">of</span> clients) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-19" title="19">      <span class="va">client</span>.<span class="at">send</span>(message)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-20" title="20">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-21" title="21">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-22" title="22"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-23" title="23">  <span class="va">ws</span>.<span class="at">on</span>(<span class="st">&#39;close&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-24" title="24">    <span class="va">clients</span>.<span class="at">delete</span>(ws)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-25" title="25">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb126-26" title="26"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here‚Äôs the working example:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúchat‚Äù height=‚Äú100‚Äù zip]</p>
<p>You can also download it (upper-right button in the iframe) and run locally. Just don‚Äôt forget to install <a href="https://nodejs.org/en/">Node.js</a> and <code>npm install ws</code> before running.</p>
<h2 id="summary-14">Summary</h2>
<p>WebSocket is a modern way to have persistent browser-server connections.</p>
<ul>
<li>WebSockets don‚Äôt have cross-origin limitations.</li>
<li>They are well-supported in browsers.</li>
<li>Can send/receive strings and binary data.</li>
</ul>
<p>The API is simple.</p>
<p>Methods: - <code>socket.send(data)</code>, - <code>socket.close([code], [reason])</code>.</p>
<p>Events: - <code>open</code>, - <code>message</code>, - <code>error</code>, - <code>close</code>.</p>
<p>WebSocket by itself does not include reconnection, authentication and many other high-level mechanisms. So there are client/server libraries for that, and it‚Äôs also possible to implement these capabilities manually.</p>
<p>Sometimes, to integrate WebSocket into existing project, people run WebSocket server in parallel with the main HTTP-server, and they share a single database. Requests to WebSocket use <code>wss://ws.site.com</code>, a subdomain that leads to WebSocket server, while <code>https://site.com</code> goes to the main HTTP-server.</p>
<p>Surely, other ways of integration are also possible. # Server Sent Events</p>
<p>The <a href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/comms.html#the-eventsource-interface">Server-Sent Events</a> specification describes a built-in class <code>EventSource</code>, that keeps connection with the server and allows to receive events from it.</p>
<p>Similar to <code>WebSocket</code>, the connection is persistent.</p>
<p>But there are several important differences:</p>
<table>
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 46%" />
<col style="width: 53%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th><code>WebSocket</code></th>
<th><code>EventSource</code></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td>Bi-directional: both client and server can exchange messages</td>
<td>One-directional: only server sends data</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td>Binary and text data</td>
<td>Only text</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td>WebSocket protocol</td>
<td>Regular HTTP</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><code>EventSource</code> is a less-powerful way of communicating with the server than <code>WebSocket</code>.</p>
<p>Why should one ever use it?</p>
<p>The main reason: it‚Äôs simpler. In many applications, the power of <code>WebSocket</code> is a little bit too much.</p>
<p>We need to receive a stream of data from server: maybe chat messages or market prices, or whatever. That‚Äôs what <code>EventSource</code> is good at. Also it supports auto-reconnect, something we need to implement manually with <code>WebSocket</code>. Besides, it‚Äôs a plain old HTTP, not a new protocol.</p>
<h2 id="getting-messages">Getting messages</h2>
<p>To start receiving messages, we just need to create <code>new EventSource(url)</code>.</p>
<p>The browser will connect to <code>url</code> and keep the connection open, waiting for events.</p>
<p>The server should respond with status 200 and the header <code>Content-Type: text/event-stream</code>, then keep the connection and write messages into it in the special format, like this:</p>
<pre><code>data: Message 1

data: Message 2

data: Message 3
data: of two lines</code></pre>
<ul>
<li>A message text goes after <code>data:</code>, the space after the colon is optional.</li>
<li>Messages are delimited with double line breaks <code>\n\n</code>.</li>
<li>To send a line break <code>\n</code>, we can immediately send one more <code>data:</code> (3rd message above).</li>
</ul>
<p>In practice, complex messages are usually sent JSON-encoded. Line-breaks are encoded as <code>\n</code> within them, so multiline <code>data:</code> messages are not necessary.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb128"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb128-1" title="1">data<span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span><span class="st">&quot;user&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span><span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span><span class="st">&quot;message&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span><span class="st">&quot;First line*!*</span><span class="sc">\n</span><span class="st">*/!* Second line&quot;</span><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶So we can assume that one <code>data:</code> holds exactly one message.</p>
<p>For each such message, the <code>message</code> event is generated:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb129"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> eventSource <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">EventSource</span>(<span class="st">&quot;/events/subscribe&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-3" title="3"><span class="va">eventSource</span>.<span class="at">onmessage</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(event) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-4" title="4">  <span class="va">console</span>.<span class="at">log</span>(<span class="st">&quot;New message&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">data</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-5" title="5">  <span class="co">// will log 3 times for the data stream above</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-6" title="6"><span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb129-8" title="8"><span class="co">// or eventSource.addEventListener(&#39;message&#39;, ...)</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="cross-origin-requests-1">Cross-origin requests</h3>
<p><code>EventSource</code> supports cross-origin requests, like <code>fetch</code> and any other networking methods. We can use any URL:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb130"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb130-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> source <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">EventSource</span>(<span class="st">&quot;https://another-site.com/events&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The remote server will get the <code>Origin</code> header and must respond with <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> to proceed.</p>
<p>To pass credentials, we should set the additional option <code>withCredentials</code>, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb131"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb131-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> source <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">EventSource</span>(<span class="st">&quot;https://another-site.com/events&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb131-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">withCredentials</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb131-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Please see the chapter <a href="info:fetch-crossorigin" class="uri">info:fetch-crossorigin</a> for more details about cross-origin headers.</p>
<h2 id="reconnection">Reconnection</h2>
<p>Upon creation, <code>new EventSource</code> connects to the server, and if the connection is broken ‚Äì reconnects.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs very convenient, as we don‚Äôt have to care about it.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a small delay between reconnections, a few seconds by default.</p>
<p>The server can set the recommended delay using <code>retry:</code> in response (in milliseconds):</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb132"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb132-1" title="1">retry<span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">15000</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb132-2" title="2">data<span class="op">:</span> Hello<span class="op">,</span> I set the reconnection delay to <span class="dv">15</span> seconds</a></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code>retry:</code> may come both together with some data, or as a standalone message.</p>
<p>The browser should wait that many milliseconds before reconnecting. Or longer, e.g.¬†if the browser knows (from OS) that there‚Äôs no network connection at the moment, it may wait until the connection appears, and then retry.</p>
<ul>
<li>If the server wants the browser to stop reconnecting, it should respond with HTTP status 204.</li>
<li>If the browser wants to close the connection, it should call <code>eventSource.close()</code>:</li>
</ul>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb133"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb133-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> eventSource <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">EventSource</span>(...)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb133-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb133-3" title="3"><span class="va">eventSource</span>.<span class="at">close</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Also, there will be no reconnection if the response has an incorrect <code>Content-Type</code> or its HTTP status differs from 301, 307, 200 and 204. In such cases the <code>"error"</code> event will be emitted, and the browser won‚Äôt reconnect.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>When a connection is finally closed, there&#39;s no way to &quot;reopen&quot; it. If we&#39;d like to connect again, just create a new `EventSource`.</code></pre>
<h2 id="message-id">Message id</h2>
<p>When a connection breaks due to network problems, either side can‚Äôt be sure which messages were received, and which weren‚Äôt.</p>
<p>To correctly resume the connection, each message should have an <code>id</code> field, like this:</p>
<pre><code>data: Message 1
id: 1

data: Message 2
id: 2

data: Message 3
data: of two lines
id: 3</code></pre>
<p>When a message with <code>id:</code> is received, the browser:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sets the property <code>eventSource.lastEventId</code> to its value.</li>
<li>Upon reconnection sends the header <code>Last-Event-ID</code> with that <code>id</code>, so that the server may re-send following messages.</li>
</ul>
<p><code>smart header="Put `id:` after `data:`" Please note: the `id` is appended below message `data` by the server, to ensure that `lastEventId` is updated after the message is received.</code></p>
<h2 id="connection-status-readystate">Connection status: readyState</h2>
<p>The <code>EventSource</code> object has <code>readyState</code> property, that has one of three values:</p>
<p><code>js no-beautify EventSource.CONNECTING = 0; // connecting or reconnecting EventSource.OPEN = 1;       // connected EventSource.CLOSED = 2;     // connection closed</code></p>
<p>When an object is created, or the connection is down, it‚Äôs always <code>EventSource.CONNECTING</code> (equals <code>0</code>).</p>
<p>We can query this property to know the state of <code>EventSource</code>.</p>
<h2 id="event-types">Event types</h2>
<p>By default <code>EventSource</code> object generates three events:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>message</code> ‚Äì a message received, available as <code>event.data</code>.</li>
<li><code>open</code> ‚Äì the connection is open.</li>
<li><code>error</code> ‚Äì the connection could not be established, e.g.¬†the server returned HTTP 500 status.</li>
</ul>
<p>The server may specify another type of event with <code>event: ...</code> at the event start.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<pre><code>event: join
data: Bob

data: Hello

event: leave
data: Bob</code></pre>
<p>To handle custom events, we must use <code>addEventListener</code>, not <code>onmessage</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb137"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-1" title="1"><span class="va">eventSource</span>.<span class="at">addEventListener</span>(<span class="st">&#39;join&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> event <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="vs">`Joined </span><span class="sc">${</span><span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">data</span><span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">`</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-5" title="5"><span class="va">eventSource</span>.<span class="at">addEventListener</span>(<span class="st">&#39;message&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> event <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-6" title="6">  <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="vs">`Said: </span><span class="sc">${</span><span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">data</span><span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">`</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-8" title="8"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-9" title="9"><span class="va">eventSource</span>.<span class="at">addEventListener</span>(<span class="st">&#39;leave&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> event <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-10" title="10">  <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="vs">`Left </span><span class="sc">${</span><span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">data</span><span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">`</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb137-11" title="11"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="full-example">Full example</h2>
<p>Here‚Äôs the server that sends messages with <code>1</code>, <code>2</code>, <code>3</code>, then <code>bye</code> and breaks the connection.</p>
<p>Then the browser automatically reconnects.</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúeventsource‚Äù]</p>
<h2 id="summary-15">Summary</h2>
<p><code>EventSource</code> object automatically establishes a persistent connection and allows the server to send messages over it.</p>
<p>It offers: - Automatic reconnect, with tunable <code>retry</code> timeout. - Message ids to resume events, the last received identifier is sent in <code>Last-Event-ID</code> header upon reconnection. - The current state is in the <code>readyState</code> property.</p>
<p>That makes <code>EventSource</code> a viable alternative to <code>WebSocket</code>, as the latter is more low-level and lacks such built-in features (though they can be implemented).</p>
<p>In many real-life applications, the power of <code>EventSource</code> is just enough.</p>
<p>Supported in all modern browsers (not IE).</p>
<p>The syntax is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb138"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb138-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> source <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">EventSource</span>(url<span class="op">,</span> [credentials])<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The second argument has only one possible option: <code>{ withCredentials: true }</code>, it allows sending cross-origin credentials.</p>
<p>Overall cross-origin security is same as for <code>fetch</code> and other network methods.</p>
<h3 id="properties-of-an-eventsource-object">Properties of an <code>EventSource</code> object</h3>
<dl>
<dt><code>readyState</code></dt>
<dd>The current connection state: either <code>EventSource.CONNECTING (=0)</code>, <code>EventSource.OPEN (=1)</code> or <code>EventSource.CLOSED (=2)</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>lastEventId</code></dt>
<dd>The last received <code>id</code>. Upon reconnection the browser sends it in the header <code>Last-Event-ID</code>.
</dd>
</dl>
<h3 id="methods">Methods</h3>
<dl>
<dt><code>close()</code></dt>
<dd>Closes the connection.
</dd>
</dl>
<h3 id="events">Events</h3>
<dl>
<dt><code>message</code></dt>
<dd>Message received, the data is in <code>event.data</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>open</code></dt>
<dd>The connection is established.
</dd>
<dt><code>error</code></dt>
<dd>In case of an error, including both lost connection (will auto-reconnect) and fatal errors. We can check <code>readyState</code> to see if the reconnection is being attempted.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The server may set a custom event name in <code>event:</code>. Such events should be handled using <code>addEventListener</code>, not <code>on&lt;event&gt;</code>.</p>
<h3 id="server-response-format">Server response format</h3>
<p>The server sends messages, delimited by <code>\n\n</code>.</p>
<p>A message may have following fields:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>data:</code> ‚Äì message body, a sequence of multiple <code>data</code> is interpreted as a single message, with <code>\n</code> between the parts.</li>
<li><code>id:</code> ‚Äì renews <code>lastEventId</code>, sent in <code>Last-Event-ID</code> on reconnect.</li>
<li><code>retry:</code> ‚Äì recommends a retry delay for reconnections in ms. There‚Äôs no way to set it from JavaScript.</li>
<li><code>event:</code> ‚Äì event name, must precede <code>data:</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>A message may include one or more fields in any order, but <code>id:</code> usually goes the last. # Cookies, document.cookie</p>
<p>Cookies are small strings of data that are stored directly in the browser. They are a part of the HTTP protocol, defined by the <a href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6265">RFC 6265</a> specification.</p>
<p>Cookies are usually set by a web-server using the response <code>Set-Cookie</code> HTTP-header. Then, the browser automatically adds them to (almost) every request to the same domain using the <code>Cookie</code> HTTP-header.</p>
<p>One of the most widespread use cases is authentication:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Upon sign in, the server uses the <code>Set-Cookie</code> HTTP-header in the response to set a cookie with a unique ‚Äúsession identifier‚Äù.</li>
<li>Next time when the request is sent to the same domain, the browser sends the cookie over the net using the <code>Cookie</code> HTTP-header.</li>
<li>So the server knows who made the request.</li>
</ol>
<p>We can also access cookies from the browser, using <code>document.cookie</code> property.</p>
<p>There are many tricky things about cookies and their options. In this chapter we‚Äôll cover them in detail.</p>
<h2 id="reading-from-document.cookie">Reading from document.cookie</h2>
<pre class="online"><code>Does your browser store any cookies from this site? Let&#39;s see:</code></pre>
<pre class="offline"><code>Assuming you&#39;re on a website, it&#39;s possible to see the cookies from it, like this:</code></pre>
<p><code>js run // At javascript.info, we use Google Analytics for statistics, // so there should be some cookies alert( document.cookie ); // cookie1=value1; cookie2=value2;...</code></p>
<p>The value of <code>document.cookie</code> consists of <code>name=value</code> pairs, delimited by <code>;</code>. Each one is a separate cookie.</p>
<p>To find a particular cookie, we can split <code>document.cookie</code> by <code>;</code>, and then find the right name. We can use either a regular expression or array functions to do that.</p>
<p>We leave it as an exercise for the reader. Also, at the end of the chapter you‚Äôll find helper functions to manipulate cookies.</p>
<h2 id="writing-to-document.cookie">Writing to document.cookie</h2>
<p>We can write to <code>document.cookie</code>. But it‚Äôs not a data property, it‚Äôs an accessor (getter/setter). An assignment to it is treated specially.</p>
<p><strong>A write operation to <code>document.cookie</code> updates only cookies mentioned in it, but doesn‚Äôt touch other cookies.</strong></p>
<p>For instance, this call sets a cookie with the name <code>user</code> and value <code>John</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run document.cookie = "user=John"; // update only cookie named 'user' alert(document.cookie); // show all cookies</code></p>
<p>If you run it, then probably you‚Äôll see multiple cookies. That‚Äôs because the <code>document.cookie=</code> operation does not overwrite all cookies. It only sets the mentioned cookie <code>user</code>.</p>
<p>Technically, name and value can have any characters. To keep the valid formatting, they should be escaped using a built-in <code>encodeURIComponent</code> function:</p>
<p>```js run // special characters (spaces), need encoding let name = ‚Äúmy name‚Äù; let value = ‚ÄúJohn Smith‚Äù</p>
<p>// encodes the cookie as my%20name=John%20Smith document.cookie = encodeURIComponent(name) + ‚Äò=‚Äô + encodeURIComponent(value);</p>
<p>alert(document.cookie); // ‚Ä¶; my%20name=John%20Smith ```</p>
<p><code>warn header="Limitations" There are few limitations: - The `name=value` pair, after `encodeURIComponent`, should not exceed 4KB. So we can't store anything huge in a cookie. - The total number of cookies per domain is limited to around 20+, the exact limit depends on the browser.</code></p>
<p>Cookies have several options, many of them are important and should be set.</p>
<p>The options are listed after <code>key=value</code>, delimited by <code>;</code>, like this:</p>
<p><code>js run document.cookie = "user=John; path=/; expires=Tue, 19 Jan 2038 03:14:07 GMT"</code></p>
<h2 id="path">path</h2>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>path=/mypath</code></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>The url path prefix must be absolute. It makes the cookie accessible for pages under that path. By default, it‚Äôs the current path.</p>
<p>If a cookie is set with <code>path=/admin</code>, it‚Äôs visible at pages <code>/admin</code> and <code>/admin/something</code>, but not at <code>/home</code> or <code>/adminpage</code>.</p>
<p>Usually, we should set <code>path</code> to the root: <code>path=/</code> to make the cookie accessible from all website pages.</p>
<h2 id="domain">domain</h2>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>domain=site.com</code></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>A domain defines where the cookie is accessible. In practice though, there are limitations. We can‚Äôt set any domain.</p>
<p>By default, a cookie is accessible only at the domain that set it. So, if the cookie was set by <code>site.com</code>, we won‚Äôt get it at <code>other.com</code>.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But what‚Äôs more tricky, we also won‚Äôt get the cookie at a subdomain <code>forum.site.com</code>!</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb141"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb141-1" title="1"><span class="co">// at site.com</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb141-2" title="2"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;user=John&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb141-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb141-4" title="4"><span class="co">// at forum.site.com</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb141-5" title="5"><span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// no user</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><strong>There‚Äôs no way to let a cookie be accessible from another 2nd-level domain, so <code>other.com</code> will never receive a cookie set at <code>site.com</code>.</strong></p>
<p>It‚Äôs a safety restriction, to allow us to store sensitive data in cookies, that should be available only on one site.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But if we‚Äôd like to allow subdomains like <code>forum.site.com</code> to get a cookie, that‚Äôs possible. When setting a cookie at <code>site.com</code>, we should explicitly set the <code>domain</code> option to the root domain: <code>domain=site.com</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb142"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-1" title="1"><span class="co">// at site.com</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-2" title="2"><span class="co">// make the cookie accessible on any subdomain *.site.com:</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-3" title="3"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;user=John; domain=site.com&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-5" title="5"><span class="co">// later</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-7" title="7"><span class="co">// at forum.site.com</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb142-8" title="8"><span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// has cookie user=John</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>For historical reasons, <code>domain=.site.com</code> (a dot before <code>site.com</code>) also works the same way, allowing access to the cookie from subdomains. That‚Äôs an old notation and should be used if we need to support very old browsers.</p>
<p>So, the <code>domain</code> option allows to make a cookie accessible at subdomains.</p>
<h2 id="expires-max-age">expires, max-age</h2>
<p>By default, if a cookie doesn‚Äôt have one of these options, it disappears when the browser is closed. Such cookies are called ‚Äúsession cookies‚Äù</p>
<p>To let cookies survive a browser close, we can set either the <code>expires</code> or <code>max-age</code> option.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>expires=Tue, 19 Jan 2038 03:14:07 GMT</code></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>The cookie expiration date defines the time, when the browser will automatically delete it.</p>
<p>The date must be exactly in this format, in the GMT timezone. We can use <code>date.toUTCString</code> to get it. For instance, we can set the cookie to expire in 1 day:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb143"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb143-1" title="1"><span class="co">// +1 day from now</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb143-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> date <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Date</span>(<span class="va">Date</span>.<span class="at">now</span>() <span class="op">+</span> <span class="fl">86400e3</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb143-3" title="3">date <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">date</span>.<span class="at">toUTCString</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb143-4" title="4"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;user=John; expires=&quot;</span> <span class="op">+</span> date<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>If we set <code>expires</code> to a date in the past, the cookie is deleted.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>max-age=3600</code></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Is an alternative to <code>expires</code> and specifies the cookie‚Äôs expiration in seconds from the current moment.</p>
<p>If set to zero or a negative value, the cookie is deleted:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb144"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb144-1" title="1"><span class="co">// cookie will die in +1 hour from now</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb144-2" title="2"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;user=John; max-age=3600&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb144-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb144-4" title="4"><span class="co">// delete cookie (let it expire right now)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb144-5" title="5"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;user=John; max-age=0&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="secure">secure</h2>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>secure</code></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>The cookie should be transferred only over HTTPS.</p>
<p><strong>By default, if we set a cookie at <code>http://site.com</code>, then it also appears at <code>https://site.com</code> and vice versa.</strong></p>
<p>That is, cookies are domain-based, they do not distinguish between the protocols.</p>
<p>With this option, if a cookie is set by <code>https://site.com</code>, then it doesn‚Äôt appear when the same site is accessed by HTTP, as <code>http://site.com</code>. So if a cookie has sensitive content that should never be sent over unencrypted HTTP, the <code>secure</code> flag is the right thing.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb145"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb145-1" title="1"><span class="co">// assuming we&#39;re on https:// now</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb145-2" title="2"><span class="co">// set the cookie to be secure (only accessible over HTTPS)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb145-3" title="3"><span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">cookie</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;user=John; secure&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="samesite">samesite</h2>
<p>That‚Äôs another security attribute <code>samesite</code>. It‚Äôs designed to protect from so-called XSRF (cross-site request forgery) attacks.</p>
<p>To understand how it works and when it‚Äôs useful, let‚Äôs take a look at XSRF attacks.</p>
<h3 id="xsrf-attack">XSRF attack</h3>
<p>Imagine, you are logged into the site <code>bank.com</code>. That is: you have an authentication cookie from that site. Your browser sends it to <code>bank.com</code> with every request, so that it recognizes you and performs all sensitive financial operations.</p>
<p>Now, while browsing the web in another window, you accidentally come to another site <code>evil.com</code>. That site has JavaScript code that submits a form <code>&lt;form action="https://bank.com/pay"&gt;</code> to <code>bank.com</code> with fields that initiate a transaction to the hacker‚Äôs account.</p>
<p>The browser sends cookies every time you visit the site <code>bank.com</code>, even if the form was submitted from <code>evil.com</code>. So the bank recognizes you and actually performs the payment.</p>
<p><img src="cookie-xsrf.svg" /></p>
<p>That‚Äôs a so-called ‚ÄúCross-Site Request Forgery‚Äù (in short, XSRF) attack.</p>
<p>Real banks are protected from it of course. All forms generated by <code>bank.com</code> have a special field, a so-called ‚ÄúXSRF protection token‚Äù, that an evil page can‚Äôt generate or extract from a remote page. It can submit a form there, but can‚Äôt get the data back. The site <code>bank.com</code> checks for such token in every form it receives.</p>
<p>Such a protection takes time to implement though. We need to ensure that every form has the required token field, and we must also check all requests.</p>
<h3 id="enter-cookie-samesite-option">Enter cookie samesite option</h3>
<p>The cookie <code>samesite</code> option provides another way to protect from such attacks, that (in theory) should not require ‚Äúxsrf protection tokens‚Äù.</p>
<p>It has two possible values:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>samesite=strict</code> (same as <code>samesite</code> without value)</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>A cookie with <code>samesite=strict</code> is never sent if the user comes from outside the same site.</p>
<p>In other words, whether a user follows a link from their mail or submits a form from <code>evil.com</code>, or does any operation that originates from another domain, the cookie is not sent.</p>
<p>If authentication cookies have the <code>samesite</code> option, then a XSRF attack has no chances to succeed, because a submission from <code>evil.com</code> comes without cookies. So <code>bank.com</code> will not recognize the user and will not proceed with the payment.</p>
<p>The protection is quite reliable. Only operations that come from <code>bank.com</code> will send the <code>samesite</code> cookie, e.g.¬†a form submission from another page at <code>bank.com</code>.</p>
<p>Although, there‚Äôs a small inconvenience.</p>
<p>When a user follows a legitimate link to <code>bank.com</code>, like from their own notes, they‚Äôll be surprised that <code>bank.com</code> does not recognize them. Indeed, <code>samesite=strict</code> cookies are not sent in that case.</p>
<p>We could work around that by using two cookies: one for ‚Äúgeneral recognition‚Äù, only for the purposes of saying: ‚ÄúHello, John‚Äù, and the other one for data-changing operations with <code>samesite=strict</code>. Then, a person coming from outside of the site will see a welcome, but payments must be initiated from the bank‚Äôs website, for the second cookie to be sent.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><code>samesite=lax</code></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>A more relaxed approach that also protects from XSRF and doesn‚Äôt break the user experience.</p>
<p>Lax mode, just like <code>strict</code>, forbids the browser to send cookies when coming from outside the site, but adds an exception.</p>
<p>A <code>samesite=lax</code> cookie is sent if both of these conditions are true: 1. The HTTP method is ‚Äúsafe‚Äù (e.g.¬†GET, but not POST).</p>
<pre><code>The full list of safe HTTP methods is in the [RFC7231 specification](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231). Basically, these are the methods that should be used for reading, but not writing the data. They must not perform any data-changing operations. Following a link is always GET, the safe method.</code></pre>
<ol start="2" type="1">
<li><p>The operation performs a top-level navigation (changes URL in the browser address bar).</p>
<p>That‚Äôs usually true, but if the navigation is performed in an <code>&lt;iframe&gt;</code>, then it‚Äôs not top-level. Also, JavaScript methods for network requests do not perform any navigation, hence they don‚Äôt fit.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>So, what <code>samesite=lax</code> does, is to basically allow the most common ‚Äúgo to URL‚Äù operation to have cookies. E.g. opening a website link from notes that satisfy these conditions.</p>
<p>But anything more complicated, like a network request from another site or a form submission, loses cookies.</p>
<p>If that‚Äôs fine for you, then adding <code>samesite=lax</code> will probably not break the user experience and add protection.</p>
<p>Overall, <code>samesite</code> is a great option, but it has an important drawback: - <code>samesite</code> is ignored (not supported) by old browsers, year 2017 or so.</p>
<p><strong>So if we solely rely on <code>samesite</code> to provide protection, then old browsers will be vulnerable.</strong></p>
<p>But we surely can use <code>samesite</code> together with other protection measures, like xsrf tokens, to add an additional layer of defence and then, in the future, when old browsers die out, we‚Äôll probably be able to drop xsrf tokens.</p>
<h2 id="httponly">httpOnly</h2>
<p>This option has nothing to do with JavaScript, but we have to mention it for completeness.</p>
<p>The web-server uses the <code>Set-Cookie</code> header to set a cookie. Also, it may set the <code>httpOnly</code> option.</p>
<p>This option forbids any JavaScript access to the cookie. We can‚Äôt see such a cookie or manipulate it using <code>document.cookie</code>.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs used as a precaution measure, to protect from certain attacks when a hacker injects his own JavaScript code into a page and waits for a user to visit that page. That shouldn‚Äôt be possible at all, hackers should not be able to inject their code into our site, but there may be bugs that let them do it.</p>
<p>Normally, if such a thing happens, and a user visits a web-page with hacker‚Äôs JavaScript code, then that code executes and gains access to <code>document.cookie</code> with user cookies containing authentication information. That‚Äôs bad.</p>
<p>But if a cookie is <code>httpOnly</code>, then <code>document.cookie</code> doesn‚Äôt see it, so it is protected.</p>
<h2 id="appendix-cookie-functions">Appendix: Cookie functions</h2>
<p>Here‚Äôs a small set of functions to work with cookies, more convenient than a manual modification of <code>document.cookie</code>.</p>
<p>There exist many cookie libraries for that, so these are for demo purposes. Fully working though.</p>
<h3 id="getcookiename">getCookie(name)</h3>
<p>The shortest way to access a cookie is to use a <a href="info:regular-expressions">regular expression</a>.</p>
<p>The function <code>getCookie(name)</code> returns the cookie with the given <code>name</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb147"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-1" title="1"><span class="co">// returns the cookie with the given name,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-2" title="2"><span class="co">// or undefined if not found</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-3" title="3"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">getCookie</span>(name) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">let</span> matches <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">document</span>.<span class="va">cookie</span>.<span class="at">match</span>(<span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">RegExp</span>(</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-5" title="5">    <span class="st">&quot;(?:^|; )&quot;</span> <span class="op">+</span> <span class="va">name</span>.<span class="at">replace</span>(<span class="ss">/</span><span class="sc">([\.$?*|{}\(\)\[\]\\\/\+^])</span><span class="ss">/g</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&#39;</span><span class="sc">\\</span><span class="st">$1&#39;</span>) <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&quot;=([^;]*)&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-6" title="6">  ))<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-7" title="7">  <span class="cf">return</span> matches <span class="op">?</span> <span class="at">decodeURIComponent</span>(matches[<span class="dv">1</span>]) : <span class="kw">undefined</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb147-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here <code>new RegExp</code> is generated dynamically, to match <code>; name=&lt;value&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>Please note that a cookie value is encoded, so <code>getCookie</code> uses a built-in <code>decodeURIComponent</code> function to decode it.</p>
<h3 id="setcookiename-value-options">setCookie(name, value, options)</h3>
<p>Sets the cookie‚Äôs <code>name</code> to the given <code>value</code> with <code>path=/</code> by default (can be modified to add other defaults):</p>
<p>```js run function setCookie(name, value, options = {}) {</p>
<p>options = { path: ‚Äò/‚Äô, // add other defaults here if necessary ‚Ä¶options };</p>
<p>if (options.expires instanceof Date) { options.expires = options.expires.toUTCString(); }</p>
<p>let updatedCookie = encodeURIComponent(name) + ‚Äú=‚Äù + encodeURIComponent(value);</p>
<p>for (let optionKey in options) { updatedCookie += ‚Äú;‚Äù + optionKey; let optionValue = options[optionKey]; if (optionValue !== true) { updatedCookie += ‚Äú=‚Äù + optionValue; } }</p>
<p>document.cookie = updatedCookie; }</p>
<p>// Example of use: setCookie(‚Äòuser‚Äô, ‚ÄòJohn‚Äô, {secure: true, ‚Äòmax-age‚Äô: 3600}); ```</p>
<h3 id="deletecookiename">deleteCookie(name)</h3>
<p>To delete a cookie, we can call it with a negative expiration date:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb148"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb148-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">deleteCookie</span>(name) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb148-2" title="2">  <span class="at">setCookie</span>(name<span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb148-3" title="3">    <span class="st">&#39;max-age&#39;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">-1</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb148-4" title="4">  <span class="op">}</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb148-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><code>warn header="Updating or deleting must use same path and domain" Please note: when we update or delete a cookie, we should use exactly the same path and domain options as when we set it.</code></p>
<p>Together: <a href="cookie.js">cookie.js</a>.</p>
<h2 id="appendix-third-party-cookies">Appendix: Third-party cookies</h2>
<p>A cookie is called ‚Äúthird-party‚Äù if it‚Äôs placed by a domain other than the page the user is visiting.</p>
<p>For instance: 1. A page at <code>site.com</code> loads a banner from another site: <code>&lt;img src="https://ads.com/banner.png"&gt;</code>. 2. Along with the banner, the remote server at <code>ads.com</code> may set the <code>Set-Cookie</code> header with a cookie like <code>id=1234</code>. Such a cookie originates from the <code>ads.com</code> domain, and will only be visible at <code>ads.com</code>:</p>
<pre><code>![](cookie-third-party.svg)</code></pre>
<ol start="3" type="1">
<li><p>Next time when <code>ads.com</code> is accessed, the remote server gets the <code>id</code> cookie and recognizes the user:</p>
<p><img src="cookie-third-party-2.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>What‚Äôs even more important is, when the user moves from <code>site.com</code> to another site <code>other.com</code>, which also has a banner, then <code>ads.com</code> gets the cookie, as it belongs to <code>ads.com</code>, thus recognizing the visitor and tracking him as he moves between sites:</p>
<p><img src="cookie-third-party-3.svg" /></p></li>
</ol>
<p>Third-party cookies are traditionally used for tracking and ads services, due to their nature. They are bound to the originating domain, so <code>ads.com</code> can track the same user between different sites, if they all access it.</p>
<p>Naturally, some people don‚Äôt like being tracked, so browsers allow to disable such cookies.</p>
<p>Also, some modern browsers employ special policies for such cookies: - Safari does not allow third-party cookies at all. - Firefox comes with a ‚Äúblack list‚Äù of third-party domains where it blocks third-party cookies.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>If we load a script from a third-party domain, like `&lt;script src=&quot;https://google-analytics.com/analytics.js&quot;&gt;`, and that script uses `document.cookie` to set a cookie, then such cookie is not third-party.

If a script sets a cookie, then no matter where the script came from -- the cookie belongs to the domain of the current webpage.</code></pre>
<h2 id="appendix-gdpr">Appendix: GDPR</h2>
<p>This topic is not related to JavaScript at all, just something to keep in mind when setting cookies.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a legislation in Europe called GDPR, that enforces a set of rules for websites to respect the users‚Äô privacy. One of these rules is to require an explicit permission for tracking cookies from the user.</p>
<p>Please note, that‚Äôs only about tracking/identifying/authorizing cookies.</p>
<p>So, if we set a cookie that just saves some information, but neither tracks nor identifies the user, then we are free to do it.</p>
<p>But if we are going to set a cookie with an authentication session or a tracking id, then a user must allow that.</p>
<p>Websites generally have two variants of following GDPR. You must have seen them both already in the web:</p>
<ol type="1">
