<a class="sourceLine" id="cb179-13" title="13">    <span class="va">console</span>.<span class="at">log</span>(<span class="st">&quot;No more books&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb179-14" title="14">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb179-15" title="15"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="promise-wrapper">Promise wrapper</h2>
<p>Adding <code>onsuccess/onerror</code> to every request is quite a cumbersome task. Sometimes we can make our life easier by using event delegation, e.g.¬†set handlers on the whole transactions, but <code>async/await</code> is much more convenient.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs use a thin promise wrapper <a href="https://github.com/jakearchibald/idb" class="uri">https://github.com/jakearchibald/idb</a> further in this chapter. It creates a global <code>idb</code> object with <a href="info:promisify">promisified</a> IndexedDB methods.</p>
<p>Then, instead of <code>onsuccess/onerror</code> we can write like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb180"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> db <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">idb</span>.<span class="at">openDB</span>(<span class="st">&#39;store&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">,</span> db <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="va">db</span>.<span class="at">oldVersion</span> <span class="op">==</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-3" title="3">    <span class="co">// perform the initialization</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-4" title="4">    <span class="va">db</span>.<span class="at">createObjectStore</span>(<span class="st">&#39;books&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="op">{</span><span class="dt">keyPath</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;id&#39;</span><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-5" title="5">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-6" title="6"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-8" title="8"><span class="kw">let</span> transaction <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">db</span>.<span class="at">transaction</span>(<span class="st">&#39;books&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&#39;readwrite&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-9" title="9"><span class="kw">let</span> books <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">transaction</span>.<span class="at">objectStore</span>(<span class="st">&#39;books&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-11" title="11"><span class="cf">try</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-12" title="12">  <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">books</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(...)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-13" title="13">  <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">books</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(...)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-15" title="15">  <span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">transaction</span>.<span class="at">complete</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-16" title="16"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-17" title="17">  <span class="va">console</span>.<span class="at">log</span>(<span class="st">&#39;jsbook saved&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-18" title="18"><span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">catch</span>(err) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-19" title="19">  <span class="va">console</span>.<span class="at">log</span>(<span class="st">&#39;error&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="va">err</span>.<span class="at">message</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb180-20" title="20"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So we have all the sweet ‚Äúplain async code‚Äù and ‚Äútry..catch‚Äù stuff.</p>
<h3 id="error-handling-1">Error handling</h3>
<p>If we don‚Äôt catch an error, then it falls through, till the closest outer <code>try..catch</code>.</p>
<p>An uncaught error becomes an ‚Äúunhandled promise rejection‚Äù event on <code>window</code> object.</p>
<p>We can handle such errors like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb181"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb181-1" title="1"><span class="va">window</span>.<span class="at">addEventListener</span>(<span class="st">&#39;unhandledrejection&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> event <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb181-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> request <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">target</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// IndexedDB native request object</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb181-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">let</span> error <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">event</span>.<span class="at">reason</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">//  Unhandled error object, same as request.error</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb181-4" title="4">  ...<span class="at">report</span> about the <span class="va">error</span>...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb181-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="inactive-transaction-pitfall">‚ÄúInactive transaction‚Äù pitfall</h3>
<p>As we already know, a transaction auto-commits as soon as the browser is done with the current code and microtasks. So if we put a <em>macrotask</em> like <code>fetch</code> in the middle of a transaction, then the transaction won‚Äôt wait for it to finish. It just auto-commits. So the next request in it would fail.</p>
<p>For a promise wrapper and <code>async/await</code> the situation is the same.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example of <code>fetch</code> in the middle of the transaction:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb182"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> transaction <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">db</span>.<span class="at">transaction</span>(<span class="st">&quot;inventory&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;readwrite&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> inventory <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">transaction</span>.<span class="at">objectStore</span>(<span class="st">&quot;inventory&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-4" title="4"><span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">inventory</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(<span class="op">{</span> <span class="dt">id</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;js&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dt">price</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dt">created</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Date</span>() <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-6" title="6"><span class="cf">await</span> <span class="at">fetch</span>(...)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// (*)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb182-8" title="8"><span class="cf">await</span> <span class="va">inventory</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(<span class="op">{</span> <span class="dt">id</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;js&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dt">price</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dt">created</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Date</span>() <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// Error</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The next <code>inventory.add</code> after <code>fetch</code> <code>(*)</code> fails with an ‚Äúinactive transaction‚Äù error, because the transaction is already committed and closed at that time.</p>
<p>The workaround is the same as when working with native IndexedDB: either make a new transaction or just split things apart. 1. Prepare the data and fetch all that‚Äôs needed first. 2. Then save in the database.</p>
<h3 id="getting-native-objects">Getting native objects</h3>
<p>Internally, the wrapper performs a native IndexedDB request, adding <code>onerror/onsuccess</code> to it, and returns a promise that rejects/resolves with the result.</p>
<p>That works fine most of the time. The examples are at the lib page <a href="https://github.com/jakearchibald/idb" class="uri">https://github.com/jakearchibald/idb</a>.</p>
<p>In few rare cases, when we need the original <code>request</code> object, we can access it as <code>promise.request</code> property of the promise:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb183"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> promise <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">books</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(book)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// get a promise (don&#39;t await for its result)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> request <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">promise</span>.<span class="at">request</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// native request object</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-4" title="4"><span class="kw">let</span> transaction <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">request</span>.<span class="at">transaction</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// native transaction object</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-6" title="6"><span class="co">// ...do some native IndexedDB voodoo...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb183-8" title="8"><span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="cf">await</span> promise<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// if still needed</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="summary-18">Summary</h2>
<p>IndexedDB can be thought of as a ‚ÄúlocalStorage on steroids‚Äù. It‚Äôs a simple key-value database, powerful enough for offline apps, yet simple to use.</p>
<p>The best manual is the specification, <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB-2/">the current one</a> is 2.0, but few methods from <a href="https://w3c.github.io/IndexedDB/">3.0</a> (it‚Äôs not much different) are partially supported.</p>
<p>The basic usage can be described with a few phrases:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Get a promise wrapper like <a href="https://github.com/jakearchibald/idb">idb</a>.</li>
<li>Open a database: <code>idb.openDb(name, version, onupgradeneeded)</code>
<ul>
<li>Create object storages and indexes in <code>onupgradeneeded</code> handler or perform version update if needed.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>For requests:
<ul>
<li>Create transaction <code>db.transaction('books')</code> (readwrite if needed).</li>
<li>Get the object store <code>transaction.objectStore('books')</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Then, to search by a key, call methods on the object store directly.
<ul>
<li>To search by an object field, create an index.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>If the data does not fit in memory, use a cursor.</li>
</ol>
<p>Here‚Äôs a small demo app:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúbooks‚Äù current=‚Äúindex.html‚Äù] # Bezier curve</p>
<p>Bezier curves are used in computer graphics to draw shapes, for CSS animation and in many other places.</p>
<p>They are a very simple thing, worth to study once and then feel comfortable in the world of vector graphics and advanced animations.</p>
<h2 id="control-points">Control points</h2>
<p>A <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve">bezier curve</a> is defined by control points.</p>
<p>There may be 2, 3, 4 or more.</p>
<p>For instance, two points curve:</p>
<p><img src="bezier2.svg" /></p>
<p>Three points curve:</p>
<p><img src="bezier3.svg" /></p>
<p>Four points curve:</p>
<p><img src="bezier4.svg" /></p>
<p>If you look closely at these curves, you can immediately notice:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><strong>Points are not always on curve.</strong> That‚Äôs perfectly normal, later we‚Äôll see how the curve is built.</li>
<li><strong>The curve order equals the number of points minus one</strong>. For two points we have a linear curve (that‚Äôs a straight line), for three points ‚Äì quadratic curve (parabolic), for four points ‚Äì cubic curve.</li>
<li><p><strong>A curve is always inside the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_hull">convex hull</a> of control points:</strong></p>
<p><img src="bezier4-e.svg" /> <img src="bezier3-e.svg" /></p></li>
</ol>
<p>Because of that last property, in computer graphics it‚Äôs possible to optimize intersection tests. If convex hulls do not intersect, then curves do not either. So checking for the convex hulls intersection first can give a very fast ‚Äúno intersection‚Äù result. Checking the intersection of convex hulls is much easier, because they are rectangles, triangles and so on (see the picture above), much simpler figures than the curve.</p>
<p><strong>The main value of Bezier curves for drawing ‚Äì by moving the points the curve is changing <em>in intuitively obvious way</em>.</strong></p>
<p>Try to move control points using a mouse in the example below:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?nocpath=1&amp;p=0,0,0.5,0,0.5,1,1,1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<p><strong>As you can notice, the curve stretches along the tangential lines 1 -&gt; 2 and 3 -&gt; 4.</strong></p>
<p>After some practice it becomes obvious how to place points to get the needed curve. And by connecting several curves we can get practically anything.</p>
<p>Here are some examples:</p>
<p><img src="bezier-car.svg" /> <img src="bezier-letter.svg" /> <img src="bezier-vase.svg" /></p>
<h2 id="de-casteljaus-algorithm">De Casteljau‚Äôs algorithm</h2>
<p>There‚Äôs a mathematical formula for Bezier curves, but let‚Äôs cover it a bit later, because <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Casteljau%27s_algorithm">De Casteljau‚Äôs algorithm</a> is identical to the mathematical definition and visually shows how it is constructed.</p>
<p>First let‚Äôs see the 3-points example.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the demo, and the explanation follow.</p>
<p>Control points (1,2 and 3) can be moved by the mouse. Press the ‚Äúplay‚Äù button to run it.</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?p=0,0,0.5,1,1,0&amp;animate=1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<p><strong>De Casteljau‚Äôs algorithm of building the 3-point bezier curve:</strong></p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Draw control points. In the demo above they are labeled: <code>1</code>, <code>2</code>, <code>3</code>.</li>
<li>Build segments between control points 1 -&gt; 2 -&gt; 3. In the demo above they are <span style="color:#825E28">brown</span>.</li>
<li><p>The parameter <code>t</code> moves from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>. In the example above the step <code>0.05</code> is used: the loop goes over <code>0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, ... 0.95, 1</code>.</p>
<p>For each of these values of <code>t</code>:</p>
<ul>
<li><p>On each <span style="color:#825E28">brown</span> segment we take a point located on the distance proportional to <code>t</code> from its beginning. As there are two segments, we have two points.</p>
<p>For instance, for <code>t=0</code> ‚Äì both points will be at the beginning of segments, and for <code>t=0.25</code> ‚Äì on the 25% of segment length from the beginning, for <code>t=0.5</code> ‚Äì 50%(the middle), for <code>t=1</code> ‚Äì in the end of segments.</p></li>
<li><p>Connect the points. On the picture below the connecting segment is painted <span style="color:#167490">blue</span>.</p></li>
</ul></li>
</ol>
<table>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>For <code>t=0.25</code></th>
<th>For <code>t=0.5</code></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><img src="bezier3-draw1.svg" /></td>
<td><img src="bezier3-draw2.svg" /></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<ol start="4" type="1">
<li><p>Now in the <span style="color:#167490">blue</span> segment take a point on the distance proportional to the same value of <code>t</code>. That is, for <code>t=0.25</code> (the left picture) we have a point at the end of the left quarter of the segment, and for <code>t=0.5</code> (the right picture) ‚Äì in the middle of the segment. On pictures above that point is <span style="color:red">red</span>.</p></li>
<li><p>As <code>t</code> runs from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>, every value of <code>t</code> adds a point to the curve. The set of such points forms the Bezier curve. It‚Äôs red and parabolic on the pictures above.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>That was a process for 3 points. But the same is for 4 points.</p>
<p>The demo for 4 points (points can be moved by a mouse):</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?p=0,0,0.5,0,0.5,1,1,1&amp;animate=1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<p>The algorithm for 4 points:</p>
<ul>
<li>Connect control points by segments: 1 -&gt; 2, 2 -&gt; 3, 3 -&gt; 4. There will be 3 <span style="color:#825E28">brown</span> segments.</li>
<li>For each <code>t</code> in the interval from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>:
<ul>
<li>We take points on these segments on the distance proportional to <code>t</code> from the beginning. These points are connected, so that we have two <span style="color:#0A0">green segments</span>.</li>
<li>On these segments we take points proportional to <code>t</code>. We get one <span style="color:#167490">blue segment</span>.</li>
<li>On the blue segment we take a point proportional to <code>t</code>. On the example above it‚Äôs <span style="color:red">red</span>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>These points together form the curve.</li>
</ul>
<p>The algorithm is recursive and can be generalized for any number of control points.</p>
<p>Given N of control points:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>We connect them to get initially N-1 segments.</li>
<li>Then for each <code>t</code> from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>, we take a point on each segment on the distance proportional to <code>t</code> and connect them. There will be N-2 segments.</li>
<li>Repeat step 2 until there is only one point.</li>
</ol>
<p>These points make the curve.</p>
<pre class="online"><code>**Run and pause examples to clearly see the segments and how the curve is built.**</code></pre>
<p>A curve that looks like <code>y=1/t</code>:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?p=0,0,0,0.75,0.25,1,1,1&amp;animate=1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<p>Zig-zag control points also work fine:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?p=0,0,1,0.5,0,0.5,1,1&amp;animate=1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<p>Making a loop is possible:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?p=0,0,1,0.5,0,1,0.5,0&amp;animate=1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<p>A non-smooth Bezier curve (yeah, that‚Äôs possible too):</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúdemo.svg?p=0,0,1,1,0,1,1,0&amp;animate=1‚Äù height=370]</p>
<pre class="online"><code>If there&#39;s something unclear in the algorithm description, please look at the live examples above to see how
the curve is built.</code></pre>
<p>As the algorithm is recursive, we can build Bezier curves of any order, that is: using 5, 6 or more control points. But in practice many points are less useful. Usually we take 2-3 points, and for complex lines glue several curves together. That‚Äôs simpler to develop and calculate.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúHow to draw a curve <em>through</em> given points?‚Äù To specify a Bezier curve, control points are used. As we can see, they are not on the curve, except the first and the last ones.</p>
<p>Sometimes we have another task: to draw a curve <em>through several points</em>, so that all of them are on a single smooth curve. That task is called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpolation">interpolation</a>, and here we don‚Äôt cover it.</p>
<p>There are mathematical formulas for such curves, for instance <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_polynomial">Lagrange polynomial</a>. In computer graphics <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spline_interpolation">spline interpolation</a> is often used to build smooth curves that connect many points. ```</p>
<h2 id="maths">Maths</h2>
<p>A Bezier curve can be described using a mathematical formula.</p>
<p>As we saw ‚Äì there‚Äôs actually no need to know it, most people just draw the curve by moving points with a mouse. But if you‚Äôre into maths ‚Äì here it is.</p>
<p>Given the coordinates of control points <code>P<sub>i</sub></code>: the first control point has coordinates <code>P<sub>1</sub> = (x<sub>1</sub>, y<sub>1</sub>)</code>, the second: <code>P<sub>2</sub> = (x<sub>2</sub>, y<sub>2</sub>)</code>, and so on, the curve coordinates are described by the equation that depends on the parameter <code>t</code> from the segment <code>[0,1]</code>.</p>
<ul>
<li><p>The formula for a 2-points curve:</p>
<code>P = (1-t)P<sub>1</sub> + tP<sub>2</sub></code></li>
<li><p>For 3 control points:</p>
<code>P = (1‚àít)<sup>2</sup>P<sub>1</sub> + 2(1‚àít)tP<sub>2</sub> + t<sup>2</sup>P<sub>3</sub></code></li>
<li><p>For 4 control points:</p>
<p><code>P = (1‚àít)<sup>3</sup>P<sub>1</sub> + 3(1‚àít)<sup>2</sup>tP<sub>2</sub> +3(1‚àít)t<sup>2</sup>P<sub>3</sub> + t<sup>3</sup>P<sub>4</sub></code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>These are vector equations. In other words, we can put <code>x</code> and <code>y</code> instead of <code>P</code> to get corresponding coordinates.</p>
<p>For instance, the 3-point curve is formed by points <code>(x,y)</code> calculated as:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>x = (1‚àít)<sup>2</sup>x<sub>1</sub> + 2(1‚àít)tx<sub>2</sub> + t<sup>2</sup>x<sub>3</sub></code></li>
<li><code>y = (1‚àít)<sup>2</sup>y<sub>1</sub> + 2(1‚àít)ty<sub>2</sub> + t<sup>2</sup>y<sub>3</sub></code></li>
</ul>
<p>Instead of <code>x<sub>1</sub>, y<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>, y<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>3</sub>, y<sub>3</sub></code> we should put coordinates of 3 control points, and then as <code>t</code> moves from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>, for each value of <code>t</code> we‚Äôll have <code>(x,y)</code> of the curve.</p>
<p>For instance, if control points are <code>(0,0)</code>, <code>(0.5, 1)</code> and <code>(1, 0)</code>, the equations become:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>x = (1‚àít)<sup>2</sup> * 0 + 2(1‚àít)t * 0.5 + t<sup>2</sup> * 1 = (1-t)t + t<sup>2</sup> = t</code></li>
<li><code>y = (1‚àít)<sup>2</sup> * 0 + 2(1‚àít)t * 1 + t<sup>2</sup> * 0 = 2(1-t)t = ‚Äì2t<sup>2</sup> + 2t</code></li>
</ul>
<p>Now as <code>t</code> runs from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>, the set of values <code>(x,y)</code> for each <code>t</code> forms the curve for such control points.</p>
<h2 id="summary-19">Summary</h2>
<p>Bezier curves are defined by their control points.</p>
<p>We saw two definitions of Bezier curves:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Using a drawing process: De Casteljau‚Äôs algorithm.</li>
<li>Using a mathematical formulas.</li>
</ol>
<p>Good properties of Bezier curves:</p>
<ul>
<li>We can draw smooth lines with a mouse by moving control points.</li>
<li>Complex shapes can be made of several Bezier curves.</li>
</ul>
<p>Usage:</p>
<ul>
<li>In computer graphics, modeling, vector graphic editors. Fonts are described by Bezier curves.</li>
<li>In web development ‚Äì for graphics on Canvas and in the SVG format. By the way, ‚Äúlive‚Äù examples above are written in SVG. They are actually a single SVG document that is given different points as parameters. You can open it in a separate window and see the source: <a href="demo.svg?p=0,0,1,0.5,0,0.5,1,1&amp;animate=1">demo.svg</a>.</li>
<li>In CSS animation to describe the path and speed of animation. # CSS-animations</li>
</ul>
<p>CSS animations make it possible to do simple animations without JavaScript at all.</p>
<p>JavaScript can be used to control CSS animations and make them even better, with little code.</p>
<h2 id="css-transitions-css-transition">CSS transitions [#css-transition]</h2>
<p>The idea of CSS transitions is simple. We describe a property and how its changes should be animated. When the property changes, the browser paints the animation.</p>
<p>That is, all we need is to change the property, and the fluid transition will be done by the browser.</p>
<p>For instance, the CSS below animates changes of <code>background-color</code> for 3 seconds:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb186"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb186-1" title="1"><span class="fu">.animated</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb186-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">transition-property</span>: background-color<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb186-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition-duration</span>: <span class="dv">3</span><span class="dt">s</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb186-4" title="4">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now if an element has <code>.animated</code> class, any change of <code>background-color</code> is animated during 3 seconds.</p>
<p>Click the button below to animate the background:</p>
<p>```html run autorun height=60 <button id="color">Click me</button></p>
<style>
  #color {
    transition-property: background-color;
    transition-duration: 3s;
  }
</style>
<script>
  color.onclick = function() {
    this.style.backgroundColor = 'red';
  };
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>There are 4 properties to describe CSS transitions:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>transition-property</code></li>
<li><code>transition-duration</code></li>
<li><code>transition-timing-function</code></li>
<li><code>transition-delay</code></li>
</ul>
<p>We‚Äôll cover them in a moment, for now let‚Äôs note that the common <code>transition</code> property allows declaring them together in the order: <code>property duration timing-function delay</code>, as well as animating multiple properties at once.</p>
<p>For instance, this button animates both <code>color</code> and <code>font-size</code>:</p>
<p>```html run height=80 autorun no-beautify <button id="growing">Click me</button></p>
<style>
#growing {
*!*
  transition: font-size 3s, color 2s;
*/!*
}
</style>
<script>
growing.onclick = function() {
  this.style.fontSize = '36px';
  this.style.color = 'red';
};
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>Now, let‚Äôs cover animation properties one by one.</p>
<h2 id="transition-property">transition-property</h2>
<p>In <code>transition-property</code>, we write a list of properties to animate, for instance: <code>left</code>, <code>margin-left</code>, <code>height</code>, <code>color</code>. Or we could write <code>all</code>, which means ‚Äúanimate all properties‚Äù.</p>
<p>Do note that, there are properties which can not be animated. However, <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_animated_properties">most of the generally used properties are animatable</a>.</p>
<h2 id="transition-duration">transition-duration</h2>
<p>In <code>transition-duration</code> we can specify how long the animation should take. The time should be in <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-values/#time">CSS time format</a>: in seconds <code>s</code> or milliseconds <code>ms</code>.</p>
<h2 id="transition-delay">transition-delay</h2>
<p>In <code>transition-delay</code> we can specify the delay <em>before</em> the animation. For instance, if <code>transition-delay</code> is <code>1s</code> and <code>transition-duration</code> is <code>2s</code>, then the animation starts 1 second after the property change and the total duration will be 2 seconds.</p>
<p>Negative values are also possible. Then the animation is shown immediately, but the starting point of the animation will be after given value (time). For example, if <code>transition-delay</code> is <code>-1s</code> and <code>transition-duration</code> is <code>2s</code>, then animation starts from the halfway point and total duration will be 1 second.</p>
<p>Here the animation shifts numbers from <code>0</code> to <code>9</code> using CSS <code>translate</code> property:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúdigits‚Äù]</p>
<p>The <code>transform</code> property is animated like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb187"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb187-1" title="1"><span class="pp">#stripe</span><span class="fu">.animate</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb187-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">transform</span>: <span class="fu">translate(</span><span class="dv">-90</span><span class="dt">%</span><span class="fu">)</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb187-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition-property</span>: transform<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb187-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">transition-duration</span>: <span class="dv">9</span><span class="dt">s</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb187-5" title="5">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>In the example above JavaScript adds the class <code>.animate</code> to the element ‚Äì and the animation starts:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb188"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb188-1" title="1"><span class="va">stripe</span>.<span class="va">classList</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(<span class="st">&#39;animate&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>We could also start it from somewhere in the middle of the transition, from an exact number, e.g.¬†corresponding to the current second, using a negative <code>transition-delay</code>.</p>
<p>Here if you click the digit ‚Äì it starts the animation from the current second:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúdigits-negative-delay‚Äù]</p>
<p>JavaScript does it with an extra line:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb189"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-1" title="1"><span class="va">stripe</span>.<span class="at">onclick</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> sec <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Date</span>().<span class="at">getSeconds</span>() <span class="op">%</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-3" title="3"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-4" title="4">  <span class="co">// for instance, -3s here starts the animation from the 3rd second</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-5" title="5">  <span class="va">stripe</span>.<span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">transitionDelay</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&#39;-&#39;</span> <span class="op">+</span> sec <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;s&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-6" title="6"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-7" title="7"><span class="ss">  stripe.classList.add</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">&#39;animate&#39;</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb189-8" title="8"><span class="ss">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="transition-timing-function">transition-timing-function</h2>
<p>The timing function describes how the animation process is distributed along its timeline. Will it start slowly and then go fast, or vice versa.</p>
<p>It appears to be the most complicated property at first. But it becomes very simple if we devote a bit time to it.</p>
<p>That property accepts two kinds of values: a Bezier curve or steps. Let‚Äôs start with the curve, as it‚Äôs used more often.</p>
<h3 id="bezier-curve">Bezier curve</h3>
<p>The timing function can be set as a <a href="/bezier-curve">Bezier curve</a> with 4 control points that satisfy the conditions:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>First control point: <code>(0,0)</code>.</li>
<li>Last control point: <code>(1,1)</code>.</li>
<li>For intermediate points, the values of <code>x</code> must be in the interval <code>0..1</code>, <code>y</code> can be anything.</li>
</ol>
<p>The syntax for a Bezier curve in CSS: <code>cubic-bezier(x2, y2, x3, y3)</code>. Here we need to specify only 2nd and 3rd control points, because the 1st one is fixed to <code>(0,0)</code> and the 4th one is <code>(1,1)</code>.</p>
<p>The timing function describes how fast the animation process goes.</p>
<ul>
<li>The <code>x</code> axis is the time: <code>0</code> ‚Äì the start, <code>1</code> ‚Äì the end of <code>transition-duration</code>.</li>
<li>The <code>y</code> axis specifies the completion of the process: <code>0</code> ‚Äì the starting value of the property, <code>1</code> ‚Äì the final value.</li>
</ul>
<p>The simplest variant is when the animation goes uniformly, with the same linear speed. That can be specified by the curve <code>cubic-bezier(0, 0, 1, 1)</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs how that curve looks:</p>
<p><img src="bezier-linear.svg" /></p>
<p>‚Ä¶As we can see, it‚Äôs just a straight line. As the time (<code>x</code>) passes, the completion (<code>y</code>) of the animation steadily goes from <code>0</code> to <code>1</code>.</p>
<p>The train in the example below goes from left to right with the permanent speed (click it):</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äútrain-linear‚Äù]</p>
<p>The CSS <code>transition</code> is based on that curve:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb190"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb190-1" title="1"><span class="fu">.train</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb190-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">left</span>: <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb190-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition</span>: <span class="dv">left</span> <span class="dv">5</span><span class="dt">s</span> <span class="fu">cubic-bezier(</span><span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="fu">)</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb190-4" title="4">  <span class="co">/* JavaScript sets left to 450px */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb190-5" title="5">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶And how can we show a train slowing down?</p>
<p>We can use another Bezier curve: <code>cubic-bezier(0.0, 0.5, 0.5 ,1.0)</code>.</p>
<p>The graph:</p>
<p><img src="train-curve.svg" /></p>
<p>As we can see, the process starts fast: the curve soars up high, and then slower and slower.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the timing function in action (click the train):</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äútrain‚Äù]</p>
<p>CSS:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb191"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb191-1" title="1"><span class="fu">.train</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb191-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">left</span>: <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb191-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition</span>: <span class="dv">left</span> <span class="dv">5</span><span class="dt">s</span> <span class="fu">cubic-bezier(</span><span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">.5</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">.5</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="fu">)</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb191-4" title="4">  <span class="co">/* JavaScript sets left to 450px */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb191-5" title="5">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>There are several built-in curves: <code>linear</code>, <code>ease</code>, <code>ease-in</code>, <code>ease-out</code> and <code>ease-in-out</code>.</p>
<p>The <code>linear</code> is a shorthand for <code>cubic-bezier(0, 0, 1, 1)</code> ‚Äì a straight line, which we described above.</p>
<p>Other names are shorthands for the following <code>cubic-bezier</code>:</p>
<table style="width:100%;">
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 30%" />
<col style="width: 21%" />
<col style="width: 22%" />
<col style="width: 25%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th><code>ease</code><sup>*</sup></th>
<th><code>ease-in</code></th>
<th><code>ease-out</code></th>
<th><code>ease-in-out</code></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>(0.25, 0.1, 0.25, 1.0)</code></td>
<td><code>(0.42, 0, 1.0, 1.0)</code></td>
<td><code>(0, 0, 0.58, 1.0)</code></td>
<td><code>(0.42, 0, 0.58, 1.0)</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><img src="ease.svg" alt="ease, figure" /></td>
<td><img src="ease-in.svg" alt="ease-in, figure" /></td>
<td><img src="ease-out.svg" alt="ease-out, figure" /></td>
<td><img src="ease-in-out.svg" alt="ease-in-out, figure" /></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><code>*</code> ‚Äì by default, if there‚Äôs no timing function, <code>ease</code> is used.</p>
<p>So we could use <code>ease-out</code> for our slowing down train:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb192"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb192-1" title="1"><span class="fu">.train</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb192-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">left</span>: <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb192-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition</span>: <span class="dv">left</span> <span class="dv">5</span><span class="dt">s</span> <span class="dv">ease-out</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb192-4" title="4">  <span class="co">/* transition: left 5s cubic-bezier(0, .5, .5, 1); */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb192-5" title="5">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>But it looks a bit differently.</p>
<p><strong>A Bezier curve can make the animation exceed its range.</strong></p>
<p>The control points on the curve can have any <code>y</code> coordinates: even negative or huge ones. Then the Bezier curve would also extend very low or high, making the animation go beyond its normal range.</p>
<p>In the example below the animation code is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb193"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb193-1" title="1"><span class="fu">.train</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb193-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">left</span>: <span class="dv">100</span><span class="dt">px</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb193-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition</span>: <span class="dv">left</span> <span class="dv">5</span><span class="dt">s</span> <span class="fu">cubic-bezier(</span><span class="dv">.5</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">-1</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">.5</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="fu">)</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb193-4" title="4">  <span class="co">/* JavaScript sets left to 400px */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb193-5" title="5">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>The property <code>left</code> should animate from <code>100px</code> to <code>400px</code>.</p>
<p>But if you click the train, you‚Äôll see that:</p>
<ul>
<li>First, the train goes <em>back</em>: <code>left</code> becomes less than <code>100px</code>.</li>
<li>Then it goes forward, a little bit farther than <code>400px</code>.</li>
<li>And then back again ‚Äì to <code>400px</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äútrain-over‚Äù]</p>
<p>Why it happens is pretty obvious if we look at the graph of the given Bezier curve:</p>
<p><img src="bezier-train-over.svg" /></p>
<p>We moved the <code>y</code> coordinate of the 2nd point below zero, and for the 3rd point we made it over <code>1</code>, so the curve goes out of the ‚Äúregular‚Äù quadrant. The <code>y</code> is out of the ‚Äústandard‚Äù range <code>0..1</code>.</p>
<p>As we know, <code>y</code> measures ‚Äúthe completion of the animation process‚Äù. The value <code>y = 0</code> corresponds to the starting property value and <code>y = 1</code> ‚Äì the ending value. So values <code>y&lt;0</code> move the property beyond the starting <code>left</code> and <code>y&gt;1</code> ‚Äì past the final <code>left</code>.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs a ‚Äúsoft‚Äù variant for sure. If we put <code>y</code> values like <code>-99</code> and <code>99</code> then the train would jump out of the range much more.</p>
<p>But how do we make a Bezier curve for a specific task? There are many tools. For instance, we can do it on the site <a href="http://cubic-bezier.com/" class="uri">http://cubic-bezier.com/</a>.</p>
<h3 id="steps">Steps</h3>
<p>The timing function <code>steps(number of steps[, start/end])</code> allows splitting an animation into steps.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs see that in an example with digits.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs a list of digits, without any animations, just as a source:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äústep-list‚Äù]</p>
<p>We‚Äôll make the digits appear in a discrete way by making the part of the list outside of the red ‚Äúwindow‚Äù invisible and shifting the list to the left with each step.</p>
<p>There will be 9 steps, a step-move for each digit:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb194"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb194-1" title="1"><span class="pp">#stripe</span><span class="fu">.animate</span>  {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb194-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">transform</span>: <span class="fu">translate(</span><span class="dv">-90</span><span class="dt">%</span><span class="fu">)</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb194-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">transition</span>: transform <span class="dv">9</span><span class="dt">s</span> *<span class="at">!</span>*<span class="fu">steps(</span><span class="dv">9</span><span class="op">,</span> start<span class="fu">)</span>*/<span class="at">!</span>*<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb194-4" title="4">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>In action:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äústep‚Äù]</p>
<p>The first argument of <code>steps(9, start)</code> is the number of steps. The transform will be split into 9 parts (10% each). The time interval is automatically divided into 9 parts as well, so <code>transition: 9s</code> gives us 9 seconds for the whole animation ‚Äì 1 second per digit.</p>
<p>The second argument is one of two words: <code>start</code> or <code>end</code>.</p>
<p>The <code>start</code> means that in the beginning of animation we need to make the first step immediately.</p>
<p>We can observe that during the animation: when we click on the digit it changes to <code>1</code> (the first step) immediately, and then changes in the beginning of the next second.</p>
<p>The process is progressing like this:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>0s</code> ‚Äì <code>-10%</code> (first change in the beginning of the 1st second, immediately)</li>
<li><code>1s</code> ‚Äì <code>-20%</code></li>
<li>‚Ä¶</li>
<li><code>8s</code> ‚Äì <code>-80%</code></li>
<li>(the last second shows the final value).</li>
</ul>
<p>The alternative value <code>end</code> would mean that the change should be applied not in the beginning, but at the end of each second.</p>
<p>So the process would go like this:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>0s</code> ‚Äì <code>0</code></li>
<li><code>1s</code> ‚Äì <code>-10%</code> (first change at the end of the 1st second)</li>
<li><code>2s</code> ‚Äì <code>-20%</code></li>
<li>‚Ä¶</li>
<li><code>9s</code> ‚Äì <code>-90%</code></li>
</ul>
<p>Here‚Äôs <code>steps(9, end)</code> in action (note the pause between the first digit change):</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äústep-end‚Äù]</p>
<p>There are also shorthand values:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>step-start</code> ‚Äì is the same as <code>steps(1, start)</code>. That is, the animation starts immediately and takes 1 step. So it starts and finishes immediately, as if there were no animation.</li>
<li><code>step-end</code> ‚Äì the same as <code>steps(1, end)</code>: make the animation in a single step at the end of <code>transition-duration</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>These values are rarely used, because that‚Äôs not really animation, but rather a single-step change.</p>
<h2 id="event-transitionend">Event transitionend</h2>
<p>When the CSS animation finishes the <code>transitionend</code> event triggers.</p>
<p>It is widely used to do an action after the animation is done. Also we can join animations.</p>
<p>For instance, the ship in the example below starts to sail there and back when clicked, each time farther and farther to the right:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúboat‚Äù height=300 edit link]</p>
<p>The animation is initiated by the function <code>go</code> that re-runs each time the transition finishes, and flips the direction:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb195"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-1" title="1"><span class="va">boat</span>.<span class="at">onclick</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-2" title="2">  <span class="co">//...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">let</span> times <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">go</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-6" title="6">    <span class="cf">if</span> (times <span class="op">%</span> <span class="dv">2</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-7" title="7">      <span class="co">// sail to the right</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-8" title="8">      <span class="va">boat</span>.<span class="va">classList</span>.<span class="at">remove</span>(<span class="st">&#39;back&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-9" title="9">      <span class="va">boat</span>.<span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">marginLeft</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">100</span> <span class="op">*</span> times <span class="op">+</span> <span class="dv">200</span> <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;px&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-10" title="10">    <span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-11" title="11">      <span class="co">// sail to the left</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-12" title="12">      <span class="va">boat</span>.<span class="va">classList</span>.<span class="at">add</span>(<span class="st">&#39;back&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-13" title="13">      <span class="va">boat</span>.<span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">marginLeft</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">100</span> <span class="op">*</span> times <span class="op">-</span> <span class="dv">200</span> <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;px&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-14" title="14">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-15" title="15"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-16" title="16">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-17" title="17"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-18" title="18">  <span class="at">go</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-19" title="19"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-20" title="20">  <span class="va">boat</span>.<span class="at">addEventListener</span>(<span class="st">&#39;transitionend&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-21" title="21">    times<span class="op">++;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-22" title="22">    <span class="at">go</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-23" title="23">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb195-24" title="24"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The event object for <code>transitionend</code> has a few specific properties:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>event.propertyName</code></dt>
<dd>The property that has finished animating. Can be good if we animate multiple properties simultaneously.
</dd>
<dt><code>event.elapsedTime</code></dt>
<dd>The time (in seconds) that the animation took, without <code>transition-delay</code>.
</dd>
</dl>
<h2 id="keyframes">Keyframes</h2>
<p>We can join multiple simple animations together using the <code>@keyframes</code> CSS rule.</p>
<p>It specifies the ‚Äúname‚Äù of the animation and rules - what, when and where to animate. Then using the <code>animation</code> property, we can attach the animation to the element and specify additional parameters for it.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example with explanations:</p>
```html run height=60 autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù no-beautify
<div class="progress">

</div>
<style>
*!*
  @keyframes go-left-right {        /* give it a name: "go-left-right" */
    from { left: 0px; }             /* animate from left: 0px */
    to { left: calc(100% - 50px); } /* animate to left: 100%-50px */
  }
*/!*

  .progress {
*!*
    animation: go-left-right 3s infinite alternate;
    /* apply the animation "go-left-right" to the element
       duration 3 seconds
       number of times: infinite
       alternate direction every time
    */
*/!*

    position: relative;
    border: 2px solid green;
    width: 50px;
    height: 20px;
    background: lime;
  }
</style>
<p>```</p>
<p>There are many articles about <code>@keyframes</code> and a <a href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-animations/">detailed specification</a>.</p>
<p>You probably won‚Äôt need <code>@keyframes</code> often, unless everything is in constant motion on your sites.</p>
<h2 id="summary-20">Summary</h2>
<p>CSS animations allow smoothly (or not) animated changes of one or multiple CSS properties.</p>
<p>They are good for most animation tasks. We‚Äôre also able to use JavaScript for animations, the next chapter is devoted to that.</p>
<p>Limitations of CSS animations compared to JavaScript animations:</p>
<p><code>compare plus="CSS animations" minus="JavaScript animations" + Simple things done simply. + Fast and lightweight for CPU. - JavaScript animations are flexible. They can implement any animation logic, like an "explosion" of an element. - Not just property changes. We can create new elements in JavaScript as part of the animation.</code></p>
<p>The majority of animations can be implemented using CSS as described in this chapter. And the <code>transitionend</code> event allows JavaScript to be run after the animation, so it integrates fine with the code.</p>
<p>But in the next chapter we‚Äôll do some JavaScript animations to cover more complex cases. # JavaScript animations</p>
<p>JavaScript animations can handle things that CSS can‚Äôt.</p>
<p>For instance, moving along a complex path, with a timing function different from Bezier curves, or an animation on a canvas.</p>
<h2 id="using-setinterval">Using setInterval</h2>
<p>An animation can be implemented as a sequence of frames ‚Äì usually small changes to HTML/CSS properties.</p>
<p>For instance, changing <code>style.left</code> from <code>0px</code> to <code>100px</code> moves the element. And if we increase it in <code>setInterval</code>, changing by <code>2px</code> with a tiny delay, like 50 times per second, then it looks smooth. That‚Äôs the same principle as in the cinema: 24 frames per second is enough to make it look smooth.</p>
<p>The pseudo-code can look like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb196"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb196-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> timer <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">setInterval</span>(<span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb196-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> (animation complete) <span class="at">clearInterval</span>(timer)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb196-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">else</span> increase <span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">left</span> by 2px</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb196-4" title="4"><span class="op">},</span> <span class="dv">20</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// change by 2px every 20ms, about 50 frames per second</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>More complete example of the animation:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb197"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> start <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">Date</span>.<span class="at">now</span>()<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// remember start time</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> timer <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">setInterval</span>(<span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-4" title="4">  <span class="co">// how much time passed from the start?</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">let</span> timePassed <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">Date</span>.<span class="at">now</span>() <span class="op">-</span> start<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-7" title="7">  <span class="cf">if</span> (timePassed <span class="op">&gt;=</span> <span class="dv">2000</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-8" title="8">    <span class="at">clearInterval</span>(timer)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// finish the animation after 2 seconds</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-9" title="9">    <span class="cf">return</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-10" title="10">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-11" title="11"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-12" title="12">  <span class="co">// draw the animation at the moment timePassed</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-13" title="13">  <span class="at">draw</span>(timePassed)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-15" title="15"><span class="op">},</span> <span class="dv">20</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-16" title="16"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-17" title="17"><span class="co">// as timePassed goes from 0 to 2000</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-18" title="18"><span class="co">// left gets values from 0px to 400px</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-19" title="19"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">draw</span>(timePassed) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-20" title="20">  <span class="va">train</span>.<span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">left</span> <span class="op">=</span> timePassed / <span class="dv">5</span> <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;px&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb197-21" title="21"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Click for the demo:</p>
<p>[codetabs height=200 src=‚Äúmove‚Äù]</p>
<h2 id="using-requestanimationframe">Using requestAnimationFrame</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs imagine we have several animations running simultaneously.</p>
<p>If we run them separately, then even though each one has <code>setInterval(..., 20)</code>, then the browser would have to repaint much more often than every <code>20ms</code>.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because they have different starting time, so ‚Äúevery 20ms‚Äù differs between different animations. The intervals are not aligned. So we‚Äôll have several independent runs within <code>20ms</code>.</p>
<p>In other words, this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb198"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb198-1" title="1"><span class="at">setInterval</span>(<span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb198-2" title="2">  <span class="at">animate1</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb198-3" title="3">  <span class="at">animate2</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb198-4" title="4">  <span class="at">animate3</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb198-5" title="5"><span class="op">},</span> <span class="dv">20</span>)</a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶Is lighter than three independent calls:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb199"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb199-1" title="1"><span class="at">setInterval</span>(animate1<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">20</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// independent animations</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb199-2" title="2"><span class="at">setInterval</span>(animate2<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">20</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// in different places of the script</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb199-3" title="3"><span class="at">setInterval</span>(animate3<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">20</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>These several independent redraws should be grouped together, to make the redraw easier for the browser and hence load less CPU load and look smoother.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs one more thing to keep in mind. Sometimes CPU is overloaded, or there are other reasons to redraw less often (like when the browser tab is hidden), so we really shouldn‚Äôt run it every <code>20ms</code>.</p>
<p>But how do we know about that in JavaScript? There‚Äôs a specification <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/animation-timing/">Animation timing</a> that provides the function <code>requestAnimationFrame</code>. It addresses all these issues and even more.</p>
<p>The syntax:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb200"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb200-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> requestId <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">requestAnimationFrame</span>(callback)</a></code></pre></div>
<p>That schedules the <code>callback</code> function to run in the closest time when the browser wants to do animation.</p>
<p>If we do changes in elements in <code>callback</code> then they will be grouped together with other <code>requestAnimationFrame</code> callbacks and with CSS animations. So there will be one geometry recalculation and repaint instead of many.</p>
<p>The returned value <code>requestId</code> can be used to cancel the call:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb201"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb201-1" title="1"><span class="co">// cancel the scheduled execution of callback</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb201-2" title="2"><span class="at">cancelAnimationFrame</span>(requestId)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code>callback</code> gets one argument ‚Äì the time passed from the beginning of the page load in microseconds. This time can also be obtained by calling <a href="mdn:api/Performance/now">performance.now()</a>.</p>
<p>Usually <code>callback</code> runs very soon, unless the CPU is overloaded or the laptop battery is almost discharged, or there‚Äôs another reason.</p>
<p>The code below shows the time between first 10 runs for <code>requestAnimationFrame</code>. Usually it‚Äôs 10-20ms:</p>
```html run height=40 refresh
<script>
  let prev = performance.now();
  let times = 0;

  requestAnimationFrame(function measure(time) {
    document.body.insertAdjacentHTML("beforeEnd", Math.floor(time - prev) + " ");
    prev = time;

    if (times++ < 10) requestAnimationFrame(measure);
  })
</script>
<p>```</p>
<h2 id="structured-animation">Structured animation</h2>
<p>Now we can make a more universal animation function based on <code>requestAnimationFrame</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb202"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">animate</span>(<span class="op">{</span>timing<span class="op">,</span> draw<span class="op">,</span> duration<span class="op">}</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">let</span> start <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">performance</span>.<span class="at">now</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-5" title="5">  <span class="at">requestAnimationFrame</span>(<span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">animate</span>(time) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-6" title="6">    <span class="co">// timeFraction goes from 0 to 1</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-7" title="7">    <span class="kw">let</span> timeFraction <span class="op">=</span> (time <span class="op">-</span> start) / duration<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-8" title="8">    <span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&gt;</span> <span class="dv">1</span>) timeFraction <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-10" title="10">    <span class="co">// calculate the current animation state</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-11" title="11">    <span class="kw">let</span> progress <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(timeFraction)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-12" title="12"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-13" title="13">    <span class="at">draw</span>(progress)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// draw it</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-15" title="15">    <span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">1</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-16" title="16">      <span class="at">requestAnimationFrame</span>(animate)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-17" title="17">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-18" title="18"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-19" title="19">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb202-20" title="20"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Function <code>animate</code> accepts 3 parameters that essentially describes the animation:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>duration</code></dt>
<dd>Total time of animation. Like, <code>1000</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>timing(timeFraction)</code></dt>
<dd><p>Timing function, like CSS-property <code>transition-timing-function</code> that gets the fraction of time that passed (<code>0</code> at start, <code>1</code> at the end) and returns the animation completion (like <code>y</code> on the Bezier curve).</p>
<p>For instance, a linear function means that the animation goes on uniformly with the same speed:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb203"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb203-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">linear</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb203-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> timeFraction<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb203-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>It‚Äôs graph: <img src="linear.svg" /></p>
<p>That‚Äôs just like <code>transition-timing-function: linear</code>. There are more interesting variants shown below.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>draw(progress)</code></dt>
<dd><p>The function that takes the animation completion state and draws it. The value <code>progress=0</code> denotes the beginning animation state, and <code>progress=1</code> ‚Äì the end state.</p>
<p>This is that function that actually draws out the animation.</p>
<p>It can move the element:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb204"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb204-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">draw</span>(progress) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb204-2" title="2">  <span class="va">train</span>.<span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">left</span> <span class="op">=</span> progress <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;px&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb204-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶Or do anything else, we can animate anything, in any way.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Let‚Äôs animate the element <code>width</code> from <code>0</code> to <code>100%</code> using our function.</p>
<p>Click on the element for the demo:</p>
<p>[codetabs height=60 src=‚Äúwidth‚Äù]</p>
<p>The code for it:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb205"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-1" title="1"><span class="at">animate</span>(<span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">duration</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">1000</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-3" title="3">  <span class="at">timing</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-4" title="4">    <span class="cf">return</span> timeFraction<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-5" title="5">  <span class="op">},</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-6" title="6">  <span class="at">draw</span>(progress) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-7" title="7">    <span class="va">elem</span>.<span class="va">style</span>.<span class="at">width</span> <span class="op">=</span> progress <span class="op">*</span> <span class="dv">100</span> <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;%&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-8" title="8">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb205-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Unlike CSS animation, we can make any timing function and any drawing function here. The timing function is not limited by Bezier curves. And <code>draw</code> can go beyond properties, create new elements for like fireworks animation or something.</p>
<h2 id="timing-functions">Timing functions</h2>
<p>We saw the simplest, linear timing function above.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs see more of them. We‚Äôll try movement animations with different timing functions to see how they work.</p>
<h3 id="power-of-n">Power of n</h3>
<p>If we want to speed up the animation, we can use <code>progress</code> in the power <code>n</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, a parabolic curve:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb206"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb206-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">quad</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb206-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">pow</span>(timeFraction<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">2</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb206-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The graph:</p>
<p><img src="quad.svg" /></p>
<p>See in action (click to activate):</p>
<p>[iframe height=40 src=‚Äúquad‚Äù link]</p>
<p>‚Ä¶Or the cubic curve or even greater <code>n</code>. Increasing the power makes it speed up faster.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the graph for <code>progress</code> in the power <code>5</code>:</p>
<p><img src="quint.svg" /></p>
<p>In action:</p>
<p>[iframe height=40 src=‚Äúquint‚Äù link]</p>
<h3 id="the-arc">The arc</h3>
<p>Function:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb207"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb207-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">circ</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb207-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">sin</span>(<span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">acos</span>(timeFraction))<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb207-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The graph:</p>
<p><img src="circ.svg" /></p>
<p>[iframe height=40 src=‚Äúcirc‚Äù link]</p>
<h3 id="back-bow-shooting">Back: bow shooting</h3>
<p>This function does the ‚Äúbow shooting‚Äù. First we ‚Äúpull the bowstring‚Äù, and then ‚Äúshoot‚Äù.</p>
<p>Unlike previous functions, it depends on an additional parameter <code>x</code>, the ‚Äúelasticity coefficient‚Äù. The distance of ‚Äúbowstring pulling‚Äù is defined by it.</p>
<p>The code:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb208"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb208-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">back</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb208-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">pow</span>(timeFraction<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">2</span>) <span class="op">*</span> ((x <span class="op">+</span> <span class="dv">1</span>) <span class="op">*</span> timeFraction <span class="op">-</span> x)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb208-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><strong>The graph for <code>x = 1.5</code>:</strong></p>
<p><img src="back.svg" /></p>
<p>For animation we use it with a specific value of <code>x</code>. Example for <code>x = 1.5</code>:</p>
<p>[iframe height=40 src=‚Äúback‚Äù link]</p>
<h3 id="bounce">Bounce</h3>
<p>Imagine we are dropping a ball. It falls down, then bounces back a few times and stops.</p>
<p>The <code>bounce</code> function does the same, but in the reverse order: ‚Äúbouncing‚Äù starts immediately. It uses few special coefficients for that:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb209"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">bounce</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> a <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span> b <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">,</span> result<span class="op">;</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span> a <span class="op">+=</span> b<span class="op">,</span> b /<span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-3" title="3">    <span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&gt;=</span> (<span class="dv">7</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="dv">4</span> <span class="op">*</span> a) / <span class="dv">11</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-4" title="4">      <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="op">-</span><span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">pow</span>((<span class="dv">11</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="dv">6</span> <span class="op">*</span> a <span class="op">-</span> <span class="dv">11</span> <span class="op">*</span> timeFraction) / <span class="dv">4</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">2</span>) <span class="op">+</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">pow</span>(b<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">2</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-5" title="5">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-6" title="6">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb209-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>In action:</p>
<p>[iframe height=40 src=‚Äúbounce‚Äù link]</p>
<h3 id="elastic-animation">Elastic animation</h3>
<p>One more ‚Äúelastic‚Äù function that accepts an additional parameter <code>x</code> for the ‚Äúinitial range‚Äù.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb210"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb210-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">elastic</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb210-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">10</span> <span class="op">*</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">-</span> <span class="dv">1</span>)) <span class="op">*</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">cos</span>(<span class="dv">20</span> <span class="op">*</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">PI</span> <span class="op">*</span> x / <span class="dv">3</span> <span class="op">*</span> timeFraction)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb210-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><strong>The graph for <code>x=1.5</code>:</strong> <img src="elastic.svg" /></p>
<p>In action for <code>x=1.5</code>:</p>
