<h2 id="reversal-ease">Reversal: ease*</h2>
<p>So we have a collection of timing functions. Their direct application is called ‚ÄúeaseIn‚Äù.</p>
<p>Sometimes we need to show the animation in the reverse order. That‚Äôs done with the ‚ÄúeaseOut‚Äù transform.</p>
<h3 id="easeout">easeOut</h3>
<p>In the ‚ÄúeaseOut‚Äù mode the <code>timing</code> function is put into a wrapper <code>timingEaseOut</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb211"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb211-1" title="1"><span class="at">timingEaseOut</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(<span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> timeFraction)</a></code></pre></div>
<p>In other words, we have a ‚Äútransform‚Äù function <code>makeEaseOut</code> that takes a ‚Äúregular‚Äù timing function and returns the wrapper around it:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb212"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb212-1" title="1"><span class="co">// accepts a timing function, returns the transformed variant</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb212-2" title="2"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">makeEaseOut</span>(timing) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb212-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb212-4" title="4">    <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(<span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> timeFraction)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb212-5" title="5">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb212-6" title="6"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>For instance, we can take the <code>bounce</code> function described above and apply it:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb213"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb213-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> bounceEaseOut <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">makeEaseOut</span>(bounce)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Then the bounce will be not in the beginning, but at the end of the animation. Looks even better:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúbounce-easeout‚Äù]</p>
<p>Here we can see how the transform changes the behavior of the function:</p>
<p><img src="bounce-inout.svg" /></p>
<p>If there‚Äôs an animation effect in the beginning, like bouncing ‚Äì it will be shown at the end.</p>
<p>In the graph above the <span style="color:#EE6B47">regular bounce</span> has the red color, and the <span style="color:#62C0DC">easeOut bounce</span> is blue.</p>
<ul>
<li>Regular bounce ‚Äì the object bounces at the bottom, then at the end sharply jumps to the top.</li>
<li>After <code>easeOut</code> ‚Äì it first jumps to the top, then bounces there.</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="easeinout">easeInOut</h3>
<p>We also can show the effect both in the beginning and the end of the animation. The transform is called ‚ÄúeaseInOut‚Äù.</p>
<p>Given the timing function, we calculate the animation state like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb214"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb214-1" title="1"><span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&lt;=</span> <span class="fl">0.5</span>) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// first half of the animation</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb214-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(<span class="dv">2</span> <span class="op">*</span> timeFraction) / <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb214-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// second half of the animation</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb214-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">return</span> (<span class="dv">2</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(<span class="dv">2</span> <span class="op">*</span> (<span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> timeFraction))) / <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb214-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The wrapper code:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb215"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">makeEaseInOut</span>(timing) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(timeFraction) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-3" title="3">    <span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="fl">.5</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-4" title="4">      <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(<span class="dv">2</span> <span class="op">*</span> timeFraction) / <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-5" title="5">    <span class="cf">else</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-6" title="6">      <span class="cf">return</span> (<span class="dv">2</span> <span class="op">-</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(<span class="dv">2</span> <span class="op">*</span> (<span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">-</span> timeFraction))) / <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-7" title="7">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb215-10" title="10">bounceEaseInOut <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">makeEaseInOut</span>(bounce)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>In action, <code>bounceEaseInOut</code>:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äúbounce-easeinout‚Äù]</p>
<p>The ‚ÄúeaseInOut‚Äù transform joins two graphs into one: <code>easeIn</code> (regular) for the first half of the animation and <code>easeOut</code> (reversed) ‚Äì for the second part.</p>
<p>The effect is clearly seen if we compare the graphs of <code>easeIn</code>, <code>easeOut</code> and <code>easeInOut</code> of the <code>circ</code> timing function:</p>
<p><img src="circ-ease.svg" /></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="color:#EE6B47">Red</span> is the regular variant of <code>circ</code> (<code>easeIn</code>).</li>
<li><span style="color:#8DB173">Green</span> ‚Äì <code>easeOut</code>.</li>
<li><span style="color:#62C0DC">Blue</span> ‚Äì <code>easeInOut</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>As we can see, the graph of the first half of the animation is the scaled down <code>easeIn</code>, and the second half is the scaled down <code>easeOut</code>. As a result, the animation starts and finishes with the same effect.</p>
<h2 id="more-interesting-draw">More interesting ‚Äúdraw‚Äù</h2>
<p>Instead of moving the element we can do something else. All we need is to write the proper <code>draw</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the animated ‚Äúbouncing‚Äù text typing:</p>
<p>[codetabs src=‚Äútext‚Äù]</p>
<h2 id="summary-21">Summary</h2>
<p>For animations that CSS can‚Äôt handle well, or those that need tight control, JavaScript can help. JavaScript animations should be implemented via <code>requestAnimationFrame</code>. That built-in method allows to setup a callback function to run when the browser will be preparing a repaint. Usually that‚Äôs very soon, but the exact time depends on the browser.</p>
<p>When a page is in the background, there are no repaints at all, so the callback won‚Äôt run: the animation will be suspended and won‚Äôt consume resources. That‚Äôs great.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the helper <code>animate</code> function to setup most animations:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb216"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">animate</span>(<span class="op">{</span>timing<span class="op">,</span> draw<span class="op">,</span> duration<span class="op">}</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">let</span> start <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">performance</span>.<span class="at">now</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-5" title="5">  <span class="at">requestAnimationFrame</span>(<span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">animate</span>(time) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-6" title="6">    <span class="co">// timeFraction goes from 0 to 1</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-7" title="7">    <span class="kw">let</span> timeFraction <span class="op">=</span> (time <span class="op">-</span> start) / duration<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-8" title="8">    <span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&gt;</span> <span class="dv">1</span>) timeFraction <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-10" title="10">    <span class="co">// calculate the current animation state</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-11" title="11">    <span class="kw">let</span> progress <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">timing</span>(timeFraction)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-12" title="12"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-13" title="13">    <span class="at">draw</span>(progress)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// draw it</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-15" title="15">    <span class="cf">if</span> (timeFraction <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">1</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-16" title="16">      <span class="at">requestAnimationFrame</span>(animate)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-17" title="17">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-18" title="18"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-19" title="19">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb216-20" title="20"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Options:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>duration</code> ‚Äì the total animation time in ms.</li>
<li><code>timing</code> ‚Äì the function to calculate animation progress. Gets a time fraction from 0 to 1, returns the animation progress, usually from 0 to 1.</li>
<li><code>draw</code> ‚Äì the function to draw the animation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Surely we could improve it, add more bells and whistles, but JavaScript animations are not applied on a daily basis. They are used to do something interesting and non-standard. So you‚Äôd want to add the features that you need when you need them.</p>
<p>JavaScript animations can use any timing function. We covered a lot of examples and transformations to make them even more versatile. Unlike CSS, we are not limited to Bezier curves here.</p>
<p>The same is about <code>draw</code>: we can animate anything, not just CSS properties. # Logical operators</p>
<p>There are four logical operators in JavaScript: <code>||</code> (OR), <code>&amp;&amp;</code> (AND), <code>!</code> (NOT), <code>??</code> (Nullish Coalescing). Here we cover the first three, the <code>??</code> operator is in the next article.</p>
<p>Although they are called ‚Äúlogical‚Äù, they can be applied to values of any type, not only boolean. Their result can also be of any type.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs see the details.</p>
<h2 id="or">|| (OR)</h2>
<p>The ‚ÄúOR‚Äù operator is represented with two vertical line symbols:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb217"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb217-1" title="1">result <span class="op">=</span> a <span class="op">||</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>In classical programming, the logical OR is meant to manipulate boolean values only. If any of its arguments are <code>true</code>, it returns <code>true</code>, otherwise it returns <code>false</code>.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, the operator is a little bit trickier and more powerful. But first, let‚Äôs see what happens with boolean values.</p>
<p>There are four possible logical combinations:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( true || true );   // true alert( false || true );  // true alert( true || false );  // true alert( false || false ); // false</code></p>
<p>As we can see, the result is always <code>true</code> except for the case when both operands are <code>false</code>.</p>
<p>If an operand is not a boolean, it‚Äôs converted to a boolean for the evaluation.</p>
<p>For instance, the number <code>1</code> is treated as <code>true</code>, the number <code>0</code> as <code>false</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run if (1 || 0) { // works just like if( true || false )   alert( 'truthy!' ); }</code></p>
<p>Most of the time, OR <code>||</code> is used in an <code>if</code> statement to test if <em>any</em> of the given conditions is <code>true</code>.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>```js run let hour = 9;</p>
<p><em>!</em> if (hour &lt; 10 || hour &gt; 18) { <em>/!</em> alert( ‚ÄòThe office is closed.‚Äô ); } ```</p>
<p>We can pass more conditions:</p>
<p>```js run let hour = 12; let isWeekend = true;</p>
<p>if (hour &lt; 10 || hour &gt; 18 || isWeekend) { alert( ‚ÄòThe office is closed.‚Äô ); // it is the weekend } ```</p>
<h2 id="or-finds-the-first-truthy-value-or-finds-the-first-truthy-value">OR ‚Äú||‚Äù finds the first truthy value [#or-finds-the-first-truthy-value]</h2>
<p>The logic described above is somewhat classical. Now, let‚Äôs bring in the ‚Äúextra‚Äù features of JavaScript.</p>
<p>The extended algorithm works as follows.</p>
<p>Given multiple OR‚Äôed values:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb218"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb218-1" title="1">result <span class="op">=</span> value1 <span class="op">||</span> value2 <span class="op">||</span> value3<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The OR <code>||</code> operator does the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Evaluates operands from left to right.</li>
<li>For each operand, converts it to boolean. If the result is <code>true</code>, stops and returns the original value of that operand.</li>
<li>If all operands have been evaluated (i.e.¬†all were <code>false</code>), returns the last operand.</li>
</ul>
<p>A value is returned in its original form, without the conversion.</p>
<p>In other words, a chain of OR <code>||</code> returns the first truthy value or the last one if no truthy value is found.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run alert( 1 || 0 ); // 1 (1 is truthy)</p>
<p>alert( null || 1 ); // 1 (1 is the first truthy value) alert( null || 0 || 1 ); // 1 (the first truthy value)</p>
<p>alert( undefined || null || 0 ); // 0 (all falsy, returns the last value) ```</p>
<p>This leads to some interesting usage compared to a ‚Äúpure, classical, boolean-only OR‚Äù.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p><strong>Getting the first truthy value from a list of variables or expressions.</strong></p>
<p>For instance, we have <code>firstName</code>, <code>lastName</code> and <code>nickName</code> variables, all optional (i.e.¬†can be undefined or have falsy values).</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs use OR <code>||</code> to choose the one that has the data and show it (or <code>"Anonymous"</code> if nothing set):</p>
<p>```js run let firstName = "‚Äú; let lastName =‚Äù‚Äú; let nickName =‚ÄùSuperCoder";</p>
<p><em>!</em> alert( firstName || lastName || nickName || ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù); // SuperCoder <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>If all variables were falsy, <code>"Anonymous"</code> would show up.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Short-circuit evaluation.</strong></p>
<p>Another feature of OR <code>||</code> operator is the so-called ‚Äúshort-circuit‚Äù evaluation.</p>
<p>It means that <code>||</code> processes its arguments until the first truthy value is reached, and then the value is returned immediately, without even touching the other argument.</p>
<p>That importance of this feature becomes obvious if an operand isn‚Äôt just a value, but an expression with a side effect, such as a variable assignment or a function call.</p>
<p>In the example below, only the second message is printed:</p>
<p><code>js run no-beautify  *!*true*/!* || alert("not printed");  *!*false*/!* || alert("printed");</code></p>
<p>In the first line, the OR <code>||</code> operator stops the evaluation immediately upon seeing <code>true</code>, so the <code>alert</code> isn‚Äôt run.</p>
<p>Sometimes, people use this feature to execute commands only if the condition on the left part is falsy.</p></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="and">&amp;&amp; (AND)</h2>
<p>The AND operator is represented with two ampersands <code>&amp;&amp;</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb219"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb219-1" title="1">result <span class="op">=</span> a <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>In classical programming, AND returns <code>true</code> if both operands are truthy and <code>false</code> otherwise:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( true &amp;&amp; true );   // true alert( false &amp;&amp; true );  // false alert( true &amp;&amp; false );  // false alert( false &amp;&amp; false ); // false</code></p>
<p>An example with <code>if</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let hour = 12; let minute = 30;</p>
<p>if (hour == 12 &amp;&amp; minute == 30) { alert( ‚ÄòThe time is 12:30‚Äô ); } ```</p>
<p>Just as with OR, any value is allowed as an operand of AND:</p>
<p><code>js run if (1 &amp;&amp; 0) { // evaluated as true &amp;&amp; false   alert( "won't work, because the result is falsy" ); }</code></p>
<h2 id="and-finds-the-first-falsy-value">AND ‚Äú&amp;&amp;‚Äù finds the first falsy value</h2>
<p>Given multiple AND‚Äôed values:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb220"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb220-1" title="1">result <span class="op">=</span> value1 <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span> value2 <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span> value3<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The AND <code>&amp;&amp;</code> operator does the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Evaluates operands from left to right.</li>
<li>For each operand, converts it to a boolean. If the result is <code>false</code>, stops and returns the original value of that operand.</li>
<li>If all operands have been evaluated (i.e.¬†all were truthy), returns the last operand.</li>
</ul>
<p>In other words, AND returns the first falsy value or the last value if none were found.</p>
<p>The rules above are similar to OR. The difference is that AND returns the first <em>falsy</em> value while OR returns the first <em>truthy</em> one.</p>
<p>Examples:</p>
<p>```js run // if the first operand is truthy, // AND returns the second operand: alert( 1 &amp;&amp; 0 ); // 0 alert( 1 &amp;&amp; 5 ); // 5</p>
<p>// if the first operand is falsy, // AND returns it. The second operand is ignored alert( null &amp;&amp; 5 ); // null alert( 0 &amp;&amp; ‚Äúno matter what‚Äù ); // 0 ```</p>
<p>We can also pass several values in a row. See how the first falsy one is returned:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 1 &amp;&amp; 2 &amp;&amp; null &amp;&amp; 3 ); // null</code></p>
<p>When all values are truthy, the last value is returned:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 1 &amp;&amp; 2 &amp;&amp; 3 ); // 3, the last one</code></p>
<p>```<code>smart header="Precedence of AND</code>&amp;&amp;<code>is higher than OR</code>||<code>" The precedence of AND</code>&amp;&amp;<code>operator is higher than OR</code>||`.</p>
<p>So the code <code>a &amp;&amp; b || c &amp;&amp; d</code> is essentially the same as if the <code>&amp;&amp;</code> expressions were in parentheses: <code>(a &amp;&amp; b) || (c &amp;&amp; d)</code>. ````</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Don't replace</code>if<code>with</code>||<code>or</code>&amp;&amp;<code>" Sometimes, people use the AND</code>&amp;&amp;<code>operator as a "shorter way to write</code>if`".</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let x = 1;</p>
<p>(x &gt; 0) &amp;&amp; alert( ‚ÄòGreater than zero!‚Äô ); ```</p>
<p>The action in the right part of <code>&amp;&amp;</code> would execute only if the evaluation reaches it. That is, only if <code>(x &gt; 0)</code> is true.</p>
<p>So we basically have an analogue for:</p>
<p>```js run let x = 1;</p>
<p>if (x &gt; 0) alert( ‚ÄòGreater than zero!‚Äô );</p>
<pre><code>
Although, the variant with `&amp;&amp;` appears shorter, `if` is more obvious and tends to be a little bit more readable. So we recommend using every construct for its purpose: use `if` if we want `if` and use `&amp;&amp;` if we want AND.</code></pre>
<h2 id="not">! (NOT)</h2>
<p>The boolean NOT operator is represented with an exclamation sign <code>!</code>.</p>
<p>The syntax is pretty simple:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb222"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb222-1" title="1">result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">!</span>value<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The operator accepts a single argument and does the following:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Converts the operand to boolean type: <code>true/false</code>.</li>
<li>Returns the inverse value.</li>
</ol>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( !true ); // false alert( !0 ); // true</code></p>
<p>A double NOT <code>!!</code> is sometimes used for converting a value to boolean type:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( !!"non-empty string" ); // true alert( !!null ); // false</code></p>
<p>That is, the first NOT converts the value to boolean and returns the inverse, and the second NOT inverses it again. In the end, we have a plain value-to-boolean conversion.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a little more verbose way to do the same thing ‚Äì a built-in <code>Boolean</code> function:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( Boolean("non-empty string") ); // true alert( Boolean(null) ); // false</code></p>
<p>The precedence of NOT <code>!</code> is the highest of all logical operators, so it always executes first, before <code>&amp;&amp;</code> or <code>||</code>. # From the orbital height</p>
<p>This section describes a set of modern standards for ‚Äúweb components‚Äù.</p>
<p>As of now, these standards are under development. Some features are well-supported and integrated into the modern HTML/DOM standard, while others are yet in draft stage. You can try examples in any browser, Google Chrome is probably the most up to date with these features. Guess, that‚Äôs because Google fellows are behind many of the related specifications.</p>
<h2 id="whats-common-between">What‚Äôs common between‚Ä¶</h2>
<p>The whole component idea is nothing new. It‚Äôs used in many frameworks and elsewhere.</p>
<p>Before we move to implementation details, take a look at this great achievement of humanity:</p>
<p><img src="satellite.jpg" /></p>
<p>That‚Äôs the International Space Station (ISS).</p>
<p>And this is how it‚Äôs made inside (approximately):</p>
<p><img src="satellite-expanded.jpg" /></p>
<p>The International Space Station: - Consists of many components. - Each component, in its turn, has many smaller details inside. - The components are very complex, much more complicated than most websites. - Components are developed internationally, by teams from different countries, speaking different languages.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶And this thing flies, keeps humans alive in space!</p>
<p>How such complex devices are created?</p>
<p>Which principles we could borrow to make our development same-level reliable and scalable? Or, at least, close to it.</p>
<h2 id="component-architecture">Component architecture</h2>
<p>The well known rule for developing complex software is: don‚Äôt make complex software.</p>
<p>If something becomes complex ‚Äì split it into simpler parts and connect in the most obvious way.</p>
<p><strong>A good architect is the one who can make the complex simple.</strong></p>
<p>We can split user interface into visual components: each of them has own place on the page, can ‚Äúdo‚Äù a well-described task, and is separate from the others.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs take a look at a website, for example Twitter.</p>
<p>It naturally splits into components:</p>
<p><img src="web-components-twitter.svg" /></p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Top navigation.</li>
<li>User info.</li>
<li>Follow suggestions.</li>
<li>Submit form.</li>
<li>(and also 6, 7) ‚Äì messages.</li>
</ol>
<p>Components may have subcomponents, e.g.¬†messages may be parts of a higher-level ‚Äúmessage list‚Äù component. A clickable user picture itself may be a component, and so on.</p>
<p>How do we decide, what is a component? That comes from intuition, experience and common sense. Usually it‚Äôs a separate visual entity that we can describe in terms of what it does and how it interacts with the page. In the case above, the page has blocks, each of them plays its own role, it‚Äôs logical to make these components.</p>
<p>A component has: - Its own JavaScript class. - DOM structure, managed solely by its class, outside code doesn‚Äôt access it (‚Äúencapsulation‚Äù principle). - CSS styles, applied to the component. - API: events, class methods etc, to interact with other components.</p>
<p>Once again, the whole ‚Äúcomponent‚Äù thing is nothing special.</p>
<p>There exist many frameworks and development methodologies to build them, each with its own bells and whistles. Usually, special CSS classes and conventions are used to provide ‚Äúcomponent feel‚Äù ‚Äì CSS scoping and DOM encapsulation.</p>
<p>‚ÄúWeb components‚Äù provide built-in browser capabilities for that, so we don‚Äôt have to emulate them any more.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#custom-elements">Custom elements</a> ‚Äì to define custom HTML elements.</li>
<li><a href="https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#shadow-trees">Shadow DOM</a> ‚Äì to create an internal DOM for the component, hidden from the others.</li>
<li><a href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-scoping/">CSS Scoping</a> ‚Äì to declare styles that only apply inside the Shadow DOM of the component.</li>
<li><a href="https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#retarget">Event retargeting</a> and other minor stuff to make custom components better fit the development.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the next chapter we‚Äôll go into details of ‚ÄúCustom Elements‚Äù ‚Äì the fundamental and well-supported feature of web components, good on its own.</p>
<h1 id="custom-elements">Custom elements</h1>
<p>We can create custom HTML elements, described by our class, with its own methods and properties, events and so on.</p>
<p>Once a custom element is defined, we can use it on par with built-in HTML elements.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs great, as HTML dictionary is rich, but not infinite. There are no <code>&lt;easy-tabs&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;sliding-carousel&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;beautiful-upload&gt;</code>‚Ä¶ Just think of any other tag we might need.</p>
<p>We can define them with a special class, and then use as if they were always a part of HTML.</p>
<p>There are two kinds of custom elements:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><strong>Autonomous custom elements</strong> ‚Äì ‚Äúall-new‚Äù elements, extending the abstract <code>HTMLElement</code> class.</li>
<li><strong>Customized built-in elements</strong> ‚Äì extending built-in elements, like a customized button, based on <code>HTMLButtonElement</code> etc.</li>
</ol>
<p>First we‚Äôll cover autonomous elements, and then move to customized built-in ones.</p>
<p>To create a custom element, we need to tell the browser several details about it: how to show it, what to do when the element is added or removed to page, etc.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs done by making a class with special methods. That‚Äôs easy, as there are only few methods, and all of them are optional.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs a sketch with the full list:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb223"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-1" title="1"><span class="kw">class</span> MyElement <span class="kw">extends</span> HTMLElement <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-2" title="2">  <span class="at">constructor</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">super</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-4" title="4">    <span class="co">// element created</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-5" title="5">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-7" title="7">  <span class="at">connectedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-8" title="8">    <span class="co">// browser calls this method when the element is added to the document</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-9" title="9">    <span class="co">// (can be called many times if an element is repeatedly added/removed)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-10" title="10">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-11" title="11"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-12" title="12">  <span class="at">disconnectedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-13" title="13">    <span class="co">// browser calls this method when the element is removed from the document</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-14" title="14">    <span class="co">// (can be called many times if an element is repeatedly added/removed)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-15" title="15">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-16" title="16"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-17" title="17">  <span class="kw">static</span> get <span class="at">observedAttributes</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-18" title="18">    <span class="cf">return</span> [<span class="co">/* array of attribute names to monitor for changes */</span>]<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-19" title="19">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-20" title="20"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-21" title="21">  <span class="at">attributeChangedCallback</span>(name<span class="op">,</span> oldValue<span class="op">,</span> newValue) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-22" title="22">    <span class="co">// called when one of attributes listed above is modified</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-23" title="23">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-24" title="24"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-25" title="25">  <span class="at">adoptedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-26" title="26">    <span class="co">// called when the element is moved to a new document</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-27" title="27">    <span class="co">// (happens in document.adoptNode, very rarely used)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-28" title="28">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-29" title="29"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-30" title="30">  <span class="co">// there can be other element methods and properties</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb223-31" title="31"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>After that, we need to register the element:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb224"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb224-1" title="1"><span class="co">// let the browser know that &lt;my-element&gt; is served by our new class</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb224-2" title="2"><span class="va">customElements</span>.<span class="at">define</span>(<span class="st">&quot;my-element&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> MyElement)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now for any HTML elements with tag <code>&lt;my-element&gt;</code>, an instance of <code>MyElement</code> is created, and the aforementioned methods are called. We also can <code>document.createElement('my-element')</code> in JavaScript.</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Custom element name must contain a hyphen</code>-<code>" Custom element name must have a hyphen</code>-<code>, e.g.</code>my-element<code>and</code>super-button<code>are valid names, but</code>myelement` is not.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs to ensure that there are no name conflicts between built-in and custom HTML elements. ```</p>
<h2 id="example-time-formatted">Example: ‚Äútime-formatted‚Äù</h2>
<p>For example, there already exists <code>&lt;time&gt;</code> element in HTML, for date/time. But it doesn‚Äôt do any formatting by itself.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs create <code>&lt;time-formatted&gt;</code> element that displays the time in a nice, language-aware format:</p>
```html run height=50 autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù
<script>
*!*
class TimeFormatted extends HTMLElement { // (1)
*/!*

  connectedCallback() {
    let date = new Date(this.getAttribute('datetime') || Date.now());

    this.innerHTML = new Intl.DateTimeFormat("default", {
      year: this.getAttribute('year') || undefined,
      month: this.getAttribute('month') || undefined,
      day: this.getAttribute('day') || undefined,
      hour: this.getAttribute('hour') || undefined,
      minute: this.getAttribute('minute') || undefined,
      second: this.getAttribute('second') || undefined,
      timeZoneName: this.getAttribute('time-zone-name') || undefined,
    }).format(date);
  }

}

*!*
customElements.define("time-formatted", TimeFormatted); // (2)
*/!*
</script>
<!-- (3) -->
<p><em>!</em> &lt;time-formatted datetime=‚Äú2019-12-01‚Äù <em>/!</em> year=‚Äúnumeric‚Äù month=‚Äúlong‚Äù day=‚Äúnumeric‚Äù hour=‚Äúnumeric‚Äù minute=‚Äúnumeric‚Äù second=‚Äúnumeric‚Äù time-zone-name=‚Äúshort‚Äù &gt;</time-formatted> ```</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The class has only one method <code>connectedCallback()</code> ‚Äì the browser calls it when <code>&lt;time-formatted&gt;</code> element is added to page (or when HTML parser detects it), and it uses the built-in <a href="mdn:/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/DateTimeFormat">Intl.DateTimeFormat</a> data formatter, well-supported across the browsers, to show a nicely formatted time.</li>
<li>We need to register our new element by <code>customElements.define(tag, class)</code>.</li>
<li>And then we can use it everywhere.</li>
</ol>
<p>``<code>smart header="Custom elements upgrade" If the browser encounters any</code><time-formatted><code>elements before</code>customElements.define`, that‚Äôs not an error. But the element is yet unknown, just like any non-standard tag.</p>
<p>Such ‚Äúundefined‚Äù elements can be styled with CSS selector <code>:not(:defined)</code>.</p>
<p>When <code>customElement.define</code> is called, they are ‚Äúupgraded‚Äù: a new instance of <code>TimeFormatted</code> is created for each, and <code>connectedCallback</code> is called. They become <code>:defined</code>.</p>
<p>To get the information about custom elements, there are methods: - <code>customElements.get(name)</code> ‚Äì returns the class for a custom element with the given <code>name</code>, - <code>customElements.whenDefined(name)</code> ‚Äì returns a promise that resolves (without value) when a custom element with the given <code>name</code> becomes defined. ```</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Rendering in</code>connectedCallback<code>, not in</code>constructor<code>" In the example above, element content is rendered (created) in</code>connectedCallback`.</p>
<p>Why not in the <code>constructor</code>?</p>
<p>The reason is simple: when <code>constructor</code> is called, it‚Äôs yet too early. The element is created, but the browser did not yet process/assign attributes at this stage: calls to <code>getAttribute</code> would return <code>null</code>. So we can‚Äôt really render there.</p>
<p>Besides, if you think about it, that‚Äôs better performance-wise ‚Äì to delay the work until it‚Äôs really needed.</p>
<p>The <code>connectedCallback</code> triggers when the element is added to the document. Not just appended to another element as a child, but actually becomes a part of the page. So we can build detached DOM, create elements and prepare them for later use. They will only be actually rendered when they make it into the page. ```</p>
<h2 id="observing-attributes">Observing attributes</h2>
<p>In the current implementation of <code>&lt;time-formatted&gt;</code>, after the element is rendered, further attribute changes don‚Äôt have any effect. That‚Äôs strange for an HTML element. Usually, when we change an attribute, like <code>a.href</code>, we expect the change to be immediately visible. So let‚Äôs fix this.</p>
<p>We can observe attributes by providing their list in <code>observedAttributes()</code> static getter. For such attributes, <code>attributeChangedCallback</code> is called when they are modified. It doesn‚Äôt trigger for other, unlisted attributes (that‚Äôs for performance reasons).</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs a new <code>&lt;time-formatted&gt;</code>, that auto-updates when attributes change:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù height=50
<script>
class TimeFormatted extends HTMLElement {

*!*
  render() { // (1)
*/!*
    let date = new Date(this.getAttribute('datetime') || Date.now());

    this.innerHTML = new Intl.DateTimeFormat("default", {
      year: this.getAttribute('year') || undefined,
      month: this.getAttribute('month') || undefined,
      day: this.getAttribute('day') || undefined,
      hour: this.getAttribute('hour') || undefined,
      minute: this.getAttribute('minute') || undefined,
      second: this.getAttribute('second') || undefined,
      timeZoneName: this.getAttribute('time-zone-name') || undefined,
    }).format(date);
  }

*!*
  connectedCallback() { // (2)
*/!*
    if (!this.rendered) {
      this.render();
      this.rendered = true;
    }
  }

*!*
  static get observedAttributes() { // (3)
*/!*
    return ['datetime', 'year', 'month', 'day', 'hour', 'minute', 'second', 'time-zone-name'];
  }

*!*
  attributeChangedCallback(name, oldValue, newValue) { // (4)
*/!*
    this.render();
  }

}

customElements.define("time-formatted", TimeFormatted);
</script>
<p><time-formatted id="elem" hour="numeric" minute="numeric" second="numeric"></time-formatted></p>
<script>
*!*
setInterval(() => elem.setAttribute('datetime', new Date()), 1000); // (5)
*/!*
</script>
<p>```</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The rendering logic is moved to <code>render()</code> helper method.</li>
<li>We call it once when the element is inserted into page.</li>
<li>For a change of an attribute, listed in <code>observedAttributes()</code>, <code>attributeChangedCallback</code> triggers.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶and re-renders the element.</li>
<li>At the end, we can easily make a live timer.</li>
</ol>
<h2 id="rendering-order">Rendering order</h2>
<p>When HTML parser builds the DOM, elements are processed one after another, parents before children. E.g. if we have <code>&lt;outer&gt;&lt;inner&gt;&lt;/inner&gt;&lt;/outer&gt;</code>, then <code>&lt;outer&gt;</code> element is created and connected to DOM first, and then <code>&lt;inner&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>That leads to important consequences for custom elements.</p>
<p>For example, if a custom element tries to access <code>innerHTML</code> in <code>connectedCallback</code>, it gets nothing:</p>
```html run height=40
<script>
customElements.define('user-info', class extends HTMLElement {

  connectedCallback() {
*!*
    alert(this.innerHTML); // empty (*)
*/!*
  }

});
</script>
<p><em>!</em> <user-info>John</user-info> <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>If you run it, the <code>alert</code> is empty.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs exactly because there are no children on that stage, the DOM is unfinished. HTML parser connected the custom element <code>&lt;user-info&gt;</code>, and is going to proceed to its children, but just didn‚Äôt yet.</p>
<p>If we‚Äôd like to pass information to custom element, we can use attributes. They are available immediately.</p>
<p>Or, if we really need the children, we can defer access to them with zero-delay <code>setTimeout</code>.</p>
<p>This works:</p>
```html run height=40
<script>
customElements.define('user-info', class extends HTMLElement {

  connectedCallback() {
*!*
    setTimeout(() => alert(this.innerHTML)); // John (*)
*/!*
  }

});
</script>
<p><em>!</em> <user-info>John</user-info> <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Now the <code>alert</code> in line <code>(*)</code> shows ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, as we run it asynchronously, after the HTML parsing is complete. We can process children if needed and finish the initialization.</p>
<p>On the other hand, this solution is also not perfect. If nested custom elements also use <code>setTimeout</code> to initialize themselves, then they queue up: the outer <code>setTimeout</code> triggers first, and then the inner one.</p>
<p>So the outer element finishes the initialization before the inner one.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs demonstrate that on example:</p>
``<code>html run height=0 &lt;script&gt; customElements.define('user-info', class extends HTMLElement {   connectedCallback() {     alert(</code><span class="math inline">${this.id} connected.`);  setTimeout(() =&gt; alert(`$</span>{this.id} initialized.`)); } });
</script>
<p><em>!</em> <user-info id="outer"> <user-info id="inner"></user-info> </user-info> <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Output order:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>outer connected.</li>
<li>inner connected.</li>
<li>outer initialized.</li>
<li>inner initialized.</li>
</ol>
<p>We can clearly see that the outer element finishes initialization <code>(3)</code> before the inner one <code>(4)</code>.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs no built-in callback that triggers after nested elements are ready. If needed, we can implement such thing on our own. For instance, inner elements can dispatch events like <code>initialized</code>, and outer ones can listen and react on them.</p>
<h2 id="customized-built-in-elements">Customized built-in elements</h2>
<p>New elements that we create, such as <code>&lt;time-formatted&gt;</code>, don‚Äôt have any associated semantics. They are unknown to search engines, and accessibility devices can‚Äôt handle them.</p>
<p>But such things can be important. E.g, a search engine would be interested to know that we actually show a time. And if we‚Äôre making a special kind of button, why not reuse the existing <code>&lt;button&gt;</code> functionality?</p>
<p>We can extend and customize built-in HTML elements by inheriting from their classes.</p>
<p>For example, buttons are instances of <code>HTMLButtonElement</code>, let‚Äôs build upon it.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>Extend <code>HTMLButtonElement</code> with our class:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb225"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb225-1" title="1"><span class="kw">class</span> HelloButton <span class="kw">extends</span> HTMLButtonElement <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">/* custom element methods */</span> <span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>Provide the third argument to <code>customElements.define</code>, that specifies the tag: <code>js  customElements.define('hello-button', HelloButton, *!*{extends: 'button'}*/!*);</code></p>
<p>There may be different tags that share the same DOM-class, that‚Äôs why specifying <code>extends</code> is needed.</p></li>
<li><p>At the end, to use our custom element, insert a regular <code>&lt;button&gt;</code> tag, but add <code>is="hello-button"</code> to it: <code>html  &lt;button is="hello-button"&gt;...&lt;/button&gt;</code></p></li>
</ol>
<p>Here‚Äôs a full example:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù
<script>
// The button that says "hello" on click
class HelloButton extends HTMLButtonElement {
*!*
  constructor() {
*/!*
    super();
    this.addEventListener('click', () => alert("Hello!"));
  }
}

*!*
customElements.define('hello-button', HelloButton, {extends: 'button'});
*/!*
</script>
<p><em>!</em> <button is="hello-button">Click me</button> <em>/!</em></p>
<p><em>!</em> <button is="hello-button" disabled>Disabled</button> <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Our new button extends the built-in one. So it keeps the same styles and standard features like <code>disabled</code> attribute.</p>
<h2 id="references-1">References</h2>
<ul>
<li>HTML Living Standard: <a href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#custom-elements" class="uri">https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#custom-elements</a>.</li>
<li>Compatiblity: <a href="https://caniuse.com/#feat=custom-elementsv1" class="uri">https://caniuse.com/#feat=custom-elementsv1</a>.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="summary-22">Summary</h2>
<p>Custom elements can be of two types:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>‚ÄúAutonomous‚Äù ‚Äì new tags, extending <code>HTMLElement</code>.</p>
<p>Definition scheme:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb226"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-1" title="1"><span class="kw">class</span> MyElement <span class="kw">extends</span> HTMLElement <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-2" title="2">  <span class="at">constructor</span>() <span class="op">{</span> <span class="kw">super</span>()<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">/* ... */</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-3" title="3">  <span class="at">connectedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">/* ... */</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-4" title="4">  <span class="at">disconnectedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">/* ... */</span>  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">static</span> get <span class="at">observedAttributes</span>() <span class="op">{</span> <span class="cf">return</span> [<span class="co">/* ... */</span>]<span class="op">;</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-6" title="6">  <span class="at">attributeChangedCallback</span>(name<span class="op">,</span> oldValue<span class="op">,</span> newValue) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">/* ... */</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-7" title="7">  <span class="at">adoptedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">/* ... */</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-8" title="8"> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-9" title="9"><span class="va">customElements</span>.<span class="at">define</span>(<span class="st">&#39;my-element&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> MyElement)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb226-10" title="10"><span class="co">/* &lt;my-element&gt; */</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>‚ÄúCustomized built-in elements‚Äù ‚Äì extensions of existing elements.</p>
<p>Requires one more <code>.define</code> argument, and <code>is="..."</code> in HTML: <code>js  class MyButton extends HTMLButtonElement { /*...*/ }  customElements.define('my-button', MyElement, {extends: 'button'});  /* &lt;button is="my-button"&gt; */</code></p></li>
</ol>
<p>Custom elements are well-supported among browsers. There‚Äôs a polyfill <a href="https://github.com/webcomponents/polyfills/tree/master/packages/webcomponentsjs" class="uri">https://github.com/webcomponents/polyfills/tree/master/packages/webcomponentsjs</a>. # Shadow DOM</p>
<p>Shadow DOM serves for encapsulation. It allows a component to have its very own ‚Äúshadow‚Äù DOM tree, that can‚Äôt be accidentally accessed from the main document, may have local style rules, and more.</p>
<h2 id="built-in-shadow-dom">Built-in shadow DOM</h2>
<p>Did you ever think how complex browser controls are created and styled?</p>
<p>Such as <code>&lt;input type="range"&gt;</code>:</p>
<p>
<input type="range">
</p>
<p>The browser uses DOM/CSS internally to draw them. That DOM structure is normally hidden from us, but we can see it in developer tools. E.g. in Chrome, we need to enable in Dev Tools ‚ÄúShow user agent shadow DOM‚Äù option.</p>
<p>Then <code>&lt;input type="range"&gt;</code> looks like this:</p>
<p><img src="shadow-dom-range.png" /></p>
<p>What you see under <code>#shadow-root</code> is called ‚Äúshadow DOM‚Äù.</p>
<p>We can‚Äôt get built-in shadow DOM elements by regular JavaScript calls or selectors. These are not regular children, but a powerful encapsulation technique.</p>
<p>In the example above, we can see a useful attribute <code>pseudo</code>. It‚Äôs non-standard, exists for historical reasons. We can use it style subelements with CSS, like this:</p>
```html run autorun
<style>
/* make the slider track red */
input::-webkit-slider-runnable-track {
  background: red;
}
</style>
<p><input type="range"> ```</p>
<p>Once again, <code>pseudo</code> is a non-standard attribute. Chronologically, browsers first started to experiment with internal DOM structures to implement controls, and then, after time, shadow DOM was standardized to allow us, developers, to do the similar thing.</p>
<p>Further on, we‚Äôll use the modern shadow DOM standard, covered by <a href="https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#shadow-trees">DOM spec</a> and other related specifications.</p>
<h2 id="shadow-tree">Shadow tree</h2>
<p>A DOM element can have two types of DOM subtrees:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Light tree ‚Äì a regular DOM subtree, made of HTML children. All subtrees that we‚Äôve seen in previous chapters were ‚Äúlight‚Äù.</li>
<li>Shadow tree ‚Äì a hidden DOM subtree, not reflected in HTML, hidden from prying eyes.</li>
</ol>
<p>If an element has both, then the browser renders only the shadow tree. But we can setup a kind of composition between shadow and light trees as well. We‚Äôll see the details later in the chapter <a href="info:slots-composition" class="uri">info:slots-composition</a>.</p>
<p>Shadow tree can be used in Custom Elements to hide component internals and apply component-local styles.</p>
<p>For example, this <code>&lt;show-hello&gt;</code> element hides its internal DOM in shadow tree:</p>
``<code>html run autorun height=60 &lt;script&gt; customElements.define('show-hello', class extends HTMLElement {   connectedCallback() {     const shadow = this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});     shadow.innerHTML =</code>
<p>
Hello, ${this.getAttribute(‚Äòname‚Äô)}
</p>
`; }<br />
});
</script>
<p><show-hello name="John"></show-hello> ```</p>
<p>That‚Äôs how the resulting DOM looks in Chrome dev tools, all the content is under ‚Äú#shadow-root‚Äù:</p>
<p><img src="shadow-dom-say-hello.png" /></p>
<p>First, the call to <code>elem.attachShadow({mode: ‚Ä¶})</code> creates a shadow tree.</p>
<p>There are two limitations: 1. We can create only one shadow root per element. 2. The <code>elem</code> must be either a custom element, or one of: ‚Äúarticle‚Äù, ‚Äúaside‚Äù, ‚Äúblockquote‚Äù, ‚Äúbody‚Äù, ‚Äúdiv‚Äù, ‚Äúfooter‚Äù, ‚Äúh1..h6‚Äù, ‚Äúheader‚Äù, ‚Äúmain‚Äù ‚Äúnav‚Äù, ‚Äúp‚Äù, ‚Äúsection‚Äù, or ‚Äúspan‚Äù. Other elements, like <code>&lt;img&gt;</code>, can‚Äôt host shadow tree.</p>
<p>The <code>mode</code> option sets the encapsulation level. It must have any of two values: - <code>"open"</code> ‚Äì the shadow root is available as <code>elem.shadowRoot</code>.</p>
<pre><code>Any code is able to access the shadow tree of `elem`.   </code></pre>
<ul>
<li><p><code>"closed"</code> ‚Äì <code>elem.shadowRoot</code> is always <code>null</code>.</p>
<p>We can only access the shadow DOM by the reference returned by <code>attachShadow</code> (and probably hidden inside a class). Browser-native shadow trees, such as <code>&lt;input type="range"&gt;</code>, are closed. There‚Äôs no way to access them.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>The <a href="https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#shadowroot">shadow root</a>, returned by <code>attachShadow</code>, is like an element: we can use <code>innerHTML</code> or DOM methods, such as <code>append</code>, to populate it.</p>
<p>The element with a shadow root is called a ‚Äúshadow tree host‚Äù, and is available as the shadow root <code>host</code> property:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb228"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb228-1" title="1"><span class="co">// assuming {mode: &quot;open&quot;}, otherwise elem.shadowRoot is null</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb228-2" title="2"><span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">elem</span>.<span class="va">shadowRoot</span>.<span class="at">host</span> <span class="op">===</span> elem)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// true</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="encapsulation">Encapsulation</h2>
<p>Shadow DOM is strongly delimited from the main document:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Shadow DOM elements are not visible to <code>querySelector</code> from the light DOM. In particular, Shadow DOM elements may have ids that conflict with those in the light DOM. They must be unique only within the shadow tree.</li>
<li>Shadow DOM has own stylesheets. Style rules from the outer DOM don‚Äôt get applied.</li>
</ol>
<p>For example:</p>
```html run untrusted height=40
<style>
*!*
  /* document style won't apply to the shadow tree inside #elem (1) */
*/!*
  p { color: red; }
</style>
<div id="elem">

</div>
<script>
  elem.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
*!*
    // shadow tree has its own style (2)
*/!*
  elem.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `
    <style> p { font-weight: bold; } </style>
    <p>Hello, John!</p>
  `;

*!*
  // <p> is only visible from queries inside the shadow tree (3)
*/!*
  alert(document.querySelectorAll('p').length); // 0
  alert(elem.shadowRoot.querySelectorAll('p').length); // 1
</script>
<p>```</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The style from the document does not affect the shadow tree.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶But the style from the inside works.</li>
<li>To get elements in shadow tree, we must query from inside the tree.</li>
</ol>
<h2 id="references-2">References</h2>
<ul>
<li>DOM: <a href="https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#shadow-trees" class="uri">https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#shadow-trees</a></li>
<li>Compatibility: <a href="https://caniuse.com/#feat=shadowdomv1" class="uri">https://caniuse.com/#feat=shadowdomv1</a></li>
<li>Shadow DOM is mentioned in many other specifications, e.g.¬†<a href="https://w3c.github.io/DOM-Parsing/#the-innerhtml-mixin">DOM Parsing</a> specifies that shadow root has <code>innerHTML</code>.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="summary-23">Summary</h2>
<p>Shadow DOM is a way to create a component-local DOM.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><code>shadowRoot = elem.attachShadow({mode: open|closed})</code> ‚Äì creates shadow DOM for <code>elem</code>. If <code>mode="open"</code>, then it‚Äôs accessible as <code>elem.shadowRoot</code> property.</li>
<li>We can populate <code>shadowRoot</code> using <code>innerHTML</code> or other DOM methods.</li>
</ol>
<p>Shadow DOM elements: - Have their own ids space, - Invisible to JavaScript selectors from the main document, such as <code>querySelector</code>, - Use styles only from the shadow tree, not from the main document.</p>
<p>Shadow DOM, if exists, is rendered by the browser instead of so-called ‚Äúlight DOM‚Äù (regular children). In the chapter <a href="info:slots-composition" class="uri">info:slots-composition</a> we‚Äôll see how to compose them.</p>
<h1 id="template-element">Template element</h1>
<p>A built-in <code>&lt;template&gt;</code> element serves as a storage for HTML markup templates. The browser ignores it contents, only checks for syntax validity, but we can access and use it in JavaScript, to create other elements.</p>
<p>In theory, we could create any invisible element somewhere in HTML for HTML markup storage purposes. What‚Äôs special about <code>&lt;template&gt;</code>?</p>
<p>First, its content can be any valid HTML, even if it normally requires a proper enclosing tag.</p>
<p>For example, we can put there a table row <code>&lt;tr&gt;</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb229"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb229-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;template&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb229-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;tr&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb229-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;td&gt;</span>Contents<span class="kw">&lt;/td&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb229-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">&lt;/tr&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb229-5" title="5"><span class="kw">&lt;/template&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Usually, if we try to put <code>&lt;tr&gt;</code> inside, say, a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code>, the browser detects the invalid DOM structure and ‚Äúfixes‚Äù it, adds <code>&lt;table&gt;</code> around. That‚Äôs not what we want. On the other hand, <code>&lt;template&gt;</code> keeps exactly what we place there.</p>
<p>We can put styles and scripts into <code>&lt;template&gt;</code> as well:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb230"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;template&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-3" title="3">    p { <span class="kw">font-weight</span>: <span class="dv">bold</span><span class="op">;</span> }</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">&lt;/style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">&lt;script&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-6" title="6">    <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="st">&quot;Hello&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-7" title="7">  <span class="kw">&lt;/script&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb230-8" title="8"><span class="kw">&lt;/template&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The browser considers <code>&lt;template&gt;</code> content ‚Äúout of the document‚Äù: styles are not applied, scripts are not executed, <code>&lt;video autoplay&gt;</code> is not run, etc.</p>
<p>The content becomes live (styles apply, scripts run etc) when we insert it into the document.</p>
<h2 id="inserting-template">Inserting template</h2>
<p>The template content is available in its <code>content</code> property as a <a href="info:modifying-document#document-fragment">DocumentFragment</a> ‚Äì a special type of DOM node.</p>
<p>We can treat it as any other DOM node, except one special property: when we insert it somewhere, its children are inserted instead.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
```html run <template id="tmpl">
<script>
    alert("Hello");
  </script>
<div class="message">
Hello, world!
</div>
<p></template></p>
<script>
  let elem = document.createElement('div');

*!*
  // Clone the template content to reuse it multiple times
  elem.append(tmpl.content.cloneNode(true));
*/!*

  document.body.append(elem);
  // Now the script from <template> runs
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs rewrite a Shadow DOM example from the previous chapter using <code>&lt;template&gt;</code>:</p>
```html run untrusted autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù height=60 <template id="tmpl">
<style> p { font-weight: bold; } </style>
<p id="message">
</p>
<p></template></p>
<div id="elem">
Click me
</div>
<script>
  elem.onclick = function() {
    elem.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});

*!*
    elem.shadowRoot.append(tmpl.content.cloneNode(true)); // (*)
*/!*

    elem.shadowRoot.getElementById('message').innerHTML = "Hello from the shadows!";
  };
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>In the line <code>(*)</code> when we clone and insert <code>tmpl.content</code>, as its <code>DocumentFragment</code>, its children (<code>&lt;style&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;p&gt;</code>) are inserted instead.</p>
<p>They form the shadow DOM:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb231"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb231-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;div</span><span class="ot"> id=</span><span class="st">&quot;elem&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb231-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb231-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;style&gt;</span> p { <span class="kw">font-weight</span>: <span class="dv">bold</span><span class="op">;</span> } <span class="kw">&lt;/style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb231-4" title="4">    <span class="kw">&lt;p</span><span class="ot"> id=</span><span class="st">&quot;message&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb231-5" title="5"><span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="summary-24">Summary</h2>
<p>To summarize:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>&lt;template&gt;</code> content can be any syntactically correct HTML.</li>
<li><code>&lt;template&gt;</code> content is considered ‚Äúout of the document‚Äù, so it doesn‚Äôt affect anything.</li>
<li>We can access <code>template.content</code> from JavaScript, clone it to reuse in a new component.</li>
</ul>
<p>The <code>&lt;template&gt;</code> tag is quite unique, because:</p>
<ul>
<li>The browser checks HTML syntax inside it (as opposed to using a template string inside a script).</li>
<li>‚Ä¶But still allows use of any top-level HTML tags, even those that don‚Äôt make sense without proper wrappers (e.g.¬†<code>&lt;tr&gt;</code>).</li>
<li>The content becomes interactive: scripts run, <code>&lt;video autoplay&gt;</code> plays etc, when inserted into the document.</li>
</ul>
<p>The <code>&lt;template&gt;</code> element does not feature any iteration mechanisms, data binding or variable substitutions, but we can implement those on top of it. # Shadow DOM slots, composition</p>
<p>Many types of components, such as tabs, menus, image galleries, and so on, need the content to render.</p>
<p>Just like built-in browser <code>&lt;select&gt;</code> expects <code>&lt;option&gt;</code> items, our <code>&lt;custom-tabs&gt;</code> may expect the actual tab content to be passed. And a <code>&lt;custom-menu&gt;</code> may expect menu items.</p>
<p>The code that makes use of <code>&lt;custom-menu&gt;</code> can look like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb232"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb232-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;custom-menu&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb232-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;title&gt;</span>Candy menu<span class="kw">&lt;/title&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb232-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">&lt;item&gt;</span>Lollipop<span class="kw">&lt;/item&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb232-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">&lt;item&gt;</span>Fruit Toast<span class="kw">&lt;/item&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb232-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">&lt;item&gt;</span>Cup Cake<span class="kw">&lt;/item&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb232-6" title="6"><span class="kw">&lt;/custom-menu&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶Then our component should render it properly, as a nice menu with given title and items, handle menu events, etc.</p>
<p>How to implement it?</p>
<p>We could try to analyze the element content and dynamically copy-rearrange DOM nodes. That‚Äôs possible, but if we‚Äôre moving elements to shadow DOM, then CSS styles from the document do not apply in there, so the visual styling may be lost. Also that requires some coding.</p>
<p>Luckily, we don‚Äôt have to. Shadow DOM supports <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> elements, that are automatically filled by the content from light DOM.</p>
<h2 id="named-slots">Named slots</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs see how slots work on a simple example.</p>
<p>Here, <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code> shadow DOM provides two slots, filled from light DOM:</p>
``<code>html run autorun="no-epub" untrusted height=80 &lt;script&gt; customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {   connectedCallback() {     this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});     this.shadowRoot.innerHTML =</code>
<div>
Name: <em>!</em> <slot name="username"></slot> <em>/!</em>
</div>
<pre><code>  &lt;div&gt;Birthday:</code></pre>
<em>!</em> <slot name="birthday"></slot> <em>/!</em>
</div>
<pre><code>`;</code></pre>
} });
</script>
<p><user-card> &lt;span <em>!</em>slot=‚Äúusername‚Äù<em>/!</em>&gt;John Smith</span> &lt;span <em>!</em>slot=‚Äúbirthday‚Äù<em>/!</em>&gt;01.01.2001</span> </user-card> ```</p>
<p>In the shadow DOM, <code>&lt;slot name="X"&gt;</code> defines an ‚Äúinsertion point‚Äù, a place where elements with <code>slot="X"</code> are rendered.</p>
<p>Then the browser performs ‚Äúcomposition‚Äù: it takes elements from the light DOM and renders them in corresponding slots of the shadow DOM. At the end, we have exactly what we want ‚Äì a component that can be filled with data.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the DOM structure after the script, not taking composition into account:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb235"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Name:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-4" title="4">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-5" title="5">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-6" title="6">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Birthday:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-7" title="7">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-8" title="8">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-9" title="9">  <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-10" title="10">  <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>01.01.2001<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb235-11" title="11"><span class="kw">&lt;/user-card&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>We created the shadow DOM, so here it is, under <code>#shadow-root</code>. Now the element has both light and shadow DOM.</p>
<p>For rendering purposes, for each <code>&lt;slot name="..."&gt;</code> in shadow DOM, the browser looks for <code>slot="..."</code> with the same name in the light DOM. These elements are rendered inside the slots:</p>
<p><img src="shadow-dom-user-card.svg" /></p>
<p>The result is called ‚Äúflattened‚Äù DOM:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb236"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Name:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-4" title="4">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-5" title="5">        <span class="co">&lt;!-- slotted element is inserted into the slot --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-6" title="6">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-7" title="7">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-8" title="8">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-9" title="9">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Birthday:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-10" title="10">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-11" title="11">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>01.01.2001<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-12" title="12">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-13" title="13">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb236-14" title="14"><span class="kw">&lt;/user-card&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶But the flattened DOM exists only for rendering and event-handling purposes. It‚Äôs kind of ‚Äúvirtual‚Äù. That‚Äôs how things are shown. But the nodes in the document are actually not moved around!</p>
<p>That can be easily checked if we run <code>querySelectorAll</code>: nodes are still at their places.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb237"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb237-1" title="1"><span class="co">// light DOM &lt;span&gt; nodes are still at the same place, under `&lt;user-card&gt;`</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb237-2" title="2"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="va">document</span>.<span class="at">querySelectorAll</span>(<span class="st">&#39;user-card span&#39;</span>).<span class="at">length</span> )<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// 2</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So, the flattened DOM is derived from shadow DOM by inserting slots. The browser renders it and uses for style inheritance, event propagation (more about that later). But JavaScript still sees the document ‚Äúas is‚Äù, before flattening.</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Only top-level children may have slot=\"...\" attribute" The</code>slot=‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù<code>attribute is only valid for direct children of the shadow host (in our example,</code><user-card>` element). For nested elements it‚Äôs ignored.</p>
<p>For example, the second <code>&lt;span&gt;</code> here is ignored (as it‚Äôs not a top-level child of <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code>):</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb238"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-4" title="4">    <span class="co">&lt;!-- invalid slot, must be direct child of user-card --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-5" title="5">    <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>01.01.2001<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-6" title="6">  <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb238-7" title="7"><span class="kw">&lt;/user-card&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>````</p>
<p>If there are multiple elements in light DOM with the same slot name, they are appended into the slot, one after another.</p>
<p>For example, this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb239"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb239-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb239-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb239-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb239-4" title="4"><span class="kw">&lt;/user-card&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Gives this flattened DOM with two elements in <code>&lt;slot name="username"&gt;</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb240"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Name:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-4" title="4">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-5" title="5">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-6" title="6">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-7" title="7">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-8" title="8">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-9" title="9">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Birthday:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-10" title="10">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-11" title="11">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb240-12" title="12"><span class="kw">&lt;/user-card&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="slot-fallback-content">Slot fallback content</h2>
<p>If we put something inside a <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code>, it becomes the fallback, ‚Äúdefault‚Äù content. The browser shows it if there‚Äôs no corresponding filler in light DOM.</p>
<p>For example, in this piece of shadow DOM, <code>Anonymous</code> renders if there‚Äôs no <code>slot="username"</code> in light DOM.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb241"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb241-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Name:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb241-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Anonymous<span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb241-3" title="3"><span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="default-slot-first-unnamed">Default slot: first unnamed</h2>
<p>The first <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> in shadow DOM that doesn‚Äôt have a name is a ‚Äúdefault‚Äù slot. It gets all nodes from the light DOM that aren‚Äôt slotted elsewhere.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs add the default slot to our <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code> that shows all unslotted information about the user:</p>
``<code>html run autorun="no-epub" untrusted height=140 &lt;script&gt; customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {   connectedCallback() {     this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});     this.shadowRoot.innerHTML =</code>
<div>
Name: <slot name="username"></slot>
</div>
<pre><code>&lt;div&gt;Birthday:
  &lt;slot name=&quot;birthday&quot;&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;fieldset&gt;
  &lt;legend&gt;Other information&lt;/legend&gt;</code></pre>
<em>!</em> <slot></slot> <em>/!</em>
</fieldset>
<pre><code>`;</code></pre>
} });
</script>
<user-card> <em>!</em>
<div>
I like to swim.
</div>
<em>/!</em> <span slot="username">John Smith</span> <span slot="birthday">01.01.2001</span> <em>!</em>
<div>
‚Ä¶And play volleyball too!
</div>
<p><em>/!</em> </user-card> ```</p>
<p>All the unslotted light DOM content gets into the ‚ÄúOther information‚Äù fieldset.</p>
<p>Elements are appended to a slot one after another, so both unslotted pieces of information are in the default slot together.</p>
<p>The flattened DOM looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb244"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Name:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-4" title="4">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-5" title="5">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-6" title="6">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-7" title="7">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-8" title="8">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>Birthday:</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-9" title="9">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-10" title="10">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>01.01.2001<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-11" title="11">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-12" title="12">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-13" title="13">    <span class="kw">&lt;fieldset&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-14" title="14">      <span class="kw">&lt;legend&gt;</span>Other information<span class="kw">&lt;/legend&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-15" title="15">*!*</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-16" title="16">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-17" title="17">        <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>I like to swim.<span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-18" title="18">        <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span>...And play volleyball too!<span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-19" title="19">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-20" title="20">*/!*</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb244-21" title="21">    <span class="kw">&lt;/fieldset&gt;</span></a>

<h2 id="menu-example">Menu example</h2>
<p>Now let‚Äôs back to <code>&lt;custom-menu&gt;</code>, mentioned at the beginning of the chapter.</p>
<p>We can use slots to distribute elements.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the markup for <code>&lt;custom-menu&gt;</code>:</p>
