<div class="sourceCode" id="cb245"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb245-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;custom-menu&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb245-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;title&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Candy menu<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb245-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">&lt;li</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Lollipop<span class="kw">&lt;/li&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb245-4" title="4">  <span class="kw">&lt;li</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Fruit Toast<span class="kw">&lt;/li&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb245-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">&lt;li</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Cup Cake<span class="kw">&lt;/li&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb245-6" title="6"><span class="kw">&lt;/custom-menu&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The shadow DOM template with proper slots:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb246"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;template</span><span class="ot"> id=</span><span class="st">&quot;tmpl&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">&lt;style&gt;</span> <span class="co">/* menu styles */</span> <span class="kw">&lt;/style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">&lt;div</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;menu&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-4" title="4">    <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;title&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-5" title="5">    <span class="kw">&lt;ul&gt;&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-6" title="6">  <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb246-7" title="7"><span class="kw">&lt;/template&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<ol type="1">
<li><code>&lt;span slot="title"&gt;</code> goes into <code>&lt;slot name="title"&gt;</code>.</li>
<li>There are many <code>&lt;li slot="item"&gt;</code> in the template, but only one <code>&lt;slot name="item"&gt;</code> in the template. So all such <code>&lt;li slot="item"&gt;</code> are appended to <code>&lt;slot name="item"&gt;</code> one after another, thus forming the list.</li>
</ol>
<p>The flattened DOM becomes:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb247"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;custom-menu&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;style&gt;</span> <span class="co">/* menu styles */</span> <span class="kw">&lt;/style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-4" title="4">    <span class="kw">&lt;div</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;menu&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-5" title="5">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;title&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-6" title="6">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;title&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Candy menu<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-7" title="7">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-8" title="8">      <span class="kw">&lt;ul&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-9" title="9">        <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-10" title="10">          <span class="kw">&lt;li</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Lollipop<span class="kw">&lt;/li&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-11" title="11">          <span class="kw">&lt;li</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Fruit Toast<span class="kw">&lt;/li&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-12" title="12">          <span class="kw">&lt;li</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;item&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Cup Cake<span class="kw">&lt;/li&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-13" title="13">        <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-14" title="14">      <span class="kw">&lt;/ul&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-15" title="15">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb247-16" title="16"><span class="kw">&lt;/custom-menu&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>One might notice that, in a valid DOM, <code>&lt;li&gt;</code> must be a direct child of <code>&lt;ul&gt;</code>. But that‚Äôs flattened DOM, it describes how the component is rendered, such thing happens naturally here.</p>
<p>We just need to add a <code>click</code> handler to open/close the list, and the <code>&lt;custom-menu&gt;</code> is ready:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb248"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-1" title="1"><span class="va">customElements</span>.<span class="at">define</span>(<span class="st">&#39;custom-menu&#39;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">class</span> <span class="kw">extends</span> HTMLElement <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-2" title="2">  <span class="at">connectedCallback</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="at">attachShadow</span>(<span class="op">{</span><span class="dt">mode</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&#39;open&#39;</span><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-5" title="5">    <span class="co">// tmpl is the shadow DOM template (above)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-6" title="6">    <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="va">shadowRoot</span>.<span class="at">append</span>( <span class="va">tmpl</span>.<span class="va">content</span>.<span class="at">cloneNode</span>(<span class="kw">true</span>) )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-8" title="8">    <span class="co">// we can&#39;t select light DOM nodes, so let&#39;s handle clicks on the slot</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-9" title="9">    <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="va">shadowRoot</span>.<span class="at">querySelector</span>(<span class="st">&#39;slot[name=&quot;title&quot;]&#39;</span>).<span class="at">onclick</span> <span class="op">=</span> () <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-10" title="10">      <span class="co">// open/close the menu</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-11" title="11">      <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="va">shadowRoot</span>.<span class="at">querySelector</span>(<span class="st">&#39;.menu&#39;</span>).<span class="va">classList</span>.<span class="at">toggle</span>(<span class="st">&#39;closed&#39;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-12" title="12">    <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-13" title="13">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb248-14" title="14"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full demo:</p>
<p>[iframe src=‚Äúmenu‚Äù height=140 edit]</p>
<p>Of course, we can add more functionality to it: events, methods and so on.</p>
<h2 id="updating-slots">Updating slots</h2>
<p>What if the outer code wants to add/remove menu items dynamically?</p>
<p><strong>The browser monitors slots and updates the rendering if slotted elements are added/removed.</strong></p>
<p>Also, as light DOM nodes are not copied, but just rendered in slots, the changes inside them immediately become visible.</p>
<p>So we don‚Äôt have to do anything to update rendering. But if the component code wants to know about slot changes, then <code>slotchange</code> event is available.</p>
<p>For example, here the menu item is inserted dynamically after 1 second, and the title changes after 2 seconds:</p>
<p>```html run untrusted height=80 <custom-menu id="menu"> <span slot="title">Candy menu</span> </custom-menu></p>
<script>
customElements.define('custom-menu', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `<div class="menu">
      <slot name="title"></slot>
      <ul><slot name="item"></slot></ul>
    </div>`;

    // shadowRoot can't have event handlers, so using the first child
    this.shadowRoot.firstElementChild.addEventListener('slotchange',
      e => alert("slotchange: " + e.target.name)
    );
  }
});

setTimeout(() => {
  menu.insertAdjacentHTML('beforeEnd', '<li slot="item">Lollipop</li>')
}, 1000);

setTimeout(() => {
  menu.querySelector('[slot="title"]').innerHTML = "New menu";
}, 2000);
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>The menu rendering updates each time without our intervention.</p>
<p>There are two <code>slotchange</code> events here:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>At initialization:</p>
<code>slotchange: title</code> triggers immediately, as the <code>slot="title"</code> from the light DOM gets into the corresponding slot.</li>
<li><p>After 1 second:</p>
<p><code>slotchange: item</code> triggers, when a new <code>&lt;li slot="item"&gt;</code> is added.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Please note: there‚Äôs no <code>slotchange</code> event after 2 seconds, when the content of <code>slot="title"</code> is modified. That‚Äôs because there‚Äôs no slot change. We modify the content inside the slotted element, that‚Äôs another thing.</p>
<p>If we‚Äôd like to track internal modifications of light DOM from JavaScript, that‚Äôs also possible using a more generic mechanism: <a href="info:mutation-observer">MutationObserver</a>.</p>
<h2 id="slot-api">Slot API</h2>
<p>Finally, let‚Äôs mention the slot-related JavaScript methods.</p>
<p>As we‚Äôve seen before, JavaScript looks at the ‚Äúreal‚Äù DOM, without flattening. But, if the shadow tree has <code>{mode: 'open'}</code>, then we can figure out which elements assigned to a slot and, vise-versa, the slot by the element inside it:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>node.assignedSlot</code> ‚Äì returns the <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> element that the <code>node</code> is assigned to.</li>
<li><code>slot.assignedNodes({flatten: true/false})</code> ‚Äì DOM nodes, assigned to the slot. The <code>flatten</code> option is <code>false</code> by default. If explicitly set to <code>true</code>, then it looks more deeply into the flattened DOM, returning nested slots in case of nested components and the fallback content if no node assigned.</li>
<li><code>slot.assignedElements({flatten: true/false})</code> ‚Äì DOM elements, assigned to the slot (same as above, but only element nodes).</li>
</ul>
<p>These methods are useful when we need not just show the slotted content, but also track it in JavaScript.</p>
<p>For example, if <code>&lt;custom-menu&gt;</code> component wants to know, what it shows, then it could track <code>slotchange</code> and get the items from <code>slot.assignedElements</code>:</p>
```html run untrusted height=120 <custom-menu id="menu"> <span slot="title">Candy menu</span>
<li slot="item">
Lollipop
</li>
<li slot="item">
Fruit Toast
</li>
<p></custom-menu></p>
<script>
customElements.define('custom-menu', class extends HTMLElement {
  items = []

  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `<div class="menu">
      <slot name="title"></slot>
      <ul><slot name="item"></slot></ul>
    </div>`;

    // triggers when slot content changes
*!*
    this.shadowRoot.firstElementChild.addEventListener('slotchange', e => {
      let slot = e.target;
      if (slot.name == 'item') {
        this.items = slot.assignedElements().map(elem => elem.textContent);
        alert("Items: " + this.items);
      }
    });
*/!*
  }
});

// items update after 1 second
setTimeout(() => {
  menu.insertAdjacentHTML('beforeEnd', '<li slot="item">Cup Cake</li>')
}, 1000);
</script>
<p>```</p>
<h2 id="summary-25">Summary</h2>
<p>Usually, if an element has shadow DOM, then its light DOM is not displayed. Slots allow to show elements from light DOM in specified places of shadow DOM.</p>
<p>There are two kinds of slots:</p>
<ul>
<li>Named slots: <code>&lt;slot name="X"&gt;...&lt;/slot&gt;</code> ‚Äì gets light children with <code>slot="X"</code>.</li>
<li>Default slot: the first <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> without a name (subsequent unnamed slots are ignored) ‚Äì gets unslotted light children.</li>
<li>If there are many elements for the same slot ‚Äì they are appended one after another.</li>
<li>The content of <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> element is used as a fallback. It‚Äôs shown if there are no light children for the slot.</li>
</ul>
<p>The process of rendering slotted elements inside their slots is called ‚Äúcomposition‚Äù. The result is called a ‚Äúflattened DOM‚Äù.</p>
<p>Composition does not really move nodes, from JavaScript point of view the DOM is still same.</p>
<p>JavaScript can access slots using methods: - <code>slot.assignedNodes/Elements()</code> ‚Äì returns nodes/elements inside the <code>slot</code>. - <code>node.assignedSlot</code> ‚Äì the reverse property, returns slot by a node.</p>
<p>If we‚Äôd like to know what we‚Äôre showing, we can track slot contents using: - <code>slotchange</code> event ‚Äì triggers the first time a slot is filled, and on any add/remove/replace operation of the slotted element, but not its children. The slot is <code>event.target</code>. - <a href="info:mutation-observer">MutationObserver</a> to go deeper into slot content, watch changes inside it.</p>
<p>Now, as we know how to show elements from light DOM in shadow DOM, let‚Äôs see how to style them properly. The basic rule is that shadow elements are styled inside, and light elements ‚Äì outside, but there are notable exceptions.</p>
<p>We‚Äôll see the details in the next chapter. # Shadow DOM styling</p>
<p>Shadow DOM may include both <code>&lt;style&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;link rel="stylesheet" href="‚Ä¶"&gt;</code> tags. In the latter case, stylesheets are HTTP-cached, so they are not redownloaded for multiple components that use same template.</p>
<p>As a general rule, local styles work only inside the shadow tree, and document styles work outside of it. But there are few exceptions.</p>
<h2 id="host">:host</h2>
<p>The <code>:host</code> selector allows to select the shadow host (the element containing the shadow tree).</p>
<p>For instance, we‚Äôre making <code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> element that should be centered. For that we need to style the <code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> element itself.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs exactly what <code>:host</code> does:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=80 <template id="tmpl">
<style>
    /* the style will be applied from inside to the custom-dialog element */
    :host {
      position: fixed;
      left: 50%;
      top: 50%;
      transform: translate(-50%, -50%);
      display: inline-block;
      border: 1px solid red;
      padding: 10px;
    }
  </style>
<p><slot></slot> </template></p>
<script>
customElements.define('custom-dialog', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'}).append(tmpl.content.cloneNode(true));
  }
});
</script>
<p><custom-dialog> Hello! </custom-dialog> ```</p>
<h2 id="cascading">Cascading</h2>
<p>The shadow host (<code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> itself) resides in the light DOM, so it‚Äôs affected by document CSS rules.</p>
<p>If there‚Äôs a property styled both in <code>:host</code> locally, and in the document, then the document style takes precedence.</p>
<p>For instance, if in the document we had:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb249"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb249-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb249-2" title="2">custom-dialog {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb249-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">padding</span>: <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb249-4" title="4">}</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb249-5" title="5"><span class="kw">&lt;/style&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶Then the <code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> would be without padding.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs very convenient, as we can setup ‚Äúdefault‚Äù component styles in its <code>:host</code> rule, and then easily override them in the document.</p>
<p>The exception is when a local property is labelled <code>!important</code>, for such properties, local styles take precedence.</p>
<h2 id="hostselector">:host(selector)</h2>
<p>Same as <code>:host</code>, but applied only if the shadow host matches the <code>selector</code>.</p>
<p>For example, we‚Äôd like to center the <code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> only if it has <code>centered</code> attribute:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=80 <template id="tmpl">
<style>
*!*
    :host([centered]) {
*/!*
      position: fixed;
      left: 50%;
      top: 50%;
      transform: translate(-50%, -50%);
      border-color: blue;
    }

    :host {
      display: inline-block;
      border: 1px solid red;
      padding: 10px;
    }
  </style>
<p><slot></slot> </template></p>
<script>
customElements.define('custom-dialog', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'}).append(tmpl.content.cloneNode(true));
  }
});
</script>
<p><custom-dialog centered> Centered! </custom-dialog></p>
<p><custom-dialog> Not centered. </custom-dialog> ```</p>
<p>Now the additional centering styles are only applied to the first dialog: <code>&lt;custom-dialog centered&gt;</code>.</p>
<h2 id="host-contextselector">:host-context(selector)</h2>
<p>Same as <code>:host</code>, but applied only if the shadow host or any of its ancestors in the outer document matches the <code>selector</code>.</p>
<p>E.g. <code>:host-context(.dark-theme)</code> matches only if there‚Äôs <code>dark-theme</code> class on <code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> on anywhere above it:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb250"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb250-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;body</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;dark-theme&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb250-2" title="2">  <span class="co">&lt;!--</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb250-3" title="3"><span class="co">    :host-context(.dark-theme) applies to custom-dialogs inside .dark-theme</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb250-4" title="4"><span class="co">  --&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb250-5" title="5">  <span class="kw">&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</span>...<span class="kw">&lt;/custom-dialog&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb250-6" title="6"><span class="kw">&lt;/body&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>To summarize, we can use <code>:host</code>-family of selectors to style the main element of the component, depending on the context. These styles (unless <code>!important</code>) can be overridden by the document.</p>
<h2 id="styling-slotted-content">Styling slotted content</h2>
<p>Now let‚Äôs consider the situation with slots.</p>
<p>Slotted elements come from light DOM, so they use document styles. Local styles do not affect slotted content.</p>
In the example below, slotted <code>&lt;span&gt;</code> is bold, as per document style, but does not take <code>background</code> from the local style: ```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=80
<style>
*!*
  span { font-weight: bold }
*/!*
</style>
<user-card>
<div slot="username">
<em>!</em><span>John Smith</span><em>/!</em>
</div>
<p></user-card></p>
<script>
customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `
      <style>
*!*
      span { background: red; }
*/!*
      </style>
      Name: <slot name="username"></slot>
    `;
  }
});
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>The result is bold, but not red.</p>
<p>If we‚Äôd like to style slotted elements in our component, there are two choices.</p>
<p>First, we can style the <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> itself and rely on CSS inheritance:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=80 <user-card>
<div slot="username">
<em>!</em><span>John Smith</span><em>/!</em>
</div>
<p></user-card></p>
<script>
customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `
      <style>
*!*
      slot[name="username"] { font-weight: bold; }
*/!*
      </style>
      Name: <slot name="username"></slot>
    `;
  }
});
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>Here <code>&lt;p&gt;John Smith&lt;/p&gt;</code> becomes bold, because CSS inheritance is in effect between the <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> and its contents. But in CSS itself not all properties are inherited.</p>
<p>Another option is to use <code>::slotted(selector)</code> pseudo-class. It matches elements based on two conditions:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>That‚Äôs a slotted element, that comes from the light DOM. Slot name doesn‚Äôt matter. Just any slotted element, but only the element itself, not its children.</li>
<li>The element matches the <code>selector</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>In our example, <code>::slotted(div)</code> selects exactly <code>&lt;div slot="username"&gt;</code>, but not its children:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=80 <user-card>
<div slot="username">
<pre><code>&lt;div&gt;John Smith&lt;/div&gt;</code></pre>
</div>
<p></user-card></p>
<script>
customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `
      <style>
*!*
      ::slotted(div) { border: 1px solid red; }
*/!*
      </style>
      Name: <slot name="username"></slot>
    `;
  }
});
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>Please note, <code>::slotted</code> selector can‚Äôt descend any further into the slot. These selectors are invalid:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb252"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-1" title="1"><span class="in">::slotted(div span)</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-2" title="2">  <span class="co">/* our slotted &lt;div&gt; does not match this */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-3" title="3">}</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-5" title="5"><span class="in">::slotted(div)</span> p {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-6" title="6">  <span class="co">/* can&#39;t go inside light DOM */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb252-7" title="7">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>Also, <code>::slotted</code> can only be used in CSS. We can‚Äôt use it in <code>querySelector</code>.</p>
<h2 id="css-hooks-with-custom-properties">CSS hooks with custom properties</h2>
<p>How do we style internal elements of a component from the main document?</p>
<p>Selectors like <code>:host</code> apply rules to <code>&lt;custom-dialog&gt;</code> element or <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code>, but how to style shadow DOM elements inside them?</p>
<p>There‚Äôs no selector that can directly affect shadow DOM styles from the document. But just as we expose methods to interact with our component, we can expose CSS variables (custom CSS properties) to style it.</p>
<p><strong>Custom CSS properties exist on all levels, both in light and shadow.</strong></p>
<p>For example, in shadow DOM we can use <code>--user-card-field-color</code> CSS variable to style fields, and the outer document can set its value:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb253"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-2" title="2">  <span class="fu">.field</span> {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">color</span>: <span class="fu">var(</span><span class="va">--user-card-field-color</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="cn">black</span><span class="fu">)</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-4" title="4">    <span class="co">/* if --user-card-field-color is not defined, use black color */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-5" title="5">  }</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-6" title="6"><span class="kw">&lt;/style&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-7" title="7"><span class="kw">&lt;div</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;field&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Name: <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb253-8" title="8"><span class="kw">&lt;div</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;field&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>Birthday: <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;birthday&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;&lt;/slot&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Then, we can declare this property in the outer document for <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb254"><pre class="sourceCode css"><code class="sourceCode css"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb254-1" title="1">user-card {</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb254-2" title="2">  <span class="va">--user-card-field-color</span>: <span class="cn">green</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb254-3" title="3">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>Custom CSS properties pierce through shadow DOM, they are visible everywhere, so the inner <code>.field</code> rule will make use of it.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full example:</p>
```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=80
<style>
*!*
  user-card {
    --user-card-field-color: green;
  }
*/!*
</style>
<template id="tmpl">
<style>
*!*
    .field {
      color: var(--user-card-field-color, black);
    }
*/!*
  </style>
<div class="field">
Name: <slot name="username"></slot>
</div>
<div class="field">
Birthday: <slot name="birthday"></slot>
</div>
<p></template></p>
<script>
customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.append(document.getElementById('tmpl').content.cloneNode(true));
  }
});
</script>
<p><user-card> <span slot="username">John Smith</span> <span slot="birthday">01.01.2001</span> </user-card> ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-26">Summary</h2>
<p>Shadow DOM can include styles, such as <code>&lt;style&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;link rel="stylesheet"&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>Local styles can affect: - shadow tree, - shadow host with <code>:host</code>-family pseudoclasses, - slotted elements (coming from light DOM), <code>::slotted(selector)</code> allows to select slotted elements themselves, but not their children.</p>
<p>Document styles can affect: - shadow host (as it lives in the outer document) - slotted elements and their contents (as that‚Äôs also in the outer document)</p>
<p>When CSS properties conflict, normally document styles have precedence, unless the property is labelled as <code>!important</code>. Then local styles have precedence.</p>
<p>CSS custom properties pierce through shadow DOM. They are used as ‚Äúhooks‚Äù to style the component:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The component uses a custom CSS property to style key elements, such as <code>var(--component-name-title, &lt;default value&gt;)</code>.</li>
<li>Component author publishes these properties for developers, they are same important as other public component methods.</li>
<li>When a developer wants to style a title, they assign <code>--component-name-title</code> CSS property for the shadow host or above.</li>
<li>Profit! # Shadow DOM and events</li>
</ol>
<p>The idea behind shadow tree is to encapsulate internal implementation details of a component.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs say, a click event happens inside a shadow DOM of <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code> component. But scripts in the main document have no idea about the shadow DOM internals, especially if the component comes from a 3rd-party library.</p>
<p>So, to keep the details encapsulated, the browser <em>retargets</em> the event.</p>
<p><strong>Events that happen in shadow DOM have the host element as the target, when caught outside of the component.</strong></p>
<p>Here‚Äôs a simple example:</p>
<p>```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=60 <user-card></user-card></p>
<script>
customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `<p>
      <button>Click me</button>
    </p>`;
    this.shadowRoot.firstElementChild.onclick =
      e => alert("Inner target: " + e.target.tagName);
  }
});

document.onclick =
  e => alert("Outer target: " + e.target.tagName);
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>If you click on the button, the messages are:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Inner target: <code>BUTTON</code> ‚Äì internal event handler gets the correct target, the element inside shadow DOM.</li>
<li>Outer target: <code>USER-CARD</code> ‚Äì document event handler gets shadow host as the target.</li>
</ol>
<p>Event retargeting is a great thing to have, because the outer document doesn‚Äôt have to know about component internals. From its point of view, the event happened on <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code>.</p>
<p><strong>Retargeting does not occur if the event occurs on a slotted element, that physically lives in the light DOM.</strong></p>
<p>For example, if a user clicks on <code>&lt;span slot="username"&gt;</code> in the example below, the event target is exactly this <code>span</code> element, for both shadow and light handlers:</p>
<p>```html run autorun=‚Äúno-epub‚Äù untrusted height=60 <user-card id="userCard"> <em>!</em> <span slot="username">John Smith</span> <em>/!</em> </user-card></p>
<script>
customElements.define('user-card', class extends HTMLElement {
  connectedCallback() {
    this.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});
    this.shadowRoot.innerHTML = `<div>
      <b>Name:</b> <slot name="username"></slot>
    </div>`;

    this.shadowRoot.firstElementChild.onclick =
      e => alert("Inner target: " + e.target.tagName);
  }
});

userCard.onclick = e => alert(`Outer target: ${e.target.tagName}`);
</script>
<p>```</p>
<p>If a click happens on <code>"John Smith"</code>, for both inner and outer handlers the target is <code>&lt;span slot="username"&gt;</code>. That‚Äôs an element from the light DOM, so no retargeting.</p>
<p>On the other hand, if the click occurs on an element originating from shadow DOM, e.g.¬†on <code>&lt;b&gt;Name&lt;/b&gt;</code>, then, as it bubbles out of the shadow DOM, its <code>event.target</code> is reset to <code>&lt;user-card&gt;</code>.</p>
<h2 id="bubbling-event.composedpath">Bubbling, event.composedPath()</h2>
<p>For purposes of event bubbling, flattened DOM is used.</p>
<p>So, if we have a slotted element, and an event occurs somewhere inside it, then it bubbles up to the <code>&lt;slot&gt;</code> and upwards.</p>
<p>The full path to the original event target, with all the shadow elements, can be obtained using <code>event.composedPath()</code>. As we can see from the name of the method, that path is taken after the composition.</p>
<p>In the example above, the flattened DOM is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb255"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;user-card</span><span class="ot"> id=</span><span class="st">&quot;userCard&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-2" title="2">  #shadow-root</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-3" title="3">    <span class="kw">&lt;div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-4" title="4">      <span class="kw">&lt;b&gt;</span>Name:<span class="kw">&lt;/b&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-5" title="5">      <span class="kw">&lt;slot</span><span class="ot"> name=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-6" title="6">        <span class="kw">&lt;span</span><span class="ot"> slot=</span><span class="st">&quot;username&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>John Smith<span class="kw">&lt;/span&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-7" title="7">      <span class="kw">&lt;/slot&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-8" title="8">    <span class="kw">&lt;/div&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb255-9" title="9"><span class="kw">&lt;/user-card&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So, for a click on <code>&lt;span slot="username"&gt;</code>, a call to <code>event.composedPath()</code> returns an array: [<code>span</code>, <code>slot</code>, <code>div</code>, <code>shadow-root</code>, <code>user-card</code>, <code>body</code>, <code>html</code>, <code>document</code>, <code>window</code>]. That‚Äôs exactly the parent chain from the target element in the flattened DOM, after the composition.</p>
<p>``<code>warn header="Shadow tree details are only provided for</code>{mode:‚Äòopen‚Äô}<code>trees" If the shadow tree was created with</code>{mode: ‚Äòclosed‚Äô}<code>, then the composed path starts from the host:</code>user-card` and upwards.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs the similar principle as for other methods that work with shadow DOM. Internals of closed trees are completely hidden. ```</p>
<h2 id="event.composed">event.composed</h2>
<p>Most events successfully bubble through a shadow DOM boundary. There are few events that do not.</p>
<p>This is governed by the <code>composed</code> event object property. If it‚Äôs <code>true</code>, then the event does cross the boundary. Otherwise, it only can be caught from inside the shadow DOM.</p>
<p>If you take a look at <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/uievents">UI Events specification</a>, most events have <code>composed: true</code>:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>blur</code>, <code>focus</code>, <code>focusin</code>, <code>focusout</code>,</li>
<li><code>click</code>, <code>dblclick</code>,</li>
<li><code>mousedown</code>, <code>mouseup</code> <code>mousemove</code>, <code>mouseout</code>, <code>mouseover</code>,</li>
<li><code>wheel</code>,</li>
<li><code>beforeinput</code>, <code>input</code>, <code>keydown</code>, <code>keyup</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>All touch events and pointer events also have <code>composed: true</code>.</p>
<p>There are some events that have <code>composed: false</code> though:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>mouseenter</code>, <code>mouseleave</code> (they do not bubble at all),</li>
<li><code>load</code>, <code>unload</code>, <code>abort</code>, <code>error</code>,</li>
<li><code>select</code>,</li>
<li><code>slotchange</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>These events can be caught only on elements within the same DOM, where the event target resides.</p>
<h2 id="custom-events">Custom events</h2>
<p>When we dispatch custom events, we need to set both <code>bubbles</code> and <code>composed</code> properties to <code>true</code> for it to bubble up and out of the component.</p>
<p>For example, here we create <code>div#inner</code> in the shadow DOM of <code>div#outer</code> and trigger two events on it. Only the one with <code>composed: true</code> makes it outside to the document:</p>
```html run untrusted height=0
<div id="outer">

</div>
<script>
outer.attachShadow({mode: 'open'});

let inner = document.createElement('div');
outer.shadowRoot.append(inner);

/*
div(id=outer)
  #shadow-dom
    div(id=inner)
*/

document.addEventListener('test', event => alert(event.detail));

inner.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('test', {
  bubbles: true,
*!*
  composed: true,
*/!*
  detail: "composed"
}));

inner.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('test', {
  bubbles: true,
*!*
  composed: false,
*/!*
  detail: "not composed"
}));
</script>
<p>```</p>
<h2 id="summary-27">Summary</h2>
<p>Events only cross shadow DOM boundaries if their <code>composed</code> flag is set to <code>true</code>.</p>
<p>Built-in events mostly have <code>composed: true</code>, as described in the relevant specifications:</p>
<ul>
<li>UI Events <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/uievents" class="uri">https://www.w3.org/TR/uievents</a>.</li>
<li>Touch Events <a href="https://w3c.github.io/touch-events" class="uri">https://w3c.github.io/touch-events</a>.</li>
<li>Pointer Events <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/pointerevents" class="uri">https://www.w3.org/TR/pointerevents</a>.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶And so on.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some built-in events that have <code>composed: false</code>:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>mouseenter</code>, <code>mouseleave</code> (also do not bubble),</li>
<li><code>load</code>, <code>unload</code>, <code>abort</code>, <code>error</code>,</li>
<li><code>select</code>,</li>
<li><code>slotchange</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>These events can be caught only on elements within the same DOM.</p>
<p>If we dispatch a <code>CustomEvent</code>, then we should explicitly set <code>composed: true</code>.</p>
<p>Please note that in case of nested components, one shadow DOM may be nested into another. In that case composed events bubble through all shadow DOM boundaries. So, if an event is intended only for the immediate enclosing component, we can also dispatch it on the shadow host and set <code>composed: false</code>. Then it‚Äôs out of the component shadow DOM, but won‚Äôt bubble up to higher-level DOM. # Patterns and flags</p>
<p>Regular expressions are patterns that provide a powerful way to search and replace in text.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, they are available via the <a href="mdn:js/RegExp">RegExp</a> object, as well as being integrated in methods of strings.</p>
<h2 id="regular-expressions">Regular Expressions</h2>
<p>A regular expression (also ‚Äúregexp‚Äù, or just ‚Äúreg‚Äù) consists of a <em>pattern</em> and optional <em>flags</em>.</p>
<p>There are two syntaxes that can be used to create a regular expression object.</p>
<p>The ‚Äúlong‚Äù syntax:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb256"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb256-1" title="1">regexp <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">RegExp</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pattern&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;flags&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>And the ‚Äúshort‚Äù one, using slashes <code>"/"</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb257"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb257-1" title="1">regexp <span class="op">=</span> <span class="ss">/pattern/</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// no flags</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb257-2" title="2">regexp <span class="op">=</span> <span class="ss">/pattern/gmi</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// with flags g,m and i (to be covered soon)</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Slashes <code>pattern:/.../</code> tell JavaScript that we are creating a regular expression. They play the same role as quotes for strings.</p>
<p>In both cases <code>regexp</code> becomes an instance of the built-in <code>RegExp</code> class.</p>
<p>The main difference between these two syntaxes is that pattern using slashes <code>/.../</code> does not allow for expressions to be inserted (like string template literals with <code>${...}</code>). They are fully static.</p>
<p>Slashes are used when we know the regular expression at the code writing time ‚Äì and that‚Äôs the most common situation. While <code>new RegExp</code> is more often used when we need to create a regexp ‚Äúon the fly‚Äù from a dynamically generated string. For instance:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb258"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb258-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> tag <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">prompt</span>(<span class="st">&quot;What tag do you want to find?&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="st">&quot;h2&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb258-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb258-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> regexp <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">RegExp</span>(<span class="vs">`&lt;</span><span class="sc">${</span>tag<span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">&gt;`</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// same as /&lt;h2&gt;/ if answered &quot;h2&quot; in the prompt above</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="flags">Flags</h2>
<p>Regular expressions may have flags that affect the search.</p>
<p>There are only 6 of them in JavaScript:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>pattern:i</code></dt>
<dd>With this flag the search is case-insensitive: no difference between <code>A</code> and <code>a</code> (see the example below).
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:g</code></dt>
<dd>With this flag the search looks for all matches, without it ‚Äì only the first match is returned.
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:m</code></dt>
<dd>Multiline mode (covered in the chapter <a href="info:regexp-multiline-mode" class="uri">info:regexp-multiline-mode</a>).
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:s</code></dt>
<dd>Enables ‚Äúdotall‚Äù mode, that allows a dot <code>pattern:.</code> to match newline character <code>\n</code> (covered in the chapter <a href="info:regexp-character-classes" class="uri">info:regexp-character-classes</a>).
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:u</code></dt>
<dd>Enables full Unicode support. The flag enables correct processing of surrogate pairs. More about that in the chapter <a href="info:regexp-unicode" class="uri">info:regexp-unicode</a>.
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:y</code></dt>
<dd>‚ÄúSticky‚Äù mode: searching at the exact position in the text (covered in the chapter <a href="info:regexp-sticky" class="uri">info:regexp-sticky</a>)
</dd>
</dl>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúColors‚Äù From here on the color scheme is:</p>
<ul>
<li>regexp ‚Äì <code>pattern:red</code></li>
<li>string (where we search) ‚Äì <code>subject:blue</code></li>
<li>result ‚Äì <code>match:green</code> ```</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="searching-str.match">Searching: str.match</h2>
<p>As mentioned previously, regular expressions are integrated with string methods.</p>
<p>The method <code>str.match(regexp)</code> finds all matches of <code>regexp</code> in the string <code>str</code>.</p>
<p>It has 3 working modes:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>If the regular expression has flag <code>pattern:g</code>, it returns an array of all matches: ```js run let str = ‚ÄúWe will, we will rock you‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/we/gi) ); // We,we (an array of 2 substrings that match) ``<code>Please note that both</code>match:We<code>and</code>match:we<code>are found, because flag</code>pattern:i` makes the regular expression case-insensitive.</p></li>
<li><p>If there‚Äôs no such flag it returns only the first match in the form of an array, with the full match at index <code>0</code> and some additional details in properties: ```js run let str = ‚ÄúWe will, we will rock you‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.match(/we/i); // without flag g</p>
<p>alert( result[0] ); // We (1st match) alert( result.length ); // 1</p>
<p>// Details: alert( result.index ); // 0 (position of the match) alert( result.input ); // We will, we will rock you (source string) ``<code>The array may have other indexes, besides</code>0` if a part of the regular expression is enclosed in parentheses. We‚Äôll cover that in the chapter <a href="info:regexp-groups" class="uri">info:regexp-groups</a>.</p></li>
<li><p>And, finally, if there are no matches, <code>null</code> is returned (doesn‚Äôt matter if there‚Äôs flag <code>pattern:g</code> or not).</p>
<p>This a very important nuance. If there are no matches, we don‚Äôt receive an empty array, but instead receive <code>null</code>. Forgetting about that may lead to errors, e.g.:</p>
<p>```js run let matches = ‚ÄúJavaScript‚Äù.match(/HTML/); // = null</p>
<p>if (!matches.length) { // Error: Cannot read property ‚Äòlength‚Äô of null alert(‚ÄúError in the line above‚Äù); } ```</p>
<p>If we‚Äôd like the result to always be an array, we can write it this way:</p>
<p>```js run let matches = ‚ÄúJavaScript‚Äù.match(/HTML/)<em>!</em> || []<em>/!</em>;</p>
<p>if (!matches.length) { alert(‚ÄúNo matches‚Äù); // now it works } ```</p></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="replacing-str.replace">Replacing: str.replace</h2>
<p>The method <code>str.replace(regexp, replacement)</code> replaces matches found using <code>regexp</code> in string <code>str</code> with <code>replacement</code> (all matches if there‚Äôs flag <code>pattern:g</code>, otherwise, only the first one).</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run // no flag g alert( ‚ÄúWe will, we will‚Äù.replace(/we/i, ‚ÄúI‚Äù) ); // I will, we will</p>
<p>// with flag g alert( ‚ÄúWe will, we will‚Äù.replace(/we/ig, ‚ÄúI‚Äù) ); // I will, I will ```</p>
<p>The second argument is the <code>replacement</code> string. We can use special character combinations in it to insert fragments of the match:</p>
<table>
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 50%" />
<col style="width: 50%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>Symbols</th>
<th>Action in the replacement string</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>$&amp;</code></td>
<td>inserts the whole match</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code><span class="math inline">$&amp;#096;&lt;/code&gt;|inserts a part of the string before the match| |`$</span>‚Äô<code>|inserts a part of the string after the match| |</code><span class="math inline">$n`|if `n` is a 1-2 digit number, then it inserts the contents of n-th parentheses, more about it in the chapter &lt;info:regexp-groups&gt;| |`$</span><name><code>|inserts the contents of the parentheses with the given</code>name<code>, more about it in the chapter &lt;info:regexp-groups&gt;| |</code>$<span class="math inline">$`|inserts character `$</span>`</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>An example with <code>pattern:$&amp;</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "I love HTML".replace(/HTML/, "$&amp; and JavaScript") ); // I love HTML and JavaScript</code></p>
<h2 id="testing-regexp.test">Testing: regexp.test</h2>
<p>The method <code>regexp.test(str)</code> looks for at least one match, if found, returns <code>true</code>, otherwise <code>false</code>.</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúI love JavaScript‚Äù; let regexp = /LOVE/i;</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(str) ); // true ```</p>
<p>Later in this chapter we‚Äôll study more regular expressions, walk through more examples, and also meet other methods.</p>
<p>Full information about the methods is given in the article <a href="info:regexp-methods" class="uri">info:regexp-methods</a>.</p>
<h2 id="summary-28">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>A regular expression consists of a pattern and optional flags: <code>pattern:g</code>, <code>pattern:i</code>, <code>pattern:m</code>, <code>pattern:u</code>, <code>pattern:s</code>, <code>pattern:y</code>.</li>
<li>Without flags and special symbols (that we‚Äôll study later), the search by a regexp is the same as a substring search.</li>
<li>The method <code>str.match(regexp)</code> looks for matches: all of them if there‚Äôs <code>pattern:g</code> flag, otherwise, only the first one.</li>
<li>The method <code>str.replace(regexp, replacement)</code> replaces matches found using <code>regexp</code> with <code>replacement</code>: all of them if there‚Äôs <code>pattern:g</code> flag, otherwise only the first one.</li>
<li>The method <code>regexp.test(str)</code> returns <code>true</code> if there‚Äôs at least one match, otherwise, it returns <code>false</code>. # Character classes</li>
</ul>
<p>Consider a practical task ‚Äì we have a phone number like <code>"+7(903)-123-45-67"</code>, and we need to turn it into pure numbers: <code>79031234567</code>.</p>
<p>To do so, we can find and remove anything that‚Äôs not a number. Character classes can help with that.</p>
<p>A <em>character class</em> is a special notation that matches any symbol from a certain set.</p>
<p>For the start, let‚Äôs explore the ‚Äúdigit‚Äù class. It‚Äôs written as <code>pattern:\d</code> and corresponds to ‚Äúany single digit‚Äù.</p>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs find the first digit in the phone number:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú+7(903)-123-45-67‚Äù;</p>
<p>let regexp = /;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // 7 ```</p>
<p>Without the flag <code>pattern:g</code>, the regular expression only looks for the first match, that is the first digit <code>pattern:\d</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs add the <code>pattern:g</code> flag to find all digits:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú+7(903)-123-45-67‚Äù;</p>
<p>let regexp = /g;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // array of matches: 7,9,0,3,1,2,3,4,5,6,7</p>
<p>// let‚Äôs make the digits-only phone number of them: alert( str.match(regexp).join(‚Äô‚Äô) ); // 79031234567 ```</p>
<p>That was a character class for digits. There are other character classes as well.</p>
<p>Most used are:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>pattern:\d</code> (‚Äúd‚Äù is from ‚Äúdigit‚Äù)</dt>
<dd>A digit: a character from <code>0</code> to <code>9</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:\s</code> (‚Äús‚Äù is from ‚Äúspace‚Äù)</dt>
<dd>A space symbol: includes spaces, tabs <code>\t</code>, newlines <code>\n</code> and few other rare characters, such as <code>\v</code>, <code>\f</code> and <code>\r</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:\w</code> (‚Äúw‚Äù is from ‚Äúword‚Äù)</dt>
<dd>A ‚Äúwordly‚Äù character: either a letter of Latin alphabet or a digit or an underscore <code>_</code>. Non-Latin letters (like cyrillic or hindi) do not belong to <code>pattern:\w</code>.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>For instance, <code>pattern:\d\s\w</code> means a ‚Äúdigit‚Äù followed by a ‚Äúspace character‚Äù followed by a ‚Äúwordly character‚Äù, such as <code>match:1 a</code>.</p>
<p><strong>A regexp may contain both regular symbols and character classes.</strong></p>
<p>For instance, <code>pattern:CSS\d</code> matches a string <code>match:CSS</code> with a digit after it:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúIs there CSS4?‚Äù; let regexp = /CSS</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // CSS4 ```</p>
<p>Also we can use many character classes:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "I love HTML5!".match(/\s\w\w\w\w\d/) ); // ' HTML5'</code></p>
<p>The match (each regexp character class has the corresponding result character):</p>
<p><img src="love-html5-classes.svg" /></p>
<h2 id="inverse-classes">Inverse classes</h2>
<p>For every character class there exists an ‚Äúinverse class‚Äù, denoted with the same letter, but uppercased.</p>
<p>The ‚Äúinverse‚Äù means that it matches all other characters, for instance:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>pattern:\D</code></dt>
<dd>Non-digit: any character except <code>pattern:\d</code>, for instance a letter.
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:\S</code></dt>
<dd>Non-space: any character except <code>pattern:\s</code>, for instance a letter.
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:\W</code></dt>
<dd>Non-wordly character: anything but <code>pattern:\w</code>, e.g a non-latin letter or a space.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>In the beginning of the chapter we saw how to make a number-only phone number from a string like <code>subject:+7(903)-123-45-67</code>: find all digits and join them.</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú+7(903)-123-45-67‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/g).join(‚Äô‚Äô) ); // 79031234567 ```</p>
<p>An alternative, shorter way is to find non-digits <code>pattern:\D</code> and remove them from the string:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú+7(903)-123-45-67‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.replace(//g, "") ); // 79031234567 ```</p>
<h2 id="a-dot-is-any-character">A dot is ‚Äúany character‚Äù</h2>
<p>A dot <code>pattern:.</code> is a special character class that matches ‚Äúany character except a newline‚Äù.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "Z".match(/./) ); // Z</code></p>
<p>Or in the middle of a regexp:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /CS.4/;</p>
<p>alert( ‚ÄúCSS4‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // CSS4 alert( ‚ÄúCS-4‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // CS-4 alert( ‚ÄúCS 4‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // CS 4 (space is also a character) ```</p>
<p>Please note that a dot means ‚Äúany character‚Äù, but not the ‚Äúabsence of a character‚Äù. There must be a character to match it:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "CS4".match(/CS.4/) ); // null, no match because there's no character for the dot</code></p>
<h3 id="dot-as-literally-any-character-with-s-flag">Dot as literally any character with ‚Äús‚Äù flag</h3>
<p>By default, a dot doesn‚Äôt match the newline character <code>\n</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, the regexp <code>pattern:A.B</code> matches <code>match:A</code>, and then <code>match:B</code> with any character between them, except a newline <code>\n</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "A\nB".match(/A.B/) ); // null (no match)</code></p>
<p>There are many situations when we‚Äôd like a dot to mean literally ‚Äúany character‚Äù, newline included.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs what flag <code>pattern:s</code> does. If a regexp has it, then a dot <code>pattern:.</code> matches literally any character:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "A\nB".match(/A.B/s) ); // A\nB (match!)</code></p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Not supported in IE" The</code>pattern:s` flag is not supported in IE.</p>
<p>Luckily, there‚Äôs an alternative, that works everywhere. We can use a regexp like <code>pattern:[\s\S]</code> to match ‚Äúany character‚Äù (this pattern will be covered in the article <a href="info:regexp-character-sets-and-ranges" class="uri">info:regexp-character-sets-and-ranges</a>).</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "A\nB".match(/A[\s\S]B/) ); // A\nB (match!)</code></p>
<p>The pattern <code>pattern:[\s\S]</code> literally says: ‚Äúa space character OR not a space character‚Äù. In other words, ‚Äúanything‚Äù. We could use another pair of complementary classes, such as <code>pattern:[\d\D]</code>, that doesn‚Äôt matter. Or even the <code>pattern:[^]</code> ‚Äì as it means match any character except nothing.</p>
<p>Also we can use this trick if we want both kind of ‚Äúdots‚Äù in the same pattern: the actual dot <code>pattern:.</code> behaving the regular way (‚Äúnot including a newline‚Äù), and also a way to match ‚Äúany character‚Äù with <code>pattern:[\s\S]</code> or alike. ````</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Pay attention to spaces" Usually we pay little attention to spaces. For us strings</code>subject:1-5<code>and</code>subject:1 - 5` are nearly identical.</p>
<p>But if a regexp doesn‚Äôt take spaces into account, it may fail to work.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs try to find digits separated by a hyphen:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "1 - 5".match(/\d-\d/) ); // null, no match!</code></p>
<p>Let‚Äôs fix it adding spaces into the regexp <code>pattern:\d - \d</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "1 - 5".match(/\d - \d/) ); // 1 - 5, now it works // or we can use \s class: alert( "1 - 5".match(/\d\s-\s\d/) ); // 1 - 5, also works</code></p>
<p><strong>A space is a character. Equal in importance with any other character.</strong></p>
<p>We can‚Äôt add or remove spaces from a regular expression and expect it to work the same.</p>
<p>In other words, in a regular expression all characters matter, spaces too. ````</p>
<h2 id="summary-29">Summary</h2>
<p>There exist following character classes:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>pattern:\d</code> ‚Äì digits.</li>
<li><code>pattern:\D</code> ‚Äì non-digits.</li>
<li><code>pattern:\s</code> ‚Äì space symbols, tabs, newlines.</li>
<li><code>pattern:\S</code> ‚Äì all but <code>pattern:\s</code>.</li>
<li><code>pattern:\w</code> ‚Äì Latin letters, digits, underscore <code>'_'</code>.</li>
<li><code>pattern:\W</code> ‚Äì all but <code>pattern:\w</code>.</li>
<li><code>pattern:.</code> ‚Äì any character if with the regexp <code>'s'</code> flag, otherwise any except a newline <code>\n</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>‚Ä¶But that‚Äôs not all!</p>
<p>Unicode encoding, used by JavaScript for strings, provides many properties for characters, like: which language the letter belongs to (if it‚Äôs a letter), is it a punctuation sign, etc.</p>
<p>We can search by these properties as well. That requires flag <code>pattern:u</code>, covered in the next article. # Unicode: flag ‚Äúu‚Äù and class </p>
<p>JavaScript uses <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode">Unicode encoding</a> for strings. Most characters are encoded with 2 bytes, but that allows to represent at most 65536 characters.</p>
<p>That range is not big enough to encode all possible characters, that‚Äôs why some rare characters are encoded with 4 bytes, for instance like <code>ùí≥</code> (mathematical X) or <code>üòÑ</code> (a smile), some hieroglyphs and so on.</p>
<p>Here are the Unicode values of some characters:</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>Character</th>
<th>Unicode</th>
<th>Bytes count in Unicode</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td>a</td>
<td><code>0x0061</code></td>
<td>2</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td>‚âà</td>
<td><code>0x2248</code></td>
<td>2</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td>ùí≥</td>
<td><code>0x1d4b3</code></td>
<td>4</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td>ùí¥</td>
<td><code>0x1d4b4</code></td>
<td>4</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td>üòÑ</td>
<td><code>0x1f604</code></td>
<td>4</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>So characters like <code>a</code> and <code>‚âà</code> occupy 2 bytes, while codes for <code>ùí≥</code>, <code>ùí¥</code> and <code>üòÑ</code> are longer, they have 4 bytes.</p>
<p>Long time ago, when JavaScript language was created, Unicode encoding was simpler: there were no 4-byte characters. So, some language features still handle them incorrectly.</p>
<p>For instance, <code>length</code> thinks that here are two characters:</p>
<p><code>js run alert('üòÑ'.length); // 2 alert('ùí≥'.length); // 2</code></p>
<p>‚Ä¶But we can see that there‚Äôs only one, right? The point is that <code>length</code> treats 4 bytes as two 2-byte characters. That‚Äôs incorrect, because they must be considered only together (so-called ‚Äúsurrogate pair‚Äù, you can read about them in the article <a href="info:string" class="uri">info:string</a>).</p>
<p>By default, regular expressions also treat 4-byte ‚Äúlong characters‚Äù as a pair of 2-byte ones. And, as it happens with strings, that may lead to odd results. We‚Äôll see that a bit later, in the article <a href="info:regexp-character-sets-and-ranges" class="uri">info:regexp-character-sets-and-ranges</a>.</p>
<p>Unlike strings, regular expressions have flag <code>pattern:u</code> that fixes such problems. With such flag, a regexp handles 4-byte characters correctly. And also Unicode property search becomes available, we‚Äôll get to it next.</p>
<h2 id="unicode-properties">Unicode properties </h2>
<p>Every character in Unicode has a lot of properties. They describe what ‚Äúcategory‚Äù the character belongs to, contain miscellaneous information about it.</p>
<p>For instance, if a character has <code>Letter</code> property, it means that the character belongs to an alphabet (of any language). And <code>Number</code> property means that it‚Äôs a digit: maybe Arabic or Chinese, and so on.</p>
<p>We can search for characters with a property, written as <code>pattern:\p{‚Ä¶}</code>. To use <code>pattern:\p{‚Ä¶}</code>, a regular expression must have flag <code>pattern:u</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, <code>\p{Letter}</code> denotes a letter in any language. We can also use <code>\p{L}</code>, as <code>L</code> is an alias of <code>Letter</code>. There are shorter aliases for almost every property.</p>
<p>In the example below three kinds of letters will be found: English, Georgian and Korean.</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúA ·Éë „Ñ±‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(//gu) ); // A,·Éë,„Ñ± alert( str.match(//g) ); // null (no matches, doesn‚Äôt work without the flag ‚Äúu‚Äù) ```</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the main character categories and their subcategories:</p>
<ul>
<li>Letter <code>L</code>:
<ul>
<li>lowercase <code>Ll</code></li>
<li>modifier <code>Lm</code>,</li>
<li>titlecase <code>Lt</code>,</li>
<li>uppercase <code>Lu</code>,</li>
<li>other <code>Lo</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Number <code>N</code>:
<ul>
<li>decimal digit <code>Nd</code>,</li>
<li>letter number <code>Nl</code>,</li>
<li>other <code>No</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Punctuation <code>P</code>:
<ul>
<li>connector <code>Pc</code>,</li>
<li>dash <code>Pd</code>,</li>
<li>initial quote <code>Pi</code>,</li>
<li>final quote <code>Pf</code>,</li>
<li>open <code>Ps</code>,</li>
<li>close <code>Pe</code>,</li>
<li>other <code>Po</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Mark <code>M</code> (accents etc):
<ul>
<li>spacing combining <code>Mc</code>,</li>
<li>enclosing <code>Me</code>,</li>
<li>non-spacing <code>Mn</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Symbol <code>S</code>:
<ul>
<li>currency <code>Sc</code>,</li>
<li>modifier <code>Sk</code>,</li>
<li>math <code>Sm</code>,</li>
<li>other <code>So</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Separator <code>Z</code>:
<ul>
<li>line <code>Zl</code>,</li>
<li>paragraph <code>Zp</code>,</li>
<li>space <code>Zs</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Other <code>C</code>:
<ul>
<li>control <code>Cc</code>,</li>
<li>format <code>Cf</code>,</li>
<li>not assigned <code>Cn</code>,</li>
<li>private use <code>Co</code>,</li>
<li>surrogate <code>Cs</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<p>So, e.g.¬†if we need letters in lower case, we can write <code>pattern:\p{Ll}</code>, punctuation signs: <code>pattern:\p{P}</code> and so on.</p>
<p>There are also other derived categories, like: - <code>Alphabetic</code> (<code>Alpha</code>), includes Letters <code>L</code>, plus letter numbers <code>Nl</code> (e.g.¬†‚Ö´ - a character for the roman number 12), plus some other symbols <code>Other_Alphabetic</code> (<code>OAlpha</code>). - <code>Hex_Digit</code> includes hexadecimal digits: <code>0-9</code>, <code>a-f</code>. - ‚Ä¶And so on.</p>
<p>Unicode supports many different properties, their full list would require a lot of space, so here are the references:</p>
<ul>
<li>List all properties by a character: <a href="https://unicode.org/cldr/utility/character.jsp" class="uri">https://unicode.org/cldr/utility/character.jsp</a>.</li>
<li>List all characters by a property: <a href="https://unicode.org/cldr/utility/list-unicodeset.jsp" class="uri">https://unicode.org/cldr/utility/list-unicodeset.jsp</a>.</li>
<li>Short aliases for properties: <a href="https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/PropertyValueAliases.txt" class="uri">https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/PropertyValueAliases.txt</a>.</li>
<li>A full base of Unicode characters in text format, with all properties, is here: <a href="https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/" class="uri">https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/</a>.</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="example-hexadecimal-numbers">Example: hexadecimal numbers</h3>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs look for hexadecimal numbers, written as <code>xFF</code>, where <code>F</code> is a hex digit (0..1 or A..F).</p>
<p>A hex digit can be denoted as <code>pattern:\p{Hex_Digit}</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /x/u;</p>
<p>alert(‚Äúnumber: xAF‚Äù.match(regexp)); // xAF ```</p>
<h3 id="example-chinese-hieroglyphs">Example: Chinese hieroglyphs</h3>
<p>Let‚Äôs look for Chinese hieroglyphs.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a Unicode property <code>Script</code> (a writing system), that may have a value: <code>Cyrillic</code>, <code>Greek</code>, <code>Arabic</code>, <code>Han</code> (Chinese) and so on, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Script_(Unicode)">here‚Äôs the full list</a>.</p>
<p>To look for characters in a given writing system we should use <code>pattern:Script=&lt;value&gt;</code>, e.g.¬†for Cyrillic letters: <code>pattern:\p{sc=Cyrillic}</code>, for Chinese hieroglyphs: <code>pattern:\p{sc=Han}</code>, and so on:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = //gu; // returns Chinese hieroglyphs</p>
<p>let str = <code>Hello –ü—Ä–∏–≤–µ—Ç ‰Ω†Â•Ω 123_456</code>;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‰Ω†,Â•Ω ```</p>
<h3 id="example-currency">Example: currency</h3>
<p>Characters that denote a currency, such as <code>$</code>, <code>‚Ç¨</code>, <code>¬•</code>, have Unicode property <code>pattern:\p{Currency_Symbol}</code>, the short alias: <code>pattern:\p{Sc}</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs use it to look for prices in the format ‚Äúcurrency, followed by a digit‚Äù:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /gu;</p>
<p>let str = <code>Prices: $2, ‚Ç¨1, ¬•9</code>;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // $2,‚Ç¨1,¬•9 ```</p>
<p>Later, in the article <a href="info:regexp-quantifiers" class="uri">info:regexp-quantifiers</a> we‚Äôll see how to look for numbers that contain many digits.</p>
<h2 id="summary-30">Summary</h2>
<p>Flag <code>pattern:u</code> enables the support of Unicode in regular expressions.</p>
<p>That means two things:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Characters of 4 bytes are handled correctly: as a single character, not two 2-byte characters.</li>
<li>Unicode properties can be used in the search: <code>\p{‚Ä¶}</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>With Unicode properties we can look for words in given languages, special characters (quotes, currencies) and so on. # Nullish coalescing operator ‚Äò??‚Äô</p>
<p>[recent browser=‚Äúnew‚Äù]</p>
<p>The nullish coalescing operator is written as two question marks <code>??</code>.</p>
<p>As it treats <code>null</code> and <code>undefined</code> similarly, we‚Äôll use a special term here, in this article. We‚Äôll say that an expression is ‚Äúdefined‚Äù when it‚Äôs neither <code>null</code> nor <code>undefined</code>.</p>
<p>The result of <code>a ?? b</code> is: - if <code>a</code> is defined, then <code>a</code>, - if <code>a</code> isn‚Äôt defined, then <code>b</code>.</p>
<p>In other words, <code>??</code> returns the first argument if it‚Äôs not <code>null/undefined</code>. Otherwise, the second one.</p>
<p>The nullish coalescing operator isn‚Äôt anything completely new. It‚Äôs just a nice syntax to get the first ‚Äúdefined‚Äù value of the two.</p>
<p>We can rewrite <code>result = a ?? b</code> using the operators that we already know, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb259"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb259-1" title="1">result <span class="op">=</span> (a <span class="op">!==</span> <span class="kw">null</span> <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span> a <span class="op">!==</span> <span class="kw">undefined</span>) <span class="op">?</span> a : b<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now it should be absolutely clear what <code>??</code> does. Let‚Äôs see where it helps.</p>
<p>The common use case for <code>??</code> is to provide a default value for a potentially undefined variable.</p>
<p>For example, here we show <code>user</code> if defined, otherwise <code>Anonymous</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let user;</p>
<p>alert(user ?? ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù); // Anonymous (user not defined) ```</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the example with <code>user</code> assigned to a name:</p>
<p>```js run let user = ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert(user ?? ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù); // John (user defined) ```</p>
<p>We can also use a sequence of <code>??</code> to select the first value from a list that isn‚Äôt <code>null/undefined</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs say we have a user‚Äôs data in variables <code>firstName</code>, <code>lastName</code> or <code>nickName</code>. All of them may be not defined, if the user decided not to enter a value.</p>
<p>We‚Äôd like to display the user name using one of these variables, or show ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù if all of them aren‚Äôt defined.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs use the <code>??</code> operator for that:</p>
<p>```js run let firstName = null; let lastName = null; let nickName = ‚ÄúSupercoder‚Äù;</p>
<p>// shows the first defined value: <em>!</em> alert(firstName ?? lastName ?? nickName ?? ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù); // Supercoder <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<h2 id="comparison-with">Comparison with ||</h2>
<p>The OR <code>||</code> operator can be used in the same way as <code>??</code>, as it was described in the <a href="info:logical-operators#or-finds-the-first-truthy-value">previous chapter</a>.</p>
<p>For example, in the code above we could replace <code>??</code> with <code>||</code> and still get the same result:</p>
<p>```js run let firstName = null; let lastName = null; let nickName = ‚ÄúSupercoder‚Äù;</p>
<p>// shows the first truthy value: <em>!</em> alert(firstName || lastName || nickName || ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù); // Supercoder <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Historically, the OR <code>||</code> operator was there first. It exists since the beginning of JavaScript, so developers were using it for such purposes for a long time.</p>
<p>On the other hand, the nullish coalescing operator <code>??</code> was added to JavaScript only recently, and the reason for that was that people weren‚Äôt quite happy with <code>||</code>.</p>
<p>The important difference between them is that: - <code>||</code> returns the first <em>truthy</em> value. - <code>??</code> returns the first <em>defined</em> value.</p>
<p>In other words, <code>||</code> doesn‚Äôt distinguish between <code>false</code>, <code>0</code>, an empty string <code>""</code> and <code>null/undefined</code>. They are all the same ‚Äì falsy values. If any of these is the first argument of <code>||</code>, then we‚Äôll get the second argument as the result.</p>
<p>In practice though, we may want to use default value only when the variable is <code>null/undefined</code>. That is, when the value is really unknown/not set.</p>
<p>For example, consider this:</p>
<p>```js run let height = 0;</p>
<p>alert(height || 100); // 100 alert(height ?? 100); // 0 ```</p>
<ul>
<li>The <code>height || 100</code> checks <code>height</code> for being a falsy value, and it‚Äôs <code>0</code>, falsy indeed.
<ul>
<li>so the result of <code>||</code> is the second argument, <code>100</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>The <code>height ?? 100</code> checks <code>height</code> for being <code>null/undefined</code>, and it‚Äôs not,
<ul>
<li>so the result is <code>height</code> ‚Äúas is‚Äù, that is <code>0</code>.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<p>In practice, the zero height is often a valid value, that shouldn‚Äôt be replaced with the default. So <code>??</code> does just the right thing.</p>
<h2 id="precedence">Precedence</h2>
<p>The precedence of the <code>??</code> operator is about the same as <code>||</code>, just a bit lower. It equals <code>5</code> in the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Operator_Precedence#Table">MDN table</a>, while <code>||</code> is <code>6</code>.</p>
<p>That means that, just like <code>||</code>, the nullish coalescing operator <code>??</code> is evaluated before <code>=</code> and <code>?</code>, but after most other operations, such as <code>+</code>, <code>*</code>.</p>
<p>So if we‚Äôd like to choose a value with <code>??</code> in an expression with other operators, consider adding parentheses:</p>
<p>```js run let height = null; let width = null;</p>
<p>// important: use parentheses let area = (height ?? 100) * (width ?? 50);</p>
<p>alert(area); // 5000 ```</p>
<p>Otherwise, if we omit parentheses, then as <code>*</code> has the higher precedence than <code>??</code>, it would execute first, leading to incorrect results.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb260"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb260-1" title="1"><span class="co">// without parentheses</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb260-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> area <span class="op">=</span> height <span class="op">??</span> <span class="dv">100</span> <span class="op">*</span> width <span class="op">??</span> <span class="dv">50</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb260-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb260-4" title="4"><span class="co">// ...works the same as this (probably not what we want):</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb260-5" title="5"><span class="kw">let</span> area <span class="op">=</span> height <span class="op">??</span> (<span class="dv">100</span> <span class="op">*</span> width) <span class="op">??</span> <span class="dv">50</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="using-with-or">Using ?? with &amp;&amp; or ||</h3>
<p>Due to safety reasons, JavaScript forbids using <code>??</code> together with <code>&amp;&amp;</code> and <code>||</code> operators, unless the precedence is explicitly specified with parentheses.</p>
<p>The code below triggers a syntax error:</p>
<p><code>js run let x = 1 &amp;&amp; 2 ?? 3; // Syntax error</code></p>
<p>The limitation is surely debatable, it was added to the language specification with the purpose to avoid programming mistakes, when people start to switch from <code>||</code> to <code>??</code>.</p>
<p>Use explicit parentheses to work around it:</p>
<p>```js run <em>!</em> let x = (1 &amp;&amp; 2) ?? 3; // Works <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert(x); // 2 ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-31">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>The nullish coalescing operator <code>??</code> provides a short way to choose the first ‚Äúdefined‚Äù value from a list.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs used to assign default values to variables:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb261"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb261-1" title="1"><span class="co">// set height=100, if height is null or undefined</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb261-2" title="2">height <span class="op">=</span> height <span class="op">??</span> <span class="dv">100</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li>The operator <code>??</code> has a very low precedence, only a bit higher than <code>?</code> and <code>=</code>, so consider adding parentheses when using it in an expression.</li>
<li><p>It‚Äôs forbidden to use it with <code>||</code> or <code>&amp;&amp;</code> without explicit parentheses. # Anchors: string start ^ and end $</p></li>
</ul>
<p>The caret <code>pattern:^</code> and dollar <code>pattern:$</code> characters have special meaning in a regexp. They are called ‚Äúanchors‚Äù.</p>
<p>The caret <code>pattern:^</code> matches at the beginning of the text, and the dollar <code>pattern:$</code> ‚Äì at the end.</p>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs test if the text starts with <code>Mary</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run let str1 = "Mary had a little lamb"; alert( /^Mary/.test(str1) ); // true</code></p>
<p>The pattern <code>pattern:^Mary</code> means: ‚Äústring start and then Mary‚Äù.</p>
<p>Similar to this, we can test if the string ends with <code>snow</code> using <code>pattern:snow$</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run let str1 = "it's fleece was white as snow"; alert( /snow$/.test(str1) ); // true</code></p>
<p>In these particular cases we could use string methods <code>startsWith/endsWith</code> instead. Regular expressions should be used for more complex tests.</p>
<h2 id="testing-for-a-full-match">Testing for a full match</h2>
<p>Both anchors together <code>pattern:^...$</code> are often used to test whether or not a string fully matches the pattern. For instance, to check if the user input is in the right format.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs check whether or not a string is a time in <code>12:34</code> format. That is: two digits, then a colon, and then another two digits.</p>
<p>In regular expressions language that‚Äôs <code>pattern:\d\d:\d\d</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let goodInput = ‚Äú12:34‚Äù; let badInput = ‚Äú12:345‚Äù;</p>
<p>let regexp = /^\d\d$/; alert( regexp.test(goodInput) ); // true alert( regexp.test(badInput) ); // false ```</p>
<p>Here the match for <code>pattern:\d\d:\d\d</code> must start exactly after the beginning of the text <code>pattern:^</code>, and the end <code>pattern:$</code> must immediately follow.</p>
<p>The whole string must be exactly in this format. If there‚Äôs any deviation or an extra character, the result is <code>false</code>.</p>
<p>Anchors behave differently if flag <code>pattern:m</code> is present. We‚Äôll see that in the next article.</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Anchors have \"zero width\"" Anchors</code>pattern:^<code>and</code>pattern:$` are tests. They have zero width.</p>
<p>In other words, they do not match a character, but rather force the regexp engine to check the condition (text start/end). ``` # Multiline mode of anchors ^ $, flag ‚Äúm‚Äù</p>
<p>The multiline mode is enabled by the flag <code>pattern:m</code>.</p>
<p>It only affects the behavior of <code>pattern:^</code> and <code>pattern:$</code>.</p>
<p>In the multiline mode they match not only at the beginning and the end of the string, but also at start/end of line.</p>
<h2 id="searching-at-line-start">Searching at line start ^</h2>
<p>In the example below the text has multiple lines. The pattern <code>pattern:/^\d/gm</code> takes a digit from the beginning of each line:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>1st place: Winnie 2nd place: Piglet 3rd place: Eeyore`;</p>
<p><em>!</em> alert( str.match(/^gm) ); // 1, 2, 3 <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Without the flag <code>pattern:m</code> only the first digit is matched:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>1st place: Winnie 2nd place: Piglet 3rd place: Eeyore`;</p>
<p><em>!</em> alert( str.match(/^g) ); // 1 <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because by default a caret <code>pattern:^</code> only matches at the beginning of the text, and in the multiline mode ‚Äì at the start of any line.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>&quot;Start of a line&quot; formally means &quot;immediately after a line break&quot;: the test  `pattern:^` in multiline mode matches at all positions preceded by a newline character `\n`.

And at the text start.</code></pre>
<h2 id="searching-at-line-end">Searching at line end $</h2>
<p>The dollar sign <code>pattern:$</code> behaves similarly.</p>
<p>The regular expression <code>pattern:\d$</code> finds the last digit in every line</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>Winnie: 1 Piglet: 2 Eeyore: 3`;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/\d$/gm) ); // 1,2,3 ```</p>
<p>Without the flag <code>pattern:m</code>, the dollar <code>pattern:$</code> would only match the end of the whole text, so only the very last digit would be found.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>&quot;End of a line&quot; formally means &quot;immediately before a line break&quot;: the test  `pattern:$` in multiline mode matches at all positions succeeded by a newline character `\n`.

And at the text end.</code></pre>
<h2 id="searching-for-instead-of">Searching for instead of ^ $</h2>
<p>To find a newline, we can use not only anchors <code>pattern:^</code> and <code>pattern:$</code>, but also the newline character <code>\n</code>.</p>
<p>What‚Äôs the difference? Let‚Äôs see an example.</p>
<p>Here we search for <code>pattern:\d\n</code> instead of <code>pattern:\d$</code>:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>Winnie: 1 Piglet: 2 Eeyore: 3`;</p>
