<p>alert( str.match(//gm) ); // 1,2 ```</p>
<p>As we can see, there are 2 matches instead of 3.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because there‚Äôs no newline after <code>subject:3</code> (there‚Äôs text end though, so it matches <code>pattern:$</code>).</p>
<p>Another difference: now every match includes a newline character <code>match:\n</code>. Unlike the anchors <code>pattern:^</code> <code>pattern:$</code>, that only test the condition (start/end of a line), <code>\n</code> is a character, so it becomes a part of the result.</p>
<p>So, a <code>\n</code> in the pattern is used when we need newline characters in the result, while anchors are used to find something at the beginning/end of a line. # Word boundary:  word boundary <code>pattern:\b</code> is a test, just like <code>pattern:^</code> and <code>pattern:$</code>.</p>
<p>When the regexp engine (program module that implements searching for regexps) comes across <code>pattern:\b</code>, it checks that the position in the string is a word boundary.</p>
<p>There are three different positions that qualify as word boundaries:</p>
<ul>
<li>At string start, if the first string character is a word character <code>pattern:\w</code>.</li>
<li>Between two characters in the string, where one is a word character <code>pattern:\w</code> and the other is not.</li>
<li>At string end, if the last string character is a word character <code>pattern:\w</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>For instance, regexp <code>pattern:\bJava\b</code> will be found in <code>subject:Hello, Java!</code>, where <code>subject:Java</code> is a standalone word, but not in <code>subject:Hello, JavaScript!</code>.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "Hello, Java!".match(/\bJava\b/) ); // Java alert( "Hello, JavaScript!".match(/\bJava\b/) ); // null</code></p>
<p>In the string <code>subject:Hello, Java!</code> following positions correspond to <code>pattern:\b</code>:</p>
<p><img src="hello-java-boundaries.svg" /></p>
<p>So, it matches the pattern <code>pattern:\bHello\b</code>, because:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>At the beginning of the string matches the first test <code>pattern:\b</code>.</li>
<li>Then matches the word <code>pattern:Hello</code>.</li>
<li>Then the test <code>pattern:\b</code> matches again, as we‚Äôre between <code>subject:o</code> and a comma.</li>
</ol>
<p>So the pattern <code>pattern:\bHello\b</code> would match, but not <code>pattern:\bHell\b</code> (because there‚Äôs no word boundary after <code>l</code>) and not <code>Java!\b</code> (because the exclamation sign is not a wordly character <code>pattern:\w</code>, so there‚Äôs no word boundary after it).</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "Hello, Java!".match(/\bHello\b/) ); // Hello alert( "Hello, Java!".match(/\bJava\b/) );  // Java alert( "Hello, Java!".match(/\bHell\b/) );  // null (no match) alert( "Hello, Java!".match(/\bJava!\b/) ); // null (no match)</code></p>
<p>We can use <code>pattern:\b</code> not only with words, but with digits as well.</p>
<p>For example, the pattern <code>pattern:\b\d\d\b</code> looks for standalone 2-digit numbers. In other words, it looks for 2-digit numbers that are surrounded by characters different from <code>pattern:\w</code>, such as spaces or punctuation (or text start/end).</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "1 23 456 78".match(/\b\d\d\b/g) ); // 23,78 alert( "12,34,56".match(/\b\d\d\b/g) ); // 12,34,56</code></p>
<p>``<code>warn header="Word boundary</code>pattern: doesn‚Äôt work for non-latin alphabets" The word boundary test <code>pattern:\b</code> checks that there should be <code>pattern:\w</code> on the one side from the position and ‚Äúnot <code>pattern:\w</code>‚Äù - on the other side.</p>
<p>But <code>pattern:\w</code> means a latin letter <code>a-z</code> (or a digit or an underscore), so the test doesn‚Äôt work for other characters, e.g.¬†cyrillic letters or hieroglyphs. ```</p>
<h1 id="escaping-special-characters">Escaping, special characters</h1>
<p>As we‚Äôve seen, a backslash <code>pattern:\</code> is used to denote character classes, e.g.¬†<code>pattern:\d</code>. So it‚Äôs a special character in regexps (just like in regular strings).</p>
<p>There are other special characters as well, that have special meaning in a regexp. They are used to do more powerful searches. Here‚Äôs a full list of them: <code>pattern:[ \ ^ $ . | ? * + ( )</code>.</p>
<p>Don‚Äôt try to remember the list ‚Äì soon we‚Äôll deal with each of them separately and you‚Äôll know them by heart automatically.</p>
<h2 id="escaping">Escaping</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs say we want to find literally a dot. Not ‚Äúany character‚Äù, but just a dot.</p>
<p>To use a special character as a regular one, prepend it with a backslash: <code>pattern:\.</code>.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs also called ‚Äúescaping a character‚Äù.</p>
<p>For example: <code>js run alert( "Chapter 5.1".match(/\d\.\d/) ); // 5.1 (match!) alert( "Chapter 511".match(/\d\.\d/) ); // null (looking for a real dot \.)</code></p>
<p>Parentheses are also special characters, so if we want them, we should use <code>pattern:\(</code>. The example below looks for a string <code>"g()"</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "function g()".match(/g\(\)/) ); // "g()"</code></p>
<p>If we‚Äôre looking for a backslash <code>\</code>, it‚Äôs a special character in both regular strings and regexps, so we should double it.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "1\\2".match(/\\/) ); // '\'</code></p>
<h2 id="a-slash">A slash</h2>
<p>A slash symbol <code>'/'</code> is not a special character, but in JavaScript it is used to open and close the regexp: <code>pattern:/...pattern.../</code>, so we should escape it too.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs what a search for a slash <code>'/'</code> looks like:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "/".match(/\//) ); // '/'</code></p>
<p>On the other hand, if we‚Äôre not using <code>pattern:/.../</code>, but create a regexp using <code>new RegExp</code>, then we don‚Äôt need to escape it:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "/".match(new RegExp("/")) ); // finds /</code></p>
<h2 id="new-regexp">new RegExp</h2>
<p>If we are creating a regular expression with <code>new RegExp</code>, then we don‚Äôt have to escape <code>/</code>, but need to do some other escaping.</p>
<p>For instance, consider this:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = new RegExp(");</p>
<p>alert( ‚ÄúChapter 5.1‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // null ```</p>
<p>The similar search in one of previous examples worked with <code>pattern:/\d\.\d/</code>, but <code>new RegExp("\d\.\d")</code> doesn‚Äôt work, why?</p>
<p>The reason is that backslashes are ‚Äúconsumed‚Äù by a string. As we may recall, regular strings have their own special characters, such as <code>\n</code>, and a backslash is used for escaping.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs how " is preceived:</p>
<p><code>js run alert("\d\.\d"); // d.d</code></p>
<p>String quotes ‚Äúconsume‚Äù backslashes and interpret them on their own, for instance:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>\n</code> ‚Äì becomes a newline character,</li>
<li><code>\u1234</code> ‚Äì becomes the Unicode character with such code,</li>
<li>‚Ä¶And when there‚Äôs no special meaning: like <code>pattern:\d</code> or <code>\z</code>, then the backslash is simply removed.</li>
</ul>
<p>So <code>new RegExp</code> gets a string without backslashes. That‚Äôs why the search doesn‚Äôt work!</p>
<p>To fix it, we need to double backslashes, because string quotes turn <code>\\</code> into <code>\</code>:</p>
<p>```js run <em>!</em> let regStr = ‚Äú\d\.\d‚Äù; <em>/!</em> alert(regStr); // correct now)</p>
<p>let regexp = new RegExp(regStr);</p>
<p>alert( ‚ÄúChapter 5.1‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // 5.1 ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-32">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>To search for special characters <code>pattern:[ \ ^ $ . | ? * + ( )</code> literally, we need to prepend them with a backslash <code>\</code> (‚Äúescape them‚Äù).</li>
<li>We also need to escape <code>/</code> if we‚Äôre inside <code>pattern:/.../</code> (but not inside <code>new RegExp</code>).</li>
<li>When passing a string to <code>new RegExp</code>, we need to double backslashes <code>\\</code>, cause string quotes consume one of them. # Sets and ranges [‚Ä¶]</li>
</ul>
<p>Several characters or character classes inside square brackets <code>[‚Ä¶]</code> mean to ‚Äúsearch for any character among given‚Äù.</p>
<h2 id="sets">Sets</h2>
<p>For instance, <code>pattern:[eao]</code> means any of the 3 characters: <code>'a'</code>, <code>'e'</code>, or <code>'o'</code>.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs called a <em>set</em>. Sets can be used in a regexp along with regular characters:</p>
<p><code>js run // find [t or m], and then "op" alert( "Mop top".match(/[tm]op/gi) ); // "Mop", "top"</code></p>
<p>Please note that although there are multiple characters in the set, they correspond to exactly one character in the match.</p>
<p>So the example below gives no matches:</p>
<p><code>js run // find "V", then [o or i], then "la" alert( "Voila".match(/V[oi]la/) ); // null, no matches</code></p>
<p>The pattern searches for:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>pattern:V</code>,</li>
<li>then <em>one</em> of the letters <code>pattern:[oi]</code>,</li>
<li>then <code>pattern:la</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>So there would be a match for <code>match:Vola</code> or <code>match:Vila</code>.</p>
<h2 id="ranges">Ranges</h2>
<p>Square brackets may also contain <em>character ranges</em>.</p>
<p>For instance, <code>pattern:[a-z]</code> is a character in range from <code>a</code> to <code>z</code>, and <code>pattern:[0-5]</code> is a digit from <code>0</code> to <code>5</code>.</p>
<p>In the example below we‚Äôre searching for <code>"x"</code> followed by two digits or letters from <code>A</code> to <code>F</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "Exception 0xAF".match(/x[0-9A-F][0-9A-F]/g) ); // xAF</code></p>
<p>Here <code>pattern:[0-9A-F]</code> has two ranges: it searches for a character that is either a digit from <code>0</code> to <code>9</code> or a letter from <code>A</code> to <code>F</code>.</p>
<p>If we‚Äôd like to look for lowercase letters as well, we can add the range <code>a-f</code>: <code>pattern:[0-9A-Fa-f]</code>. Or add the flag <code>pattern:i</code>.</p>
<p>We can also use character classes inside <code>[‚Ä¶]</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, if we‚Äôd like to look for a wordly character <code>pattern:\w</code> or a hyphen <code>pattern:-</code>, then the set is <code>pattern:[\w-]</code>.</p>
<p>Combining multiple classes is also possible, e.g.¬†<code>pattern:[\s\d]</code> means ‚Äúa space character or a digit‚Äù.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúCharacter classes are shorthands for certain character sets‚Äù For instance:</p>
<ul>
<li>** ‚Äì is the same as <code>pattern:[0-9]</code>,</li>
<li>*** ‚Äì is the same as <code>pattern:[a-zA-Z0-9_]</code>,</li>
<li>*** ‚Äì is the same as <code>pattern:[\t\n\v\f\r ]</code>, plus few other rare Unicode space characters. ```</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="example-multi-language">Example: multi-language </h3>
<p>As the character class <code>pattern:\w</code> is a shorthand for <code>pattern:[a-zA-Z0-9_]</code>, it can‚Äôt find Chinese hieroglyphs, Cyrillic letters, etc.</p>
<p>We can write a more universal pattern, that looks for wordly characters in any language. That‚Äôs easy with Unicode properties: <code>pattern:[\p{Alpha}\p{M}\p{Nd}\p{Pc}\p{Join_C}]</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs decipher it. Similar to <code>pattern:\w</code>, we‚Äôre making a set of our own that includes characters with following Unicode properties:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Alphabetic</code> (<code>Alpha</code>) - for letters,</li>
<li><code>Mark</code> (<code>M</code>) - for accents,</li>
<li><code>Decimal_Number</code> (<code>Nd</code>) - for digits,</li>
<li><code>Connector_Punctuation</code> (<code>Pc</code>) - for the underscore <code>'_'</code> and similar characters,</li>
<li><code>Join_Control</code> (<code>Join_C</code>) - two special codes <code>200c</code> and <code>200d</code>, used in ligatures, e.g.¬†in Arabic.</li>
</ul>
<p>An example of use:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /[]/gu;</p>
<p>let str = <code>Hi ‰Ω†Â•Ω 12</code>;</p>
<p>// finds all letters and digits: alert( str.match(regexp) ); // H,i,‰Ω†,Â•Ω,1,2 ```</p>
<p>Of course, we can edit this pattern: add Unicode properties or remove them. Unicode properties are covered in more details in the article <a href="info:regexp-unicode" class="uri">info:regexp-unicode</a>.</p>
<p>``<code>warn header="Unicode properties aren't supported in IE" Unicode properties</code>pattern:p{‚Ä¶}` are not implemented in IE. If we really need them, we can use library <a href="http://xregexp.com/">XRegExp</a>.</p>
<p>Or just use ranges of characters in a language that interests us, e.g.¬†<code>pattern:[–∞-—è]</code> for Cyrillic letters. ```</p>
<h2 id="excluding-ranges">Excluding ranges</h2>
<p>Besides normal ranges, there are ‚Äúexcluding‚Äù ranges that look like <code>pattern:[^‚Ä¶]</code>.</p>
<p>They are denoted by a caret character <code>^</code> at the start and match any character <em>except the given ones</em>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>pattern:[^aeyo]</code> ‚Äì any character except <code>'a'</code>, <code>'e'</code>, <code>'y'</code> or <code>'o'</code>.</li>
<li><code>pattern:[^0-9]</code> ‚Äì any character except a digit, the same as <code>pattern:\D</code>.</li>
<li><code>pattern:[^\s]</code> ‚Äì any non-space character, same as <code>\S</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>The example below looks for any characters except letters, digits and spaces:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "alice15@gmail.com".match(/[^\d\sA-Z]/gi) ); // @ and .</code></p>
<h2 id="escaping-in">Escaping in [‚Ä¶]</h2>
<p>Usually when we want to find exactly a special character, we need to escape it like <code>pattern:\.</code>. And if we need a backslash, then we use <code>pattern:\\</code>, and so on.</p>
<p>In square brackets we can use the vast majority of special characters without escaping:</p>
<ul>
<li>Symbols <code>pattern:. + ( )</code> never need escaping.</li>
<li>A hyphen <code>pattern:-</code> is not escaped in the beginning or the end (where it does not define a range).</li>
<li>A caret <code>pattern:^</code> is only escaped in the beginning (where it means exclusion).</li>
<li>The closing square bracket <code>pattern:]</code> is always escaped (if we need to look for that symbol).</li>
</ul>
<p>In other words, all special characters are allowed without escaping, except when they mean something for square brackets.</p>
<p>A dot <code>.</code> inside square brackets means just a dot. The pattern <code>pattern:[.,]</code> would look for one of characters: either a dot or a comma.</p>
<p>In the example below the regexp <code>pattern:[-().^+]</code> looks for one of the characters <code>-().^+</code>:</p>
<p>```js run // No need to escape let regexp = /[-().^+]/g;</p>
<p>alert( ‚Äú1 + 2 - 3‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // Matches +, - ```</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But if you decide to escape them ‚Äújust in case‚Äù, then there would be no harm:</p>
<p>```js run // Escaped everything let regexp = /[-().^+]/g;</p>
<p>alert( ‚Äú1 + 2 - 3‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // also works: +, - ```</p>
<h2 id="ranges-and-flag-u">Ranges and flag ‚Äúu‚Äù</h2>
<p>If there are surrogate pairs in the set, flag <code>pattern:u</code> is required for them to work correctly.</p>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs look for <code>pattern:[ùí≥ùí¥]</code> in the string <code>subject:ùí≥</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'ùí≥'.match(/[ùí≥ùí¥]/) ); // shows a strange character, like [?] // (the search was performed incorrectly, half-character returned)</code></p>
<p>The result is incorrect, because by default regular expressions ‚Äúdon‚Äôt know‚Äù about surrogate pairs.</p>
<p>The regular expression engine thinks that <code>[ùí≥ùí¥]</code> ‚Äì are not two, but four characters: 1. left half of <code>ùí≥</code> <code>(1)</code>, 2. right half of <code>ùí≥</code> <code>(2)</code>, 3. left half of <code>ùí¥</code> <code>(3)</code>, 4. right half of <code>ùí¥</code> <code>(4)</code>.</p>
<p>We can see their codes like this:</p>
<p><code>js run for(let i=0; i&lt;'ùí≥ùí¥'.length; i++) {   alert('ùí≥ùí¥'.charCodeAt(i)); // 55349, 56499, 55349, 56500 };</code></p>
<p>So, the example above finds and shows the left half of <code>ùí≥</code>.</p>
<p>If we add flag <code>pattern:u</code>, then the behavior will be correct:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'ùí≥'.match(/[ùí≥ùí¥]/u) ); // ùí≥</code></p>
<p>The similar situation occurs when looking for a range, such as <code>[ùí≥-ùí¥]</code>.</p>
<p>If we forget to add flag <code>pattern:u</code>, there will be an error:</p>
<p><code>js run 'ùí≥'.match(/[ùí≥-ùí¥]/); // Error: Invalid regular expression</code></p>
<p>The reason is that without flag <code>pattern:u</code> surrogate pairs are perceived as two characters, so <code>[ùí≥-ùí¥]</code> is interpreted as <code>[&lt;55349&gt;&lt;56499&gt;-&lt;55349&gt;&lt;56500&gt;]</code> (every surrogate pair is replaced with its codes). Now it‚Äôs easy to see that the range <code>56499-55349</code> is invalid: its starting code <code>56499</code> is greater than the end <code>55349</code>. That‚Äôs the formal reason for the error.</p>
<p>With the flag <code>pattern:u</code> the pattern works correctly:</p>
<p><code>js run // look for characters from ùí≥ to ùíµ alert( 'ùí¥'.match(/[ùí≥-ùíµ]/u) ); // ùí¥</code> # Quantifiers +, *, ? and {n}</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs say we have a string like <code>+7(903)-123-45-67</code> and want to find all numbers in it. But unlike before, we are interested not in single digits, but full numbers: <code>7, 903, 123, 45, 67</code>.</p>
<p>A number is a sequence of 1 or more digits <code>pattern:\d</code>. To mark how many we need, we can append a <em>quantifier</em>.</p>
<h2 id="quantity-n">Quantity {n}</h2>
<p>The simplest quantifier is a number in curly braces: <code>pattern:{n}</code>.</p>
<p>A quantifier is appended to a character (or a character class, or a <code>[...]</code> set etc) and specifies how many we need.</p>
<p>It has a few advanced forms, let‚Äôs see examples:</p>
<dl>
<dt>The exact count: <code>pattern:{5}</code></dt>
<dd><p><code>pattern:\d{5}</code> denotes exactly 5 digits, the same as <code>pattern:\d\d\d\d\d</code>.</p>
<p>The example below looks for a 5-digit number:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "I'm 12345 years old".match(/\d{5}/) ); //  "12345"</code></p>
<p>We can add <code>\b</code> to exclude longer numbers: <code>pattern:\b\d{5}\b</code>.</p>
</dd>
<dt>The range: <code>pattern:{3,5}</code>, match 3-5 times</dt>
<dd><p>To find numbers from 3 to 5 digits we can put the limits into curly braces: <code>pattern:\d{3,5}</code></p>
<p><code>js run alert( "I'm not 12, but 1234 years old".match(/\d{3,5}/) ); // "1234"</code></p>
<p>We can omit the upper limit.</p>
<p>Then a regexp <code>pattern:\d{3,}</code> looks for sequences of digits of length <code>3</code> or more:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "I'm not 12, but 345678 years old".match(/\d{3,}/) ); // "345678"</code></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Let‚Äôs return to the string <code>+7(903)-123-45-67</code>.</p>
<p>A number is a sequence of one or more digits in a row. So the regexp is <code>pattern:\d{1,}</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú+7(903)-123-45-67‚Äù;</p>
<p>let numbers = str.match(//g);</p>
<p>alert(numbers); // 7,903,123,45,67 ```</p>
<h2 id="shorthands">Shorthands</h2>
<p>There are shorthands for most used quantifiers:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>pattern:+</code></dt>
<dd><p>Means ‚Äúone or more‚Äù, the same as <code>pattern:{1,}</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, <code>pattern:\d+</code> looks for numbers:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú+7(903)-123-45-67‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(//g) ); // 7,903,123,45,67 ```</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:?</code></dt>
<dd><p>Means ‚Äúzero or one‚Äù, the same as <code>pattern:{0,1}</code>. In other words, it makes the symbol optional.</p>
<p>For instance, the pattern <code>pattern:ou?r</code> looks for <code>match:o</code> followed by zero or one <code>match:u</code>, and then <code>match:r</code>.</p>
<p>So, <code>pattern:colou?r</code> finds both <code>match:color</code> and <code>match:colour</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúShould I write color or colour?‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/colou?r/g) ); // color, colour ```</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>pattern:*</code></dt>
<dd><p>Means ‚Äúzero or more‚Äù, the same as <code>pattern:{0,}</code>. That is, the character may repeat any times or be absent.</p>
<p>For example, <code>pattern:\d0*</code> looks for a digit followed by any number of zeroes (may be many or none):</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "100 10 1".match(/\d0*/g) ); // 100, 10, 1</code></p>
<p>Compare it with <code>pattern:+</code> (one or more):</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "100 10 1".match(/\d0+/g) ); // 100, 10 // 1 not matched, as 0+ requires at least one zero</code></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<h2 id="more-examples">More examples</h2>
<p>Quantifiers are used very often. They serve as the main ‚Äúbuilding block‚Äù of complex regular expressions, so let‚Äôs see more examples.</p>
<p><strong>Regexp for decimal fractions (a number with a floating point): <code>pattern:\d+\.\d+</code></strong></p>
<p>In action: <code>js run alert( "0 1 12.345 7890".match(/\d+\.\d+/g) ); // 12.345</code></p>
<p><strong>Regexp for an ‚Äúopening HTML-tag without attributes‚Äù, such as <code>&lt;span&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;p&gt;</code>.</strong></p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>The simplest one: <code>pattern:/&lt;[a-z]+&gt;/i</code></p>
<p><code>js run  alert( "&lt;body&gt; ... &lt;/body&gt;".match(/&lt;[a-z]+&gt;/gi) ); // &lt;body&gt;</code></p>
<p>The regexp looks for character <code>pattern:'&lt;'</code> followed by one or more Latin letters, and then <code>pattern:'&gt;'</code>.</p></li>
<li><p>Improved: <code>pattern:/&lt;[a-z][a-z0-9]*&gt;/i</code></p>
<p>According to the standard, HTML tag name may have a digit at any position except the first one, like <code>&lt;h1&gt;</code>.</p>
<p><code>js run  alert( "&lt;h1&gt;Hi!&lt;/h1&gt;".match(/&lt;[a-z][a-z0-9]*&gt;/gi) ); // &lt;h1&gt;</code></p></li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Regexp ‚Äúopening or closing HTML-tag without attributes‚Äù: <code>pattern:/&lt;\/?[a-z][a-z0-9]*&gt;/i</code></strong></p>
<p>We added an optional slash <code>pattern:/?</code> near the beginning of the pattern. Had to escape it with a backslash, otherwise JavaScript would think it is the pattern end.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "&lt;h1&gt;Hi!&lt;/h1&gt;".match(/&lt;\/?[a-z][a-z0-9]*&gt;/gi) ); // &lt;h1&gt;, &lt;/h1&gt;</code></p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúTo make a regexp more precise, we often need make it more complex‚Äù We can see one common rule in these examples: the more precise is the regular expression ‚Äì the longer and more complex it is.</p>
<p>For instance, for HTML tags we could use a simpler regexp: <code>pattern:&lt;\w+&gt;</code>. But as HTML has stricter restrictions for a tag name, <code>pattern:&lt;[a-z][a-z0-9]*&gt;</code> is more reliable.</p>
<p>Can we use <code>pattern:&lt;\w+&gt;</code> or we need <code>pattern:&lt;[a-z][a-z0-9]*&gt;</code>?</p>
<p>In real life both variants are acceptable. Depends on how tolerant we can be to ‚Äúextra‚Äù matches and whether it‚Äôs difficult or not to remove them from the result by other means. ``` # Greedy and lazy quantifiers</p>
<p>Quantifiers are very simple from the first sight, but in fact they can be tricky.</p>
<p>We should understand how the search works very well if we plan to look for something more complex than <code>pattern:/\d+/</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs take the following task as an example.</p>
<p>We have a text and need to replace all quotes <code>"..."</code> with guillemet marks: <code>¬´...¬ª</code>. They are preferred for typography in many countries.</p>
<p>For instance: <code>"Hello, world"</code> should become <code>¬´Hello, world¬ª</code>. There exist other quotes, such as <code>‚ÄûWitam, ≈õwiat!‚Äù</code> (Polish) or <code>„Äå‰Ω†Â•ΩÔºå‰∏ñÁïå„Äç</code> (Chinese), but for our task let‚Äôs choose <code>¬´...¬ª</code>.</p>
<p>The first thing to do is to locate quoted strings, and then we can replace them.</p>
<p>A regular expression like <code>pattern:/".+"/g</code> (a quote, then something, then the other quote) may seem like a good fit, but it isn‚Äôt!</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs try it:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /‚Äú.+‚Äù/g;</p>
<p>let str = ‚Äòa ‚Äúwitch‚Äù and her ‚Äúbroom‚Äù is one‚Äô;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‚Äúwitch‚Äù and her ‚Äúbroom‚Äù ```</p>
<p>‚Ä¶We can see that it works not as intended!</p>
<p>Instead of finding two matches <code>match:"witch"</code> and <code>match:"broom"</code>, it finds one: <code>match:"witch" and her "broom"</code>.</p>
<p>That can be described as ‚Äúgreediness is the cause of all evil‚Äù.</p>
<h2 id="greedy-search">Greedy search</h2>
<p>To find a match, the regular expression engine uses the following algorithm:</p>
<ul>
<li>For every position in the string
<ul>
<li>Try to match the pattern at that position.</li>
<li>If there‚Äôs no match, go to the next position.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>
<p>These common words do not make it obvious why the regexp fails, so let‚Äôs elaborate how the search works for the pattern <code>pattern:".+"</code>.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>The first pattern character is a quote <code>pattern:"</code>.</p>
<p>The regular expression engine tries to find it at the zero position of the source string <code>subject:a "witch" and her "broom" is one</code>, but there‚Äôs <code>subject:a</code> there, so there‚Äôs immediately no match.</p>
<p>Then it advances: goes to the next positions in the source string and tries to find the first character of the pattern there, fails again, and finally finds the quote at the 3rd position:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy1.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>The quote is detected, and then the engine tries to find a match for the rest of the pattern. It tries to see if the rest of the subject string conforms to <code>pattern:.+"</code>.</p>
<p>In our case the next pattern character is <code>pattern:.</code> (a dot). It denotes ‚Äúany character except a newline‚Äù, so the next string letter <code>match:'w'</code> fits:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy2.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>Then the dot repeats because of the quantifier <code>pattern:.+</code>. The regular expression engine adds to the match one character after another.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶Until when? All characters match the dot, so it only stops when it reaches the end of the string:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy3.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>Now the engine finished repeating <code>pattern:.+</code> and tries to find the next character of the pattern. It‚Äôs the quote <code>pattern:"</code>. But there‚Äôs a problem: the string has finished, there are no more characters!</p>
<p>The regular expression engine understands that it took too many <code>pattern:.+</code> and starts to <em>backtrack</em>.</p>
<p>In other words, it shortens the match for the quantifier by one character:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy4.svg" /></p>
<p>Now it assumes that <code>pattern:.+</code> ends one character before the string end and tries to match the rest of the pattern from that position.</p>
<p>If there were a quote there, then the search would end, but the last character is <code>subject:'e'</code>, so there‚Äôs no match.</p></li>
<li><p>‚Ä¶So the engine decreases the number of repetitions of <code>pattern:.+</code> by one more character:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy5.svg" /></p>
<p>The quote <code>pattern:'"'</code> does not match <code>subject:'n'</code>.</p></li>
<li><p>The engine keep backtracking: it decreases the count of repetition for <code>pattern:'.'</code> until the rest of the pattern (in our case <code>pattern:'"'</code>) matches:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy6.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>The match is complete.</p></li>
<li><p>So the first match is <code>match:"witch" and her "broom"</code>. If the regular expression has flag <code>pattern:g</code>, then the search will continue from where the first match ends. There are no more quotes in the rest of the string <code>subject:is one</code>, so no more results.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>That‚Äôs probably not what we expected, but that‚Äôs how it works.</p>
<p><strong>In the greedy mode (by default) a quantified character is repeated as many times as possible.</strong></p>
<p>The regexp engine adds to the match as many characters as it can for <code>pattern:.+</code>, and then shortens that one by one, if the rest of the pattern doesn‚Äôt match.</p>
<p>For our task we want another thing. That‚Äôs where a lazy mode can help.</p>
<h2 id="lazy-mode">Lazy mode</h2>
<p>The lazy mode of quantifiers is an opposite to the greedy mode. It means: ‚Äúrepeat minimal number of times‚Äù.</p>
<p>We can enable it by putting a question mark <code>pattern:'?'</code> after the quantifier, so that it becomes <code>pattern:*?</code> or <code>pattern:+?</code> or even <code>pattern:??</code> for <code>pattern:'?'</code>.</p>
<p>To make things clear: usually a question mark <code>pattern:?</code> is a quantifier by itself (zero or one), but if added <em>after another quantifier (or even itself)</em> it gets another meaning ‚Äì it switches the matching mode from greedy to lazy.</p>
<p>The regexp <code>pattern:/".+?"/g</code> works as intended: it finds <code>match:"witch"</code> and <code>match:"broom"</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /‚Äú.+?‚Äù/g;</p>
<p>let str = ‚Äòa ‚Äúwitch‚Äù and her ‚Äúbroom‚Äù is one‚Äô;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‚Äúwitch‚Äù, ‚Äúbroom‚Äù ```</p>
<p>To clearly understand the change, let‚Äôs trace the search step by step.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>The first step is the same: it finds the pattern start <code>pattern:'"'</code> at the 3rd position:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy1.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>The next step is also similar: the engine finds a match for the dot <code>pattern:'.'</code>:</p>
<p><img src="witch_greedy2.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>And now the search goes differently. Because we have a lazy mode for <code>pattern:+?</code>, the engine doesn‚Äôt try to match a dot one more time, but stops and tries to match the rest of the pattern <code>pattern:'"'</code> right now:</p>
<p><img src="witch_lazy3.svg" /></p>
If there were a quote there, then the search would end, but there‚Äôs <code>'i'</code>, so there‚Äôs no match.</li>
<li><p>Then the regular expression engine increases the number of repetitions for the dot and tries one more time:</p>
<p><img src="witch_lazy4.svg" /></p>
Failure again. Then the number of repetitions is increased again and again‚Ä¶</li>
<li><p>‚Ä¶Till the match for the rest of the pattern is found:</p>
<p><img src="witch_lazy5.svg" /></p></li>
<li><p>The next search starts from the end of the current match and yield one more result:</p>
<p><img src="witch_lazy6.svg" /></p></li>
</ol>
<p>In this example we saw how the lazy mode works for <code>pattern:+?</code>. Quantifiers <code>pattern:*?</code> and <code>pattern:??</code> work the similar way ‚Äì the regexp engine increases the number of repetitions only if the rest of the pattern can‚Äôt match on the given position.</p>
<p><strong>Laziness is only enabled for the quantifier with <code>?</code>.</strong></p>
<p>Other quantifiers remain greedy.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "123 456".match(/\d+ \d+?/) ); // 123 4</code></p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The pattern <code>pattern:\d+</code> tries to match as many digits as it can (greedy mode), so it finds <code>match:123</code> and stops, because the next character is a space <code>pattern:' '</code>.</li>
<li>Then there‚Äôs a space in the pattern, it matches.</li>
<li><p>Then there‚Äôs <code>pattern:\d+?</code>. The quantifier is in lazy mode, so it finds one digit <code>match:4</code> and tries to check if the rest of the pattern matches from there.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But there‚Äôs nothing in the pattern after <code>pattern:\d+?</code>.</p>
<p>The lazy mode doesn‚Äôt repeat anything without a need. The pattern finished, so we‚Äôre done. We have a match <code>match:123 4</code>.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúOptimizations‚Äù Modern regular expression engines can optimize internal algorithms to work faster. So they may work a bit differently from the described algorithm.</p>
<p>But to understand how regular expressions work and to build regular expressions, we don‚Äôt need to know about that. They are only used internally to optimize things.</p>
<p>Complex regular expressions are hard to optimize, so the search may work exactly as described as well. ```</p>
<h2 id="alternative-approach">Alternative approach</h2>
<p>With regexps, there‚Äôs often more than one way to do the same thing.</p>
<p>In our case we can find quoted strings without lazy mode using the regexp <code>pattern:"[^"]+"</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /‚Äú[^"]+‚Äù/g;</p>
<p>let str = ‚Äòa ‚Äúwitch‚Äù and her ‚Äúbroom‚Äù is one‚Äô;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‚Äúwitch‚Äù, ‚Äúbroom‚Äù ```</p>
<p>The regexp <code>pattern:"[^"]+"</code> gives correct results, because it looks for a quote <code>pattern:'"'</code> followed by one or more non-quotes <code>pattern:[^"]</code>, and then the closing quote.</p>
<p>When the regexp engine looks for <code>pattern:[^"]+</code> it stops the repetitions when it meets the closing quote, and we‚Äôre done.</p>
<p>Please note, that this logic does not replace lazy quantifiers!</p>
<p>It is just different. There are times when we need one or another.</p>
<p><strong>Let‚Äôs see an example where lazy quantifiers fail and this variant works right.</strong></p>
<p>For instance, we want to find links of the form <code>&lt;a href="..." class="doc"&gt;</code>, with any <code>href</code>.</p>
<p>Which regular expression to use?</p>
<p>The first idea might be: <code>pattern:/&lt;a href=".*" class="doc"&gt;/g</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs check it: ```js run let str = ‚Äò‚Ä¶<a href="link" class="doc">‚Ä¶‚Äô; let regexp = /<a href=".*" class="doc">/g;</p>
<p>// Works! alert( str.match(regexp) ); // <a href="link" class="doc"> ```</p>
<p>It worked. But let‚Äôs see what happens if there are many links in the text?</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äò‚Ä¶<a href="link1" class="doc">‚Ä¶ <a href="link2" class="doc">‚Ä¶‚Äô; let regexp = /<a href=".*" class="doc">/g;</p>
<p>// Whoops! Two links in one match! alert( str.match(regexp) ); // <a href="link1" class="doc">‚Ä¶ <a href="link2" class="doc"> ```</p>
<p>Now the result is wrong for the same reason as our ‚Äúwitches‚Äù example. The quantifier <code>pattern:.*</code> took too many characters.</p>
<p>The match looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb264"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb264-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;.....................................&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb264-2" title="2"><span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;link1&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>... <span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;link2&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Let‚Äôs modify the pattern by making the quantifier <code>pattern:.*?</code> lazy:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äò‚Ä¶<a href="link1" class="doc">‚Ä¶ <a href="link2" class="doc">‚Ä¶‚Äô; let regexp = /<a href=".*?" class="doc">/g;</p>
<p>// Works! alert( str.match(regexp) ); // <a href="link1" class="doc">, <a href="link2" class="doc"> ```</p>
<p>Now it seems to work, there are two matches:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb265"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb265-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;.....&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>    <span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;.....&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb265-2" title="2"><span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;link1&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>... <span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;link2&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶But let‚Äôs test it on one more text input:</p>
```js run let str = ‚Äô‚Ä¶<a href="link1" class="wrong">‚Ä¶
<p style="" class="doc">
<p>‚Ä¶‚Äô; let regexp = /<a href=".*?" class="doc">/g;</p>
// Wrong match! alert( str.match(regexp) ); // <a href="link1" class="wrong">‚Ä¶
<p style="" class="doc">
<p>```</p>
<p>Now it fails. The match includes not just a link, but also a lot of text after it, including <code>&lt;p...&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>Why?</p>
<p>That‚Äôs what‚Äôs going on:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>First the regexp finds a link start <code>match:&lt;a href="</code>.</li>
<li>Then it looks for <code>pattern:.*?</code>: takes one character (lazily!), check if there‚Äôs a match for <code>pattern:" class="doc"&gt;</code> (none).</li>
<li>Then takes another character into <code>pattern:.*?</code>, and so on‚Ä¶ until it finally reaches <code>match:" class="doc"&gt;</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>But the problem is: that‚Äôs already beyond the link <code>&lt;a...&gt;</code>, in another tag <code>&lt;p&gt;</code>. Not what we want.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the picture of the match aligned with the text:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb266"><pre class="sourceCode html"><code class="sourceCode html"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb266-1" title="1"><span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;...................................&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb266-2" title="2"><span class="kw">&lt;a</span><span class="ot"> href=</span><span class="st">&quot;link1&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;wrong&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span>... <span class="kw">&lt;p</span><span class="ot"> style=</span><span class="st">&quot;&quot;</span><span class="ot"> class=</span><span class="st">&quot;doc&quot;</span><span class="kw">&gt;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So, we need the pattern to look for <code>&lt;a href="...something..." class="doc"&gt;</code>, but both greedy and lazy variants have problems.</p>
<p>The correct variant can be: <code>pattern:href="[^"]*"</code>. It will take all characters inside the <code>href</code> attribute till the nearest quote, just what we need.</p>
<p>A working example:</p>
```js run let str1 = ‚Äô‚Ä¶<a href="link1" class="wrong">‚Ä¶
<p style="" class="doc">
<p>‚Ä¶‚Äò; let str2 =‚Äô‚Ä¶<a href="link1" class="doc">‚Ä¶ <a href="link2" class="doc">‚Ä¶‚Äô; let regexp = /&lt;a href="[^"]*" class=‚Äúdoc‚Äù&gt;/g;</p>
<p>// Works! alert( str1.match(regexp) ); // null, no matches, that‚Äôs correct alert( str2.match(regexp) ); // <a href="link1" class="doc">, <a href="link2" class="doc"> ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-33">Summary</h2>
<p>Quantifiers have two modes of work:</p>
<dl>
<dt>Greedy</dt>
<dd>By default the regular expression engine tries to repeat the quantified character as many times as possible. For instance, <code>pattern:\d+</code> consumes all possible digits. When it becomes impossible to consume more (no more digits or string end), then it continues to match the rest of the pattern. If there‚Äôs no match then it decreases the number of repetitions (backtracks) and tries again.
</dd>
<dt>Lazy</dt>
<dd>Enabled by the question mark <code>pattern:?</code> after the quantifier. The regexp engine tries to match the rest of the pattern before each repetition of the quantified character.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>As we‚Äôve seen, the lazy mode is not a ‚Äúpanacea‚Äù from the greedy search. An alternative is a ‚Äúfine-tuned‚Äù greedy search, with exclusions, as in the pattern <code>pattern:"[^"]+"</code>. # Capturing groups</p>
<p>A part of a pattern can be enclosed in parentheses <code>pattern:(...)</code>. This is called a ‚Äúcapturing group‚Äù.</p>
<p>That has two effects:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>It allows to get a part of the match as a separate item in the result array.</li>
<li>If we put a quantifier after the parentheses, it applies to the parentheses as a whole.</li>
</ol>
<h2 id="examples">Examples</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs see how parentheses work in examples.</p>
<h3 id="example-gogogo">Example: gogogo</h3>
<p>Without parentheses, the pattern <code>pattern:go+</code> means <code>subject:g</code> character, followed by <code>subject:o</code> repeated one or more times. For instance, <code>match:goooo</code> or <code>match:gooooooooo</code>.</p>
<p>Parentheses group characters together, so <code>pattern:(go)+</code> means <code>match:go</code>, <code>match:gogo</code>, <code>match:gogogo</code> and so on.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'Gogogo now!'.match(/(go)+/ig) ); // "Gogogo"</code></p>
<h3 id="example-domain">Example: domain</h3>
<p>Let‚Äôs make something more complex ‚Äì a regular expression to search for a website domain.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<pre><code>mail.com
users.mail.com
smith.users.mail.com</code></pre>
<p>As we can see, a domain consists of repeated words, a dot after each one except the last one.</p>
<p>In regular expressions that‚Äôs <code>pattern:(\w+\.)+\w+</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /(+.)++/g;</p>
<p>alert( ‚Äúsite.com my.site.com‚Äù.match(regexp) ); // site.com,my.site.com ```</p>
<p>The search works, but the pattern can‚Äôt match a domain with a hyphen, e.g.¬†<code>my-site.com</code>, because the hyphen does not belong to class <code>pattern:\w</code>.</p>
<p>We can fix it by replacing <code>pattern:\w</code> with <code>pattern:[\w-]</code> in every word except the last one: <code>pattern:([\w-]+\.)+\w+</code>.</p>
<h3 id="example-email">Example: email</h3>
<p>The previous example can be extended. We can create a regular expression for emails based on it.</p>
<p>The email format is: <code>name@domain</code>. Any word can be the name, hyphens and dots are allowed. In regular expressions that‚Äôs <code>pattern:[-.\w]+</code>.</p>
<p>The pattern:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /[-.]+@([-]+.)+[-]+/g;</p>
<p>alert(‚Äúmy@mail.com @ his@site.com.uk‚Äù.match(regexp)); // my@mail.com, his@site.com.uk ```</p>
<p>That regexp is not perfect, but mostly works and helps to fix accidental mistypes. The only truly reliable check for an email can only be done by sending a letter.</p>
<h2 id="parentheses-contents-in-the-match">Parentheses contents in the match</h2>
<p>Parentheses are numbered from left to right. The search engine memorizes the content matched by each of them and allows to get it in the result.</p>
<p>The method <code>str.match(regexp)</code>, if <code>regexp</code> has no flag <code>g</code>, looks for the first match and returns it as an array:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>At index <code>0</code>: the full match.</li>
<li>At index <code>1</code>: the contents of the first parentheses.</li>
<li>At index <code>2</code>: the contents of the second parentheses.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶and so on‚Ä¶</li>
</ol>
<p>For instance, we‚Äôd like to find HTML tags <code>pattern:&lt;.*?&gt;</code>, and process them. It would be convenient to have tag content (what‚Äôs inside the angles), in a separate variable.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs wrap the inner content into parentheses, like this: <code>pattern:&lt;(.*?)&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>Now we‚Äôll get both the tag as a whole <code>match:&lt;h1&gt;</code> and its contents <code>match:h1</code> in the resulting array:</p>
```js run let str = ‚Äô
<h1>
Hello, world!
</h1>
<p>‚Äô;</p>
<p>let tag = str.match(/&lt;(.*?)&gt;/);</p>
alert( tag[0] ); //
<h1>
<p>alert( tag[1] ); // h1 ```</p>
<h3 id="nested-groups">Nested groups</h3>
<p>Parentheses can be nested. In this case the numbering also goes from left to right.</p>
<p>For instance, when searching a tag in <code>subject:&lt;span class="my"&gt;</code> we may be interested in:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The tag content as a whole: <code>match:span class="my"</code>.</li>
<li>The tag name: <code>match:span</code>.</li>
<li>The tag attributes: <code>match:class="my"</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>Let‚Äôs add parentheses for them: <code>pattern:&lt;(([a-z]+)\s*([^&gt;]*))&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs how they are numbered (left to right, by the opening paren):</p>
<p><img src="regexp-nested-groups-pattern.svg" /></p>
<p>In action:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äò<span class="my">‚Äô;</p>
<p>let regexp = /&lt;(([a-z]+)([^&gt;]*))&gt;/;</p>
<p>let result = str.match(regexp); alert(result[0]); // <span class="my"> alert(result[1]); // span class=‚Äúmy‚Äù alert(result[2]); // span alert(result[3]); // class=‚Äúmy‚Äù ```</p>
<p>The zero index of <code>result</code> always holds the full match.</p>
<p>Then groups, numbered from left to right by an opening paren. The first group is returned as <code>result[1]</code>. Here it encloses the whole tag content.</p>
<p>Then in <code>result[2]</code> goes the group from the second opening paren <code>pattern:([a-z]+)</code> - tag name, then in <code>result[3]</code> the tag: <code>pattern:([^&gt;]*)</code>.</p>
<p>The contents of every group in the string:</p>
<p><img src="regexp-nested-groups-matches.svg" /></p>
<h3 id="optional-groups">Optional groups</h3>
<p>Even if a group is optional and doesn‚Äôt exist in the match (e.g.¬†has the quantifier <code>pattern:(...)?</code>), the corresponding <code>result</code> array item is present and equals <code>undefined</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs consider the regexp <code>pattern:a(z)?(c)?</code>. It looks for <code>"a"</code> optionally followed by <code>"z"</code> optionally followed by <code>"c"</code>.</p>
<p>If we run it on the string with a single letter <code>subject:a</code>, then the result is:</p>
<p>```js run let match = ‚Äòa‚Äô.match(/a(z)?(c)?/);</p>
<p>alert( match.length ); // 3 alert( match[0] ); // a (whole match) alert( match[1] ); // undefined alert( match[2] ); // undefined ```</p>
<p>The array has the length of <code>3</code>, but all groups are empty.</p>
<p>And here‚Äôs a more complex match for the string <code>subject:ac</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let match = ‚Äòac‚Äô.match(/a(z)?(c)?/)</p>
<p>alert( match.length ); // 3 alert( match[0] ); // ac (whole match) alert( match[1] ); // undefined, because there‚Äôs nothing for (z)? alert( match[2] ); // c ```</p>
<p>The array length is permanent: <code>3</code>. But there‚Äôs nothing for the group <code>pattern:(z)?</code>, so the result is <code>["ac", undefined, "c"]</code>.</p>
<h2 id="searching-for-all-matches-with-groups-matchall">Searching for all matches with groups: matchAll</h2>
<p>``<code>warn header="</code>matchAll<code>is a new method, polyfill may be needed" The method</code>matchAll` is not supported in old browsers.</p>
<p>A polyfill may be required, such as <a href="https://github.com/ljharb/String.prototype.matchAll" class="uri">https://github.com/ljharb/String.prototype.matchAll</a>. ```</p>
<p>When we search for all matches (flag <code>pattern:g</code>), the <code>match</code> method does not return contents for groups.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs find all tags in a string:</p>
```js run let str = ‚Äô
<h1>
<h2>
<p>‚Äô;</p>
<p>let tags = str.match(/&lt;(.*?)&gt;/g);</p>
alert( tags ); //
<h1>
,
<h2>
<p>```</p>
<p>The result is an array of matches, but without details about each of them. But in practice we usually need contents of capturing groups in the result.</p>
<p>To get them, we should search using the method <code>str.matchAll(regexp)</code>.</p>
<p>It was added to JavaScript language long after <code>match</code>, as its ‚Äúnew and improved version‚Äù.</p>
<p>Just like <code>match</code>, it looks for matches, but there are 3 differences:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>It returns not an array, but an iterable object.</li>
<li>When the flag <code>pattern:g</code> is present, it returns every match as an array with groups.</li>
<li>If there are no matches, it returns not <code>null</code>, but an empty iterable object.</li>
</ol>
<p>For instance:</p>
```js run let results = ‚Äô
<h1>
<h2>
<p>‚Äô.matchAll(/&lt;(.*?)&gt;/gi);</p>
<p>// results - is not an array, but an iterable object alert(results); // [object RegExp String Iterator]</p>
<p>alert(results[0]); // undefined (*)</p>
<p>results = Array.from(results); // let‚Äôs turn it into array</p>
alert(results[0]); //
<h1>
,h1 (1st tag) alert(results[1]); //
<h2>
<p>,h2 (2nd tag) ```</p>
<p>As we can see, the first difference is very important, as demonstrated in the line <code>(*)</code>. We can‚Äôt get the match as <code>results[0]</code>, because that object isn‚Äôt pseudoarray. We can turn it into a real <code>Array</code> using <code>Array.from</code>. There are more details about pseudoarrays and iterables in the article <a href="info:iterable" class="uri">info:iterable</a>.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs no need in <code>Array.from</code> if we‚Äôre looping over results:</p>
```js run let results = ‚Äô
<h1>
<h2>
<p>‚Äô.matchAll(/&lt;(.*?)&gt;/gi);</p>
for(let result of results) { alert(result); // first alert:
<h1>
,h1 // second:
<h2>
<p>,h2 } ```</p>
<p>‚Ä¶Or using destructuring:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb268"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb268-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> [tag1<span class="op">,</span> tag2] <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&#39;&lt;h1&gt; &lt;h2&gt;&#39;</span>.<span class="at">matchAll</span>(<span class="ss">/&lt;</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">.</span><span class="sc">*?)</span><span class="ss">&gt;/gi</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Every match, returned by <code>matchAll</code>, has the same format as returned by <code>match</code> without flag <code>pattern:g</code>: it‚Äôs an array with additional properties <code>index</code> (match index in the string) and <code>input</code> (source string):</p>
```js run let results = ‚Äô
<h1>
<h2>
<p>‚Äô.matchAll(/&lt;(.*?)&gt;/gi);</p>
<p>let [tag1, tag2] = results;</p>
alert( tag1[0] ); //
<h1>
alert( tag1[1] ); // h1 alert( tag1.index ); // 0 alert( tag1.input ); //
<h1>
<h2>
<p>```</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Why is a result of</code>matchAll` an iterable object, not an array?" Why is the method designed like that? The reason is simple - for the optimization.</p>
<p>The call to <code>matchAll</code> does not perform the search. Instead, it returns an iterable object, without the results initially. The search is performed each time we iterate over it, e.g.¬†in the loop.</p>
<p>So, there will be found as many results as needed, not more.</p>
<p>E.g. there are potentially 100 matches in the text, but in a <code>for..of</code> loop we found 5 of them, then decided it‚Äôs enough and made a <code>break</code>. Then the engine won‚Äôt spend time finding other 95 matches. ```</p>
<h2 id="named-groups">Named groups</h2>
<p>Remembering groups by their numbers is hard. For simple patterns it‚Äôs doable, but for more complex ones counting parentheses is inconvenient. We have a much better option: give names to parentheses.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs done by putting <code>pattern:?&lt;name&gt;</code> immediately after the opening paren.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs look for a date in the format ‚Äúyear-month-day‚Äù:</p>
<p>```js run <em>!</em> let dateRegexp = /(?<year>[0-9]{4})-(?<month>[0-9]{2})-(?<day>[0-9]{2})/; <em>/!</em> let str = ‚Äú2019-04-30‚Äù;</p>
<p>let groups = str.match(dateRegexp).groups;</p>
<p>alert(groups.year); // 2019 alert(groups.month); // 04 alert(groups.day); // 30 ```</p>
<p>As you can see, the groups reside in the <code>.groups</code> property of the match.</p>
<p>To look for all dates, we can add flag <code>pattern:g</code>.</p>
<p>We‚Äôll also need <code>matchAll</code> to obtain full matches, together with groups:</p>
<p>```js run let dateRegexp = /(?<year>[0-9]{4})-(?<month>[0-9]{2})-(?<day>[0-9]{2})/g;</p>
<p>let str = ‚Äú2019-10-30 2020-01-01‚Äù;</p>
<p>let results = str.matchAll(dateRegexp);</p>
<p>for(let result of results) { let {year, month, day} = result.groups;</p>
<p>alert(<code>${day}.${month}.${year}</code>); // first alert: 30.10.2019 // second: 01.01.2020 } ```</p>
<h2 id="capturing-groups-in-replacement">Capturing groups in replacement</h2>
<p>Method <code>str.replace(regexp, replacement)</code> that replaces all matches with <code>regexp</code> in <code>str</code> allows to use parentheses contents in the <code>replacement</code> string. That‚Äôs done using <code>pattern:$n</code>, where <code>pattern:n</code> is the group number.</p>
<p>For example,</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúJohn Bull‚Äù; let regexp = /(+) (+)/;</p>
<p>alert( str.replace(regexp, ‚Äò$2, $1‚Äô) ); // Bull, John ```</p>
<p>For named parentheses the reference will be <code>pattern:$&lt;name&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs reformat dates from ‚Äúyear-month-day‚Äù to ‚Äúday.month.year‚Äù:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /(?<year>[0-9]{4})-(?<month>[0-9]{2})-(?<day>[0-9]{2})/g;</p>
<p>let str = ‚Äú2019-10-30, 2020-01-01‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.replace(regexp, ‚Äò<span class="math inline">‚ÄÑ&lt;‚ÄÑ<em>d</em><em>a</em><em>y</em>‚ÄÑ&gt;‚ÄÑ.</span><month>.$<year>‚Äô) ); // 30.10.2019, 01.01.2020 ```</p>
<h2 id="non-capturing-groups-with">Non-capturing groups with ?:</h2>
<p>Sometimes we need parentheses to correctly apply a quantifier, but we don‚Äôt want their contents in results.</p>
<p>A group may be excluded by adding <code>pattern:?:</code> in the beginning.</p>
<p>For instance, if we want to find <code>pattern:(go)+</code>, but don‚Äôt want the parentheses contents (<code>go</code>) as a separate array item, we can write: <code>pattern:(?:go)+</code>.</p>
<p>In the example below we only get the name <code>match:John</code> as a separate member of the match:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúGogogo John!‚Äù;</p>
<p><em>!</em> // ?: exludes ‚Äògo‚Äô from capturing let regexp = /(?:go)+ (+)/i; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>let result = str.match(regexp);</p>
<p>alert( result[0] ); // Gogogo John (full match) alert( result[1] ); // John alert( result.length ); // 2 (no more items in the array) ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-34">Summary</h2>
<p>Parentheses group together a part of the regular expression, so that the quantifier applies to it as a whole.</p>
<p>Parentheses groups are numbered left-to-right, and can optionally be named with <code>(?&lt;name&gt;...)</code>.</p>
<p>The content, matched by a group, can be obtained in the results:</p>
<ul>
<li>The method <code>str.match</code> returns capturing groups only without flag <code>pattern:g</code>.</li>
<li>The method <code>str.matchAll</code> always returns capturing groups.</li>
</ul>
<p>If the parentheses have no name, then their contents is available in the match array by its number. Named parentheses are also available in the property <code>groups</code>.</p>
<p>We can also use parentheses contents in the replacement string in <code>str.replace</code>: by the number <code>$n</code> or the name <code>$&lt;name&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>A group may be excluded from numbering by adding <code>pattern:?:</code> in its start. That‚Äôs used when we need to apply a quantifier to the whole group, but don‚Äôt want it as a separate item in the results array. We also can‚Äôt reference such parentheses in the replacement string. # Backreferences in pattern: and name&gt;</p>
<p>We can use the contents of capturing groups <code>pattern:(...)</code> not only in the result or in the replacement string, but also in the pattern itself.</p>
<h2 id="backreference-by-number">Backreference by number: </h2>
<p>A group can be referenced in the pattern using <code>pattern:\N</code>, where <code>N</code> is the group number.</p>
<p>To make clear why that‚Äôs helpful, let‚Äôs consider a task.</p>
<p>We need to find quoted strings: either single-quoted <code>subject:'...'</code> or a double-quoted <code>subject:"..."</code> ‚Äì both variants should match.</p>
<p>How to find them?</p>
<p>We can put both kinds of quotes in the square brackets: <code>pattern:['"](.*?)['"]</code>, but it would find strings with mixed quotes, like <code>match:"...'</code> and <code>match:'..."</code>. That would lead to incorrect matches when one quote appears inside other ones, like in the string <code>subject:"She's the one!"</code>:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>He said: ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the one!‚Äù.`;</p>
<p>let regexp = /<a href=".*?">‚Äô"</a>[‚Äô"]/g;</p>
<p>// The result is not what we‚Äôd like to have alert( str.match(regexp) ); // "She‚Äô ```</p>
<p>As we can see, the pattern found an opening quote <code>match:"</code>, then the text is consumed till the other quote <code>match:'</code>, that closes the match.</p>
<p>To make sure that the pattern looks for the closing quote exactly the same as the opening one, we can wrap it into a capturing group and backreference it: <code>pattern:(['"])(.*?)\1</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the correct code:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>He said: ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the one!‚Äù.`;</p>
<p><em>!</em> let regexp = /([‚Äô"])(.<em>?)\1/g; </em>/!*</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the one!‚Äù ```</p>
<p>Now it works! The regular expression engine finds the first quote <code>pattern:(['"])</code> and memorizes its content. That‚Äôs the first capturing group.</p>
<p>Further in the pattern <code>pattern:\1</code> means ‚Äúfind the same text as in the first group‚Äù, exactly the same quote in our case.</p>
<p>Similar to that, <code>pattern:\2</code> would mean the contents of the second group, <code>pattern:\3</code> - the 3rd group, and so on.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>If we use `?:` in the group, then we can&#39;t reference it. Groups that are excluded from capturing `(?:...)` are not memorized by the engine.</code></pre>
<p><code>warn header="Don't mess up: in the pattern `pattern:\1`, in the replacement: `pattern:$1`" In the replacement string we use a dollar sign: `pattern:$1`, while in the pattern - a backslash `pattern:\1`.</code></p>
<h2 id="backreference-by-name-kname">Backreference by name: <code>\k&lt;name&gt;</code></h2>
<p>If a regexp has many parentheses, it‚Äôs convenient to give them names.</p>
<p>To reference a named group we can use <code>pattern:\k&lt;name&gt;</code>.</p>
<p>In the example below the group with quotes is named <code>pattern:?&lt;quote&gt;</code>, so the backreference is <code>pattern:\k&lt;quote&gt;</code>:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>He said: ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the one!‚Äù.`;</p>
<p><em>!</em> let regexp = /(?<quote>[‚Äô"])(.<em>?)quote&gt;/g; </em>/!*</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs the one!‚Äù ``` # Alternation (OR) |</p>
<p>Alternation is the term in regular expression that is actually a simple ‚ÄúOR‚Äù.</p>
<p>In a regular expression it is denoted with a vertical line character <code>pattern:|</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, we need to find programming languages: HTML, PHP, Java or JavaScript.</p>
<p>The corresponding regexp: <code>pattern:html|php|java(script)?</code>.</p>
<p>A usage example:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /html|php|css|java(script)?/gi;</p>
<p>let str = ‚ÄúFirst HTML appeared, then CSS, then JavaScript‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // ‚ÄòHTML‚Äô, ‚ÄòCSS‚Äô, ‚ÄòJavaScript‚Äô</p>
<pre><code>
We already saw a similar thing -- square brackets. They allow to choose between multiple characters, for instance `pattern:gr[ae]y` matches `match:gray` or `match:grey`.

Square brackets allow only characters or character classes. Alternation allows any expressions. A regexp `pattern:A|B|C` means one of expressions `A`, `B` or `C`.

For instance:

- `pattern:gr(a|e)y` means exactly the same as `pattern:gr[ae]y`.
- `pattern:gra|ey` means `match:gra` or `match:ey`.

To apply alternation to a chosen part of the pattern, we can enclose it in parentheses:
- `pattern:I love HTML|CSS` matches `match:I love HTML` or `match:CSS`.
- `pattern:I love (HTML|CSS)` matches `match:I love HTML` or `match:I love CSS`.

## Example: regexp for time

In previous articles there was a task to build a regexp for searching time in the form `hh:mm`, for instance `12:00`. But a simple `pattern:\d\d:\d\d` is too vague. It accepts `25:99` as the time (as 99 minutes match the pattern, but that time is invalid).

How can we make a better pattern?

We can use more careful matching. First, the hours:

- If the first digit is `0` or `1`, then the next digit can be any: `pattern:[01]\d`.
- Otherwise, if the first digit is `2`, then the next must be `pattern:[0-3]`.
- (no other first digit is allowed)

We can write both variants in a regexp using alternation: `pattern:[01]\d|2[0-3]`.

Next, minutes must be from `00` to `59`. In the regular expression language that can be written as `pattern:[0-5]\d`: the first digit `0-5`, and then any digit.

If we glue hours and minutes together, we get the pattern: `pattern:[01]\d|2[0-3]:[0-5]\d`.

We&#39;re almost done, but there&#39;s a problem. The alternation `pattern:|` now happens to be between `pattern:[01]\d` and `pattern:2[0-3]:[0-5]\d`.

That is: minutes are added to the second alternation variant, here&#39;s a clear picture:
</code></pre>
<p>[01] 2[0-3]:[0-5]``</p>
<p>That pattern looks for <code>pattern:[01]\d</code> or <code>pattern:2[0-3]:[0-5]\d</code>.</p>
<p>But that‚Äôs wrong, the alternation should only be used in the ‚Äúhours‚Äù part of the regular expression, to allow <code>pattern:[01]\d</code> OR <code>pattern:2[0-3]</code>. Let‚Äôs correct that by enclosing ‚Äúhours‚Äù into parentheses: <code>pattern:([01]\d|2[0-3]):[0-5]\d</code>.</p>
<p>The final solution:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /([01]2[0-3]):[0-5]g;</p>
<p>alert(‚Äú00:00 10:10 23:59 25:99 1:2‚Äù.match(regexp)); // 00:00,10:10,23:59 ``` # Loops: while and for</p>
<p>We often need to repeat actions.</p>
<p>For example, outputting goods from a list one after another or just running the same code for each number from 1 to 10.</p>
<p><em>Loops</em> are a way to repeat the same code multiple times.</p>
<h2 id="the-while-loop">The ‚Äúwhile‚Äù loop</h2>
<p>The <code>while</code> loop has the following syntax:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb271"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb271-1" title="1"><span class="cf">while</span> (condition) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb271-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// code</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb271-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// so-called &quot;loop body&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb271-4" title="4"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>While the <code>condition</code> is truthy, the <code>code</code> from the loop body is executed.</p>
<p>For instance, the loop below outputs <code>i</code> while <code>i &lt; 3</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run let i = 0; while (i &lt; 3) { // shows 0, then 1, then 2   alert( i );   i++; }</code></p>
<p>A single execution of the loop body is called <em>an iteration</em>. The loop in the example above makes three iterations.</p>
<p>If <code>i++</code> was missing from the example above, the loop would repeat (in theory) forever. In practice, the browser provides ways to stop such loops, and in server-side JavaScript, we can kill the process.</p>
<p>Any expression or variable can be a loop condition, not just comparisons: the condition is evaluated and converted to a boolean by <code>while</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, a shorter way to write <code>while (i != 0)</code> is <code>while (i)</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run let i = 3; *!* while (i) { // when i becomes 0, the condition becomes falsy, and the loop stops */!*   alert( i );   i--; }</code></p>
<p>```<code>smart header="Curly braces are not required for a single-line body" If the loop body has a single statement, we can omit the curly braces</code>{‚Ä¶}`:</p>
<p><code>js run let i = 3; *!* while (i) alert(i--); */!*</code> ````</p>
<h2 id="the-do..while-loop">The ‚Äúdo..while‚Äù loop</h2>
<p>The condition check can be moved <em>below</em> the loop body using the <code>do..while</code> syntax:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb272"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb272-1" title="1"><span class="cf">do</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb272-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// loop body</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb272-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">while</span> (condition)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The loop will first execute the body, then check the condition, and, while it‚Äôs truthy, execute it again and again.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p><code>js run let i = 0; do {   alert( i );   i++; } while (i &lt; 3);</code></p>
<p>This form of syntax should only be used when you want the body of the loop to execute <strong>at least once</strong> regardless of the condition being truthy. Usually, the other form is preferred: <code>while(‚Ä¶) {‚Ä¶}</code>.</p>
<h2 id="the-for-loop">The ‚Äúfor‚Äù loop</h2>
<p>The <code>for</code> loop is more complex, but it‚Äôs also the most commonly used loop.</p>
<p>It looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb273"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb273-1" title="1"><span class="cf">for</span> (begin<span class="op">;</span> condition<span class="op">;</span> step) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb273-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// ... loop body ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb273-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Let‚Äôs learn the meaning of these parts by example. The loop below runs <code>alert(i)</code> for <code>i</code> from <code>0</code> up to (but not including) <code>3</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run for (let i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) { // shows 0, then 1, then 2   alert(i); }</code></p>
<p>Let‚Äôs examine the <code>for</code> statement part-by-part:</p>
<table>
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 7%" />
<col style="width: 10%" />
<col style="width: 81%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>part</th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td>begin</td>
<td><code>i = 0</code></td>
<td>Executes once upon entering the loop.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td>condition</td>
<td><code>i &lt; 3</code></td>
<td>Checked before every loop iteration. If false, the loop stops.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td>body</td>
<td><code>alert(i)</code></td>
<td>Runs again and again while the condition is truthy.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td>step</td>
<td><code>i++</code></td>
<td>Executes after the body on each iteration.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>The general loop algorithm works like this:</p>
<pre><code>Run begin
‚Üí (if condition ‚Üí run body and run step)
‚Üí (if condition ‚Üí run body and run step)
‚Üí (if condition ‚Üí run body and run step)
‚Üí ...</code></pre>
<p>That is, <code>begin</code> executes once, and then it iterates: after each <code>condition</code> test, <code>body</code> and <code>step</code> are executed.</p>
<p>If you are new to loops, it could help to go back to the example and reproduce how it runs step-by-step on a piece of paper.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs exactly what happens in our case:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb275"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-1" title="1"><span class="co">// for (let i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) alert(i)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-3" title="3"><span class="co">// run begin</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-4" title="4"><span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-5" title="5"><span class="co">// if condition ‚Üí run body and run step</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-6" title="6"><span class="cf">if</span> (i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">3</span>) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="at">alert</span>(i)<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-7" title="7"><span class="co">// if condition ‚Üí run body and run step</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-8" title="8"><span class="cf">if</span> (i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">3</span>) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="at">alert</span>(i)<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-9" title="9"><span class="co">// if condition ‚Üí run body and run step</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-10" title="10"><span class="cf">if</span> (i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">3</span>) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="at">alert</span>(i)<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span> <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb275-11" title="11"><span class="co">// ...finish, because now i == 3</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>```<code>smart header="Inline variable declaration" Here, the "counter" variable</code>i` is declared right in the loop. This is called an ‚Äúinline‚Äù variable declaration. Such variables are visible only inside the loop.</p>
<p><code>js run for (*!*let*/!* i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) {   alert(i); // 0, 1, 2 } alert(i); // error, no such variable</code></p>
<p>Instead of defining a variable, we could use an existing one:</p>
<p>```js run let i = 0;</p>
<p>for (i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) { // use an existing variable alert(i); // 0, 1, 2 }</p>
<p>alert(i); // 3, visible, because declared outside of the loop</p>
<pre><code></code></pre>
<h3 id="skipping-parts">Skipping parts</h3>
<p>Any part of <code>for</code> can be skipped.</p>
<p>For example, we can omit <code>begin</code> if we don‚Äôt need to do anything at the loop start.</p>
<p>Like here:</p>
<p>```js run let i = 0; // we have i already declared and assigned</p>
<p>for (; i &lt; 3; i++) { // no need for ‚Äúbegin‚Äù alert( i ); // 0, 1, 2 } ```</p>
<p>We can also remove the <code>step</code> part:</p>
<p>```js run let i = 0;</p>
<p>for (; i &lt; 3;) { alert( i++ ); } ```</p>
<p>This makes the loop identical to <code>while (i &lt; 3)</code>.</p>
<p>We can actually remove everything, creating an infinite loop:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb277"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb277-1" title="1"><span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="op">;;</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb277-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// repeats without limits</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb277-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Please note that the two <code>for</code> semicolons <code>;</code> must be present. Otherwise, there would be a syntax error.</p>
<h2 id="breaking-the-loop">Breaking the loop</h2>
<p>Normally, a loop exits when its condition becomes falsy.</p>
<p>But we can force the exit at any time using the special <code>break</code> directive.</p>
<p>For example, the loop below asks the user for a series of numbers, ‚Äúbreaking‚Äù when no number is entered:</p>
<p>```js run let sum = 0;</p>
<p>while (true) {</p>
<p>let value = +prompt(‚ÄúEnter a number‚Äù, ‚Äô‚Äô);</p>
<p><em>!</em> if (!value) break; // (<em>) </em>/!*</p>
<p>sum += value;</p>
<p>} alert( ‚ÄòSum:‚Äô + sum ); ```</p>
<p>The <code>break</code> directive is activated at the line <code>(*)</code> if the user enters an empty line or cancels the input. It stops the loop immediately, passing control to the first line after the loop. Namely, <code>alert</code>.</p>
<p>The combination ‚Äúinfinite loop + <code>break</code> as needed‚Äù is great for situations when a loop‚Äôs condition must be checked not in the beginning or end of the loop, but in the middle or even in several places of its body.</p>
<h2 id="continue-to-the-next-iteration-continue">Continue to the next iteration [#continue]</h2>
<p>The <code>continue</code> directive is a ‚Äúlighter version‚Äù of <code>break</code>. It doesn‚Äôt stop the whole loop. Instead, it stops the current iteration and forces the loop to start a new one (if the condition allows).</p>
<p>We can use it if we‚Äôre done with the current iteration and would like to move on to the next one.</p>
<p>The loop below uses <code>continue</code> to output only odd values:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify for (let i = 0; i &lt; 10; i++) {</p>
<p>// if true, skip the remaining part of the body <em>!</em>if (i % 2 == 0) continue;<em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert(i); // 1, then 3, 5, 7, 9 } ```</p>
<p>For even values of <code>i</code>, the <code>continue</code> directive stops executing the body and passes control to the next iteration of <code>for</code> (with the next number). So the <code>alert</code> is only called for odd values.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="The</code>continue` directive helps decrease nesting" A loop that shows odd values could look like this:</p>
<p>```js run for (let i = 0; i &lt; 10; i++) {</p>
<p>if (i % 2) { alert( i ); }</p>
<p>}</p>
<pre><code>
From a technical point of view, this is identical to the example above. Surely, we can just wrap the code in an `if` block instead of using `continue`.

But as a side-effect, this created one more level of nesting (the `alert` call inside the curly braces). If the code inside of `if` is longer than a few lines, that may decrease the overall readability.</code></pre>
<p>```<code>warn header="No</code>break/continue<code>to the right side of '?'" Please note that syntax constructs that are not expressions cannot be used with the ternary operator</code>?<code>. In particular, directives such as</code>break/continue` aren‚Äôt allowed there.</p>
<p>For example, if we take this code:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb279"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb279-1" title="1"><span class="cf">if</span> (i <span class="op">&gt;</span> <span class="dv">5</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb279-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>(i)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb279-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb279-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">continue</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb279-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶and rewrite it using a question mark:</p>
<p><code>js no-beautify (i &gt; 5) ? alert(i) : *!*continue*/!*; // continue isn't allowed here</code></p>
<p>‚Ä¶it stops working: there‚Äôs a syntax error.</p>
<p>This is just another reason not to use the question mark operator <code>?</code> instead of <code>if</code>. ````</p>
<h2 id="labels-for-breakcontinue">Labels for break/continue</h2>
<p>Sometimes we need to break out from multiple nested loops at once.</p>
<p>For example, in the code below we loop over <code>i</code> and <code>j</code>, prompting for the coordinates <code>(i, j)</code> from <code>(0,0)</code> to <code>(2,2)</code>:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify for (let i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) {</p>
<p>for (let j = 0; j &lt; 3; j++) {</p>
<pre><code>let input = prompt(`Value at coords (${i},${j})`, &#39;&#39;);

// what if we want to exit from here to Done (below)?</code></pre>
<p>} }</p>
<p>alert(‚ÄòDone!‚Äô); ```</p>
<p>We need a way to stop the process if the user cancels the input.</p>
<p>The ordinary <code>break</code> after <code>input</code> would only break the inner loop. That‚Äôs not sufficient ‚Äì labels, come to the rescue!</p>
<p>A <em>label</em> is an identifier with a colon before a loop:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb281"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb281-1" title="1">labelName<span class="op">:</span> <span class="cf">for</span> (...) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb281-2" title="2">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb281-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code>break &lt;labelName&gt;</code> statement in the loop below breaks out to the label:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify <em>!</em>outer:<em>/!</em> for (let i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) {</p>
<p>for (let j = 0; j &lt; 3; j++) {</p>
<pre><code>let input = prompt(`Value at coords (${i},${j})`, &#39;&#39;);

// if an empty string or canceled, then break out of both loops
if (!input) *!*break outer*/!*; // (*)

// do something with the value...</code></pre>
<p>} } alert(‚ÄòDone!‚Äô); ```</p>
<p>In the code above, <code>break outer</code> looks upwards for the label named <code>outer</code> and breaks out of that loop.</p>
<p>So the control goes straight from <code>(*)</code> to <code>alert('Done!')</code>.</p>
<p>We can also move the label onto a separate line:</p>
<p><code>js no-beautify outer: for (let i = 0; i &lt; 3; i++) { ... }</code></p>
<p>The <code>continue</code> directive can also be used with a label. In this case, code execution jumps to the next iteration of the labeled loop.</p>
<p>````warn header=‚ÄúLabels do not allow to "jump" anywhere‚Äù Labels do not allow us to jump into an arbitrary place in the code.</p>
<p>For example, it is impossible to do this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb283"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb283-1" title="1"><span class="cf">break</span> label<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// jump to the label below (doesn&#39;t work)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb283-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb283-3" title="3">label<span class="op">:</span> <span class="cf">for</span> (...)</a></code></pre></div>
<p>A <code>break</code> directive must be inside a code block. Technically, any labelled code block will do, e.g.:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb284"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb284-1" title="1">label<span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb284-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb284-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">break</span> label<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// works</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb284-4" title="4">  <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb284-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶Although, 99.9% of the time <code>break</code> used is inside loops, as we‚Äôve seen in the examples above.</p>
<p>A <code>continue</code> is only possible from inside a loop. ````</p>
<h2 id="summary-35">Summary</h2>
<p>We covered 3 types of loops:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>while</code> ‚Äì The condition is checked before each iteration.</li>
<li><code>do..while</code> ‚Äì The condition is checked after each iteration.</li>
<li><code>for (;;)</code> ‚Äì The condition is checked before each iteration, additional settings available.</li>
</ul>
<p>To make an ‚Äúinfinite‚Äù loop, usually the <code>while(true)</code> construct is used. Such a loop, just like any other, can be stopped with the <code>break</code> directive.</p>
<p>If we don‚Äôt want to do anything in the current iteration and would like to forward to the next one, we can use the <code>continue</code> directive.</p>
<p><code>break/continue</code> support labels before the loop. A label is the only way for <code>break/continue</code> to escape a nested loop to go to an outer one. # Lookahead and lookbehind</p>
<p>Sometimes we need to find only those matches for a pattern that are followed or preceded by another pattern.</p>
