<p>There‚Äôs a special syntax for that, called ‚Äúlookahead‚Äù and ‚Äúlookbehind‚Äù, together referred to as ‚Äúlookaround‚Äù.</p>
<p>For the start, let‚Äôs find the price from the string like <code>subject:1 turkey costs 30‚Ç¨</code>. That is: a number, followed by <code>subject:‚Ç¨</code> sign.</p>
<h2 id="lookahead">Lookahead</h2>
<p>The syntax is: <code>pattern:X(?=Y)</code>, it means ‚Äúlook for <code>pattern:X</code>, but match only if followed by <code>pattern:Y</code>‚Äù. There may be any pattern instead of <code>pattern:X</code> and <code>pattern:Y</code>.</p>
<p>For an integer number followed by <code>subject:‚Ç¨</code>, the regexp will be <code>pattern:\d+(?=‚Ç¨)</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú1 turkey costs 30‚Ç¨‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/(?=‚Ç¨)/) ); // 30, the number 1 is ignored, as it‚Äôs not followed by ‚Ç¨ ```</p>
<p>Please note: the lookahead is merely a test, the contents of the parentheses <code>pattern:(?=...)</code> is not included in the result <code>match:30</code>.</p>
<p>When we look for <code>pattern:X(?=Y)</code>, the regular expression engine finds <code>pattern:X</code> and then checks if there‚Äôs <code>pattern:Y</code> immediately after it. If it‚Äôs not so, then the potential match is skipped, and the search continues.</p>
<p>More complex tests are possible, e.g.¬†<code>pattern:X(?=Y)(?=Z)</code> means:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Find <code>pattern:X</code>.</li>
<li>Check if <code>pattern:Y</code> is immediately after <code>pattern:X</code> (skip if isn‚Äôt).</li>
<li>Check if <code>pattern:Z</code> is also immediately after <code>pattern:X</code> (skip if isn‚Äôt).</li>
<li>If both tests passed, then the <code>pattern:X</code> is a match, otherwise continue searching.</li>
</ol>
<p>In other words, such pattern means that we‚Äôre looking for <code>pattern:X</code> followed by <code>pattern:Y</code> and <code>pattern:Z</code> at the same time.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs only possible if patterns <code>pattern:Y</code> and <code>pattern:Z</code> aren‚Äôt mutually exclusive.</p>
<p>For example, <code>pattern:\d+(?=\s)(?=.*30)</code> looks for <code>pattern:\d+</code> that is followed by a space <code>pattern:(?=\s)</code>, and there‚Äôs <code>30</code> somewhere after it <code>pattern:(?=.*30)</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú1 turkey costs 30‚Ç¨‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/(?=)(?=.*30)/) ); // 1 ```</p>
<p>In our string that exactly matches the number <code>1</code>.</p>
<h2 id="negative-lookahead">Negative lookahead</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs say that we want a quantity instead, not a price from the same string. That‚Äôs a number <code>pattern:\d+</code>, NOT followed by <code>subject:‚Ç¨</code>.</p>
<p>For that, a negative lookahead can be applied.</p>
<p>The syntax is: <code>pattern:X(?!Y)</code>, it means ‚Äúsearch <code>pattern:X</code>, but only if not followed by <code>pattern:Y</code>‚Äù.</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú2 turkeys cost 60‚Ç¨‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/?!‚Ç¨)/g) ); // 2 (the price is not matched) ```</p>
<h2 id="lookbehind">Lookbehind</h2>
<p>Lookahead allows to add a condition for ‚Äúwhat follows‚Äù.</p>
<p>Lookbehind is similar, but it looks behind. That is, it allows to match a pattern only if there‚Äôs something before it.</p>
<p>The syntax is: - Positive lookbehind: <code>pattern:(?&lt;=Y)X</code>, matches <code>pattern:X</code>, but only if there‚Äôs <code>pattern:Y</code> before it. - Negative lookbehind: <code>pattern:(?&lt;!Y)X</code>, matches <code>pattern:X</code>, but only if there‚Äôs no <code>pattern:Y</code> before it.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs change the price to US dollars. The dollar sign is usually before the number, so to look for <code>$30</code> we‚Äôll use <code>pattern:(?&lt;=\$)\d+</code> ‚Äì an amount preceded by <code>subject:$</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú1 turkey costs $30‚Äù;</p>
<p>// the dollar sign is escaped $ alert( str.match(/(?&lt;=$)/) ); // 30 (skipped the sole number) ```</p>
<p>And, if we need the quantity ‚Äì a number, not preceded by <code>subject:$</code>, then we can use a negative lookbehind <code>pattern:(?&lt;!\$)\d+</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú2 turkeys cost $60‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(/(?&lt;!$)/g) ); // 2 (the price is not matched) ```</p>
<h2 id="capturing-groups">Capturing groups</h2>
<p>Generally, the contents inside lookaround parentheses does not become a part of the result.</p>
<p>E.g. in the pattern <code>pattern:\d+(?=‚Ç¨)</code>, the <code>pattern:‚Ç¨</code> sign doesn‚Äôt get captured as a part of the match. That‚Äôs natural: we look for a number <code>pattern:\d+</code>, while <code>pattern:(?=‚Ç¨)</code> is just a test that it should be followed by <code>subject:‚Ç¨</code>.</p>
<p>But in some situations we might want to capture the lookaround expression as well, or a part of it. That‚Äôs possible. Just wrap that part into additional parentheses.</p>
<p>In the example below the currency sign <code>pattern:(‚Ç¨|kr)</code> is captured, along with the amount:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú1 turkey costs 30‚Ç¨‚Äù; let regexp = /(?=(‚Ç¨|kr))/; // extra parentheses around ‚Ç¨|kr</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // 30, ‚Ç¨ ```</p>
<p>And here‚Äôs the same for lookbehind:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äú1 turkey costs $30‚Äù; let regexp = /(?&lt;=($|¬£))/;</p>
<p>alert( str.match(regexp) ); // 30, $ ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-36">Summary</h2>
<p>Lookahead and lookbehind (commonly referred to as ‚Äúlookaround‚Äù) are useful when we‚Äôd like to match something depending on the context before/after it.</p>
<p>For simple regexps we can do the similar thing manually. That is: match everything, in any context, and then filter by context in the loop.</p>
<p>Remember, <code>str.match</code> (without flag <code>pattern:g</code>) and <code>str.matchAll</code> (always) return matches as arrays with <code>index</code> property, so we know where exactly in the text it is, and can check the context.</p>
<p>But generally lookaround is more convenient.</p>
<p>Lookaround types:</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>Pattern</th>
<th>type</th>
<th>matches</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>X(?=Y)</code></td>
<td>Positive lookahead</td>
<td><code>pattern:X</code> if followed by <code>pattern:Y</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>X(?!Y)</code></td>
<td>Negative lookahead</td>
<td><code>pattern:X</code> if not followed by <code>pattern:Y</code></td>

<td><code>(?&lt;=Y)X</code></td>

<td><code>pattern:X</code> if after <code>pattern:Y</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>(?&lt;!Y)X</code></td>
<td>Negative lookbehind</td>
<td><code>pattern:X</code> if not after <code>pattern:Y</code></td>
</tr>

<h1 id="catastrophic-backtracking">Catastrophic backtracking</h1>
<p>Some regular expressions are looking simple, but can execute a veeeeeery long time, and even ‚Äúhang‚Äù the JavaScript engine.</p>
<p>Sooner or later most developers occasionally face such behavior. The typical symptom ‚Äì a regular expression works fine sometimes, but for certain strings it ‚Äúhangs‚Äù, consuming 100% of CPU.</p>
<p>In such case a web-browser suggests to kill the script and reload the page. Not a good thing for sure.</p>
<p>For server-side JavaScript such a regexp may hang the server process, that‚Äôs even worse. So we definitely should take a look at it.</p>
<h2 id="example">Example</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs say we have a string, and we‚Äôd like to check if it consists of words <code>pattern:\w+</code> with an optional space <code>pattern:\s?</code> after each.</p>
<p>An obvious way to construct a regexp would be to take a word followed by an optional space <code>pattern:\w+\s?</code> and then repeat it with <code>*</code>.</p>
<p>That leads us to the regexp <code>pattern:^(\w+\s?)*$</code>, it specifies zero or more such words, that start at the beginning <code>pattern:^</code> and finish at the end <code>pattern:$</code> of the line.</p>
<p>In action:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /^(+?)*$/;</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(‚ÄúA good string‚Äù) ); // true alert( regexp.test(‚ÄúBad characters: $@#‚Äù) ); // false ```</p>
<p>The regexp seems to work. The result is correct. Although, on certain strings it takes a lot of time. So long that JavaScript engine ‚Äúhangs‚Äù with 100% CPU consumption.</p>
<p>If you run the example below, you probably won‚Äôt see anything, as JavaScript will just ‚Äúhang‚Äù. A web-browser will stop reacting on events, the UI will stop working (most browsers allow only scrolling). After some time it will suggest to reload the page. So be careful with this:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /^(+?)*$/; let str = ‚ÄúAn input string that takes a long time or even makes this regexp hang!‚Äù;</p>
<p>// will take a very long time alert( regexp.test(str) ); ```</p>
<p>To be fair, let‚Äôs note that some regular expression engines can handle such a search effectively, for example V8 engine version starting from 8.8 can do that (so Google Chrome 88 doesn‚Äôt hang here), while Firefox browser does hang.</p>
<h2 id="simplified-example">Simplified example</h2>
<p>What‚Äôs the matter? Why does the regular expression hang?</p>
<p>To understand that, let‚Äôs simplify the example: remove spaces <code>pattern:\s?</code>. Then it becomes <code>pattern:^(\w+)*$</code>.</p>
<p>And, to make things more obvious, let‚Äôs replace <code>pattern:\w</code> with <code>pattern:\d</code>. The resulting regular expression still hangs, for instance:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /^()*$/;</p>
<p>let str = ‚Äú012345678901234567890123456789z‚Äù;</p>
<p>// will take a very long time (careful!) alert( regexp.test(str) );</p>
<pre><code>
So what&#39;s wrong with the regexp?

First, one may notice that the regexp `pattern:(\d+)*` is a little bit strange. The quantifier `pattern:*` looks extraneous. If we want a number, we can use `pattern:\d+`.

Indeed, the regexp is artificial; we got it by simplifying the previous example. But the reason why it is slow is the same. So let&#39;s understand it, and then the previous example will become obvious.

What happens during the search of `pattern:^(\d+)*$` in the line `subject:123456789z` (shortened a bit for clarity, please note a non-digit character `subject:z` at the end, it&#39;s important), why does it take so long?

Here&#39;s what the regexp engine does:

1. First, the regexp engine tries to find the content of the parentheses: the number `pattern:\d+`. The plus `pattern:+` is greedy by default, so it consumes all digits:

    ```
    \d+.......
    (123456789)z
    ```

    After all digits are consumed, `pattern:\d+` is considered found (as `match:123456789`).

    Then the star quantifier `pattern:(\d+)*` applies. But there are no more digits in the text, so the star doesn&#39;t give anything.

    The next character in the pattern is the string end `pattern:$`. But in the text we have `subject:z` instead, so there&#39;s no match:

    ```
               X
    \d+........$
    (123456789)z
    ```

2. As there&#39;s no match, the greedy quantifier `pattern:+` decreases the count of repetitions, backtracks one character back.

    Now `pattern:\d+` takes all digits except the last one (`match:12345678`):
    ```
    \d+.......
    (12345678)9z
    ```
3. Then the engine tries to continue the search from the next position (right after `match:12345678`).

    The star `pattern:(\d+)*` can be applied -- it gives one more match of `pattern:\d+`, the number `match:9`:

    ```

    \d+.......\d+
    (12345678)(9)z
    ```

    The engine tries to match `pattern:$` again, but fails, because it meets `subject:z` instead:

    ```
                 X
    \d+.......\d+
    (12345678)(9)z
    ```


4. There&#39;s no match, so the engine will continue backtracking, decreasing the number of repetitions. Backtracking generally works like this: the last greedy quantifier decreases the number of repetitions until it reaches the minimum. Then the previous greedy quantifier decreases, and so on.

    All possible combinations are attempted. Here are their examples.

    The first number `pattern:\d+` has 7 digits, and then a number of 2 digits:

    ```
                 X
    \d+......\d+
    (1234567)(89)z
    ```

    The first number has 7 digits, and then two numbers of 1 digit each:

    ```
                   X
    \d+......\d+\d+
    (1234567)(8)(9)z
    ```

    The first number has 6 digits, and then a number of 3 digits:

    ```
                 X
    \d+.......\d+
    (123456)(789)z
    ```

    The first number has 6 digits, and then 2 numbers:

    ```
                   X
    \d+.....\d+ \d+
    (123456)(78)(9)z
    ```

    ...And so on.


There are many ways to split a sequence of digits `123456789` into numbers. To be precise, there are &lt;code&gt;2&lt;sup&gt;n&lt;/sup&gt;-1&lt;/code&gt;, where `n` is the length of the sequence.

- For `123456789` we have `n=9`, that gives 511 combinations.
- For a longer sequence with `n=20` there are about one million (1048575) combinations.
- For `n=30` - a thousand times more (1073741823 combinations).

Trying each of them is exactly the reason why the search takes so long.

## Back to words and strings

The similar thing happens in our first example, when we look for words by pattern `pattern:^(\w+\s?)*$` in the string `subject:An input that hangs!`.

The reason is that a word can be represented as one `pattern:\w+` or many:
</code></pre>
<p>(input) (inpu)(t) (inp)(u)(t) (in)(p)(ut) ‚Ä¶ ```</p>
<p>For a human, it‚Äôs obvious that there may be no match, because the string ends with an exclamation sign <code>!</code>, but the regular expression expects a wordly character <code>pattern:\w</code> or a space <code>pattern:\s</code> at the end. But the engine doesn‚Äôt know that.</p>
<p>It tries all combinations of how the regexp <code>pattern:(\w+\s?)*</code> can ‚Äúconsume‚Äù the string, including variants with spaces <code>pattern:(\w+\s)*</code> and without them <code>pattern:(\w+)*</code> (because spaces <code>pattern:\s?</code> are optional). As there are many such combinations (we‚Äôve seen it with digits), the search takes a lot of time.</p>
<p>What to do?</p>
<p>Should we turn on the lazy mode?</p>
<p>Unfortunately, that won‚Äôt help: if we replace <code>pattern:\w+</code> with <code>pattern:\w+?</code>, the regexp will still hang. The order of combinations will change, but not their total count.</p>
<p>Some regular expression engines have tricky tests and finite automations that allow to avoid going through all combinations or make it much faster, but most engines don‚Äôt, and it doesn‚Äôt always help.</p>
<h2 id="how-to-fix">How to fix?</h2>
<p>There are two main approaches to fixing the problem.</p>
<p>The first is to lower the number of possible combinations.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs make the space non-optional by rewriting the regular expression as <code>pattern:^(\w+\s)*\w*$</code> - we‚Äôll look for any number of words followed by a space <code>pattern:(\w+\s)*</code>, and then (optionally) a final word <code>pattern:\w*</code>.</p>
<p>This regexp is equivalent to the previous one (matches the same) and works well:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /^(+)*$/; let str = ‚ÄúAn input string that takes a long time or even makes this regex hang!‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(str) ); // false</p>
<pre><code>
Why did the problem disappear?

That&#39;s because now the space is mandatory.

The previous regexp, if we omit the space, becomes `pattern:(\w+)*`, leading to many combinations of `\w+` within a single word

So `subject:input` could be matched as two repetitions of `pattern:\w+`, like this:
</code></pre>
<p>+ + (inp)(ut)</p>
<pre><code>
The new pattern is different: `pattern:(\w+\s)*` specifies repetitions of words followed by a space! The `subject:input` string can&#39;t be matched as two repetitions of `pattern:\w+\s`, because the space is mandatory.

The time needed to try a lot of (actually most of) combinations is now saved.

## Preventing backtracking

It&#39;s not always convenient to rewrite a regexp though. In the example above it was easy, but it&#39;s not always obvious how to do it.

Besides, a rewritten regexp is usually more complex, and that&#39;s not good. Regexps are complex enough without extra efforts.

Luckily, there&#39;s an alternative approach. We can forbid backtracking for the quantifier.

The root of the problem is that the regexp engine tries many combinations that are obviously wrong for a human.

E.g. in the regexp `pattern:(\d+)*$` it&#39;s obvious for a human, that `pattern:+` shouldn&#39;t backtrack. If we replace one `pattern:\d+` with two separate `pattern:\d+\d+`, nothing changes:
</code></pre>
<p>‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.. (123456789)!</p>
<p>‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. (1234)(56789)! ```</p>
<p>And in the original example <code>pattern:^(\w+\s?)*$</code> we may want to forbid backtracking in <code>pattern:\w+</code>. That is: <code>pattern:\w+</code> should match a whole word, with the maximal possible length. There‚Äôs no need to lower the repetitions count in <code>pattern:\w+</code> or to split it into two words <code>pattern:\w+\w+</code> and so on.</p>
<p>Modern regular expression engines support possessive quantifiers for that. Regular quantifiers become possessive if we add <code>pattern:+</code> after them. That is, we use <code>pattern:\d++</code> instead of <code>pattern:\d+</code> to stop <code>pattern:+</code> from backtracking.</p>
<p>Possessive quantifiers are in fact simpler than ‚Äúregular‚Äù ones. They just match as many as they can, without any backtracking. The search process without bracktracking is simpler.</p>
<p>There are also so-called ‚Äúatomic capturing groups‚Äù - a way to disable backtracking inside parentheses.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But the bad news is that, unfortunately, in JavaScript they are not supported.</p>
<p>We can emulate them though using a ‚Äúlookahead transform‚Äù.</p>
<h3 id="lookahead-to-the-rescue">Lookahead to the rescue!</h3>
<p>So we‚Äôve come to real advanced topics. We‚Äôd like a quantifier, such as <code>pattern:+</code> not to backtrack, because sometimes backtracking makes no sense.</p>
<p>The pattern to take as many repetitions of <code>pattern:\w</code> as possible without backtracking is: <code>pattern:(?=(\w+))\1</code>. Of course, we could take another pattern instead of <code>pattern:\w</code>.</p>
<p>That may seem odd, but it‚Äôs actually a very simple transform.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs decipher it:</p>
<ul>
<li>Lookahead <code>pattern:?=</code> looks forward for the longest word <code>pattern:\w+</code> starting at the current position.</li>
<li>The contents of parentheses with <code>pattern:?=...</code> isn‚Äôt memorized by the engine, so wrap <code>pattern:\w+</code> into parentheses. Then the engine will memorize their contents</li>
<li>‚Ä¶And allow us to reference it in the pattern as <code>pattern:\1</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>That is: we look ahead - and if there‚Äôs a word <code>pattern:\w+</code>, then match it as <code>pattern:\1</code>.</p>
<p>Why? That‚Äôs because the lookahead finds a word <code>pattern:\w+</code> as a whole and we capture it into the pattern with <code>pattern:\1</code>. So we essentially implemented a possessive plus <code>pattern:+</code> quantifier. It captures only the whole word <code>pattern:\w+</code>, not a part of it.</p>
<p>For instance, in the word <code>subject:JavaScript</code> it may not only match <code>match:Java</code>, but leave out <code>match:Script</code> to match the rest of the pattern.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the comparison of two patterns:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "JavaScript".match(/\w+Script/)); // JavaScript alert( "JavaScript".match(/(?=(\w+))\1Script/)); // null</code></p>
<ol type="1">
<li>In the first variant <code>pattern:\w+</code> first captures the whole word <code>subject:JavaScript</code> but then <code>pattern:+</code> backtracks character by character, to try to match the rest of the pattern, until it finally succeeds (when <code>pattern:\w+</code> matches <code>match:Java</code>).</li>
<li>In the second variant <code>pattern:(?=(\w+))</code> looks ahead and finds the word <code>subject:JavaScript</code>, that is included into the pattern as a whole by <code>pattern:\1</code>, so there remains no way to find <code>subject:Script</code> after it.</li>
</ol>
<p>We can put a more complex regular expression into <code>pattern:(?=(\w+))\1</code> instead of <code>pattern:\w</code>, when we need to forbid backtracking for <code>pattern:+</code> after it.</p>
<pre class="smart"><code>There&#39;s more about the relation between possessive quantifiers and lookahead in articles [Regex: Emulate Atomic Grouping (and Possessive Quantifiers) with LookAhead](http://instanceof.me/post/52245507631/regex-emulate-atomic-grouping-with-lookahead) and [Mimicking Atomic Groups](http://blog.stevenlevithan.com/archives/mimic-atomic-groups).</code></pre>
<p>Let‚Äôs rewrite the first example using lookahead to prevent backtracking:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /^((?=(+))\2?)*$/;</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(‚ÄúA good string‚Äù) ); // true</p>
<p>let str = ‚ÄúAn input string that takes a long time or even makes this regex hang!‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(str) ); // false, works and fast! ```</p>
<p>Here <code>pattern:\2</code> is used instead of <code>pattern:\1</code>, because there are additional outer parentheses. To avoid messing up with the numbers, we can give the parentheses a name, e.g.¬†<code>pattern:(?&lt;word&gt;\w+)</code>.</p>
<p>```js run // parentheses are named ?<word>, referenced as word&gt; let regexp = /^((?=(?<word>+))word&gt;?)*$/;</p>
<p>let str = ‚ÄúAn input string that takes a long time or even makes this regex hang!‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(str) ); // false</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(‚ÄúA correct string‚Äù) ); // true ```</p>
<p>The problem described in this article is called ‚Äúcatastrophic backtracking‚Äù.</p>
<p>We covered two ways how to solve it: - Rewrite the regexp to lower the possible combinations count. - Prevent backtracking.</p>
<h1 id="sticky-flag-y-searching-at-position">Sticky flag ‚Äúy‚Äù, searching at position</h1>
<p>The flag <code>pattern:y</code> allows to perform the search at the given position in the source string.</p>
<p>To grasp the use case of <code>pattern:y</code> flag, and better understand the ways of regexps, let‚Äôs explore a practical example.</p>
<p>One of common tasks for regexps is ‚Äúlexical analysis‚Äù: we get a text, e.g.¬†in a programming language, and need to find its structural elements. For instance, HTML has tags and attributes, JavaScript code has functions, variables, and so on.</p>
<p>Writing lexical analyzers is a special area, with its own tools and algorithms, so we don‚Äôt go deep in there, but there‚Äôs a common task: to read something at the given position.</p>
<p>E.g. we have a code string <code>subject:let varName = "value"</code>, and we need to read the variable name from it, that starts at position <code>4</code>.</p>
<p>We‚Äôll look for variable name using regexp <code>pattern:\w+</code>. Actually, JavaScript variable names need a bit more complex regexp for accurate matching, but here it doesn‚Äôt matter.</p>
<ul>
<li>A call to <code>str.match(/\w+/)</code> will find only the first word in the line (<code>let</code>). That‚Äôs not it.</li>
<li>We can add the flag <code>pattern:g</code>. But then the call <code>str.match(/\w+/g)</code> will look for all words in the text, while we need one word at position <code>4</code>. Again, not what we need.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>So, how to search for a regexp exactly at the given position?</strong></p>
<p>Let‚Äôs try using method <code>regexp.exec(str)</code>.</p>
<p>For a <code>regexp</code> without flags <code>pattern:g</code> and <code>pattern:y</code>, this method looks only for the first match, it works exactly like <code>str.match(regexp)</code>.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But if there‚Äôs flag <code>pattern:g</code>, then it performs the search in <code>str</code>, starting from position stored in the <code>regexp.lastIndex</code> property. And, if it finds a match, then sets <code>regexp.lastIndex</code> to the index immediately after the match.</p>
<p>In other words, <code>regexp.lastIndex</code> serves as a starting point for the search, that each <code>regexp.exec(str)</code> call resets to the new value (‚Äúafter the last match‚Äù). That‚Äôs only if there‚Äôs <code>pattern:g</code> flag, of course.</p>
<p>So, successive calls to <code>regexp.exec(str)</code> return matches one after another.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example of such calls:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äòlet varName‚Äô; // Let‚Äôs find all words in this string let regexp = /+/g;</p>
<p>alert(regexp.lastIndex); // 0 (initially lastIndex=0)</p>
<p>let word1 = regexp.exec(str); alert(word1[0]); // let (1st word) alert(regexp.lastIndex); // 3 (position after the match)</p>
<p>let word2 = regexp.exec(str); alert(word2[0]); // varName (2nd word) alert(regexp.lastIndex); // 11 (position after the match)</p>
<p>let word3 = regexp.exec(str); alert(word3); // null (no more matches) alert(regexp.lastIndex); // 0 (resets at search end) ```</p>
<p>We can get all matches in the loop:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äòlet varName‚Äô; let regexp = /+/g;</p>
<p>let result;</p>
<p>while (result = regexp.exec(str)) { alert( <code>Found ${result[0]} at position ${result.index}</code> ); // Found let at position 0, then // Found varName at position 4 } ```</p>
<p>Such use of <code>regexp.exec</code> is an alternative to method <code>str.matchAll</code>, with a bit more control over the process.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs go back to our task.</p>
<p>We can manually set <code>lastIndex</code> to <code>4</code>, to start the search from the given position!</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äòlet varName = ‚Äúvalue‚Äù‚Äô;</p>
<p>let regexp = /+/g; // without flag ‚Äúg‚Äù, property lastIndex is ignored</p>
<p><em>!</em> regexp.lastIndex = 4; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>let word = regexp.exec(str); alert(word); // varName ```</p>
<p>Hooray! Problem solved!</p>
<p>We performed a search of <code>pattern:\w+</code>, starting from position <code>regexp.lastIndex = 4</code>.</p>
<p>The result is correct.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But wait, not so fast.</p>
<p>Please note: the <code>regexp.exec</code> call starts searching at position <code>lastIndex</code> and then goes further. If there‚Äôs no word at position <code>lastIndex</code>, but it‚Äôs somewhere after it, then it will be found:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äòlet varName = ‚Äúvalue‚Äù‚Äô;</p>
<p>let regexp = /+/g;</p>
<p><em>!</em> // start the search from position 3 regexp.lastIndex = 3; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>let word = regexp.exec(str); // found the match at position 4 alert(word[0]); // varName alert(word.index); // 4 ```</p>
<p>For some tasks, including the lexical analysis, that‚Äôs just wrong. We need to find a match exactly at the given position at the text, not somewhere after it. And that‚Äôs what the flag <code>y</code> is for.</p>
<p><strong>The flag <code>pattern:y</code> makes <code>regexp.exec</code> to search exactly at position <code>lastIndex</code>, not ‚Äústarting from‚Äù it.</strong></p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the same search with flag <code>pattern:y</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äòlet varName = ‚Äúvalue‚Äù‚Äô;</p>
<p>let regexp = /+/y;</p>
<p>regexp.lastIndex = 3; alert( regexp.exec(str) ); // null (there‚Äôs a space at position 3, not a word)</p>
<p>regexp.lastIndex = 4; alert( regexp.exec(str) ); // varName (word at position 4) ```</p>
<p>As we can see, regexp <code>pattern:/\w+/y</code> doesn‚Äôt match at position <code>3</code> (unlike the flag <code>pattern:g</code>), but matches at position <code>4</code>.</p>
<p>Not only that‚Äôs what we need, there‚Äôs an important performance gain when using flag <code>pattern:y</code>.</p>
<p>Imagine, we have a long text, and there are no matches in it, at all. Then a search with flag <code>pattern:g</code> will go till the end of the text and find nothing, and this will take significantly more time than the search with flag <code>pattern:y</code>, that checks only the exact position.</p>
<p>In tasks like lexical analysis, there are usually many searches at an exact position, to check what we have there. Using flag <code>pattern:y</code> is the key for correct implementations and a good performance. # Methods of RegExp and String</p>
<p>In this article we‚Äôll cover various methods that work with regexps in-depth.</p>
<h2 id="str.matchregexp">str.match(regexp)</h2>
<p>The method <code>str.match(regexp)</code> finds matches for <code>regexp</code> in the string <code>str</code>.</p>
<p>It has 3 modes:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>If the <code>regexp</code> doesn‚Äôt have flag <code>pattern:g</code>, then it returns the first match as an array with capturing groups and properties <code>index</code> (position of the match), <code>input</code> (input string, equals <code>str</code>):</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúI love JavaScript‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.match(/Java(Script)/);</p>
<p>alert( result[0] ); // JavaScript (full match) alert( result[1] ); // Script (first capturing group) alert( result.length ); // 2</p>
<p>// Additional information: alert( result.index ); // 7 (match position) alert( result.input ); // I love JavaScript (source string) ```</p></li>
<li><p>If the <code>regexp</code> has flag <code>pattern:g</code>, then it returns an array of all matches as strings, without capturing groups and other details. ```js run let str = ‚ÄúI love JavaScript‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.match(/Java(Script)/g);</p>
<p>alert( result[0] ); // JavaScript alert( result.length ); // 1 ```</p></li>
<li><p>If there are no matches, no matter if there‚Äôs flag <code>pattern:g</code> or not, <code>null</code> is returned.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs an important nuance. If there are no matches, we don‚Äôt get an empty array, but <code>null</code>. It‚Äôs easy to make a mistake forgetting about it, e.g.:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúI love JavaScript‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.match(/HTML/);</p>
<p>alert(result); // null alert(result.length); // Error: Cannot read property ‚Äòlength‚Äô of null ```</p>
<p>If we want the result to be an array, we can write like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb289"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb289-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">str</span>.<span class="at">match</span>(regexp) <span class="op">||</span> []<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="str.matchallregexp">str.matchAll(regexp)</h2>
<p>[recent browser=‚Äúnew‚Äù]</p>
<p>The method <code>str.matchAll(regexp)</code> is a ‚Äúnewer, improved‚Äù variant of <code>str.match</code>.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs used mainly to search for all matches with all groups.</p>
<p>There are 3 differences from <code>match</code>:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>It returns an iterable object with matches instead of an array. We can make a regular array from it using <code>Array.from</code>.</li>
<li>Every match is returned as an array with capturing groups (the same format as <code>str.match</code> without flag <code>pattern:g</code>).</li>
<li>If there are no results, it returns not <code>null</code>, but an empty iterable object.</li>
</ol>
<p>Usage example:</p>
```js run let str = ‚Äô
<h1>
Hello, world!
</h1>
<p>‚Äô; let regexp = /&lt;(.*?)&gt;/g;</p>
<p>let matchAll = str.matchAll(regexp);</p>
<p>alert(matchAll); // [object RegExp String Iterator], not array, but an iterable</p>
<p>matchAll = Array.from(matchAll); // array now</p>
let firstMatch = matchAll[0]; alert( firstMatch[0] ); //
<h1>
alert( firstMatch[1] ); // h1 alert( firstMatch.index ); // 0 alert( firstMatch.input ); //
<h1>
Hello, world!
</h1>
<p>```</p>
<p>If we use <code>for..of</code> to loop over <code>matchAll</code> matches, then we don‚Äôt need <code>Array.from</code> any more.</p>
<h2 id="str.splitregexpsubstr-limit">str.split(regexp|substr, limit)</h2>
<p>Splits the string using the regexp (or a substring) as a delimiter.</p>
<p>We can use <code>split</code> with strings, like this:</p>
<p><code>js run alert('12-34-56'.split('-')) // array of ['12', '34', '56']</code></p>
<p>But we can split by a regular expression, the same way:</p>
<p><code>js run alert('12, 34, 56'.split(/,\s*/)) // array of ['12', '34', '56']</code></p>
<h2 id="str.searchregexp">str.search(regexp)</h2>
<p>The method <code>str.search(regexp)</code> returns the position of the first match or <code>-1</code> if none found:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúA drop of ink may make a million think‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.search( /ink/i ) ); // 10 (first match position) ```</p>
<p><strong>The important limitation: <code>search</code> only finds the first match.</strong></p>
<p>If we need positions of further matches, we should use other means, such as finding them all with <code>str.matchAll(regexp)</code>.</p>
<h2 id="str.replacestrregexp-strfunc">str.replace(str|regexp, str|func)</h2>
<p>This is a generic method for searching and replacing, one of most useful ones. The swiss army knife for searching and replacing.</p>
<p>We can use it without regexps, to search and replace a substring:</p>
<p><code>js run // replace a dash by a colon alert('12-34-56'.replace("-", ":")) // 12:34-56</code></p>
<p>There‚Äôs a pitfall though.</p>
<p><strong>When the first argument of <code>replace</code> is a string, it only replaces the first match.</strong></p>
<p>You can see that in the example above: only the first <code>"-"</code> is replaced by <code>":"</code>.</p>
<p>To find all hyphens, we need to use not the string <code>"-"</code>, but a regexp <code>pattern:/-/g</code>, with the obligatory <code>pattern:g</code> flag:</p>
<p><code>js run // replace all dashes by a colon alert( '12-34-56'.replace( *!*/-/g*/!*, ":" ) )  // 12:34:56</code></p>
<p>The second argument is a replacement string. We can use special characters in it:</p>
<table>
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 50%" />
<col style="width: 50%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>Symbols</th>
<th>Action in the replacement string</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>$&amp;</code></td>
<td>inserts the whole match</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code><span class="math inline">$&amp;#096;&lt;/code&gt;|inserts a part of the string before the match| |`$</span>‚Äô<code>|inserts a part of the string after the match| |</code><span class="math inline">$n`|if `n` is a 1-2 digit number, inserts the contents of n-th capturing group, for details see [](info:regexp-groups)| |`$</span><name><code>|inserts the contents of the parentheses with the given</code>name<code>, for details see [](info:regexp-groups)| |</code>$<span class="math inline">$`|inserts character `$</span>`</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúJohn Smith‚Äù;</p>
<p>// swap first and last name alert(str.replace(/(john) (smith)/i, ‚Äò$2, $1‚Äô)) // Smith, John ```</p>
<p><strong>For situations that require ‚Äúsmart‚Äù replacements, the second argument can be a function.</strong></p>
<p>It will be called for each match, and the returned value will be inserted as a replacement.</p>
<p>The function is called with arguments <code>func(match, p1, p2, ..., pn, offset, input, groups)</code>:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><code>match</code> ‚Äì the match,</li>
<li><code>p1, p2, ..., pn</code> ‚Äì contents of capturing groups (if there are any),</li>
<li><code>offset</code> ‚Äì position of the match,</li>
<li><code>input</code> ‚Äì the source string,</li>
<li><code>groups</code> ‚Äì an object with named groups.</li>
</ol>
<p>If there are no parentheses in the regexp, then there are only 3 arguments: <code>func(str, offset, input)</code>.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs uppercase all matches:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äúhtml and css‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.replace(/html|css/gi, str =&gt; str.toUpperCase());</p>
<p>alert(result); // HTML and CSS ```</p>
<p>Replace each match by its position in the string:</p>
<p><code>js run alert("Ho-Ho-ho".replace(/ho/gi, (match, offset) =&gt; offset)); // 0-3-6</code></p>
<p>In the example below there are two parentheses, so the replacement function is called with 5 arguments: the first is the full match, then 2 parentheses, and after it (not used in the example) the match position and the source string:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúJohn Smith‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.replace(/(+) (+)/, (match, name, surname) =&gt; <code>${surname}, ${name}</code>);</p>
<p>alert(result); // Smith, John ```</p>
<p>If there are many groups, it‚Äôs convenient to use rest parameters to access them:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúJohn Smith‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.replace(/(+) (+)/, (‚Ä¶match) =&gt; <code>${match[2]}, ${match[1]}</code>);</p>
<p>alert(result); // Smith, John ```</p>
<p>Or, if we‚Äôre using named groups, then <code>groups</code> object with them is always the last, so we can obtain it like this:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúJohn Smith‚Äù;</p>
<p>let result = str.replace(/(?<name>+) (?<surname>+)/, (‚Ä¶match) =&gt; { let groups = match.pop();</p>
<p>return <code>${groups.surname}, ${groups.name}</code>; });</p>
<p>alert(result); // Smith, John ```</p>
<p>Using a function gives us the ultimate replacement power, because it gets all the information about the match, has access to outer variables and can do everything.</p>
<h2 id="str.replaceallstrregexp-strfunc">str.replaceAll(str|regexp, str|func)</h2>
<p>This method is essentially the same as <code>str.replace</code>, with two major differences:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>If the first argument is a string, it replaces <em>all occurences</em> of the string, while <code>replace</code> replaces only the <em>first occurence</em>.</li>
<li>If the first argument is a regular expression without the <code>g</code> flag, there‚Äôll be an error. With <code>g</code> flag, it works the same as <code>replace</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>The main use case for <code>replaceAll</code> is replacing all occurences of a string.</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<p><code>js run // replace all dashes by a colon alert('12-34-56'.replaceAll("-", ":")) // 12:34:56</code></p>
<h2 id="regexp.execstr">regexp.exec(str)</h2>
<p>The method <code>regexp.exec(str)</code> method returns a match for <code>regexp</code> in the string <code>str</code>. Unlike previous methods, it‚Äôs called on a regexp, not on a string.</p>
<p>It behaves differently depending on whether the regexp has flag <code>pattern:g</code>.</p>
<p>If there‚Äôs no <code>pattern:g</code>, then <code>regexp.exec(str)</code> returns the first match exactly as <code>str.match(regexp)</code>. This behavior doesn‚Äôt bring anything new.</p>
<p>But if there‚Äôs flag <code>pattern:g</code>, then: - A call to <code>regexp.exec(str)</code> returns the first match and saves the position immediately after it in the property <code>regexp.lastIndex</code>. - The next such call starts the search from position <code>regexp.lastIndex</code>, returns the next match and saves the position after it in <code>regexp.lastIndex</code>. - ‚Ä¶And so on. - If there are no matches, <code>regexp.exec</code> returns <code>null</code> and resets <code>regexp.lastIndex</code> to <code>0</code>.</p>
<p>So, repeated calls return all matches one after another, using property <code>regexp.lastIndex</code> to keep track of the current search position.</p>
<p>In the past, before the method <code>str.matchAll</code> was added to JavaScript, calls of <code>regexp.exec</code> were used in the loop to get all matches with groups:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòMore about JavaScript at https://javascript.info‚Äô; let regexp = /javascript/ig;</p>
<p>let result;</p>
<p>while (result = regexp.exec(str)) { alert( <code>Found ${result[0]} at position ${result.index}</code> ); // Found JavaScript at position 11, then // Found javascript at position 33 } ```</p>
<p>This works now as well, although for newer browsers <code>str.matchAll</code> is usually more convenient.</p>
<p><strong>We can use <code>regexp.exec</code> to search from a given position by manually setting <code>lastIndex</code>.</strong></p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòHello, world!‚Äô;</p>
<p>let regexp = /+/g; // without flag ‚Äúg‚Äù, lastIndex property is ignored regexp.lastIndex = 5; // search from 5th position (from the comma)</p>
<p>alert( regexp.exec(str) ); // world ```</p>
<p>If the regexp has flag <code>pattern:y</code>, then the search will be performed exactly at the position <code>regexp.lastIndex</code>, not any further.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs replace flag <code>pattern:g</code> with <code>pattern:y</code> in the example above. There will be no matches, as there‚Äôs no word at position <code>5</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòHello, world!‚Äô;</p>
<p>let regexp = /+/y; regexp.lastIndex = 5; // search exactly at position 5</p>
<p>alert( regexp.exec(str) ); // null ```</p>
<p>That‚Äôs convenient for situations when we need to ‚Äúread‚Äù something from the string by a regexp at the exact position, not somewhere further.</p>
<h2 id="regexp.teststr">regexp.test(str)</h2>
<p>The method <code>regexp.test(str)</code> looks for a match and returns <code>true/false</code> whether it exists.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúI love JavaScript‚Äù;</p>
<p>// these two tests do the same alert( <em>!</em>/love/i<em>/!</em>.test(str) ); // true alert( str.search(<em>!</em>/love/i<em>/!</em>) != -1 ); // true ```</p>
<p>An example with the negative answer:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúBla-bla-bla‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( <em>!</em>/love/i<em>/!</em>.test(str) ); // false alert( str.search(<em>!</em>/love/i<em>/!</em>) != -1 ); // false ```</p>
<p>If the regexp has flag <code>pattern:g</code>, then <code>regexp.test</code> looks from <code>regexp.lastIndex</code> property and updates this property, just like <code>regexp.exec</code>.</p>
<p>So we can use it to search from a given position:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /love/gi;</p>
<p>let str = ‚ÄúI love JavaScript‚Äù;</p>
<p>// start the search from position 10: regexp.lastIndex = 10; alert( regexp.test(str) ); // false (no match) ```</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Same global regexp tested repeatedly on different sources may fail" If we apply the same global regexp to different inputs, it may lead to wrong result, because</code>regexp.test<code>call advances</code>regexp.lastIndex` property, so the search in another string may start from non-zero position.</p>
<p>For instance, here we call <code>regexp.test</code> twice on the same text, and the second time fails:</p>
<p>```js run let regexp = /javascript/g; // (regexp just created: regexp.lastIndex=0)</p>
<p>alert( regexp.test(‚Äújavascript‚Äù) ); // true (regexp.lastIndex=10 now) alert( regexp.test(‚Äújavascript‚Äù) ); // false</p>
<pre><code>
That&#39;s exactly because `regexp.lastIndex` is non-zero in the second test.

To work around that, we can set `regexp.lastIndex = 0` before each search. Or instead of calling methods on regexp, use string methods `str.match/search/...`, they don&#39;t use `lastIndex`.</code></pre>
<h1 id="the-switch-statement">The ‚Äúswitch‚Äù statement</h1>
<p>A <code>switch</code> statement can replace multiple <code>if</code> checks.</p>
<p>It gives a more descriptive way to compare a value with multiple variants.</p>
<h2 id="the-syntax">The syntax</h2>
<p>The <code>switch</code> has one or more <code>case</code> blocks and an optional default.</p>
<p>It looks like this:</p>
<p>```js no-beautify switch(x) { case ‚Äòvalue1‚Äô: // if (x === ‚Äòvalue1‚Äô) ‚Ä¶ [break]</p>
<p>case ‚Äòvalue2‚Äô: // if (x === ‚Äòvalue2‚Äô) ‚Ä¶ [break]</p>
<p>default: ‚Ä¶ [break] } ```</p>
<ul>
<li>The value of <code>x</code> is checked for a strict equality to the value from the first <code>case</code> (that is, <code>value1</code>) then to the second (<code>value2</code>) and so on.</li>
<li>If the equality is found, <code>switch</code> starts to execute the code starting from the corresponding <code>case</code>, until the nearest <code>break</code> (or until the end of <code>switch</code>).</li>
<li>If no case is matched then the <code>default</code> code is executed (if it exists).</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="an-example">An example</h2>
<p>An example of <code>switch</code> (the executed code is highlighted):</p>
<p>```js run let a = 2 + 2;</p>
<p>switch (a) { case 3: alert( ‚ÄòToo small‚Äô ); break; <em>!</em> case 4: alert( ‚ÄòExactly!‚Äô ); break; <em>/!</em> case 5: alert( ‚ÄòToo big‚Äô ); break; default: alert( ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know such values‚Äù ); } ```</p>
<p>Here the <code>switch</code> starts to compare <code>a</code> from the first <code>case</code> variant that is <code>3</code>. The match fails.</p>
<p>Then <code>4</code>. That‚Äôs a match, so the execution starts from <code>case 4</code> until the nearest <code>break</code>.</p>
<p><strong>If there is no <code>break</code> then the execution continues with the next <code>case</code> without any checks.</strong></p>
<p>An example without <code>break</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let a = 2 + 2;</p>
<p>switch (a) { case 3: alert( ‚ÄòToo small‚Äô ); <em>!</em> case 4: alert( ‚ÄòExactly!‚Äô ); case 5: alert( ‚ÄòToo big‚Äô ); default: alert( ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know such values‚Äù ); <em>/!</em> } ```</p>
<p>In the example above we‚Äôll see sequential execution of three <code>alert</code>s:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb291"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb291-1" title="1"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&#39;Exactly!&#39;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb291-2" title="2"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&#39;Too big&#39;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb291-3" title="3"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&quot;I don&#39;t know such values&quot;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>```<code>smart header="Any expression can be a</code>switch/case<code>argument" Both</code>switch<code>and</code>case` allow arbitrary expressions.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>```js run let a = ‚Äú1‚Äù; let b = 0;</p>
<p>switch (+a) { <em>!</em> case b + 1: alert(‚Äúthis runs, because +a is 1, exactly equals b+1‚Äù); break; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>default: alert(‚Äúthis doesn‚Äôt run‚Äù); }</p>
<pre><code>Here `+a` gives `1`, that&#39;s compared with `b + 1` in `case`, and the corresponding code is executed.</code></pre>
<h2 id="grouping-of-case">Grouping of ‚Äúcase‚Äù</h2>
<p>Several variants of <code>case</code> which share the same code can be grouped.</p>
<p>For example, if we want the same code to run for <code>case 3</code> and <code>case 5</code>:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify let a = 3;</p>
<p>switch (a) { case 4: alert(‚ÄòRight!‚Äô); break;</p>
<p><em>!</em> case 3: // (<em>) grouped two cases case 5: alert(‚ÄòWrong!‚Äô); alert(‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you take a math class?‚Äù); break; </em>/!*</p>
<p>default: alert(‚ÄòThe result is strange. Really.‚Äô); } ```</p>
<p>Now both <code>3</code> and <code>5</code> show the same message.</p>
<p>The ability to ‚Äúgroup‚Äù cases is a side-effect of how <code>switch/case</code> works without <code>break</code>. Here the execution of <code>case 3</code> starts from the line <code>(*)</code> and goes through <code>case 5</code>, because there‚Äôs no <code>break</code>.</p>
<h2 id="type-matters">Type matters</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs emphasize that the equality check is always strict. The values must be of the same type to match.</p>
<p>For example, let‚Äôs consider the code:</p>
<p>```js run let arg = prompt(‚ÄúEnter a value?‚Äù); switch (arg) { case ‚Äò0‚Äô: case ‚Äò1‚Äô: alert( ‚ÄòOne or zero‚Äô ); break;</p>
<p>case ‚Äò2‚Äô: alert( ‚ÄòTwo‚Äô ); break;</p>
<p>case 3: alert( ‚ÄòNever executes!‚Äô ); break; default: alert( ‚ÄòAn unknown value‚Äô ); } ```</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>For <code>0</code>, <code>1</code>, the first <code>alert</code> runs.</li>
<li>For <code>2</code> the second <code>alert</code> runs.</li>
<li>But for <code>3</code>, the result of the <code>prompt</code> is a string <code>"3"</code>, which is not strictly equal <code>===</code> to the number <code>3</code>. So we‚Äôve got a dead code in <code>case 3</code>! The <code>default</code> variant will execute. # Functions</li>
</ol>
<p>Quite often we need to perform a similar action in many places of the script.</p>
<p>For example, we need to show a nice-looking message when a visitor logs in, logs out and maybe somewhere else.</p>
<p>Functions are the main ‚Äúbuilding blocks‚Äù of the program. They allow the code to be called many times without repetition.</p>
<p>We‚Äôve already seen examples of built-in functions, like <code>alert(message)</code>, <code>prompt(message, default)</code> and <code>confirm(question)</code>. But we can create functions of our own as well.</p>
<h2 id="function-declaration">Function Declaration</h2>
<p>To create a function we can use a <em>function declaration</em>.</p>
<p>It looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb293"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb293-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showMessage</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb293-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&#39;Hello everyone!&#39;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb293-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The <code>function</code> keyword goes first, then goes the <em>name of the function</em>, then a list of <em>parameters</em> between the parentheses (comma-separated, empty in the example above) and finally the code of the function, also named ‚Äúthe function body‚Äù, between curly braces.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb294"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb294-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">name</span>(parameters) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb294-2" title="2">  ...<span class="va">body</span>...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb294-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Our new function can be called by its name: <code>showMessage()</code>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run function showMessage() { alert( ‚ÄòHello everyone!‚Äô ); }</p>
<p><em>!</em> showMessage(); showMessage(); <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>The call <code>showMessage()</code> executes the code of the function. Here we will see the message two times.</p>
<p>This example clearly demonstrates one of the main purposes of functions: to avoid code duplication.</p>
<p>If we ever need to change the message or the way it is shown, it‚Äôs enough to modify the code in one place: the function which outputs it.</p>
<h2 id="local-variables">Local variables</h2>
<p>A variable declared inside a function is only visible inside that function.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>```js run function showMessage() { <em>!</em> let message = ‚ÄúHello, I‚Äôm JavaScript!‚Äù; // local variable <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert( message ); }</p>
<p>showMessage(); // Hello, I‚Äôm JavaScript!</p>
<p>alert( message ); // &lt;‚Äì Error! The variable is local to the function ```</p>
<h2 id="outer-variables">Outer variables</h2>
<p>A function can access an outer variable as well, for example:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify let <em>!</em>userName<em>/!</em> = ‚ÄòJohn‚Äô;</p>
<p>function showMessage() { let message = ‚ÄòHello,‚Äô + <em>!</em>userName<em>/!</em>; alert(message); }</p>
<p>showMessage(); // Hello, John ```</p>
<p>The function has full access to the outer variable. It can modify it as well.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let <em>!</em>userName<em>/!</em> = ‚ÄòJohn‚Äô;</p>
<p>function showMessage() { <em>!</em>userName<em>/!</em> = ‚ÄúBob‚Äù; // (1) changed the outer variable</p>
<p>let message = ‚ÄòHello,‚Äô + <em>!</em>userName<em>/!</em>; alert(message); }</p>
<p>alert( userName ); // <em>!</em>John<em>/!</em> before the function call</p>
<p>showMessage();</p>
<p>alert( userName ); // <em>!</em>Bob<em>/!</em>, the value was modified by the function ```</p>
<p>The outer variable is only used if there‚Äôs no local one.</p>
<p>If a same-named variable is declared inside the function then it <em>shadows</em> the outer one. For instance, in the code below the function uses the local <code>userName</code>. The outer one is ignored:</p>
<p>```js run let userName = ‚ÄòJohn‚Äô;</p>
<p>function showMessage() { <em>!</em> let userName = ‚ÄúBob‚Äù; // declare a local variable <em>/!</em></p>
<p>let message = ‚ÄòHello,‚Äô + userName; // <em>!</em>Bob<em>/!</em> alert(message); }</p>
<p>// the function will create and use its own userName showMessage();</p>
<p>alert( userName ); // <em>!</em>John<em>/!</em>, unchanged, the function did not access the outer variable ```</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Global variables" Variables declared outside of any function, such as the outer</code>userName` in the code above, are called <em>global</em>.</p>
<p>Global variables are visible from any function (unless shadowed by locals).</p>
<p>It‚Äôs a good practice to minimize the use of global variables. Modern code has few or no globals. Most variables reside in their functions. Sometimes though, they can be useful to store project-level data. ```</p>
<h2 id="parameters">Parameters</h2>
<p>We can pass arbitrary data to functions using parameters (also called <em>function arguments</em>) .</p>
<p>In the example below, the function has two parameters: <code>from</code> and <code>text</code>.</p>
<p>```js run function showMessage(<em>!</em>from, text<em>/!</em>) { // arguments: from, text alert(from + ‚Äò:‚Äô + text); }</p>
<p><em>!</em> showMessage(‚ÄòAnn‚Äô, ‚ÄòHello!‚Äô); // Ann: Hello! (*) showMessage(‚ÄòAnn‚Äô, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up?‚Äù); // Ann: What‚Äôs up? (**) <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>When the function is called in lines <code>(*)</code> and <code>(**)</code>, the given values are copied to local variables <code>from</code> and <code>text</code>. Then the function uses them.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs one more example: we have a variable <code>from</code> and pass it to the function. Please note: the function changes <code>from</code>, but the change is not seen outside, because a function always gets a copy of the value:</p>
<p>```js run function showMessage(from, text) {</p>
<p><em>!</em> from = ‚Äò<em>‚Äô + from + ‚Äô</em>‚Äô; // make ‚Äúfrom‚Äù look nicer <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert( from + ‚Äò:‚Äô + text ); }</p>
<p>let from = ‚ÄúAnn‚Äù;</p>
<p>showMessage(from, ‚ÄúHello‚Äù); // <em>Ann</em>: Hello</p>
<p>// the value of ‚Äúfrom‚Äù is the same, the function modified a local copy alert( from ); // Ann ```</p>
<h2 id="default-values">Default values</h2>
<p>If a parameter is not provided, then its value becomes <code>undefined</code>.</p>
<p>For instance, the aforementioned function <code>showMessage(from, text)</code> can be called with a single argument:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb295"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb295-1" title="1"><span class="at">showMessage</span>(<span class="st">&quot;Ann&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>That‚Äôs not an error. Such a call would output <code>"*Ann*: undefined"</code>. There‚Äôs no <code>text</code>, so it‚Äôs assumed that <code>text === undefined</code>.</p>
<p>If we want to use a ‚Äúdefault‚Äù <code>text</code> in this case, then we can specify it after <code>=</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function showMessage(from, <em>!</em>text = ‚Äúno text given‚Äù<em>/!</em>) { alert( from + ‚Äú:‚Äù + text ); }</p>
<p>showMessage(‚ÄúAnn‚Äù); // Ann: no text given ```</p>
<p>Now if the <code>text</code> parameter is not passed, it will get the value <code>"no text given"</code></p>
<p>Here <code>"no text given"</code> is a string, but it can be a more complex expression, which is only evaluated and assigned if the parameter is missing. So, this is also possible:</p>
<p><code>js run function showMessage(from, text = anotherFunction()) {   // anotherFunction() only executed if no text given   // its result becomes the value of text }</code></p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúEvaluation of default parameters‚Äù In JavaScript, a default parameter is evaluated every time the function is called without the respective parameter.</p>
<p>In the example above, <code>anotherFunction()</code> is called every time <code>showMessage()</code> is called without the <code>text</code> parameter. ```</p>
<h3 id="alternative-default-parameters">Alternative default parameters</h3>
<p>Sometimes it makes sense to set default values for parameters not in the function declaration, but at a later stage, during its execution.</p>
<p>To check for an omitted parameter, we can compare it with <code>undefined</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function showMessage(text) { <em>!</em> if (text === undefined) { text = ‚Äòempty message‚Äô; } <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert(text); }</p>
<p>showMessage(); // empty message ```</p>
<p>‚Ä¶Or we could use the <code>||</code> operator:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb296"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb296-1" title="1"><span class="co">// if text parameter is omitted or &quot;&quot; is passed, set it to &#39;empty&#39;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb296-2" title="2"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showMessage</span>(text) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb296-3" title="3">  text <span class="op">=</span> text <span class="op">||</span> <span class="st">&#39;empty&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb296-4" title="4">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb296-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Modern JavaScript engines support the <a href="info:nullish-coalescing-operator">nullish coalescing operator</a> <code>??</code>, it‚Äôs better when falsy values, such as <code>0</code>, are considered regular:</p>
<p>```js run // if there‚Äôs no ‚Äúcount‚Äù parameter, show ‚Äúunknown‚Äù function showCount(count) { alert(count ?? ‚Äúunknown‚Äù); }</p>
<p>showCount(0); // 0 showCount(null); // unknown showCount(); // unknown ```</p>
<h2 id="returning-a-value">Returning a value</h2>
<p>A function can return a value back into the calling code as the result.</p>
<p>The simplest example would be a function that sums two values:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify function sum(a, b) { <em>!</em>return<em>/!</em> a + b; }</p>
<p>let result = sum(1, 2); alert( result ); // 3 ```</p>
<p>The directive <code>return</code> can be in any place of the function. When the execution reaches it, the function stops, and the value is returned to the calling code (assigned to <code>result</code> above).</p>
<p>There may be many occurrences of <code>return</code> in a single function. For instance:</p>
<p>```js run function checkAge(age) { if (age &gt;= 18) { <em>!</em> return true; <em>/!</em> } else { <em>!</em> return confirm(‚ÄòDo you have permission from your parents?‚Äô); <em>/!</em> } }</p>
<p>let age = prompt(‚ÄòHow old are you?‚Äô, 18);</p>
<p>if ( checkAge(age) ) { alert( ‚ÄòAccess granted‚Äô ); } else { alert( ‚ÄòAccess denied‚Äô ); } ```</p>
<p>It is possible to use <code>return</code> without a value. That causes the function to exit immediately.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb297"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showMovie</span>(age) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> ( <span class="op">!</span><span class="at">checkAge</span>(age) ) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-3" title="3"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-4" title="4">    <span class="cf">return</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-5" title="5"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-6" title="6"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-8" title="8"><span class="ss">  alert</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss"> &quot;Showing you the movie&quot; </span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">; // </span><span class="sc">(*)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-9" title="9"><span class="ss">  // ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb297-10" title="10"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>In the code above, if <code>checkAge(age)</code> returns <code>false</code>, then <code>showMovie</code> won‚Äôt proceed to the <code>alert</code>.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="A function with an empty</code>return<code>or without it returns</code>undefined<code>" If a function does not return a value, it is the same as if it returns</code>undefined`:</p>
<p>```js run function doNothing() { /* empty */ }</p>
<p>alert( doNothing() === undefined ); // true ```</p>
<p>An empty <code>return</code> is also the same as <code>return undefined</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function doNothing() { return; }</p>
<p>alert( doNothing() === undefined ); // true</p>
<pre><code></code></pre>
<p>```<code>warn header="Never add a newline between</code>return<code>and the value" For a long expression in</code>return`, it might be tempting to put it on a separate line, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb299"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb299-1" title="1"><span class="cf">return</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb299-2" title="2"> (some <span class="op">+</span> long <span class="op">+</span> expression <span class="op">+</span> or <span class="op">+</span> whatever <span class="op">*</span> <span class="at">f</span>(a) <span class="op">+</span> <span class="at">f</span>(b))</a></code></pre></div>
<p>That doesn‚Äôt work, because JavaScript assumes a semicolon after <code>return</code>. That‚Äôll work the same as:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb300"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb300-1" title="1"><span class="cf">return</span><span class="op">*!*;*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb300-2" title="2"><span class="ss"> </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">some </span><span class="sc">+</span><span class="ss"> long </span><span class="sc">+</span><span class="ss"> expression </span><span class="sc">+</span><span class="ss"> or </span><span class="sc">+</span><span class="ss"> whatever </span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss"> f</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">a</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> </span><span class="sc">+</span><span class="ss"> f</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">b</span><span class="sc">))</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So, it effectively becomes an empty return.</p>
<p>If we want the returned expression to wrap across multiple lines, we should start it at the same line as <code>return</code>. Or at least put the opening parentheses there as follows:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb301"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb301-1" title="1"><span class="cf">return</span> (</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb301-2" title="2">  some <span class="op">+</span> long <span class="op">+</span> expression</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb301-3" title="3">  <span class="op">+</span> or <span class="op">+</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb301-4" title="4">  whatever <span class="op">*</span> <span class="at">f</span>(a) <span class="op">+</span> <span class="at">f</span>(b)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb301-5" title="5">  )</a></code></pre></div>
<p>And it will work just as we expect it to. ````</p>
<h2 id="naming-a-function-function-naming">Naming a function [#function-naming]</h2>
<p>Functions are actions. So their name is usually a verb. It should be brief, as accurate as possible and describe what the function does, so that someone reading the code gets an indication of what the function does.</p>
<p>It is a widespread practice to start a function with a verbal prefix which vaguely describes the action. There must be an agreement within the team on the meaning of the prefixes.</p>
<p>For instance, functions that start with <code>"show"</code> usually show something.</p>
<p>Function starting with‚Ä¶</p>
<ul>
<li><code>"get‚Ä¶"</code> ‚Äì return a value,</li>
<li><code>"calc‚Ä¶"</code> ‚Äì calculate something,</li>
<li><code>"create‚Ä¶"</code> ‚Äì create something,</li>
<li><code>"check‚Ä¶"</code> ‚Äì check something and return a boolean, etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of such names:</p>
<p><code>js no-beautify showMessage(..)     // shows a message getAge(..)          // returns the age (gets it somehow) calcSum(..)         // calculates a sum and returns the result createForm(..)      // creates a form (and usually returns it) checkPermission(..) // checks a permission, returns true/false</code></p>
<p>With prefixes in place, a glance at a function name gives an understanding what kind of work it does and what kind of value it returns.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúOne function ‚Äì one action‚Äù A function should do exactly what is suggested by its name, no more.</p>
<p>Two independent actions usually deserve two functions, even if they are usually called together (in that case we can make a 3rd function that calls those two).</p>
<p>A few examples of breaking this rule:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>getAge</code> ‚Äì would be bad if it shows an <code>alert</code> with the age (should only get).</li>
<li><code>createForm</code> ‚Äì would be bad if it modifies the document, adding a form to it (should only create it and return).</li>
<li><code>checkPermission</code> ‚Äì would be bad if it displays the <code>access granted/denied</code> message (should only perform the check and return the result).</li>
</ul>
<p>These examples assume common meanings of prefixes. You and your team are free to agree on other meanings, but usually they‚Äôre not much different. In any case, you should have a firm understanding of what a prefix means, what a prefixed function can and cannot do. All same-prefixed functions should obey the rules. And the team should share the knowledge. ```</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúUltrashort function names‚Äù Functions that are used <em>very often</em> sometimes have ultrashort names.</p>
<p>For example, the <a href="http://jquery.com">jQuery</a> framework defines a function with <code>$</code>. The <a href="http://lodash.com/">Lodash</a> library has its core function named <code>_</code>.</p>
<p>These are exceptions. Generally function names should be concise and descriptive. ```</p>
<h2 id="functions-comments">Functions == Comments</h2>
<p>Functions should be short and do exactly one thing. If that thing is big, maybe it‚Äôs worth it to split the function into a few smaller functions. Sometimes following this rule may not be that easy, but it‚Äôs definitely a good thing.</p>
<p>A separate function is not only easier to test and debug ‚Äì its very existence is a great comment!</p>
<p>For instance, compare the two functions <code>showPrimes(n)</code> below. Each one outputs <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_number">prime numbers</a> up to <code>n</code>.</p>
<p>The first variant uses a label:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb302"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showPrimes</span>(n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">nextPrime</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-4" title="4">    <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> j <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span> j <span class="op">&lt;</span> i<span class="op">;</span> j<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-5" title="5">      <span class="cf">if</span> (i <span class="op">%</span> j <span class="op">==</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="cf">continue</span> nextPrime<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-6" title="6">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-8" title="8">    <span class="at">alert</span>( i )<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// a prime</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-9" title="9">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb302-10" title="10"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The second variant uses an additional function <code>isPrime(n)</code> to test for primality:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb303"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showPrimes</span>(n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-4" title="4">    <span class="op">*!*</span><span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="op">!</span><span class="at">isPrime</span>(i)) <span class="cf">continue</span><span class="op">;*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-6" title="6"><span class="ss">    alert</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">i</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;  // a prime</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-7" title="7"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-8" title="8"><span class="ss">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-10" title="10"><span class="ss">function isPrime</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">n</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-11" title="11"><span class="ss">  for </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">let i = 2; i &lt; n; i</span><span class="sc">++)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-12" title="12"><span class="ss">    if </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss"> n % i == 0</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> return false;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-13" title="13"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-14" title="14"><span class="ss">  return true;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb303-15" title="15"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The second variant is easier to understand, isn‚Äôt it? Instead of the code piece we see a name of the action (<code>isPrime</code>). Sometimes people refer to such code as <em>self-describing</em>.</p>
<p>So, functions can be created even if we don‚Äôt intend to reuse them. They structure the code and make it readable.</p>
<h2 id="summary-37">Summary</h2>
<p>A function declaration looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb304"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb304-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">name</span>(parameters<span class="op">,</span> delimited<span class="op">,</span> by<span class="op">,</span> comma) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb304-2" title="2">  <span class="co">/* code */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb304-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<ul>
<li>Values passed to a function as parameters are copied to its local variables.</li>
<li>A function may access outer variables. But it works only from inside out. The code outside of the function doesn‚Äôt see its local variables.</li>
<li>A function can return a value. If it doesn‚Äôt, then its result is <code>undefined</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>To make the code clean and easy to understand, it‚Äôs recommended to use mainly local variables and parameters in the function, not outer variables.</p>
<p>It is always easier to understand a function which gets parameters, works with them and returns a result than a function which gets no parameters, but modifies outer variables as a side-effect.</p>
<p>Function naming:</p>
<ul>
<li>A name should clearly describe what the function does. When we see a function call in the code, a good name instantly gives us an understanding what it does and returns.</li>
<li>A function is an action, so function names are usually verbal.</li>
<li>There exist many well-known function prefixes like <code>create‚Ä¶</code>, <code>show‚Ä¶</code>, <code>get‚Ä¶</code>, <code>check‚Ä¶</code> and so on. Use them to hint what a function does.</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions are the main building blocks of scripts. Now we‚Äôve covered the basics, so we actually can start creating and using them. But that‚Äôs only the beginning of the path. We are going to return to them many times, going more deeply into their advanced features.</p>
<h1 id="manuals-and-specifications">Manuals and specifications</h1>
<p>This book is a <em>tutorial</em>. It aims to help you gradually learn the language. But once you‚Äôre familiar with the basics, you‚Äôll need other sources.</p>
<h2 id="specification">Specification</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-262.htm">The ECMA-262 specification</a> contains the most in-depth, detailed and formalized information about JavaScript. It defines the language.</p>
<p>But being that formalized, it‚Äôs difficult to understand at first. So if you need the most trustworthy source of information about the language details, the specification is the right place. But it‚Äôs not for everyday use.</p>
<p>A new specification version is released every year. In-between these releases, the latest specification draft is at <a href="https://tc39.es/ecma262/" class="uri">https://tc39.es/ecma262/</a>.</p>
<p>To read about new bleeding-edge features, including those that are ‚Äúalmost standard‚Äù (so-called ‚Äústage 3‚Äù), see proposals at <a href="https://github.com/tc39/proposals" class="uri">https://github.com/tc39/proposals</a>.</p>
<p>Also, if you‚Äôre developing for the browser, then there are other specifications covered in the <a href="info:browser-environment">second part</a> of the tutorial.</p>
<h2 id="manuals">Manuals</h2>
<ul>
<li><p><strong>MDN (Mozilla) JavaScript Reference</strong> is the main manual with examples and other information. It‚Äôs great to get in-depth information about individual language functions, methods etc.</p>
<p>One can find it at <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference" class="uri">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference</a>.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Although, it‚Äôs often best to use an internet search instead. Just use ‚ÄúMDN [term]‚Äù in the query, e.g.¬†<a href="https://google.com/search?q=MDN+parseInt" class="uri">https://google.com/search?q=MDN+parseInt</a> to search for <code>parseInt</code> function.</p>
<h2 id="compatibility-tables">Compatibility tables</h2>
<p>JavaScript is a developing language, new features get added regularly.</p>
<p>To see their support among browser-based and other engines, see:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://caniuse.com" class="uri">http://caniuse.com</a> - per-feature tables of support, e.g.¬†to see which engines support modern cryptography functions: <a href="http://caniuse.com/#feat=cryptography" class="uri">http://caniuse.com/#feat=cryptography</a>.</li>
<li><a href="https://kangax.github.io/compat-table" class="uri">https://kangax.github.io/compat-table</a> - a table with language features and engines that support those or don‚Äôt support.</li>
</ul>
<p>All these resources are useful in real-life development, as they contain valuable information about language details, their support etc.</p>
<p>Please remember them (or this page) for the cases when you need in-depth information about a particular feature. # Function expressions</p>
<p>In JavaScript, a function is not a ‚Äúmagical language structure‚Äù, but a special kind of value.</p>
<p>The syntax that we used before is called a <em>Function Declaration</em>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb305"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb305-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">sayHi</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb305-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&quot;Hello&quot;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb305-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>There is another syntax for creating a function that is called a <em>Function Expression</em>.</p>
<p>It looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb306"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb306-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> sayHi <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb306-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&quot;Hello&quot;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb306-3" title="3"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here, the function is created and assigned to the variable explicitly, like any other value. No matter how the function is defined, it‚Äôs just a value stored in the variable <code>sayHi</code>.</p>
<p>The meaning of these code samples is the same: ‚Äúcreate a function and put it into the variable <code>sayHi</code>‚Äù.</p>
<p>We can even print out that value using <code>alert</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function sayHi() { alert( ‚ÄúHello‚Äù ); }</p>
<p><em>!</em> alert( sayHi ); // shows the function code <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Please note that the last line does not run the function, because there are no parentheses after <code>sayHi</code>. There are programming languages where any mention of a function name causes its execution, but JavaScript is not like that.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, a function is a value, so we can deal with it as a value. The code above shows its string representation, which is the source code.</p>
<p>Surely, a function is a special value, in the sense that we can call it like <code>sayHi()</code>.</p>
<p>But it‚Äôs still a value. So we can work with it like with other kinds of values.</p>
<p>We can copy a function to another variable:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify function sayHi() { // (1) create alert( ‚ÄúHello‚Äù ); }</p>
<p>let func = sayHi; // (2) copy</p>
<p>func(); // Hello // (3) run the copy (it works)! sayHi(); // Hello // this still works too (why wouldn‚Äôt it) ```</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs what happens above in detail:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The Function Declaration <code>(1)</code> creates the function and puts it into the variable named <code>sayHi</code>.</li>
