<li>Line <code>(2)</code> copies it into the variable <code>func</code>. Please note again: there are no parentheses after <code>sayHi</code>. If there were, then <code>func = sayHi()</code> would write <em>the result of the call</em> <code>sayHi()</code> into <code>func</code>, not <em>the function</em> <code>sayHi</code> itself.</li>
<li>Now the function can be called as both <code>sayHi()</code> and <code>func()</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>Note that we could also have used a Function Expression to declare <code>sayHi</code>, in the first line:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb307"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb307-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> sayHi <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb307-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&quot;Hello&quot;</span> )<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb307-3" title="3"><span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb307-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb307-5" title="5"><span class="kw">let</span> func <span class="op">=</span> sayHi<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb307-6" title="6"><span class="co">// ...</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Everything would work the same.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="Why is there a semicolon at the end?" You might wonder, why does Function Expression have a semicolon</code>;` at the end, but Function Declaration does not:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb308"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">sayHi</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-5" title="5"><span class="kw">let</span> sayHi <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb308-7" title="7"><span class="op">}*!*;*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The answer is simple: - There‚Äôs no need for <code>;</code> at the end of code blocks and syntax structures that use them like <code>if { ... }</code>, <code>for {  }</code>, <code>function f { }</code> etc. - A Function Expression is used inside the statement: <code>let sayHi = ...;</code>, as a value. It‚Äôs not a code block, but rather an assignment. The semicolon <code>;</code> is recommended at the end of statements, no matter what the value is. So the semicolon here is not related to the Function Expression itself, it just terminates the statement. ````</p>
<h2 id="callback-functions">Callback functions</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs look at more examples of passing functions as values and using function expressions.</p>
<p>We‚Äôll write a function <code>ask(question, yes, no)</code> with three parameters:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>question</code></dt>
<dd>Text of the question
</dd>
<dt><code>yes</code></dt>
<dd>Function to run if the answer is ‚ÄúYes‚Äù
</dd>
<dt><code>no</code></dt>
<dd>Function to run if the answer is ‚ÄúNo‚Äù
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The function should ask the <code>question</code> and, depending on the user‚Äôs answer, call <code>yes()</code> or <code>no()</code>:</p>
<p>```js run <em>!</em> function ask(question, yes, no) { if (confirm(question)) yes() else no(); } <em>/!</em></p>
<p>function showOk() { alert( ‚ÄúYou agreed.‚Äù ); }</p>
<p>function showCancel() { alert( ‚ÄúYou canceled the execution.‚Äù ); }</p>
<p>// usage: functions showOk, showCancel are passed as arguments to ask ask(‚ÄúDo you agree?‚Äù, showOk, showCancel); ```</p>
<p>In practice, such functions are quite useful. The major difference between a real-life <code>ask</code> and the example above is that real-life functions use more complex ways to interact with the user than a simple <code>confirm</code>. In the browser, such function usually draws a nice-looking question window. But that‚Äôs another story.</p>
<p><strong>The arguments <code>showOk</code> and <code>showCancel</code> of <code>ask</code> are called <em>callback functions</em> or just <em>callbacks</em>.</strong></p>
<p>The idea is that we pass a function and expect it to be ‚Äúcalled back‚Äù later if necessary. In our case, <code>showOk</code> becomes the callback for ‚Äúyes‚Äù answer, and <code>showCancel</code> for ‚Äúno‚Äù answer.</p>
<p>We can use Function Expressions to write the same function much shorter:</p>
<p>```js run no-beautify function ask(question, yes, no) { if (confirm(question)) yes() else no(); }</p>
<p><em>!</em> ask( ‚ÄúDo you agree?‚Äù, function() { alert(‚ÄúYou agreed.‚Äù); }, function() { alert(‚ÄúYou canceled the execution.‚Äù); } ); <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Here, functions are declared right inside the <code>ask(...)</code> call. They have no name, and so are called <em>anonymous</em>. Such functions are not accessible outside of <code>ask</code> (because they are not assigned to variables), but that‚Äôs just what we want here.</p>
<p>Such code appears in our scripts very naturally, it‚Äôs in the spirit of JavaScript.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúA function is a value representing an "action"‚Äù Regular values like strings or numbers represent the <em>data</em>.</p>
<p>A function can be perceived as an <em>action</em>.</p>
<p>We can pass it between variables and run when we want. ```</p>
<h2 id="function-expression-vs-function-declaration">Function Expression vs Function Declaration</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs formulate the key differences between Function Declarations and Expressions.</p>
<p>First, the syntax: how to differentiate between them in the code.</p>
<ul>
<li><p><em>Function Declaration:</em> a function, declared as a separate statement, in the main code flow.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb309"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb309-1" title="1"><span class="co">// Function Declaration</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb309-2" title="2"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">sum</span>(a<span class="op">,</span> b) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb309-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">return</span> a <span class="op">+</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb309-4" title="4"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p><em>Function Expression:</em> a function, created inside an expression or inside another syntax construct. Here, the function is created at the right side of the ‚Äúassignment expression‚Äù <code>=</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb310"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb310-1" title="1"><span class="co">// Function Expression</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb310-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> sum <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(a<span class="op">,</span> b) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb310-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">return</span> a <span class="op">+</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb310-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
</ul>
<p>The more subtle difference is <em>when</em> a function is created by the JavaScript engine.</p>
<p><strong>A Function Expression is created when the execution reaches it and is usable only from that moment.</strong></p>
<p>Once the execution flow passes to the right side of the assignment <code>let sum = function‚Ä¶</code> ‚Äì here we go, the function is created and can be used (assigned, called, etc. ) from now on.</p>
<p>Function Declarations are different.</p>
<p><strong>A Function Declaration can be called earlier than it is defined.</strong></p>
<p>For example, a global Function Declaration is visible in the whole script, no matter where it is.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs due to internal algorithms. When JavaScript prepares to run the script, it first looks for global Function Declarations in it and creates the functions. We can think of it as an ‚Äúinitialization stage‚Äù.</p>
<p>And after all Function Declarations are processed, the code is executed. So it has access to these functions.</p>
<p>For example, this works:</p>
<p>```js run refresh untrusted <em>!</em> sayHi(‚ÄúJohn‚Äù); // Hello, John <em>/!</em></p>
<p>function sayHi(name) { alert( <code>Hello, ${name}</code> ); } ```</p>
<p>The Function Declaration <code>sayHi</code> is created when JavaScript is preparing to start the script and is visible everywhere in it.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶If it were a Function Expression, then it wouldn‚Äôt work:</p>
<p>```js run refresh untrusted <em>!</em> sayHi(‚ÄúJohn‚Äù); // error! <em>/!</em></p>
<p>let sayHi = function(name) { // (*) no magic any more alert( <code>Hello, ${name}</code> ); }; ```</p>
<p>Function Expressions are created when the execution reaches them. That would happen only in the line <code>(*)</code>. Too late.</p>
<p>Another special feature of Function Declarations is their block scope.</p>
<p><strong>In strict mode, when a Function Declaration is within a code block, it‚Äôs visible everywhere inside that block. But not outside of it.</strong></p>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs imagine that we need to declare a function <code>welcome()</code> depending on the <code>age</code> variable that we get during runtime. And then we plan to use it some time later.</p>
<p>If we use Function Declaration, it won‚Äôt work as intended:</p>
<p>```js run let age = prompt(‚ÄúWhat is your age?‚Äù, 18);</p>
<p>// conditionally declare a function if (age &lt; 18) {</p>
<p>function welcome() { alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù); }</p>
<p>} else {</p>
<p>function welcome() { alert(‚ÄúGreetings!‚Äù); }</p>
<p>}</p>
<p>// ‚Ä¶use it later <em>!</em> welcome(); // Error: welcome is not defined <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because a Function Declaration is only visible inside the code block in which it resides.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs another example:</p>
<p>```js run let age = 16; // take 16 as an example</p>
<p>if (age &lt; 18) { <em>!</em> welcome(); // ¬† (runs) <em>/!</em> // | function welcome() { // |<br />
alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù); // | Function Declaration is available } // | everywhere in the block where it‚Äôs declared // | <em>!</em> welcome(); // / (runs) <em>/!</em></p>
<p>} else {</p>
<p>function welcome() {<br />
alert(‚ÄúGreetings!‚Äù); } }</p>
<p>// Here we‚Äôre out of curly braces, // so we can not see Function Declarations made inside of them.</p>
<p><em>!</em> welcome(); // Error: welcome is not defined <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>What can we do to make <code>welcome</code> visible outside of <code>if</code>?</p>
<p>The correct approach would be to use a Function Expression and assign <code>welcome</code> to the variable that is declared outside of <code>if</code> and has the proper visibility.</p>
<p>This code works as intended:</p>
<p>```js run let age = prompt(‚ÄúWhat is your age?‚Äù, 18);</p>
<p>let welcome;</p>
<p>if (age &lt; 18) {</p>
<p>welcome = function() { alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù); };</p>
<p>} else {</p>
<p>welcome = function() { alert(‚ÄúGreetings!‚Äù); };</p>
<p>}</p>
<p><em>!</em> welcome(); // ok now <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Or we could simplify it even further using a question mark operator <code>?</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let age = prompt(‚ÄúWhat is your age?‚Äù, 18);</p>
<p>let welcome = (age &lt; 18) ? function() { alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù); } : function() { alert(‚ÄúGreetings!‚Äù); };</p>
<p><em>!</em> welcome(); // ok now <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúWhen to choose Function Declaration versus Function Expression?‚Äù As a rule of thumb, when we need to declare a function, the first to consider is Function Declaration syntax. It gives more freedom in how to organize our code, because we can call such functions before they are declared.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs also better for readability, as it‚Äôs easier to look up <code>function f(‚Ä¶) {‚Ä¶}</code> in the code than <code>let f = function(‚Ä¶) {‚Ä¶};</code>. Function Declarations are more ‚Äúeye-catching‚Äù.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But if a Function Declaration does not suit us for some reason, or we need a conditional declaration (we‚Äôve just seen an example), then Function Expression should be used. ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-38">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>Functions are values. They can be assigned, copied or declared in any place of the code.</li>
<li>If the function is declared as a separate statement in the main code flow, that‚Äôs called a ‚ÄúFunction Declaration‚Äù.</li>
<li>If the function is created as a part of an expression, it‚Äôs called a ‚ÄúFunction Expression‚Äù.</li>
<li>Function Declarations are processed before the code block is executed. They are visible everywhere in the block.</li>
<li>Function Expressions are created when the execution flow reaches them.</li>
</ul>
<p>In most cases when we need to declare a function, a Function Declaration is preferable, because it is visible prior to the declaration itself. That gives us more flexibility in code organization, and is usually more readable.</p>
<p>So we should use a Function Expression only when a Function Declaration is not fit for the task. We‚Äôve seen a couple of examples of that in this chapter, and will see more in the future. # Arrow functions, the basics</p>
<p>There‚Äôs another very simple and concise syntax for creating functions, that‚Äôs often better than Function Expressions.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs called ‚Äúarrow functions‚Äù, because it looks like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb311"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb311-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> func <span class="op">=</span> (arg1<span class="op">,</span> arg2<span class="op">,</span> ...<span class="op">,</span> argN) <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> expression</a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶This creates a function <code>func</code> that accepts arguments <code>arg1..argN</code>, then evaluates the <code>expression</code> on the right side with their use and returns its result.</p>
<p>In other words, it‚Äôs the shorter version of:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb312"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb312-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> func <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(arg1<span class="op">,</span> arg2<span class="op">,</span> ...<span class="op">,</span> argN) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb312-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> expression<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb312-3" title="3"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Let‚Äôs see a concrete example:</p>
<p>```js run let sum = (a, b) =&gt; a + b;</p>
<p>/* This arrow function is a shorter form of:</p>
<p>let sum = function(a, b) { return a + b; }; */</p>
<p>alert( sum(1, 2) ); // 3 ```</p>
<p>As you can, see <code>(a, b) =&gt; a + b</code> means a function that accepts two arguments named <code>a</code> and <code>b</code>. Upon the execution, it evaluates the expression <code>a + b</code> and returns the result.</p>
<ul>
<li><p>If we have only one argument, then parentheses around parameters can be omitted, making that even shorter.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>```js run <em>!</em> let double = n =&gt; n * 2; // roughly the same as: let double = function(n) { return n * 2 } <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert( double(3) ); // 6 ```</p></li>
<li><p>If there are no arguments, parentheses will be empty (but they should be present):</p>
<p>```js run let sayHi = () =&gt; alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù);</p>
<p>sayHi(); ```</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Arrow functions can be used in the same way as Function Expressions.</p>
<p>For instance, to dynamically create a function:</p>
<p>```js run let age = prompt(‚ÄúWhat is your age?‚Äù, 18);</p>
<p>let welcome = (age &lt; 18) ? () =&gt; alert(‚ÄòHello‚Äô) : () =&gt; alert(‚ÄúGreetings!‚Äù);</p>
<p>welcome(); ```</p>
<p>Arrow functions may appear unfamiliar and not very readable at first, but that quickly changes as the eyes get used to the structure.</p>
<p>They are very convenient for simple one-line actions, when we‚Äôre just too lazy to write many words.</p>
<h2 id="multiline-arrow-functions">Multiline arrow functions</h2>
<p>The examples above took arguments from the left of <code>=&gt;</code> and evaluated the right-side expression with them.</p>
<p>Sometimes we need something a little bit more complex, like multiple expressions or statements. It is also possible, but we should enclose them in curly braces. Then use a normal <code>return</code> within them.</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<p>```js run let sum = (a, b) =&gt; { // the curly brace opens a multiline function let result = a + b; <em>!</em> return result; // if we use curly braces, then we need an explicit ‚Äúreturn‚Äù <em>/!</em> };</p>
<p>alert( sum(1, 2) ); // 3 ```</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúMore to come‚Äù Here we praised arrow functions for brevity. But that‚Äôs not all!</p>
<p>Arrow functions have other interesting features.</p>
<p>To study them in-depth, we first need to get to know some other aspects of JavaScript, so we‚Äôll return to arrow functions later in the chapter <a href="info:arrow-functions" class="uri">info:arrow-functions</a>.</p>
<p>For now, we can already use arrow functions for one-line actions and callbacks. ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-39">Summary</h2>
<p>Arrow functions are handy for one-liners. They come in two flavors:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Without curly braces: <code>(...args) =&gt; expression</code> ‚Äì the right side is an expression: the function evaluates it and returns the result.</li>
<li>With curly braces: <code>(...args) =&gt; { body }</code> ‚Äì brackets allow us to write multiple statements inside the function, but we need an explicit <code>return</code> to return something. # JavaScript specials</li>
</ol>
<p>This chapter briefly recaps the features of JavaScript that we‚Äôve learned by now, paying special attention to subtle moments.</p>
<h2 id="code-structure">Code structure</h2>
<p>Statements are delimited with a semicolon:</p>
<p><code>js run no-beautify alert('Hello'); alert('World');</code></p>
<p>Usually, a line-break is also treated as a delimiter, so that would also work:</p>
<p><code>js run no-beautify alert('Hello') alert('World')</code></p>
<p>That‚Äôs called ‚Äúautomatic semicolon insertion‚Äù. Sometimes it doesn‚Äôt work, for instance:</p>
<p>```js run alert(‚ÄúThere will be an error after this message‚Äù)</p>
<p>[1, 2].forEach(alert) ```</p>
<p>Most codestyle guides agree that we should put a semicolon after each statement.</p>
<p>Semicolons are not required after code blocks <code>{...}</code> and syntax constructs with them like loops:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb313"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">f</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// no semicolon needed after function declaration</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-5" title="5"><span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="op">;;</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// no semicolon needed after the loop</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb313-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶But even if we can put an ‚Äúextra‚Äù semicolon somewhere, that‚Äôs not an error. It will be ignored.</p>
<p>More in: <a href="info:structure" class="uri">info:structure</a>.</p>
<h2 id="strict-mode">Strict mode</h2>
<p>To fully enable all features of modern JavaScript, we should start scripts with <code>"use strict"</code>.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb314"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb314-1" title="1"><span class="st">&#39;use strict&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb314-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb314-3" title="3">...</a></code></pre></div>
<p>The directive must be at the top of a script or at the beginning of a function body.</p>
<p>Without <code>"use strict"</code>, everything still works, but some features behave in the old-fashion, ‚Äúcompatible‚Äù way. We‚Äôd generally prefer the modern behavior.</p>
<p>Some modern features of the language (like classes that we‚Äôll study in the future) enable strict mode implicitly.</p>
<p>More in: <a href="info:strict-mode" class="uri">info:strict-mode</a>.</p>
<h2 id="variables">Variables</h2>
<p>Can be declared using:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>let</code></li>
<li><code>const</code> (constant, can‚Äôt be changed)</li>
<li><code>var</code> (old-style, will see later)</li>
</ul>
<p>A variable name can include: - Letters and digits, but the first character may not be a digit. - Characters <code>$</code> and <code>_</code> are normal, on par with letters. - Non-Latin alphabets and hieroglyphs are also allowed, but commonly not used.</p>
<p>Variables are dynamically typed. They can store any value:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb315"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb315-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> x <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">5</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb315-2" title="2">x <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>There are 8 data types:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>number</code> for both floating-point and integer numbers,</li>
<li><code>bigint</code> for integer numbers of arbitrary length,</li>
<li><code>string</code> for strings,</li>
<li><code>boolean</code> for logical values: <code>true/false</code>,</li>
<li><code>null</code> ‚Äì a type with a single value <code>null</code>, meaning ‚Äúempty‚Äù or ‚Äúdoes not exist‚Äù,</li>
<li><code>undefined</code> ‚Äì a type with a single value <code>undefined</code>, meaning ‚Äúnot assigned‚Äù,</li>
<li><code>object</code> and <code>symbol</code> ‚Äì for complex data structures and unique identifiers, we haven‚Äôt learnt them yet.</li>
</ul>
<p>The <code>typeof</code> operator returns the type for a value, with two exceptions:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb316"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb316-1" title="1"><span class="kw">typeof</span> <span class="kw">null</span> <span class="op">==</span> <span class="st">&quot;object&quot;</span> <span class="co">// error in the language</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb316-2" title="2"><span class="kw">typeof</span> <span class="kw">function</span>()<span class="op">{}</span> <span class="op">==</span> <span class="st">&quot;function&quot;</span> <span class="co">// functions are treated specially</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>More in: <a href="info:variables" class="uri">info:variables</a> and <a href="info:types" class="uri">info:types</a>.</p>
<h2 id="interaction">Interaction</h2>
<p>We‚Äôre using a browser as a working environment, so basic UI functions will be:</p>
<dl>
<dt><a href="mdn:api/Window/prompt"><code>prompt(question, [default])</code></a></dt>
<dd>Ask a <code>question</code>, and return either what the visitor entered or <code>null</code> if they clicked ‚Äúcancel‚Äù.
</dd>
<dt><a href="mdn:api/Window/confirm"><code>confirm(question)</code></a></dt>
<dd>Ask a <code>question</code> and suggest to choose between Ok and Cancel. The choice is returned as <code>true/false</code>.
</dd>
<dt><a href="mdn:api/Window/alert"><code>alert(message)</code></a></dt>
<dd>Output a <code>message</code>.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>All these functions are <em>modal</em>, they pause the code execution and prevent the visitor from interacting with the page until they answer.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let userName = prompt(‚ÄúYour name?‚Äù, ‚ÄúAlice‚Äù); let isTeaWanted = confirm(‚ÄúDo you want some tea?‚Äù);</p>
<p>alert( ‚ÄúVisitor:‚Äù + userName ); // Alice alert( ‚ÄúTea wanted:‚Äù + isTeaWanted ); // true ```</p>
<p>More in: <a href="info:alert-prompt-confirm" class="uri">info:alert-prompt-confirm</a>.</p>
<h2 id="operators">Operators</h2>
<p>JavaScript supports the following operators:</p>
<dl>
<dt>Arithmetical</dt>
<dd><p>Regular: <code>* + - /</code>, also <code>%</code> for the remainder and <code>**</code> for power of a number.</p>
<p>The binary plus <code>+</code> concatenates strings. And if any of the operands is a string, the other one is converted to string too:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( '1' + 2 ); // '12', string alert( 1 + '2' ); // '12', string</code></p>
</dd>
<dt>Assignments</dt>
<dd>There is a simple assignment: <code>a = b</code> and combined ones like <code>a *= 2</code>.
</dd>
<dt>Bitwise</dt>
<dd>Bitwise operators work with 32-bit integers at the lowest, bit-level: see the <a href="mdn:/JavaScript/Guide/Expressions_and_Operators#Bitwise">docs</a> when they are needed.
</dd>
<dt>Conditional</dt>
<dd>The only operator with three parameters: <code>cond ? resultA : resultB</code>. If <code>cond</code> is truthy, returns <code>resultA</code>, otherwise <code>resultB</code>.
</dd>
<dt>Logical operators</dt>
<dd>Logical AND <code>&amp;&amp;</code> and OR <code>||</code> perform short-circuit evaluation and then return the value where it stopped (not necessary <code>true</code>/<code>false</code>). Logical NOT <code>!</code> converts the operand to boolean type and returns the inverse value.
</dd>
<dt>Nullish coalescing operator</dt>
<dd>The <code>??</code> operator provides a way to choose a defined value from a list of variables. The result of <code>a ?? b</code> is <code>a</code> unless it‚Äôs <code>null/undefined</code>, then <code>b</code>.
</dd>
<dt>Comparisons</dt>
<dd><p>Equality check <code>==</code> for values of different types converts them to a number (except <code>null</code> and <code>undefined</code> that equal each other and nothing else), so these are equal:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 0 == false ); // true alert( 0 == '' ); // true</code></p>
<p>Other comparisons convert to a number as well.</p>
<p>The strict equality operator <code>===</code> doesn‚Äôt do the conversion: different types always mean different values for it.</p>
<p>Values <code>null</code> and <code>undefined</code> are special: they equal <code>==</code> each other and don‚Äôt equal anything else.</p>
<p>Greater/less comparisons compare strings character-by-character, other types are converted to a number.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Other operators</dt>
<dd>There are few others, like a comma operator.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>More in: <a href="info:operators" class="uri">info:operators</a>, <a href="info:comparison" class="uri">info:comparison</a>, <a href="info:logical-operators" class="uri">info:logical-operators</a>, <a href="info:nullish-coalescing-operator" class="uri">info:nullish-coalescing-operator</a>.</p>
<h2 id="loops">Loops</h2>
<ul>
<li><p>We covered 3 types of loops:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb317"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-1" title="1"><span class="co">// 1</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-2" title="2"><span class="cf">while</span> (condition) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-3" title="3">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-4" title="4"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-6" title="6"><span class="co">// 2</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-7" title="7"><span class="cf">do</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-8" title="8">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">while</span> (condition)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-11" title="11"><span class="co">// 3</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-12" title="12"><span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-13" title="13">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb317-14" title="14"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li>The variable declared in <code>for(let...)</code> loop is visible only inside the loop. But we can also omit <code>let</code> and reuse an existing variable.</li>
<li><p>Directives <code>break/continue</code> allow to exit the whole loop/current iteration. Use labels to break nested loops.</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Details in: <a href="info:while-for" class="uri">info:while-for</a>.</p>
<p>Later we‚Äôll study more types of loops to deal with objects.</p>
<h2 id="the-switch-construct">The ‚Äúswitch‚Äù construct</h2>
<p>The ‚Äúswitch‚Äù construct can replace multiple <code>if</code> checks. It uses <code>===</code> (strict equality) for comparisons.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let age = prompt(‚ÄòYour age?‚Äô, 18);</p>
<p>switch (age) { case 18: alert(‚ÄúWon‚Äôt work‚Äù); // the result of prompt is a string, not a number break;</p>
<p>case ‚Äú18‚Äù: alert(‚ÄúThis works!‚Äù); break;</p>
<p>default: alert(‚ÄúAny value not equal to one above‚Äù); } ```</p>
<p>Details in: <a href="info:switch" class="uri">info:switch</a>.</p>
<h2 id="functions">Functions</h2>
<p>We covered three ways to create a function in JavaScript:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>Function Declaration: the function in the main code flow</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb318"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb318-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">sum</span>(a<span class="op">,</span> b) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb318-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> a <span class="op">+</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb318-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb318-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">return</span> result<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb318-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>Function Expression: the function in the context of an expression</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb319"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb319-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> sum <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(a<span class="op">,</span> b) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb319-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> a <span class="op">+</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb319-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb319-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">return</span> result<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb319-5" title="5"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>Arrow functions:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb320"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-1" title="1"><span class="co">// expression at the right side</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> sum <span class="op">=</span> (a<span class="op">,</span> b) <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> a <span class="op">+</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-4" title="4"><span class="co">// or multi-line syntax with { ... }, need return here:</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-5" title="5"><span class="kw">let</span> sum <span class="op">=</span> (a<span class="op">,</span> b) <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-7" title="7">  <span class="cf">return</span> a <span class="op">+</span> b<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-10" title="10"><span class="co">// without arguments</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-11" title="11"><span class="kw">let</span> sayHi <span class="op">=</span> () <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="st">&quot;Hello&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-12" title="12"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-13" title="13"><span class="co">// with a single argument</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb320-14" title="14"><span class="kw">let</span> double <span class="op">=</span> n <span class="kw">=&gt;</span> n <span class="op">*</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Functions may have local variables: those declared inside its body or its parameter list. Such variables are only visible inside the function.</li>
<li>Parameters can have default values: <code>function sum(a = 1, b = 2) {...}</code>.</li>
<li>Functions always return something. If there‚Äôs no <code>return</code> statement, then the result is <code>undefined</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Details: see <a href="info:function-basics" class="uri">info:function-basics</a>, <a href="info:arrow-functions-basics" class="uri">info:arrow-functions-basics</a>.</p>
<h2 id="more-to-come">More to come</h2>
<p>That was a brief list of JavaScript features. As of now we‚Äôve studied only basics. Further in the tutorial you‚Äôll find more specials and advanced features of JavaScript. # Debugging in Chrome</p>
<p>Before writing more complex code, let‚Äôs talk about debugging.</p>
<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Debugging">Debugging</a> is the process of finding and fixing errors within a script. All modern browsers and most other environments support debugging tools ‚Äì a special UI in developer tools that makes debugging much easier. It also allows to trace the code step by step to see what exactly is going on.</p>
<p>We‚Äôll be using Chrome here, because it has enough features, most other browsers have a similar process.</p>
<h2 id="the-sources-panel">The ‚ÄúSources‚Äù panel</h2>
<p>Your Chrome version may look a little bit different, but it still should be obvious what‚Äôs there.</p>
<ul>
<li>Open the <a href="debugging/index.html">example page</a> in Chrome.</li>
<li>Turn on developer tools with <code>key:F12</code> (Mac: <code>key:Cmd+Opt+I</code>).</li>
<li>Select the <code>Sources</code> panel.</li>
</ul>
<p>Here‚Äôs what you should see if you are doing it for the first time:</p>
<p><img src="chrome-open-sources.svg" /></p>
<p>The toggler button <span class="devtools" style="background-position:-172px -98px"></span> opens the tab with files.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs click it and select <code>hello.js</code> in the tree view. Here‚Äôs what should show up:</p>
<p><img src="chrome-tabs.svg" /></p>
<p>The Sources panel has 3 parts:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The <strong>File Navigator</strong> pane lists HTML, JavaScript, CSS and other files, including images that are attached to the page. Chrome extensions may appear here too.</li>
<li>The <strong>Code Editor</strong> pane shows the source code.</li>
<li>The <strong>JavaScript Debugging</strong> pane is for debugging, we‚Äôll explore it soon.</li>
</ol>
<p>Now you could click the same toggler <span class="devtools" style="background-position:-172px -122px"></span> again to hide the resources list and give the code some space.</p>
<h2 id="console">Console</h2>
<p>If we press <code>key:Esc</code>, then a console opens below. We can type commands there and press <code>key:Enter</code> to execute.</p>
<p>After a statement is executed, its result is shown below.</p>
<p>For example, here <code>1+2</code> results in <code>3</code>, and <code>hello("debugger")</code> returns nothing, so the result is <code>undefined</code>:</p>
<p><img src="chrome-sources-console.svg" /></p>
<h2 id="breakpoints">Breakpoints</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs examine what‚Äôs going on within the code of the <a href="debugging/index.html">example page</a>. In <code>hello.js</code>, click at line number <code>4</code>. Yes, right on the <code>4</code> digit, not on the code.</p>
<p>Congratulations! You‚Äôve set a breakpoint. Please also click on the number for line <code>8</code>.</p>
<p>It should look like this (blue is where you should click):</p>
<p><img src="chrome-sources-breakpoint.svg" /></p>
<p>A <em>breakpoint</em> is a point of code where the debugger will automatically pause the JavaScript execution.</p>
<p>While the code is paused, we can examine current variables, execute commands in the console etc. In other words, we can debug it.</p>
<p>We can always find a list of breakpoints in the right panel. That‚Äôs useful when we have many breakpoints in various files. It allows us to: - Quickly jump to the breakpoint in the code (by clicking on it in the right panel). - Temporarily disable the breakpoint by unchecking it. - Remove the breakpoint by right-clicking and selecting Remove. - ‚Ä¶And so on.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúConditional breakpoints‚Äù <em>Right click</em> on the line number allows to create a <em>conditional</em> breakpoint. It only triggers when the given expression is truthy.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs handy when we need to stop only for a certain variable value or for certain function parameters. ```</p>
<h2 id="debugger-command">Debugger command</h2>
<p>We can also pause the code by using the <code>debugger</code> command in it, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb321"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">hello</span>(name) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> phrase <span class="op">=</span> <span class="vs">`Hello, </span><span class="sc">${</span>name<span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">!`</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-4" title="4"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-5" title="5">  <span class="cf">debugger</span><span class="op">;</span>  <span class="co">// &lt;-- the debugger stops here</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-6" title="6"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-8" title="8"><span class="ss">  say</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">phrase</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb321-9" title="9"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>That‚Äôs very convenient when we are in a code editor and don‚Äôt want to switch to the browser and look up the script in developer tools to set the breakpoint.</p>
<h2 id="pause-and-look-around">Pause and look around</h2>
<p>In our example, <code>hello()</code> is called during the page load, so the easiest way to activate the debugger (after we‚Äôve set the breakpoints) is to reload the page. So let‚Äôs press <code>key:F5</code> (Windows, Linux) or <code>key:Cmd+R</code> (Mac).</p>
<p>As the breakpoint is set, the execution pauses at the 4th line:</p>
<p><img src="chrome-sources-debugger-pause.svg" /></p>
<p>Please open the informational dropdowns to the right (labeled with arrows). They allow you to examine the current code state:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p><strong><code>Watch</code> ‚Äì shows current values for any expressions.</strong></p>
<p>You can click the plus <code>+</code> and input an expression. The debugger will show its value at any moment, automatically recalculating it in the process of execution.</p></li>
<li><p><strong><code>Call Stack</code> ‚Äì shows the nested calls chain.</strong></p>
<p>At the current moment the debugger is inside <code>hello()</code> call, called by a script in <code>index.html</code> (no function there, so it‚Äôs called ‚Äúanonymous‚Äù).</p>
If you click on a stack item (e.g.¬†‚Äúanonymous‚Äù), the debugger jumps to the corresponding code, and all its variables can be examined as well.</li>
<li><p><strong><code>Scope</code> ‚Äì current variables.</strong></p>
<p><code>Local</code> shows local function variables. You can also see their values highlighted right over the source.</p>
<p><code>Global</code> has global variables (out of any functions).</p>
<p>There‚Äôs also <code>this</code> keyword there that we didn‚Äôt study yet, but we‚Äôll do that soon.</p></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="tracing-the-execution">Tracing the execution</h2>
<p>Now it‚Äôs time to <em>trace</em> the script.</p>
<p>There are buttons for it at the top of the right panel. Let‚Äôs engage them. <!-- https://github.com/ChromeDevTools/devtools-frontend/blob/master/front_end/Images/src/largeIcons.svg --> <span class="devtools" style="background-position:-146px -168px"></span> ‚Äì ‚ÄúResume‚Äù: continue the execution, hotkey <code>key:F8</code>. : Resumes the execution. If there are no additional breakpoints, then the execution just continues and the debugger loses control.</p>
<pre><code>Here&#39;s what we can see after a click on it:

![](chrome-sources-debugger-trace-1.svg)

The execution has resumed, reached another breakpoint inside `say()` and paused there. Take a look at the &quot;Call Stack&quot; at the right. It has increased by one more call. We&#39;re inside `say()` now.</code></pre>
<dl>
<dt><span class="devtools" style="background-position:-200px -190px"></span> ‚Äì ‚ÄúStep‚Äù: run the next command, hotkey <code>key:F9</code>.</dt>
<dd><p>Run the next statement. If we click it now, <code>alert</code> will be shown.</p>
<p>Clicking this again and again will step through all script statements one by one.</p>
</dd>
<dt><span class="devtools" style="background-position:-62px -192px"></span> ‚Äì ‚ÄúStep over‚Äù: run the next command, but <em>don‚Äôt go into a function</em>, hotkey <code>key:F10</code>.</dt>
<dd><p>Similar to the previous ‚ÄúStep‚Äù command, but behaves differently if the next statement is a function call. That is: not a built-in, like <code>alert</code>, but a function of our own.</p>
<p>The ‚ÄúStep‚Äù command goes into it and pauses the execution at its first line, while ‚ÄúStep over‚Äù executes the nested function call invisibly, skipping the function internals.</p>
<p>The execution is then paused immediately after that function.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs good if we‚Äôre not interested to see what happens inside the function call.</p>
</dd>
<dt><span class="devtools" style="background-position:-4px -194px"></span> ‚Äì ‚ÄúStep into‚Äù, hotkey <code>key:F11</code>.</dt>
<dd><p>That‚Äôs similar to ‚ÄúStep‚Äù, but behaves differently in case of asynchronous function calls. If you‚Äôre only starting to learn JavaScript, then you can ignore the difference, as we don‚Äôt have asynchronous calls yet.</p>
<p>For the future, just note that ‚ÄúStep‚Äù command ignores async actions, such as <code>setTimeout</code> (scheduled function call), that execute later. The ‚ÄúStep into‚Äù goes into their code, waiting for them if necessary. See <a href="https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2018/01/devtools#async">DevTools manual</a> for more details.</p>
</dd>
<dt><span class="devtools" style="background-position:-32px -194px"></span> ‚Äì ‚ÄúStep out‚Äù: continue the execution till the end of the current function, hotkey <code>key:Shift+F11</code>.</dt>
<dd>Continue the execution and stop it at the very last line of the current function. That‚Äôs handy when we accidentally entered a nested call using <span class="devtools" style="background-position:-200px -190px"></span>, but it does not interest us, and we want to continue to its end as soon as possible.
</dd>
<dt><span class="devtools" style="background-position:-61px -74px"></span> ‚Äì enable/disable all breakpoints.</dt>
<dd>That button does not move the execution. Just a mass on/off for breakpoints.
</dd>
<dt><span class="devtools" style="background-position:-90px -146px"></span> ‚Äì enable/disable automatic pause in case of an error.</dt>
<dd>When enabled, and the developer tools is open, a script error automatically pauses the execution. Then we can analyze variables to see what went wrong. So if our script dies with an error, we can open debugger, enable this option and reload the page to see where it dies and what‚Äôs the context at that moment.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúContinue to here‚Äù Right click on a line of code opens the context menu with a great option called ‚ÄúContinue to here‚Äù.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs handy when we want to move multiple steps forward to the line, but we‚Äôre too lazy to set a breakpoint. ```</p>
<h2 id="logging">Logging</h2>
<p>To output something to console from our code, there‚Äôs <code>console.log</code> function.</p>
<p>For instance, this outputs values from <code>0</code> to <code>4</code> to console:</p>
<p><code>js run // open console to see for (let i = 0; i &lt; 5; i++) {   console.log("value,", i); }</code></p>
<p>Regular users don‚Äôt see that output, it is in the console. To see it, either open the Console panel of developer tools or press <code>key:Esc</code> while in another panel: that opens the console at the bottom.</p>
<p>If we have enough logging in our code, then we can see what‚Äôs going on from the records, without the debugger.</p>
<h2 id="summary-40">Summary</h2>
<p>As we can see, there are three main ways to pause a script: 1. A breakpoint. 2. The <code>debugger</code> statements. 3. An error (if dev tools are open and the button <span class="devtools" style="background-position:-90px -146px"></span> is ‚Äúon‚Äù).</p>
<p>When paused, we can debug - examine variables and trace the code to see where the execution goes wrong.</p>
<p>There are many more options in developer tools than covered here. The full manual is at <a href="https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools" class="uri">https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools</a>.</p>
<p>The information from this chapter is enough to begin debugging, but later, especially if you do a lot of browser stuff, please go there and look through more advanced capabilities of developer tools.</p>
<p>Oh, and also you can click at various places of dev tools and just see what‚Äôs showing up. That‚Äôs probably the fastest route to learn dev tools. Don‚Äôt forget about the right click and context menus! # Coding Style</p>
<p>Our code must be as clean and easy to read as possible.</p>
<p>That is actually the art of programming ‚Äì to take a complex task and code it in a way that is both correct and human-readable. A good code style greatly assists in that.</p>
<h2 id="syntax">Syntax</h2>
<p>Here is a cheat sheet with some suggested rules (see below for more details):</p>
<p><img src="code-style.svg" /> <!--
```js
function pow(x, n) {
  let result = 1;

  for (let i = 0; i < n; i++) {
    result *= x;
  }

  return result;
}

let x = prompt("x?", "");
let n = prompt("n?", "");

if (n < 0) {
  alert(`Power ${n} is not supported,
    please enter a non-negative integer number`);
} else {
  alert( pow(x, n) );
}
```

--></p>
<p>Now let‚Äôs discuss the rules and reasons for them in detail.</p>
<p><code>warn header="There are no \"you must\" rules" Nothing is set in stone here. These are style preferences, not religious dogmas.</code></p>
<h3 id="curly-braces">Curly Braces</h3>
<p>In most JavaScript projects curly braces are written in ‚ÄúEgyptian‚Äù style with the opening brace on the same line as the corresponding keyword ‚Äì not on a new line. There should also be a space before the opening bracket, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb323"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb323-1" title="1"><span class="cf">if</span> (condition) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb323-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// do this</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb323-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// ...and that</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb323-4" title="4">  <span class="co">// ...and that</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb323-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>A single-line construct, such as <code>if (condition) doSomething()</code>, is an important edge case. Should we use braces at all?</p>
<p>Here are the annotated variants so you can judge their readability for yourself:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>üò† Beginners sometimes do that. Bad! Curly braces are not needed: <code>js  if (n &lt; 0) *!*{*/!*alert(`Power ${n} is not supported`);*!*}*/!*</code></li>
<li>üò† Split to a separate line without braces. Never do that, easy to make an error when adding new lines: <code>js  if (n &lt; 0)    alert(`Power ${n} is not supported`);</code></li>
<li>üòè One line without braces - acceptable, if it‚Äôs short: <code>js  if (n &lt; 0) alert(`Power ${n} is not supported`);</code></li>
<li>üòÉ The best variant: <code>js  if (n &lt; 0) {    alert(`Power ${n} is not supported`);  }</code></li>
</ol>
<p>For a very brief code, one line is allowed, e.g.¬†<code>if (cond) return null</code>. But a code block (the last variant) is usually more readable.</p>
<h3 id="line-length">Line Length</h3>
<p>No one likes to read a long horizontal line of code. It‚Äôs best practice to split them.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb324"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb324-1" title="1"><span class="co">// backtick quotes ` allow to split the string into multiple lines</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb324-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> str <span class="op">=</span> <span class="vs">`</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb324-3" title="3"><span class="vs">  ECMA International&#39;s TC39 is a group of JavaScript developers,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb324-4" title="4"><span class="vs">  implementers, academics, and more, collaborating with the community</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb324-5" title="5"><span class="vs">  to maintain and evolve the definition of JavaScript.</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb324-6" title="6"><span class="vs">`</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>And, for <code>if</code> statements:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb325"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-1" title="1"><span class="cf">if</span> (</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-2" title="2">  id <span class="op">===</span> <span class="dv">123</span> <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-3" title="3">  moonPhase <span class="op">===</span> <span class="st">&#39;Waning Gibbous&#39;</span> <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-4" title="4">  zodiacSign <span class="op">===</span> <span class="st">&#39;Libra&#39;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-5" title="5">) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-6" title="6">  <span class="at">letTheSorceryBegin</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb325-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The maximum line length should be agreed upon at the team-level. It‚Äôs usually 80 or 120 characters.</p>
<h3 id="indents">Indents</h3>
<p>There are two types of indents:</p>
<ul>
<li><p><strong>Horizontal indents: 2 or 4 spaces.</strong></p>
<p>A horizontal indentation is made using either 2 or 4 spaces or the horizontal tab symbol (key <code>key:Tab</code>). Which one to choose is an old holy war. Spaces are more common nowadays.</p>
<p>One advantage of spaces over tabs is that spaces allow more flexible configurations of indents than the tab symbol.</p>
<p>For instance, we can align the parameters with the opening bracket, like this:</p>
<p><code>js no-beautify   show(parameters,        aligned, // 5 spaces padding at the left          one,        after,        another     ) {     // ...   }</code></p></li>
<li><p><strong>Vertical indents: empty lines for splitting code into logical blocks.</strong></p>
<p>Even a single function can often be divided into logical blocks. In the example below, the initialization of variables, the main loop and returning the result are split vertically:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb326"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-3" title="3">  <span class="co">//              &lt;--</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-5" title="5">    result <span class="op">*=</span> x<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-6" title="6">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-7" title="7">  <span class="co">//              &lt;--</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-8" title="8">  <span class="cf">return</span> result<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb326-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Insert an extra newline where it helps to make the code more readable. There should not be more than nine lines of code without a vertical indentation.</p></li>
</ul>
<h3 id="semicolons">Semicolons</h3>
<p>A semicolon should be present after each statement, even if it could possibly be skipped.</p>
<p>There are languages where a semicolon is truly optional and it is rarely used. In JavaScript, though, there are cases where a line break is not interpreted as a semicolon, leaving the code vulnerable to errors. See more about that in the chapter <a href="info:structure#semicolon" class="uri">info:structure#semicolon</a>.</p>
<p>If you‚Äôre an experienced JavaScript programmer, you may choose a no-semicolon code style like <a href="https://standardjs.com/">StandardJS</a>. Otherwise, it‚Äôs best to use semicolons to avoid possible pitfalls. The majority of developers put semicolons.</p>
<h3 id="nesting-levels">Nesting Levels</h3>
<p>Try to avoid nesting code too many levels deep.</p>
<p>For example, in the loop, it‚Äôs sometimes a good idea to use the <a href="info:while-for#continue"><code>continue</code></a> directive to avoid extra nesting.</p>
<p>For example, instead of adding a nested <code>if</code> conditional like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb327"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb327-1" title="1"><span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb327-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> (cond) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb327-3" title="3">    ... <span class="co">// &lt;- one more nesting level</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb327-4" title="4">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb327-5" title="5"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>We can write:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb328"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb328-1" title="1"><span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb328-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="op">!</span>cond) <span class="op">*!*</span><span class="cf">continue</span><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb328-3" title="3"><span class="ss">  ...  // &lt;- no extra nesting level</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb328-4" title="4"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>A similar thing can be done with <code>if/else</code> and <code>return</code>.</p>
<p>For example, two constructs below are identical.</p>
<p>Option 1:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb329"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> (n <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-3" title="3">    <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="st">&quot;Negative &#39;n&#39; not supported&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-4" title="4">  <span class="op">}</span> <span class="cf">else</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-5" title="5">    <span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-7" title="7">    <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-8" title="8">      result <span class="op">*=</span> x<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-9" title="9">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-11" title="11">    <span class="cf">return</span> result<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-12" title="12">  <span class="op">}</span>  </a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb329-13" title="13"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Option 2:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb330"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">if</span> (n <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-3" title="3">    <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="st">&quot;Negative &#39;n&#39; not supported&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-4" title="4">    <span class="cf">return</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-5" title="5">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-7" title="7">  <span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-8" title="8"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-9" title="9">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-10" title="10">    result <span class="op">*=</span> x<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-11" title="11">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-12" title="12"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-13" title="13">  <span class="cf">return</span> result<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb330-14" title="14"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The second one is more readable because the ‚Äúspecial case‚Äù of <code>n &lt; 0</code> is handled early on. Once the check is done we can move on to the ‚Äúmain‚Äù code flow without the need for additional nesting.</p>
<h2 id="function-placement">Function Placement</h2>
<p>If you are writing several ‚Äúhelper‚Äù functions and the code that uses them, there are three ways to organize the functions.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>Declare the functions <em>above</em> the code that uses them:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb331"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-1" title="1"><span class="co">// *!*function declarations*/!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-2" title="2"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">createElement</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-3" title="3">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-4" title="4"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-6" title="6"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">setHandler</span>(elem) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-7" title="7">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-10" title="10"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">walkAround</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-11" title="11">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-12" title="12"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-13" title="13"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-14" title="14"><span class="co">// *!*the code which uses them*/!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-15" title="15"><span class="kw">let</span> elem <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">createElement</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-16" title="16"><span class="at">setHandler</span>(elem)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb331-17" title="17"><span class="at">walkAround</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>Code first, then functions</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb332"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-1" title="1"><span class="co">// *!*the code which uses the functions*/!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> elem <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">createElement</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-3" title="3"><span class="at">setHandler</span>(elem)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-4" title="4"><span class="at">walkAround</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-6" title="6"><span class="co">// --- *!*helper functions*/!* ---</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-7" title="7"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">createElement</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-8" title="8">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-11" title="11"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">setHandler</span>(elem) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-12" title="12">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-13" title="13"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-15" title="15"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">walkAround</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-16" title="16">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb332-17" title="17"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>Mixed: a function is declared where it‚Äôs first used.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Most of time, the second variant is preferred.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because when reading code, we first want to know <em>what it does</em>. If the code goes first, then it becomes clear from the start. Then, maybe we won‚Äôt need to read the functions at all, especially if their names are descriptive of what they actually do.</p>
<h2 id="style-guides">Style Guides</h2>
<p>A style guide contains general rules about ‚Äúhow to write‚Äù code, e.g.¬†which quotes to use, how many spaces to indent, the maximal line length, etc. A lot of minor things.</p>
<p>When all members of a team use the same style guide, the code looks uniform, regardless of which team member wrote it.</p>
<p>Of course, a team can always write their own style guide, but usually there‚Äôs no need to. There are many existing guides to choose from.</p>
<p>Some popular choices:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://google.github.io/styleguide/jsguide.html">Google JavaScript Style Guide</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/airbnb/javascript">Airbnb JavaScript Style Guide</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/rwaldron/idiomatic.js">Idiomatic.JS</a></li>
<li><a href="https://standardjs.com/">StandardJS</a></li>
<li>(plus many more)</li>
</ul>
<p>If you‚Äôre a novice developer, start with the cheat sheet at the beginning of this chapter. Then you can browse other style guides to pick up more ideas and decide which one you like best.</p>
<h2 id="automated-linters">Automated Linters</h2>
<p>Linters are tools that can automatically check the style of your code and make improving suggestions.</p>
<p>The great thing about them is that style-checking can also find some bugs, like typos in variable or function names. Because of this feature, using a linter is recommended even if you don‚Äôt want to stick to one particular ‚Äúcode style‚Äù.</p>
<p>Here are some well-known linting tools:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.jslint.com/">JSLint</a> ‚Äì one of the first linters.</li>
<li><a href="http://www.jshint.com/">JSHint</a> ‚Äì more settings than JSLint.</li>
<li><a href="http://eslint.org/">ESLint</a> ‚Äì probably the newest one.</li>
</ul>
<p>All of them can do the job. The author uses <a href="http://eslint.org/">ESLint</a>.</p>
<p>Most linters are integrated with many popular editors: just enable the plugin in the editor and configure the style.</p>
<p>For instance, for ESLint you should do the following:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Install <a href="https://nodejs.org/">Node.js</a>.</li>
<li>Install ESLint with the command <code>npm install -g eslint</code> (npm is a JavaScript package installer).</li>
<li>Create a config file named <code>.eslintrc</code> in the root of your JavaScript project (in the folder that contains all your files).</li>
<li>Install/enable the plugin for your editor that integrates with ESLint. The majority of editors have one.</li>
</ol>
<p>Here‚Äôs an example of an <code>.eslintrc</code> file:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb333"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-1" title="1"><span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-2" title="2">  <span class="st">&quot;extends&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;eslint:recommended&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-3" title="3">  <span class="st">&quot;env&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-4" title="4">    <span class="st">&quot;browser&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-5" title="5">    <span class="st">&quot;node&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-6" title="6">    <span class="st">&quot;es6&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-7" title="7">  <span class="op">},</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-8" title="8">  <span class="st">&quot;rules&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-9" title="9">    <span class="st">&quot;no-console&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-10" title="10">    <span class="st">&quot;indent&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">2</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-11" title="11">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb333-12" title="12"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here the directive <code>"extends"</code> denotes that the configuration is based on the ‚Äúeslint:recommended‚Äù set of settings. After that, we specify our own.</p>
<p>It is also possible to download style rule sets from the web and extend them instead. See <a href="http://eslint.org/docs/user-guide/getting-started" class="uri">http://eslint.org/docs/user-guide/getting-started</a> for more details about installation.</p>
<p>Also certain IDEs have built-in linting, which is convenient but not as customizable as ESLint.</p>
<h2 id="summary-41">Summary</h2>
<p>All syntax rules described in this chapter (and in the style guides referenced) aim to increase the readability of your code. All of them are debatable.</p>
<p>When we think about writing ‚Äúbetter‚Äù code, the questions we should ask ourselves are: ‚ÄúWhat makes the code more readable and easier to understand?‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhat can help us avoid errors?‚Äù These are the main things to keep in mind when choosing and debating code styles.</p>
<p>Reading popular style guides will allow you to keep up to date with the latest ideas about code style trends and best practices. # Comments</p>
<p>As we know from the chapter <a href="info:structure" class="uri">info:structure</a>, comments can be single-line: starting with <code>//</code> and multiline: <code>/* ... */</code>.</p>
<p>We normally use them to describe how and why the code works.</p>
<p>At first sight, commenting might be obvious, but novices in programming often use them wrongly.</p>
<h2 id="bad-comments">Bad comments</h2>
<p>Novices tend to use comments to explain ‚Äúwhat is going on in the code‚Äù. Like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb334"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb334-1" title="1"><span class="co">// This code will do this thing (...) and that thing (...)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb334-2" title="2"><span class="co">// ...and who knows what else...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb334-3" title="3">very<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb334-4" title="4">complex<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb334-5" title="5">code<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>But in good code, the amount of such ‚Äúexplanatory‚Äù comments should be minimal. Seriously, the code should be easy to understand without them.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a great rule about that: ‚Äúif the code is so unclear that it requires a comment, then maybe it should be rewritten instead‚Äù.</p>
<h3 id="recipe-factor-out-functions">Recipe: factor out functions</h3>
<p>Sometimes it‚Äôs beneficial to replace a code piece with a function, like here:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb335"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showPrimes</span>(n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">nextPrime</span><span class="op">:</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-5" title="5"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-6" title="6">    <span class="co">// check if i is a prime number</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-7" title="7">    <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> j <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span> j <span class="op">&lt;</span> i<span class="op">;</span> j<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-8" title="8">      <span class="cf">if</span> (i <span class="op">%</span> j <span class="op">==</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="cf">continue</span> nextPrime<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-9" title="9">    <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-10" title="10"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-11" title="11"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-12" title="12"><span class="ss">    alert</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">i</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-13" title="13"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb335-14" title="14"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The better variant, with a factored out function <code>isPrime</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb336"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">showPrimes</span>(n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-4" title="4">    <span class="op">*!*</span><span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="op">!</span><span class="at">isPrime</span>(i)) <span class="cf">continue</span><span class="op">;*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-6" title="6"><span class="ss">    alert</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">i</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;  </span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-7" title="7"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-8" title="8"><span class="ss">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-10" title="10"><span class="ss">function isPrime</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">n</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-11" title="11"><span class="ss">  for </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">let i = 2; i &lt; n; i</span><span class="sc">++)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-12" title="12"><span class="ss">    if </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">n % i == 0</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> return false;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-13" title="13"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-14" title="14"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-15" title="15"><span class="ss">  return true;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb336-16" title="16"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now we can understand the code easily. The function itself becomes the comment. Such code is called <em>self-descriptive</em>.</p>
<h3 id="recipe-create-functions">Recipe: create functions</h3>
<p>And if we have a long ‚Äúcode sheet‚Äù like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb337"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-1" title="1"><span class="co">// here we add whiskey</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-2" title="2"><span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">let</span> drop <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">getWhiskey</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-4" title="4">  <span class="at">smell</span>(drop)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-5" title="5">  <span class="at">add</span>(drop<span class="op">,</span> glass)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-6" title="6"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-8" title="8"><span class="co">// here we add juice</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-9" title="9"><span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="kw">let</span> t <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> t <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">3</span><span class="op">;</span> t<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-10" title="10">  <span class="kw">let</span> tomato <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">getTomato</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-11" title="11">  <span class="at">examine</span>(tomato)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-12" title="12">  <span class="kw">let</span> juice <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">press</span>(tomato)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-13" title="13">  <span class="at">add</span>(juice<span class="op">,</span> glass)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-14" title="14"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-15" title="15"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb337-16" title="16"><span class="co">// ...</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Then it might be a better variant to refactor it into functions like:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb338"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-1" title="1"><span class="at">addWhiskey</span>(glass)<span class="op">;</span></a>
