<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-2" title="2"><span class="at">addJuice</span>(glass)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-4" title="4"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">addWhiskey</span>(container) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-5" title="5">  <span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">10</span><span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-6" title="6">    <span class="kw">let</span> drop <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">getWhiskey</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-7" title="7">    <span class="co">//...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-8" title="8">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-11" title="11"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">addJuice</span>(container) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-12" title="12">  <span class="cf">for</span>(<span class="kw">let</span> t <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> t <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">3</span><span class="op">;</span> t<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-13" title="13">    <span class="kw">let</span> tomato <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">getTomato</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-14" title="14">    <span class="co">//...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-15" title="15">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb338-16" title="16"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Once again, functions themselves tell what‚Äôs going on. There‚Äôs nothing to comment. And also the code structure is better when split. It‚Äôs clear what every function does, what it takes and what it returns.</p>
<p>In reality, we can‚Äôt totally avoid ‚Äúexplanatory‚Äù comments. There are complex algorithms. And there are smart ‚Äútweaks‚Äù for purposes of optimization. But generally we should try to keep the code simple and self-descriptive.</p>
<h2 id="good-comments">Good comments</h2>
<p>So, explanatory comments are usually bad. Which comments are good?</p>
<dl>
<dt>Describe the architecture</dt>
<dd>Provide a high-level overview of components, how they interact, what‚Äôs the control flow in various situations‚Ä¶ In short ‚Äì the bird‚Äôs eye view of the code. There‚Äôs a special language <a href="http://wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_Modeling_Language">UML</a> to build high-level architecture diagrams explaining the code. Definitely worth studying.
</dd>
<dt>Document function parameters and usage</dt>
<dd>There‚Äôs a special syntax <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSDoc">JSDoc</a> to document a function: usage, parameters, returned value.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>For instance:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb339"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-1" title="1"><span class="co">/**</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-2" title="2"><span class="co"> * Returns x raised to the n-th power.</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-3" title="3"><span class="co"> *</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-4" title="4"><span class="co"> * </span><span class="an">@param</span><span class="co"> </span><span class="cv">{number}</span><span class="co"> x The number to raise.</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-5" title="5"><span class="co"> * </span><span class="an">@param</span><span class="co"> </span><span class="cv">{number}</span><span class="co"> n The power, must be a natural number.</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-6" title="6"><span class="co"> * </span><span class="an">@return</span><span class="co"> {number} x raised to the n-th power.</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-7" title="7"><span class="co"> */</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-8" title="8"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-9" title="9">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb339-10" title="10"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Such comments allow us to understand the purpose of the function and use it the right way without looking in its code.</p>
<p>By the way, many editors like <a href="https://www.jetbrains.com/webstorm/">WebStorm</a> can understand them as well and use them to provide autocomplete and some automatic code-checking.</p>
<p>Also, there are tools like <a href="https://github.com/jsdoc3/jsdoc">JSDoc 3</a> that can generate HTML-documentation from the comments. You can read more information about JSDoc at <a href="http://usejsdoc.org/" class="uri">http://usejsdoc.org/</a>.</p>
<dl>
<dt>Why is the task solved this way?</dt>
<dd><p>What‚Äôs written is important. But what‚Äôs <em>not</em> written may be even more important to understand what‚Äôs going on. Why is the task solved exactly this way? The code gives no answer.</p>
<p>If there are many ways to solve the task, why this one? Especially when it‚Äôs not the most obvious one.</p>
<p>Without such comments the following situation is possible: 1. You (or your colleague) open the code written some time ago, and see that it‚Äôs ‚Äúsuboptimal‚Äù. 2. You think: ‚ÄúHow stupid I was then, and how much smarter I‚Äôm now‚Äù, and rewrite using the ‚Äúmore obvious and correct‚Äù variant. 3. ‚Ä¶The urge to rewrite was good. But in the process you see that the ‚Äúmore obvious‚Äù solution is actually lacking. You even dimly remember why, because you already tried it long ago. You revert to the correct variant, but the time was wasted.</p>
<p>Comments that explain the solution are very important. They help to continue development the right way.</p>
</dd>
<dt>Any subtle features of the code? Where they are used?</dt>
<dd>If the code has anything subtle and counter-intuitive, it‚Äôs definitely worth commenting.
</dd>
</dl>
<h2 id="summary-42">Summary</h2>
<p>An important sign of a good developer is comments: their presence and even their absence.</p>
<p>Good comments allow us to maintain the code well, come back to it after a delay and use it more effectively.</p>
<p><strong>Comment this:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Overall architecture, high-level view.</li>
<li>Function usage.</li>
<li>Important solutions, especially when not immediately obvious.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Avoid comments:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>That tell ‚Äúhow code works‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat it does‚Äù.</li>
<li>Put them in only if it‚Äôs impossible to make the code so simple and self-descriptive that it doesn‚Äôt require them.</li>
</ul>
<p>Comments are also used for auto-documenting tools like JSDoc3: they read them and generate HTML-docs (or docs in another format). # Ninja code</p>
<p><code>quote author="Confucius (Analects)" Learning without thought is labor lost; thought without learning is perilous.</code></p>
<p>Programmer ninjas of the past used these tricks to sharpen the mind of code maintainers.</p>
<p>Code review gurus look for them in test tasks.</p>
<p>Novice developers sometimes use them even better than programmer ninjas.</p>
<p>Read them carefully and find out who you are ‚Äì a ninja, a novice, or maybe a code reviewer?</p>
<p><code>warn header="Irony detected" Many try to follow ninja paths. Few succeed.</code></p>
<h2 id="brevity-is-the-soul-of-wit">Brevity is the soul of wit</h2>
<p>Make the code as short as possible. Show how smart you are.</p>
<p>Let subtle language features guide you.</p>
<p>For instance, take a look at this ternary operator <code>'?'</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb340"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb340-1" title="1"><span class="co">// taken from a well-known javascript library</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb340-2" title="2">i <span class="op">=</span> i <span class="op">?</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">0</span> <span class="op">?</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">max</span>(<span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">,</span> len <span class="op">+</span> i) : i : <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Cool, right? If you write like that, a developer who comes across this line and tries to understand what is the value of <code>i</code> is going to have a merry time. Then come to you, seeking for an answer.</p>
<p>Tell them that shorter is always better. Initiate them into the paths of ninja.</p>
<h2 id="one-letter-variables">One-letter variables</h2>
<p><code>quote author="Laozi (Tao Te Ching)" The Dao hides in wordlessness. Only the Dao is well begun and well completed.</code></p>
<p>Another way to code shorter is to use single-letter variable names everywhere. Like <code>a</code>, <code>b</code> or <code>c</code>.</p>
<p>A short variable disappears in the code like a real ninja in the forest. No one will be able to find it using ‚Äúsearch‚Äù of the editor. And even if someone does, they won‚Äôt be able to ‚Äúdecipher‚Äù what the name <code>a</code> or <code>b</code> means.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But there‚Äôs an exception. A real ninja will never use <code>i</code> as the counter in a <code>"for"</code> loop. Anywhere, but not here. Look around, there are many more exotic letters. For instance, <code>x</code> or <code>y</code>.</p>
<p>An exotic variable as a loop counter is especially cool if the loop body takes 1-2 pages (make it longer if you can). Then if someone looks deep inside the loop, they won‚Äôt be able to quickly figure out that the variable named <code>x</code> is the loop counter.</p>
<h2 id="use-abbreviations">Use abbreviations</h2>
<p>If the team rules forbid the use of one-letter and vague names ‚Äì shorten them, make abbreviations.</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>list</code> -&gt; <code>lst</code>.</li>
<li><code>userAgent</code> -&gt; <code>ua</code>.</li>
<li><code>browser</code> -&gt; <code>brsr</code>.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶etc</li>
</ul>
<p>Only the one with truly good intuition will be able to understand such names. Try to shorten everything. Only a worthy person should be able to uphold the development of your code.</p>
<h2 id="soar-high.-be-abstract.">Soar high. Be abstract.</h2>
<p><code>quote author="Laozi (Tao Te Ching)" The great square is cornerless&lt;br&gt; The great vessel is last complete,&lt;br&gt; The great note is rarified sound,&lt;br&gt; The great image has no form.</code></p>
<p>While choosing a name try to use the most abstract word. Like <code>obj</code>, <code>data</code>, <code>value</code>, <code>item</code>, <code>elem</code> and so on.</p>
<ul>
<li><p><strong>The ideal name for a variable is <code>data</code>.</strong> Use it everywhere you can. Indeed, every variable holds <em>data</em>, right?</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But what to do if <code>data</code> is already taken? Try <code>value</code>, it‚Äôs also universal. After all, a variable eventually gets a <em>value</em>.</p></li>
<li><p><strong>Name a variable by its type: <code>str</code>, <code>num</code>‚Ä¶</strong></p>
<p>Give them a try. A young initiate may wonder ‚Äì are such names really useful for a ninja? Indeed, they are!</p>
<p>Sure, the variable name still means something. It says what‚Äôs inside the variable: a string, a number or something else. But when an outsider tries to understand the code, they‚Äôll be surprised to see that there‚Äôs actually no information at all! And will ultimately fail to alter your well-thought code.</p>
<p>The value type is easy to find out by debugging. But what‚Äôs the meaning of the variable? Which string/number does it store?</p>
<p>There‚Äôs just no way to figure out without a good meditation!</p></li>
<li><p><strong>‚Ä¶But what if there are no more such names?</strong> Just add a number: <code>data1, item2, elem5</code>‚Ä¶</p></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="attention-test">Attention test</h2>
<p>Only a truly attentive programmer should be able to understand your code. But how to check that?</p>
<p><strong>One of the ways ‚Äì use similar variable names, like <code>date</code> and <code>data</code>.</strong></p>
<p>Mix them where you can.</p>
<p>A quick read of such code becomes impossible. And when there‚Äôs a typo‚Ä¶ Ummm‚Ä¶ We‚Äôre stuck for long, time to drink tea.</p>
<h2 id="smart-synonyms">Smart synonyms</h2>
<p><code>quote author="Laozi (Tao Te Ching)" The Tao that can be told is not the eternal Tao. The name that can be named is not the eternal name.</code></p>
<p>Using <em>similar</em> names for <em>same</em> things makes life more interesting and shows your creativity to the public.</p>
<p>For instance, consider function prefixes. If a function shows a message on the screen ‚Äì start it with <code>display‚Ä¶</code>, like <code>displayMessage</code>. And then if another function shows on the screen something else, like a user name, start it with <code>show‚Ä¶</code> (like <code>showName</code>).</p>
<p>Insinuate that there‚Äôs a subtle difference between such functions, while there is none.</p>
<p>Make a pact with fellow ninjas of the team: if John starts ‚Äúshowing‚Äù functions with <code>display...</code> in his code, then Peter could use <code>render..</code>, and Ann ‚Äì <code>paint...</code>. Note how much more interesting and diverse the code became.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶And now the hat trick!</p>
<p>For two functions with important differences ‚Äì use the same prefix!</p>
<p>For instance, the function <code>printPage(page)</code> will use a printer. And the function <code>printText(text)</code> will put the text on-screen. Let an unfamiliar reader think well over similarly named function <code>printMessage</code>: ‚ÄúWhere does it put the message? To a printer or on the screen?‚Äù. To make it really shine, <code>printMessage(message)</code> should output it in the new window!</p>
<h2 id="reuse-names">Reuse names</h2>
<p><code>quote author="Laozi (Tao Te Ching)" Once the whole is divided, the parts&lt;br&gt; need names.&lt;br&gt; There are already enough names.&lt;br&gt; One must know when to stop.</code></p>
<p>Add a new variable only when absolutely necessary.</p>
<p>Instead, reuse existing names. Just write new values into them.</p>
<p>In a function try to use only variables passed as parameters.</p>
<p>That would make it really hard to identify what‚Äôs exactly in the variable <em>now</em>. And also where it comes from. The purpose is to develop the intuition and memory of a person reading the code. A person with weak intuition would have to analyze the code line-by-line and track the changes through every code branch.</p>
<p><strong>An advanced variant of the approach is to covertly (!) replace the value with something alike in the middle of a loop or a function.</strong></p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb341"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">ninjaFunction</span>(elem) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// 20 lines of code working with elem</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-4" title="4">  elem <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">clone</span>(elem)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// 20 more lines, now working with the clone of the elem!</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb341-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>A fellow programmer who wants to work with <code>elem</code> in the second half of the function will be surprised‚Ä¶ Only during the debugging, after examining the code they will find out that they‚Äôre working with a clone!</p>
<p>Seen in code regularly. Deadly effective even against an experienced ninja.</p>
<h2 id="underscores-for-fun">Underscores for fun</h2>
<p>Put underscores <code>_</code> and <code>__</code> before variable names. Like <code>_name</code> or <code>__value</code>. It would be great if only you knew their meaning. Or, better, add them just for fun, without particular meaning at all. Or different meanings in different places.</p>
<p>You kill two rabbits with one shot. First, the code becomes longer and less readable, and the second, a fellow developer may spend a long time trying to figure out what the underscores mean.</p>
<p>A smart ninja puts underscores at one spot of code and evades them at other places. That makes the code even more fragile and increases the probability of future errors.</p>
<h2 id="show-your-love">Show your love</h2>
<p>Let everyone see how magnificent your entities are! Names like <code>superElement</code>, <code>megaFrame</code> and <code>niceItem</code> will definitely enlighten a reader.</p>
<p>Indeed, from one hand, something is written: <code>super..</code>, <code>mega..</code>, <code>nice..</code> But from the other hand ‚Äì that brings no details. A reader may decide to look for a hidden meaning and meditate for an hour or two of their paid working time.</p>
<h2 id="overlap-outer-variables">Overlap outer variables</h2>
<p><code>quote author="Guan Yin Zi" When in the light, can't see anything in the darkness.&lt;br&gt; When in the darkness, can see everything in the light.</code></p>
<p>Use same names for variables inside and outside a function. As simple. No efforts to invent new names.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb342"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> <span class="op">*!*</span>user<span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss"> = authenticateUser</span><span class="sc">()</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-3" title="3"><span class="ss">function render</span><span class="sc">()</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-4" title="4"><span class="ss">  let </span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">!</span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">user</span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">/</span><span class="op">!*</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">anotherValue</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-5" title="5">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-6" title="6">  ...<span class="at">many</span> <span class="va">lines</span>...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-7" title="7">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-8" title="8">  ... <span class="co">// &lt;-- a programmer wants to work with user here and...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-9" title="9">  ...</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb342-10" title="10">}</a></code></pre></div>
<p>A programmer who jumps inside the <code>render</code> will probably fail to notice that there‚Äôs a local <code>user</code> shadowing the outer one.</p>
<p>Then they‚Äôll try to work with <code>user</code> assuming that it‚Äôs the external variable, the result of <code>authenticateUser()</code>‚Ä¶ The trap is sprung! Hello, debugger‚Ä¶</p>
<h2 id="side-effects-everywhere">Side-effects everywhere!</h2>
<p>There are functions that look like they don‚Äôt change anything. Like <code>isReady()</code>, <code>checkPermission()</code>, <code>findTags()</code>‚Ä¶ They are assumed to carry out calculations, find and return the data, without changing anything outside of them. In other words, without ‚Äúside-effects‚Äù.</p>
<p><strong>A really beautiful trick is to add a ‚Äúuseful‚Äù action to them, besides the main task.</strong></p>
<p>An expression of dazed surprise on the face of your colleague when they see a function named <code>is..</code>, <code>check..</code> or <code>find...</code> changing something ‚Äì will definitely broaden your boundaries of reason.</p>
<p><strong>Another way to surprise is to return a non-standard result.</strong></p>
<p>Show your original thinking! Let the call of <code>checkPermission</code> return not <code>true/false</code>, but a complex object with the results of the check.</p>
<p>Those developers who try to write <code>if (checkPermission(..))</code>, will wonder why it doesn‚Äôt work. Tell them: ‚ÄúRead the docs!‚Äù. And give this article.</p>
<h2 id="powerful-functions">Powerful functions!</h2>
<p><code>quote author="Laozi (Tao Te Ching)" The great Tao flows everywhere,&lt;br&gt; both to the left and to the right.</code></p>
<p>Don‚Äôt limit the function by what‚Äôs written in its name. Be broader.</p>
<p>For instance, a function <code>validateEmail(email)</code> could (besides checking the email for correctness) show an error message and ask to re-enter the email.</p>
<p>Additional actions should not be obvious from the function name. A true ninja coder will make them not obvious from the code as well.</p>
<p><strong>Joining several actions into one protects your code from reuse.</strong></p>
<p>Imagine, another developer wants only to check the email, and not output any message. Your function <code>validateEmail(email)</code> that does both will not suit them. So they won‚Äôt break your meditation by asking anything about it.</p>
<h2 id="summary-43">Summary</h2>
<p>All ‚Äúpieces of advice‚Äù above are from the real code‚Ä¶ Sometimes, written by experienced developers. Maybe even more experienced than you are ;)</p>
<ul>
<li>Follow some of them, and your code will become full of surprises.</li>
<li>Follow many of them, and your code will become truly yours, no one would want to change it.</li>
<li>Follow all, and your code will become a valuable lesson for young developers looking for enlightenment. # Automated testing with Mocha</li>
</ul>
<p>Automated testing will be used in further tasks, and it‚Äôs also widely used in real projects.</p>
<h2 id="why-do-we-need-tests">Why do we need tests?</h2>
<p>When we write a function, we can usually imagine what it should do: which parameters give which results.</p>
<p>During development, we can check the function by running it and comparing the outcome with the expected one. For instance, we can do it in the console.</p>
<p>If something is wrong ‚Äì then we fix the code, run again, check the result ‚Äì and so on till it works.</p>
<p>But such manual ‚Äúre-runs‚Äù are imperfect.</p>
<p><strong>When testing a code by manual re-runs, it‚Äôs easy to miss something.</strong></p>
<p>For instance, we‚Äôre creating a function <code>f</code>. Wrote some code, testing: <code>f(1)</code> works, but <code>f(2)</code> doesn‚Äôt work. We fix the code and now <code>f(2)</code> works. Looks complete? But we forgot to re-test <code>f(1)</code>. That may lead to an error.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs very typical. When we develop something, we keep a lot of possible use cases in mind. But it‚Äôs hard to expect a programmer to check all of them manually after every change. So it becomes easy to fix one thing and break another one.</p>
<p><strong>Automated testing means that tests are written separately, in addition to the code. They run our functions in various ways and compare results with the expected.</strong></p>
<h2 id="behavior-driven-development-bdd">Behavior Driven Development (BDD)</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs start with a technique named <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior-driven_development">Behavior Driven Development</a> or, in short, BDD.</p>
<p><strong>BDD is three things in one: tests AND documentation AND examples.</strong></p>
<p>To understand BDD, we‚Äôll examine a practical case of development.</p>
<h2 id="development-of-pow-the-spec">Development of ‚Äúpow‚Äù: the spec</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs say we want to make a function <code>pow(x, n)</code> that raises <code>x</code> to an integer power <code>n</code>. We assume that <code>n‚â•0</code>.</p>
<p>That task is just an example: there‚Äôs the <code>**</code> operator in JavaScript that can do that, but here we concentrate on the development flow that can be applied to more complex tasks as well.</p>
<p>Before creating the code of <code>pow</code>, we can imagine what the function should do and describe it.</p>
<p>Such description is called a <em>specification</em> or, in short, a spec, and contains descriptions of use cases together with tests for them, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb343"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-1" title="1"><span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pow&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-3" title="3">  <span class="at">it</span>(<span class="st">&quot;raises to n-th power&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-4" title="4">    <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">equal</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">3</span>)<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">8</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-5" title="5">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb343-7" title="7"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>A spec has three main building blocks that you can see above:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>describe("title", function() { ... })</code></dt>
<dd>What functionality we‚Äôre describing. In our case we‚Äôre describing the function <code>pow</code>. Used to group ‚Äúworkers‚Äù ‚Äì the <code>it</code> blocks.
</dd>
<dt><code>it("use case description", function() { ... })</code></dt>
<dd>In the title of <code>it</code> we <em>in a human-readable way</em> describe the particular use case, and the second argument is a function that tests it.
</dd>
<dt><code>assert.equal(value1, value2)</code></dt>
<dd><p>The code inside <code>it</code> block, if the implementation is correct, should execute without errors.</p>
<p>Functions <code>assert.*</code> are used to check whether <code>pow</code> works as expected. Right here we‚Äôre using one of them ‚Äì <code>assert.equal</code>, it compares arguments and yields an error if they are not equal. Here it checks that the result of <code>pow(2, 3)</code> equals <code>8</code>. There are other types of comparisons and checks, that we‚Äôll add later.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The specification can be executed, and it will run the test specified in <code>it</code> block. We‚Äôll see that later.</p>
<h2 id="the-development-flow">The development flow</h2>
<p>The flow of development usually looks like this:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>An initial spec is written, with tests for the most basic functionality.</li>
<li>An initial implementation is created.</li>
<li>To check whether it works, we run the testing framework <a href="http://mochajs.org/">Mocha</a> (more details soon) that runs the spec. While the functionality is not complete, errors are displayed. We make corrections until everything works.</li>
<li>Now we have a working initial implementation with tests.</li>
<li>We add more use cases to the spec, probably not yet supported by the implementations. Tests start to fail.</li>
<li>Go to 3, update the implementation till tests give no errors.</li>
<li>Repeat steps 3-6 till the functionality is ready.</li>
</ol>
<p>So, the development is <em>iterative</em>. We write the spec, implement it, make sure tests pass, then write more tests, make sure they work etc. At the end we have both a working implementation and tests for it.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs see this development flow in our practical case.</p>
<p>The first step is already complete: we have an initial spec for <code>pow</code>. Now, before making the implementation, let‚Äôs use few JavaScript libraries to run the tests, just to see that they are working (they will all fail).</p>
<h2 id="the-spec-in-action">The spec in action</h2>
<p>Here in the tutorial we‚Äôll be using the following JavaScript libraries for tests:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://mochajs.org/">Mocha</a> ‚Äì the core framework: it provides common testing functions including <code>describe</code> and <code>it</code> and the main function that runs tests.</li>
<li><a href="http://chaijs.com">Chai</a> ‚Äì the library with many assertions. It allows to use a lot of different assertions, for now we need only <code>assert.equal</code>.</li>
<li><a href="http://sinonjs.org/">Sinon</a> ‚Äì a library to spy over functions, emulate built-in functions and more, we‚Äôll need it much later.</li>
</ul>
<p>These libraries are suitable for both in-browser and server-side testing. Here we‚Äôll consider the browser variant.</p>
<p>The full HTML page with these frameworks and <code>pow</code> spec:</p>
<p><code>html src="index.html"</code></p>
<p>The page can be divided into five parts:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The <code>&lt;head&gt;</code> ‚Äì add third-party libraries and styles for tests.</li>
<li>The <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> with the function to test, in our case ‚Äì with the code for <code>pow</code>.</li>
<li>The tests ‚Äì in our case an external script <code>test.js</code> that has <code>describe("pow", ...)</code> from above.</li>
<li>The HTML element <code>&lt;div id="mocha"&gt;</code> will be used by Mocha to output results.</li>
<li>The tests are started by the command <code>mocha.run()</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>The result:</p>
<p>[iframe height=250 src=‚Äúpow-1‚Äù border=1 edit]</p>
<p>As of now, the test fails, there‚Äôs an error. That‚Äôs logical: we have an empty function code in <code>pow</code>, so <code>pow(2,3)</code> returns <code>undefined</code> instead of <code>8</code>.</p>
<p>For the future, let‚Äôs note that there are more high-level test-runners, like <a href="https://karma-runner.github.io/">karma</a> and others, that make it easy to autorun many different tests.</p>
<h2 id="initial-implementation">Initial implementation</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs make a simple implementation of <code>pow</code>, for tests to pass:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb344"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb344-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb344-2" title="2">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="dv">8</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// :) we cheat!</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb344-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Wow, now it works!</p>
<p>[iframe height=250 src=‚Äúpow-min‚Äù border=1 edit]</p>
<h2 id="improving-the-spec">Improving the spec</h2>
<p>What we‚Äôve done is definitely a cheat. The function does not work: an attempt to calculate <code>pow(3,4)</code> would give an incorrect result, but tests pass.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But the situation is quite typical, it happens in practice. Tests pass, but the function works wrong. Our spec is imperfect. We need to add more use cases to it.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs add one more test to check that <code>pow(3, 4) = 81</code>.</p>
<p>We can select one of two ways to organize the test here:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>The first variant ‚Äì add one more <code>assert</code> into the same <code>it</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb345"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-1" title="1"><span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pow&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-3" title="3">  <span class="at">it</span>(<span class="st">&quot;raises to n-th power&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-4" title="4">    <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">equal</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">3</span>)<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">8</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-5" title="5"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-6" title="6">    <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">equal</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">3</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">4</span>)<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">81</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-7" title="7"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-8" title="8"><span class="ss">  }</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb345-10" title="10"><span class="ss">}</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
<li><p>The second ‚Äì make two tests:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb346"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-1" title="1"><span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pow&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-3" title="3">  <span class="at">it</span>(<span class="st">&quot;2 raised to power 3 is 8&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-4" title="4">    <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">equal</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">3</span>)<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">8</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-5" title="5">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-7" title="7">  <span class="at">it</span>(<span class="st">&quot;3 raised to power 4 is 81&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-8" title="8">    <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">equal</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">3</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">4</span>)<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">81</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-9" title="9">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb346-11" title="11"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div></li>
</ol>
<p>The principal difference is that when <code>assert</code> triggers an error, the <code>it</code> block immediately terminates. So, in the first variant if the first <code>assert</code> fails, then we‚Äôll never see the result of the second <code>assert</code>.</p>
<p>Making tests separate is useful to get more information about what‚Äôs going on, so the second variant is better.</p>
<p>And besides that, there‚Äôs one more rule that‚Äôs good to follow.</p>
<p><strong>One test checks one thing.</strong></p>
<p>If we look at the test and see two independent checks in it, it‚Äôs better to split it into two simpler ones.</p>
<p>So let‚Äôs continue with the second variant.</p>
<p>The result:</p>
<p>[iframe height=250 src=‚Äúpow-2‚Äù edit border=‚Äú1‚Äù]</p>
<p>As we could expect, the second test failed. Sure, our function always returns <code>8</code>, while the <code>assert</code> expects <code>81</code>.</p>
<h2 id="improving-the-implementation">Improving the implementation</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs write something more real for tests to pass:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb347"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">let</span> result <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> i <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">0</span><span class="op">;</span> i <span class="op">&lt;</span> n<span class="op">;</span> i<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-5" title="5">    result <span class="op">*=</span> x<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-6" title="6">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-8" title="8">  <span class="cf">return</span> result<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb347-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>To be sure that the function works well, let‚Äôs test it for more values. Instead of writing <code>it</code> blocks manually, we can generate them in <code>for</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb348"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-1" title="1"><span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pow&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">makeTest</span>(x) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-4" title="4">    <span class="kw">let</span> expected <span class="op">=</span> x <span class="op">*</span> x <span class="op">*</span> x<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-5" title="5">    <span class="at">it</span>(<span class="vs">`</span><span class="sc">${</span>x<span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs"> in the power 3 is </span><span class="sc">${</span>expected<span class="sc">}</span><span class="vs">`</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-6" title="6">      <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">equal</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">3</span>)<span class="op">,</span> expected)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-7" title="7">    <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-8" title="8">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-10" title="10">  <span class="cf">for</span> (<span class="kw">let</span> x <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span><span class="op">;</span> x <span class="op">&lt;=</span> <span class="dv">5</span><span class="op">;</span> x<span class="op">++</span>) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-11" title="11">    <span class="at">makeTest</span>(x)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-12" title="12">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-13" title="13"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb348-14" title="14"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The result:</p>
<p>[iframe height=250 src=‚Äúpow-3‚Äù edit border=‚Äú1‚Äù]</p>
<h2 id="nested-describe">Nested describe</h2>
<p>We‚Äôre going to add even more tests. But before that let‚Äôs note that the helper function <code>makeTest</code> and <code>for</code> should be grouped together. We won‚Äôt need <code>makeTest</code> in other tests, it‚Äôs needed only in <code>for</code>: their common task is to check how <code>pow</code> raises into the given power.</p>
<p>Grouping is done with a nested <code>describe</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb349"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-1" title="1"><span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pow&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-3" title="3"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-4" title="4">  <span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;raises x to power 3&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-5" title="5"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-7" title="7"><span class="ss">    function makeTest</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">x</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-8" title="8"><span class="ss">      let expected = x </span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss"> x </span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss"> x;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-9" title="9"><span class="ss">      it</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">`${x} in the power 3 is ${expected}`, function</span><span class="sc">()</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-10" title="10"><span class="ss">        assert.equal</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">pow</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">x, 3</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">, expected</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-11" title="11"><span class="ss">      }</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-12" title="12"><span class="ss">    }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-13" title="13"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-14" title="14"><span class="ss">    for </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">let x = 1; x &lt;= 5; x</span><span class="sc">++)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-15" title="15"><span class="ss">      makeTest</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">x</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-16" title="16"><span class="ss">    }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-17" title="17"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-18" title="18"><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-19" title="19"><span class="ss">  }</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-20" title="20"><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">/</span><span class="op">!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-21" title="21"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-22" title="22">  <span class="co">// ... more tests to follow here, both describe and it can be added</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb349-23" title="23"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The nested <code>describe</code> defines a new ‚Äúsubgroup‚Äù of tests. In the output we can see the titled indentation:</p>
<p>[iframe height=250 src=‚Äúpow-4‚Äù edit border=‚Äú1‚Äù]</p>
<p>In the future we can add more <code>it</code> and <code>describe</code> on the top level with helper functions of their own, they won‚Äôt see <code>makeTest</code>.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="</code>before/after<code>and</code>beforeEach/afterEach<code>" We can setup</code>before/after<code>functions that execute before/after running tests, and also</code>beforeEach/afterEach<code>functions that execute before/after *every*</code>it`.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js no-beautify describe(‚Äútest‚Äù, function() {</p>
<p>before(() =&gt; alert(‚ÄúTesting started ‚Äì before all tests‚Äù)); after(() =&gt; alert(‚ÄúTesting finished ‚Äì after all tests‚Äù));</p>
<p>beforeEach(() =&gt; alert(‚ÄúBefore a test ‚Äì enter a test‚Äù)); afterEach(() =&gt; alert(‚ÄúAfter a test ‚Äì exit a test‚Äù));</p>
<p>it(‚Äòtest 1‚Äô, () =&gt; alert(1)); it(‚Äòtest 2‚Äô, () =&gt; alert(2));</p>
<p>});</p>
<pre><code>
The running sequence will be:
</code></pre>
<p>Testing started ‚Äì before all tests (before) Before a test ‚Äì enter a test (beforeEach) 1 After a test ‚Äì exit a test (afterEach) Before a test ‚Äì enter a test (beforeEach) 2 After a test ‚Äì exit a test (afterEach) Testing finished ‚Äì after all tests (after)</p>
<pre><code>
[edit src=&quot;beforeafter&quot; title=&quot;Open the example in the sandbox.&quot;]

Usually, `beforeEach/afterEach` and `before/after` are used to perform initialization, zero out counters or do something else between the tests (or test groups).</code></pre>
<h2 id="extending-the-spec">Extending the spec</h2>
<p>The basic functionality of <code>pow</code> is complete. The first iteration of the development is done. When we‚Äôre done celebrating and drinking champagne ‚Äì let‚Äôs go on and improve it.</p>
<p>As it was said, the function <code>pow(x, n)</code> is meant to work with positive integer values <code>n</code>.</p>
<p>To indicate a mathematical error, JavaScript functions usually return <code>NaN</code>. Let‚Äôs do the same for invalid values of <code>n</code>.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs first add the behavior to the spec(!):</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb352"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-1" title="1"><span class="at">describe</span>(<span class="st">&quot;pow&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-5" title="5">  <span class="at">it</span>(<span class="st">&quot;for negative n the result is NaN&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-6" title="6"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-7" title="7">    <span class="va">assert</span>.<span class="at">isNaN</span>(<span class="at">pow</span>(<span class="dv">2</span><span class="op">,</span> <span class="dv">-1</span>))<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-8" title="8"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-9" title="9"><span class="ss">  }</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-11" title="11"><span class="ss">  it</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">&quot;for non-integer n the result is NaN&quot;, function</span><span class="sc">()</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-12" title="12"><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-13" title="13"><span class="ss">    assert.isNaN</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">pow</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">2, 1.5</span><span class="sc">))</span><span class="ss">;    </span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-14" title="14"><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">/</span><span class="op">!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-15" title="15">  <span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-16" title="16"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb352-17" title="17"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The result with new tests:</p>
<p>[iframe height=530 src=‚Äúpow-nan‚Äù edit border=‚Äú1‚Äù]</p>
<p>The newly added tests fail, because our implementation does not support them. That‚Äôs how BDD is done: first we write failing tests, and then make an implementation for them.</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Other assertions" Please note the assertion</code>assert.isNaN<code>: it checks for</code>NaN`.</p>
<p>There are other assertions in <a href="http://chaijs.com">Chai</a> as well, for instance:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>assert.equal(value1, value2)</code> ‚Äì checks the equality <code>value1 == value2</code>.</li>
<li><code>assert.strictEqual(value1, value2)</code> ‚Äì checks the strict equality <code>value1 === value2</code>.</li>
<li><code>assert.notEqual</code>, <code>assert.notStrictEqual</code> ‚Äì inverse checks to the ones above.</li>
<li><code>assert.isTrue(value)</code> ‚Äì checks that <code>value === true</code></li>
<li><code>assert.isFalse(value)</code> ‚Äì checks that <code>value === false</code></li>
<li>‚Ä¶the full list is in the <a href="http://chaijs.com/api/assert/">docs</a> ```</li>
</ul>
<p>So we should add a couple of lines to <code>pow</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb353"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">pow</span>(x<span class="op">,</span> n) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-2" title="2"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">if</span> (n <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">0</span>) <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="kw">NaN</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-4" title="4">  <span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">round</span>(n) <span class="op">!=</span> n) <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="kw">NaN</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-5" title="5"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-6" title="6"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-7" title="7"><span class="ss">  let result = 1;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-8" title="8"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-9" title="9"><span class="ss">  for </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">let i = 0; i &lt; n; i</span><span class="sc">++)</span><span class="ss"> {</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-10" title="10"><span class="ss">    result </span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">= x;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-11" title="11"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-12" title="12"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-13" title="13"><span class="ss">  return result;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb353-14" title="14"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now it works, all tests pass:</p>
<p>[iframe height=300 src=‚Äúpow-full‚Äù edit border=‚Äú1‚Äù]</p>
<p>[edit src=‚Äúpow-full‚Äù title=‚ÄúOpen the full final example in the sandbox.‚Äù]</p>
<h2 id="summary-44">Summary</h2>
<p>In BDD, the spec goes first, followed by implementation. At the end we have both the spec and the code.</p>
<p>The spec can be used in three ways:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>As <strong>Tests</strong> - they guarantee that the code works correctly.</li>
<li>As <strong>Docs</strong> ‚Äì the titles of <code>describe</code> and <code>it</code> tell what the function does.</li>
<li>As <strong>Examples</strong> ‚Äì the tests are actually working examples showing how a function can be used.</li>
</ol>
<p>With the spec, we can safely improve, change, even rewrite the function from scratch and make sure it still works right.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs especially important in large projects when a function is used in many places. When we change such a function, there‚Äôs just no way to manually check if every place that uses it still works right.</p>
<p>Without tests, people have two ways:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>To perform the change, no matter what. And then our users meet bugs, as we probably fail to check something manually.</li>
<li>Or, if the punishment for errors is harsh, as there are no tests, people become afraid to modify such functions, and then the code becomes outdated, no one wants to get into it. Not good for development.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Automatic testing helps to avoid these problems!</strong></p>
<p>If the project is covered with tests, there‚Äôs just no such problem. After any changes, we can run tests and see a lot of checks made in a matter of seconds.</p>
<p><strong>Besides, a well-tested code has better architecture.</strong></p>
<p>Naturally, that‚Äôs because auto-tested code is easier to modify and improve. But there‚Äôs also another reason.</p>
<p>To write tests, the code should be organized in such a way that every function has a clearly described task, well-defined input and output. That means a good architecture from the beginning.</p>
<p>In real life that‚Äôs sometimes not that easy. Sometimes it‚Äôs difficult to write a spec before the actual code, because it‚Äôs not yet clear how it should behave. But in general writing tests makes development faster and more stable.</p>
<p>Later in the tutorial you will meet many tasks with tests baked-in. So you‚Äôll see more practical examples.</p>
<p>Writing tests requires good JavaScript knowledge. But we‚Äôre just starting to learn it. So, to settle down everything, as of now you‚Äôre not required to write tests, but you should already be able to read them even if they are a little bit more complex than in this chapter.</p>
<h1 id="polyfills-and-transpilers">Polyfills and transpilers</h1>
<p>The JavaScript language steadily evolves. New proposals to the language appear regularly, they are analyzed and, if considered worthy, are appended to the list at <a href="https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/" class="uri">https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/</a> and then progress to the <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-262.htm">specification</a>.</p>
<p>Teams behind JavaScript engines have their own ideas about what to implement first. They may decide to implement proposals that are in draft and postpone things that are already in the spec, because they are less interesting or just harder to do.</p>
<p>So it‚Äôs quite common for an engine to implement only the part of the standard.</p>
<p>A good page to see the current state of support for language features is <a href="https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/" class="uri">https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/</a> (it‚Äôs big, we have a lot to study yet).</p>
<p>As programmers, we‚Äôd like to use most recent features. The more good stuff - the better!</p>
<p>On the other hand, how to make our modern code work on older engines that don‚Äôt understand recent features yet?</p>
<p>There are two tools for that:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Transpilers.</li>
<li>Polyfills.</li>
</ol>
<p>Here, in this chapter, our purpose is to get the gist of how they work, and their place in web development.</p>
<h2 id="transpilers">Transpilers</h2>
<p>A <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source-to-source_compiler">transpiler</a> is a special piece of software that can parse (‚Äúread and understand‚Äù) modern code, and rewrite it using older syntax constructs, so that the result would be the same.</p>
<p>E.g. JavaScript before year 2020 didn‚Äôt have the ‚Äúnullish coalescing operator‚Äù <code>??</code>. So, if a visitor uses an outdated browser, it may fail to understand the code like <code>height = height ?? 100</code>.</p>
<p>A transpiler would analyze our code and rewrite <code>height ?? 100</code> into <code>(height !== undefined &amp;&amp; height !== null) ? height : 100</code>.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb354"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb354-1" title="1"><span class="co">// before running the transpiler</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb354-2" title="2">height <span class="op">=</span> height <span class="op">??</span> <span class="dv">100</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb354-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb354-4" title="4"><span class="co">// after running the transpiler</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb354-5" title="5">height <span class="op">=</span> (height <span class="op">!==</span> <span class="kw">undefined</span> <span class="op">&amp;&amp;</span> height <span class="op">!==</span> <span class="kw">null</span>) <span class="op">?</span> height : <span class="dv">100</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now the rewritten code is suitable for older JavaScript engines.</p>
<p>Usually, a developer runs the transpiler on their own computer, and then deploys the transpiled code to the server.</p>
<p>Speaking of names, <a href="https://babeljs.io">Babel</a> is one of the most prominent transpilers out there.</p>
<p>Modern project build systems, such as <a href="http://webpack.github.io/">webpack</a>, provide means to run transpiler automatically on every code change, so it‚Äôs very easy to integrate into development process.</p>
<h2 id="polyfills">Polyfills</h2>
<p>New language features may include not only syntax constructs and operators, but also built-in functions.</p>
<p>For example, <code>Math.trunc(n)</code> is a function that ‚Äúcuts off‚Äù the decimal part of a number, e.g <code>Math.trunc(1.23)</code> returns <code>1</code>.</p>
<p>In some (very outdated) JavaScript engines, there‚Äôs no <code>Math.trunc</code>, so such code will fail.</p>
<p>As we‚Äôre talking about new functions, not syntax changes, there‚Äôs no need to transpile anything here. We just need to declare the missing function.</p>
<p>A script that updates/adds new functions is called ‚Äúpolyfill‚Äù. It ‚Äúfills in‚Äù the gap and adds missing implementations.</p>
<p>For this particular case, the polyfill for <code>Math.trunc</code> is a script that implements it, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb355"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-1" title="1"><span class="cf">if</span> (<span class="op">!</span><span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">trunc</span>) <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// if no such function</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// implement it</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-3" title="3">  <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">trunc</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(number) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-4" title="4">    <span class="co">// Math.ceil and Math.floor exist even in ancient JavaScript engines</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-5" title="5">    <span class="co">// they are covered later in the tutorial</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-6" title="6">    <span class="cf">return</span> number <span class="op">&lt;</span> <span class="dv">0</span> <span class="op">?</span> <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">ceil</span>(number) : <span class="va">Math</span>.<span class="at">floor</span>(number)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-7" title="7">  <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb355-8" title="8"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>JavaScript is a highly dynamic language, scripts may add/modify any functions, even including built-in ones.</p>
<p>Two interesting libraries of polyfills are: - <a href="https://github.com/zloirock/core-js">core js</a> that supports a lot, allows to include only needed features. - <a href="http://polyfill.io">polyfill.io</a> service that provides a script with polyfills, depending on the features and user‚Äôs browser.</p>
<h2 id="summary-45">Summary</h2>
<p>In this chapter we‚Äôd like to motivate you to study modern and even ‚Äúbleeding-edge‚Äù language features, even if they aren‚Äôt yet well-supported by JavaScript engines.</p>
<p>Just don‚Äôt forget to use transpiler (if using modern syntax or operators) and polyfills (to add functions that may be missing). And they‚Äôll ensure that the code works.</p>
<p>For example, later when you‚Äôre familiar with JavaScript, you can setup a code build system based on <a href="http://webpack.github.io/">webpack</a> with <a href="https://github.com/babel/babel-loader">babel-loader</a> plugin.</p>
<p>Good resources that show the current state of support for various features: - <a href="https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/" class="uri">https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/</a> - for pure JavaScript. - <a href="https://caniuse.com/" class="uri">https://caniuse.com/</a> - for browser-related functions.</p>
<p>P.S. Google Chrome is usually the most up-to-date with language features, try it if a tutorial demo fails. Most tutorial demos work with any modern browser though.</p>
<h1 id="objects">Objects</h1>
<p>As we know from the chapter <a href="info:types" class="uri">info:types</a>, there are eight data types in JavaScript. Seven of them are called ‚Äúprimitive‚Äù, because their values contain only a single thing (be it a string or a number or whatever).</p>
<p>In contrast, objects are used to store keyed collections of various data and more complex entities. In JavaScript, objects penetrate almost every aspect of the language. So we must understand them first before going in-depth anywhere else.</p>
<p>An object can be created with figure brackets <code>{‚Ä¶}</code> with an optional list of <em>properties</em>. A property is a ‚Äúkey: value‚Äù pair, where <code>key</code> is a string (also called a ‚Äúproperty name‚Äù), and <code>value</code> can be anything.</p>
<p>We can imagine an object as a cabinet with signed files. Every piece of data is stored in its file by the key. It‚Äôs easy to find a file by its name or add/remove a file.</p>
<p><img src="object.svg" /></p>
<p>An empty object (‚Äúempty cabinet‚Äù) can be created using one of two syntaxes:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb356"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb356-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">Object</span>()<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// &quot;object constructor&quot; syntax</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb356-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{};</span>  <span class="co">// &quot;object literal&quot; syntax</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><img src="object-user-empty.svg" /></p>
<p>Usually, the figure brackets <code>{...}</code> are used. That declaration is called an <em>object literal</em>.</p>
<h2 id="literals-and-properties">Literals and properties</h2>
<p>We can immediately put some properties into <code>{...}</code> as ‚Äúkey: value‚Äù pairs:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb357"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb357-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span>     <span class="co">// an object</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb357-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span>  <span class="co">// by key &quot;name&quot; store value &quot;John&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb357-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span>        <span class="co">// by key &quot;age&quot; store value 30</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb357-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>A property has a key (also known as ‚Äúname‚Äù or ‚Äúidentifier‚Äù) before the colon <code>":"</code> and a value to the right of it.</p>
<p>In the <code>user</code> object, there are two properties:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The first property has the name <code>"name"</code> and the value <code>"John"</code>.</li>
<li>The second one has the name <code>"age"</code> and the value <code>30</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>The resulting <code>user</code> object can be imagined as a cabinet with two signed files labeled ‚Äúname‚Äù and ‚Äúage‚Äù.</p>
<figure>
<img src="object-user.svg" alt="user object" /><figcaption>user object</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>We can add, remove and read files from it any time.</p>
<p>Property values are accessible using the dot notation:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb358"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb358-1" title="1"><span class="co">// get property values of the object:</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb358-2" title="2"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">name</span> )<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// John</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb358-3" title="3"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">age</span> )<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// 30</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The value can be of any type. Let‚Äôs add a boolean one:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb359"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb359-1" title="1"><span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">isAdmin</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">true</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<figure>
<img src="object-user-isadmin.svg" alt="user object 2" /><figcaption>user object 2</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>To remove a property, we can use <code>delete</code> operator:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb360"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb360-1" title="1"><span class="kw">delete</span> <span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">age</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<figure>
<img src="object-user-delete.svg" alt="user object 3" /><figcaption>user object 3</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>We can also use multiword property names, but then they must be quoted:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb361"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb361-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb361-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb361-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb361-4" title="4">  <span class="st">&quot;likes birds&quot;</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span>  <span class="co">// multiword property name must be quoted</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb361-5" title="5"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><img src="object-user-props.svg" /></p>
<p>The last property in the list may end with a comma:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb362"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb362-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb362-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb362-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span><span class="op">*!*,*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb362-4" title="4"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>That is called a ‚Äútrailing‚Äù or ‚Äúhanging‚Äù comma. Makes it easier to add/remove/move around properties, because all lines become alike.</p>
<h2 id="square-brackets">Square brackets</h2>
<p>For multiword properties, the dot access doesn‚Äôt work:</p>
<p><code>js run // this would give a syntax error user.likes birds = true</code></p>
<p>JavaScript doesn‚Äôt understand that. It thinks that we address <code>user.likes</code>, and then gives a syntax error when comes across unexpected <code>birds</code>.</p>
<p>The dot requires the key to be a valid variable identifier. That implies: contains no spaces, doesn‚Äôt start with a digit and doesn‚Äôt include special characters (<code>$</code> and <code>_</code> are allowed).</p>
<p>There‚Äôs an alternative ‚Äúsquare bracket notation‚Äù that works with any string:</p>
<p>```js run let user = {};</p>
<p>// set user[‚Äúlikes birds‚Äù] = true;</p>
<p>// get alert(user[‚Äúlikes birds‚Äù]); // true</p>
<p>// delete delete user[‚Äúlikes birds‚Äù]; ```</p>
<p>Now everything is fine. Please note that the string inside the brackets is properly quoted (any type of quotes will do).</p>
<p>Square brackets also provide a way to obtain the property name as the result of any expression ‚Äì as opposed to a literal string ‚Äì like from a variable as follows:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb363"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb363-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> key <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;likes birds&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb363-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb363-3" title="3"><span class="co">// same as user[&quot;likes birds&quot;] = true;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb363-4" title="4">user[key] <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">true</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here, the variable <code>key</code> may be calculated at run-time or depend on the user input. And then we use it to access the property. That gives us a great deal of flexibility.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30 };</p>
<p>let key = prompt(‚ÄúWhat do you want to know about the user?‚Äù, ‚Äúname‚Äù);</p>
<p>// access by variable alert( user[key] ); // John (if enter ‚Äúname‚Äù) ```</p>
<p>The dot notation cannot be used in a similar way:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30 };</p>
<p>let key = ‚Äúname‚Äù; alert( user.key ) // undefined ```</p>
<h3 id="computed-properties">Computed properties</h3>
<p>We can use square brackets in an object literal, when creating an object. That‚Äôs called <em>computed properties</em>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let fruit = prompt(‚ÄúWhich fruit to buy?‚Äù, ‚Äúapple‚Äù);</p>
<p>let bag = { <em>!</em> [fruit]: 5, // the name of the property is taken from the variable fruit <em>/!</em> };</p>
<p>alert( bag.apple ); // 5 if fruit=‚Äúapple‚Äù ```</p>
<p>The meaning of a computed property is simple: <code>[fruit]</code> means that the property name should be taken from <code>fruit</code>.</p>
<p>So, if a visitor enters <code>"apple"</code>, <code>bag</code> will become <code>{apple: 5}</code>.</p>
<p>Essentially, that works the same as: ```js run let fruit = prompt(‚ÄúWhich fruit to buy?‚Äù, ‚Äúapple‚Äù); let bag = {};</p>
<p>// take property name from the fruit variable bag[fruit] = 5; ```</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But looks nicer.</p>
<p>We can use more complex expressions inside square brackets:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb364"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb364-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> fruit <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&#39;apple&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb364-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> bag <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb364-3" title="3">  [fruit <span class="op">+</span> <span class="st">&#39;Computers&#39;</span>]<span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">5</span> <span class="co">// bag.appleComputers = 5</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb364-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Square brackets are much more powerful than the dot notation. They allow any property names and variables. But they are also more cumbersome to write.</p>
<p>So most of the time, when property names are known and simple, the dot is used. And if we need something more complex, then we switch to square brackets.</p>
<h2 id="property-value-shorthand">Property value shorthand</h2>
<p>In real code we often use existing variables as values for property names.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run function makeUser(name, age) { return { name: name, age: age, // ‚Ä¶other properties }; }</p>
<p>let user = makeUser(‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, 30); alert(user.name); // John ```</p>
<p>In the example above, properties have the same names as variables. The use-case of making a property from a variable is so common, that there‚Äôs a special <em>property value shorthand</em> to make it shorter.</p>
<p>Instead of <code>name:name</code> we can just write <code>name</code>, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb365"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">makeUser</span>(name<span class="op">,</span> age) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-2" title="2"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-3" title="3">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-4" title="4">    name<span class="op">,</span> <span class="co">// same as name: name</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-5" title="5">    age<span class="op">,</span>  <span class="co">// same as age: age</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-6" title="6">    <span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-7" title="7">  <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-8" title="8"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb365-9" title="9"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>We can use both normal properties and shorthands in the same object:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb366"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb366-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb366-2" title="2">  name<span class="op">,</span>  <span class="co">// same as name:name</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb366-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb366-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="property-names-limitations">Property names limitations</h2>
<p>As we already know, a variable cannot have a name equal to one of language-reserved words like ‚Äúfor‚Äù, ‚Äúlet‚Äù, ‚Äúreturn‚Äù etc.</p>
<p>But for an object property, there‚Äôs no such restriction:</p>
<p>```js run // these properties are all right let obj = { for: 1, let: 2, return: 3 };</p>
<p>alert( obj.for + obj.let + obj.return ); // 6 ```</p>
<p>In short, there are no limitations on property names. They can be any strings or symbols (a special type for identifiers, to be covered later).</p>
<p>Other types are automatically converted to strings.</p>
<p>For instance, a number <code>0</code> becomes a string <code>"0"</code> when used as a property key:</p>
<p>```js run let obj = { 0: ‚Äútest‚Äù // same as ‚Äú0‚Äù: ‚Äútest‚Äù };</p>
<p>// both alerts access the same property (the number 0 is converted to string ‚Äú0‚Äù) alert( obj[‚Äú0‚Äù] ); // test alert( obj[0] ); // test (same property) ```</p>
<p>There‚Äôs a minor gotcha with a special property named <code>__proto__</code>. We can‚Äôt set it to a non-object value:</p>
<p><code>js run let obj = {}; obj.__proto__ = 5; // assign a number alert(obj.__proto__); // [object Object] - the value is an object, didn't work as intended</code></p>
<p>As we see from the code, the assignment to a primitive <code>5</code> is ignored.</p>
<p>We‚Äôll cover the special nature of <code>__proto__</code> in <a href="info:prototype-inheritance">subsequent chapters</a>, and suggest the <a href="info:prototype-methods">ways to fix</a> such behavior.</p>
<h2 id="property-existence-test-in-operator">Property existence test, ‚Äúin‚Äù operator</h2>
<p>A notable feature of objects in JavaScript, compared to many other languages, is that it‚Äôs possible to access any property. There will be no error if the property doesn‚Äôt exist!</p>
<p>Reading a non-existing property just returns <code>undefined</code>. So we can easily test whether the property exists:</p>
<p>```js run let user = {};</p>
<p>alert( user.noSuchProperty === undefined ); // true means ‚Äúno such property‚Äù ```</p>
<p>There‚Äôs also a special operator <code>"in"</code> for that.</p>
<p>The syntax is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb367"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb367-1" title="1"><span class="st">&quot;key&quot;</span> <span class="kw">in</span> object</a></code></pre></div>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30 };</p>
<p>alert( ‚Äúage‚Äù in user ); // true, user.age exists alert( ‚Äúblabla‚Äù in user ); // false, user.blabla doesn‚Äôt exist ```</p>
<p>Please note that on the left side of <code>in</code> there must be a <em>property name</em>. That‚Äôs usually a quoted string.</p>
<p>If we omit quotes, that means a variable, it should contain the actual name to be tested. For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { age: 30 };</p>
<p>let key = ‚Äúage‚Äù; alert( <em>!</em>key<em>/!</em> in user ); // true, property ‚Äúage‚Äù exists ```</p>
<p>Why does the <code>in</code> operator exist? Isn‚Äôt it enough to compare against <code>undefined</code>?</p>
<p>Well, most of the time the comparison with <code>undefined</code> works fine. But there‚Äôs a special case when it fails, but <code>"in"</code> works correctly.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs when an object property exists, but stores <code>undefined</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let obj = { test: undefined };</p>
<p>alert( obj.test ); // it‚Äôs undefined, so - no such property?</p>
<p>alert( ‚Äútest‚Äù in obj ); // true, the property does exist! ```</p>
<p>In the code above, the property <code>obj.test</code> technically exists. So the <code>in</code> operator works right.</p>
<p>Situations like this happen very rarely, because <code>undefined</code> should not be explicitly assigned. We mostly use <code>null</code> for ‚Äúunknown‚Äù or ‚Äúempty‚Äù values. So the <code>in</code> operator is an exotic guest in the code.</p>
<h2 id="the-for..in-loop">The ‚Äúfor..in‚Äù loop</h2>
<p>To walk over all keys of an object, there exists a special form of the loop: <code>for..in</code>. This is a completely different thing from the <code>for(;;)</code> construct that we studied before.</p>
<p>The syntax:</p>
