<div class="sourceCode" id="cb368"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb368-1" title="1"><span class="cf">for</span> (key <span class="kw">in</span> object) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb368-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// executes the body for each key among object properties</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb368-3" title="3"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>For instance, let‚Äôs output all properties of <code>user</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30, isAdmin: true };</p>
<p>for (let key in user) { // keys alert( key ); // name, age, isAdmin // values for the keys alert( user[key] ); // John, 30, true } ```</p>
<p>Note that all ‚Äúfor‚Äù constructs allow us to declare the looping variable inside the loop, like <code>let key</code> here.</p>
<p>Also, we could use another variable name here instead of <code>key</code>. For instance, <code>"for (let prop in obj)"</code> is also widely used.</p>
<h3 id="ordered-like-an-object">Ordered like an object</h3>
<p>Are objects ordered? In other words, if we loop over an object, do we get all properties in the same order they were added? Can we rely on this?</p>
<p>The short answer is: ‚Äúordered in a special fashion‚Äù: integer properties are sorted, others appear in creation order. The details follow.</p>
<p>As an example, let‚Äôs consider an object with the phone codes:</p>
<p>```js run let codes = { ‚Äú49‚Äù: ‚ÄúGermany‚Äù, ‚Äú41‚Äù: ‚ÄúSwitzerland‚Äù, ‚Äú44‚Äù: ‚ÄúGreat Britain‚Äù, // .., ‚Äú1‚Äù: ‚ÄúUSA‚Äù };</p>
<p><em>!</em> for (let code in codes) { alert(code); // 1, 41, 44, 49 } <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>The object may be used to suggest a list of options to the user. If we‚Äôre making a site mainly for German audience then we probably want <code>49</code> to be the first.</p>
<p>But if we run the code, we see a totally different picture:</p>
<ul>
<li>USA (1) goes first</li>
<li>then Switzerland (41) and so on.</li>
</ul>
<p>The phone codes go in the ascending sorted order, because they are integers. So we see <code>1, 41, 44, 49</code>.</p>
<p>````smart header=‚ÄúInteger properties? What‚Äôs that?‚Äù The ‚Äúinteger property‚Äù term here means a string that can be converted to-and-from an integer without a change.</p>
<p>So, ‚Äú49‚Äù is an integer property name, because when it‚Äôs transformed to an integer number and back, it‚Äôs still the same. But ‚Äú+49‚Äù and ‚Äú1.2‚Äù are not:</p>
<p><code>js run // Math.trunc is a built-in function that removes the decimal part alert( String(Math.trunc(Number("49"))) ); // "49", same, integer property alert( String(Math.trunc(Number("+49"))) ); // "49", not same "+49" ‚áí not integer property alert( String(Math.trunc(Number("1.2"))) ); // "1", not same "1.2" ‚áí not integer property</code> ````</p>
<p>‚Ä¶On the other hand, if the keys are non-integer, then they are listed in the creation order, for instance:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, surname: ‚ÄúSmith‚Äù }; user.age = 25; // add one more</p>
<p><em>!</em> // non-integer properties are listed in the creation order <em>/!</em> for (let prop in user) { alert( prop ); // name, surname, age } ```</p>
<p>So, to fix the issue with the phone codes, we can ‚Äúcheat‚Äù by making the codes non-integer. Adding a plus <code>"+"</code> sign before each code is enough.</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<p>```js run let codes = { ‚Äú+49‚Äù: ‚ÄúGermany‚Äù, ‚Äú+41‚Äù: ‚ÄúSwitzerland‚Äù, ‚Äú+44‚Äù: ‚ÄúGreat Britain‚Äù, // .., ‚Äú+1‚Äù: ‚ÄúUSA‚Äù };</p>
<p>for (let code in codes) { alert( +code ); // 49, 41, 44, 1 } ```</p>
<p>Now it works as intended.</p>
<h2 id="summary-46">Summary</h2>
<p>Objects are associative arrays with several special features.</p>
<p>They store properties (key-value pairs), where: - Property keys must be strings or symbols (usually strings). - Values can be of any type.</p>
<p>To access a property, we can use: - The dot notation: <code>obj.property</code>. - Square brackets notation <code>obj["property"]</code>. Square brackets allow to take the key from a variable, like <code>obj[varWithKey]</code>.</p>
<p>Additional operators: - To delete a property: <code>delete obj.prop</code>. - To check if a property with the given key exists: <code>"key" in obj</code>. - To iterate over an object: <code>for (let key in obj)</code> loop.</p>
<p>What we‚Äôve studied in this chapter is called a ‚Äúplain object‚Äù, or just <code>Object</code>.</p>
<p>There are many other kinds of objects in JavaScript:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Array</code> to store ordered data collections,</li>
<li><code>Date</code> to store the information about the date and time,</li>
<li><code>Error</code> to store the information about an error.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶And so on.</li>
</ul>
<p>They have their special features that we‚Äôll study later. Sometimes people say something like ‚ÄúArray type‚Äù or ‚ÄúDate type‚Äù, but formally they are not types of their own, but belong to a single ‚Äúobject‚Äù data type. And they extend it in various ways.</p>
<p>Objects in JavaScript are very powerful. Here we‚Äôve just scratched the surface of a topic that is really huge. We‚Äôll be closely working with objects and learning more about them in further parts of the tutorial. # Code editors</p>
<p>A code editor is the place where programmers spend most of their time.</p>
<p>There are two main types of code editors: IDEs and lightweight editors. Many people use one tool of each type.</p>
<h2 id="ide">IDE</h2>
<p>The term <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_development_environment">IDE</a> (Integrated Development Environment) refers to a powerful editor with many features that usually operates on a ‚Äúwhole project.‚Äù As the name suggests, it‚Äôs not just an editor, but a full-scale ‚Äúdevelopment environment.‚Äù</p>
<p>An IDE loads the project (which can be many files), allows navigation between files, provides autocompletion based on the whole project (not just the open file), and integrates with a version management system (like <a href="https://git-scm.com/">git</a>), a testing environment, and other ‚Äúproject-level‚Äù stuff.</p>
<p>If you haven‚Äôt selected an IDE yet, consider the following options:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://code.visualstudio.com/">Visual Studio Code</a> (cross-platform, free).</li>
<li><a href="http://www.jetbrains.com/webstorm/">WebStorm</a> (cross-platform, paid).</li>
</ul>
<p>For Windows, there‚Äôs also ‚ÄúVisual Studio‚Äù, not to be confused with ‚ÄúVisual Studio Code‚Äù. ‚ÄúVisual Studio‚Äù is a paid and mighty Windows-only editor, well-suited for the .NET platform. It‚Äôs also good at JavaScript. There‚Äôs also a free version <a href="https://www.visualstudio.com/vs/community/">Visual Studio Community</a>.</p>
<p>Many IDEs are paid, but have a trial period. Their cost is usually negligible compared to a qualified developer‚Äôs salary, so just choose the best one for you.</p>
<h2 id="lightweight-editors">Lightweight editors</h2>
<p>‚ÄúLightweight editors‚Äù are not as powerful as IDEs, but they‚Äôre fast, elegant and simple.</p>
<p>They are mainly used to open and edit a file instantly.</p>
<p>The main difference between a ‚Äúlightweight editor‚Äù and an ‚ÄúIDE‚Äù is that an IDE works on a project-level, so it loads much more data on start, analyzes the project structure if needed and so on. A lightweight editor is much faster if we need only one file.</p>
<p>In practice, lightweight editors may have a lot of plugins including directory-level syntax analyzers and autocompleters, so there‚Äôs no strict border between a lightweight editor and an IDE.</p>
<p>The following options deserve your attention:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://atom.io/">Atom</a> (cross-platform, free).</li>
<li><a href="https://code.visualstudio.com/">Visual Studio Code</a> (cross-platform, free).</li>
<li><a href="http://www.sublimetext.com">Sublime Text</a> (cross-platform, shareware).</li>
<li><a href="https://notepad-plus-plus.org/">Notepad++</a> (Windows, free).</li>
<li><a href="http://www.vim.org/">Vim</a> and <a href="https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/">Emacs</a> are also cool if you know how to use them.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="lets-not-argue">Let‚Äôs not argue</h2>
<p>The editors in the lists above are those that either I or my friends whom I consider good developers have been using for a long time and are happy with.</p>
<p>There are other great editors in our big world. Please choose the one you like the most.</p>
<p>The choice of an editor, like any other tool, is individual and depends on your projects, habits, and personal preferences. # Object references and copying</p>
<p>One of the fundamental differences of objects versus primitives is that objects are stored and copied ‚Äúby reference‚Äù, whereas primitive values: strings, numbers, booleans, etc ‚Äì are always copied ‚Äúas a whole value‚Äù.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs easy to understand if we look a bit under the hood of what happens when we copy a value.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs start with a primitive, such as a string.</p>
<p>Here we put a copy of <code>message</code> into <code>phrase</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb369"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb369-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> message <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;Hello!&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb369-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> phrase <span class="op">=</span> message<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>As a result we have two independent variables, each one storing the string <code>"Hello!"</code>.</p>
<p><img src="variable-copy-value.svg" /></p>
<p>Quite an obvious result, right?</p>
<p>Objects are not like that.</p>
<p><strong>A variable assigned to an object stores not the object itself, but its ‚Äúaddress in memory‚Äù ‚Äì in other words ‚Äúa reference‚Äù to it.</strong></p>
<p>Let‚Äôs look at an example of such a variable:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb370"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb370-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb370-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb370-3" title="3"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>And here‚Äôs how it‚Äôs actually stored in memory:</p>
<p><img src="variable-contains-reference.svg" /></p>
<p>The object is stored somewhere in memory (at the right of the picture), while the <code>user</code> variable (at the left) has a ‚Äúreference‚Äù to it.</p>
<p>We may think of an object variable, such as <code>user</code>, as like a sheet of paper with the address of the object on it.</p>
<p>When we perform actions with the object, e.g.¬†take a property <code>user.name</code>, the JavaScript engine looks at what‚Äôs at that address and performs the operation on the actual object.</p>
<p>Now here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important.</p>
<p><strong>When an object variable is copied, the reference is copied, but the object itself is not duplicated.</strong></p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js no-beautify let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù };</p>
<p>let admin = user; // copy the reference ```</p>
<p>Now we have two variables, each storing a reference to the same object:</p>
<p><img src="variable-copy-reference.svg" /></p>
<p>As you can see, there‚Äôs still one object, but now with two variables that reference it.</p>
<p>We can use either variable to access the object and modify its contents:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄòJohn‚Äô };</p>
<p>let admin = user;</p>
<p><em>!</em> admin.name = ‚ÄòPete‚Äô; // changed by the ‚Äúadmin‚Äù reference <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert(<em>!</em>user.name<em>/!</em>); // ‚ÄòPete‚Äô, changes are seen from the ‚Äúuser‚Äù reference ```</p>
<p>It‚Äôs as if we had a cabinet with two keys and used one of them (<code>admin</code>) to get into it and make changes. Then, if we later use another key (<code>user</code>), we are still opening the same cabinet and can access the changed contents.</p>
<h2 id="comparison-by-reference">Comparison by reference</h2>
<p>Two objects are equal only if they are the same object.</p>
<p>For instance, here <code>a</code> and <code>b</code> reference the same object, thus they are equal:</p>
<p>```js run let a = {}; let b = a; // copy the reference</p>
<p>alert( a == b ); // true, both variables reference the same object alert( a === b ); // true ```</p>
<p>And here two independent objects are not equal, even though they look alike (both are empty):</p>
<p>```js run let a = {}; let b = {}; // two independent objects</p>
<p>alert( a == b ); // false ```</p>
<p>For comparisons like <code>obj1 &gt; obj2</code> or for a comparison against a primitive <code>obj == 5</code>, objects are converted to primitives. We‚Äôll study how object conversions work very soon, but to tell the truth, such comparisons are needed very rarely ‚Äì usually they appear as a result of a programming mistake.</p>
<h2 id="cloning-and-merging-object.assign-cloning-and-merging-object-assign">Cloning and merging, Object.assign [#cloning-and-merging-object-assign]</h2>
<p>So, copying an object variable creates one more reference to the same object.</p>
<p>But what if we need to duplicate an object? Create an independent copy, a clone?</p>
<p>That‚Äôs also doable, but a little bit more difficult, because there‚Äôs no built-in method for that in JavaScript. But there is rarely a need ‚Äì copying by reference is good most of the time.</p>
<p>But if we really want that, then we need to create a new object and replicate the structure of the existing one by iterating over its properties and copying them on the primitive level.</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30 };</p>
<p><em>!</em> let clone = {}; // the new empty object</p>
<p>// let‚Äôs copy all user properties into it for (let key in user) { clone[key] = user[key]; } <em>/!</em></p>
<p>// now clone is a fully independent object with the same content clone.name = ‚ÄúPete‚Äù; // changed the data in it</p>
<p>alert( user.name ); // still John in the original object ```</p>
<p>Also we can use the method <a href="mdn:js/Object/assign">Object.assign</a> for that.</p>
<p>The syntax is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb371"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb371-1" title="1"><span class="va">Object</span>.<span class="at">assign</span>(dest<span class="op">,</span> [src1<span class="op">,</span> src2<span class="op">,</span> <span class="va">src3</span>...])</a></code></pre></div>
<ul>
<li>The first argument <code>dest</code> is a target object.</li>
<li>Further arguments <code>src1, ..., srcN</code> (can be as many as needed) are source objects.</li>
<li>It copies the properties of all source objects <code>src1, ..., srcN</code> into the target <code>dest</code>. In other words, properties of all arguments starting from the second are copied into the first object.</li>
<li>The call returns <code>dest</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>For instance, we can use it to merge several objects into one:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb372"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span> <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> permissions1 <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="dt">canView</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span> <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-4" title="4"><span class="kw">let</span> permissions2 <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="dt">canEdit</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">true</span> <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-6" title="6"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-7" title="7"><span class="co">// copies all properties from permissions1 and permissions2 into user</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-8" title="8"><span class="va">Object</span>.<span class="at">assign</span>(user<span class="op">,</span> permissions1<span class="op">,</span> permissions2)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-9" title="9"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb372-11" title="11"><span class="ss">// now user = { name: &quot;John&quot;, canView: true, canEdit: true }</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>If the copied property name already exists, it gets overwritten:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù };</p>
<p>Object.assign(user, { name: ‚ÄúPete‚Äù });</p>
<p>alert(user.name); // now user = { name: ‚ÄúPete‚Äù } ```</p>
<p>We also can use <code>Object.assign</code> to replace <code>for..in</code> loop for simple cloning:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb373"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-6" title="6"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-7" title="7"><span class="kw">let</span> clone <span class="op">=</span> <span class="va">Object</span>.<span class="at">assign</span>(<span class="op">{},</span> user)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb373-8" title="8"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>It copies all properties of <code>user</code> into the empty object and returns it.</p>
<p>There are also other methods of cloning an object, e.g.¬†using the <a href="info:rest-parameters-spread">spread syntax</a> <code>clone = {...user}</code>, covered later in the tutorial.</p>
<h2 id="nested-cloning">Nested cloning</h2>
<p>Until now we assumed that all properties of <code>user</code> are primitive. But properties can be references to other objects. What to do with them?</p>
<p>Like this: ```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, sizes: { height: 182, width: 50 } };</p>
<p>alert( user.sizes.height ); // 182 ```</p>
<p>Now it‚Äôs not enough to copy <code>clone.sizes = user.sizes</code>, because the <code>user.sizes</code> is an object, it will be copied by reference. So <code>clone</code> and <code>user</code> will share the same sizes:</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, sizes: { height: 182, width: 50 } };</p>
<p>let clone = Object.assign({}, user);</p>
<p>alert( user.sizes === clone.sizes ); // true, same object</p>
<p>// user and clone share sizes user.sizes.width++; // change a property from one place alert(clone.sizes.width); // 51, see the result from the other one ```</p>
<p>To fix that, we should use a cloning loop that examines each value of <code>user[key]</code> and, if it‚Äôs an object, then replicate its structure as well. That is called a ‚Äúdeep cloning‚Äù.</p>
<p>We can use recursion to implement it. Or, to not reinvent the wheel, take an existing implementation, for instance <a href="https://lodash.com/docs#cloneDeep">_.cloneDeep(obj)</a> from the JavaScript library <a href="https://lodash.com">lodash</a>.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="Const objects can be modified" An important side effect of storing objects as references is that an object declared as</code>const` <em>can</em> be modified.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run const user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù };</p>
<p><em>!</em> user.name = ‚ÄúPete‚Äù; // (<em>) </em>/!*</p>
<p>alert(user.name); // Pete</p>
<pre><code>
It might seem that the line `(*)` would cause an error, but it does not. The value of `user` is constant, it must always reference the same object, but properties of that object are free to change.

In other words, the `const user` gives an error only if we try to set `user=...` as a whole.

That said, if we really need to make constant object properties, it&#39;s also possible, but using totally different methods. We&#39;ll mention that in the chapter &lt;info:property-descriptors&gt;.</code></pre>
<h2 id="summary-47">Summary</h2>
<p>Objects are assigned and copied by reference. In other words, a variable stores not the ‚Äúobject value‚Äù, but a ‚Äúreference‚Äù (address in memory) for the value. So copying such a variable or passing it as a function argument copies that reference, not the object itself.</p>
<p>All operations via copied references (like adding/removing properties) are performed on the same single object.</p>
<p>To make a ‚Äúreal copy‚Äù (a clone) we can use <code>Object.assign</code> for the so-called ‚Äúshallow copy‚Äù (nested objects are copied by reference) or a ‚Äúdeep cloning‚Äù function, such as <a href="https://lodash.com/docs#cloneDeep">_.cloneDeep(obj)</a>. # Garbage collection</p>
<p>Memory management in JavaScript is performed automatically and invisibly to us. We create primitives, objects, functions‚Ä¶ All that takes memory.</p>
<p>What happens when something is not needed any more? How does the JavaScript engine discover it and clean it up?</p>
<h2 id="reachability">Reachability</h2>
<p>The main concept of memory management in JavaScript is <em>reachability</em>.</p>
<p>Simply put, ‚Äúreachable‚Äù values are those that are accessible or usable somehow. They are guaranteed to be stored in memory.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>There‚Äôs a base set of inherently reachable values, that cannot be deleted for obvious reasons.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<ul>
<li>The currently executing function, its local variables and parameters.</li>
<li>Other functions on the current chain of nested calls, their local variables and parameters.</li>
<li>Global variables.</li>
<li>(there are some other, internal ones as well)</li>
</ul>
<p>These values are called <em>roots</em>.</p></li>
<li><p>Any other value is considered reachable if it‚Äôs reachable from a root by a reference or by a chain of references.</p>
<p>For instance, if there‚Äôs an object in a global variable, and that object has a property referencing another object, <em>that</em> object is considered reachable. And those that it references are also reachable. Detailed examples to follow.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>There‚Äôs a background process in the JavaScript engine that is called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garbage_collection_(computer_science)">garbage collector</a>. It monitors all objects and removes those that have become unreachable.</p>
<h2 id="a-simple-example-1">A simple example</h2>
<p>Here‚Äôs the simplest example:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb375"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb375-1" title="1"><span class="co">// user has a reference to the object</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb375-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb375-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb375-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><img src="memory-user-john.svg" /></p>
<p>Here the arrow depicts an object reference. The global variable <code>"user"</code> references the object <code>{name: "John"}</code> (we‚Äôll call it John for brevity). The <code>"name"</code> property of John stores a primitive, so it‚Äôs painted inside the object.</p>
<p>If the value of <code>user</code> is overwritten, the reference is lost:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb376"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb376-1" title="1">user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">null</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><img src="memory-user-john-lost.svg" /></p>
<p>Now John becomes unreachable. There‚Äôs no way to access it, no references to it. Garbage collector will junk the data and free the memory.</p>
<h2 id="two-references">Two references</h2>
<p>Now let‚Äôs imagine we copied the reference from <code>user</code> to <code>admin</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb377"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-1" title="1"><span class="co">// user has a reference to the object</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-6" title="6"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-7" title="7"><span class="kw">let</span> admin <span class="op">=</span> user<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb377-8" title="8"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><img src="memory-user-john-admin.svg" /></p>
<p>Now if we do the same:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb378"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb378-1" title="1">user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">null</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶Then the object is still reachable via <code>admin</code> global variable, so it‚Äôs in memory. If we overwrite <code>admin</code> too, then it can be removed.</p>
<h2 id="interlinked-objects">Interlinked objects</h2>
<p>Now a more complex example. The family:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb379"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">marry</span>(man<span class="op">,</span> woman) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-2" title="2">  <span class="va">woman</span>.<span class="at">husband</span> <span class="op">=</span> man<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-3" title="3">  <span class="va">man</span>.<span class="at">wife</span> <span class="op">=</span> woman<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-5" title="5">  <span class="cf">return</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-6" title="6">    <span class="dt">father</span><span class="op">:</span> man<span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-7" title="7">    <span class="dt">mother</span><span class="op">:</span> woman</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-8" title="8">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-9" title="9"><span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-11" title="11"><span class="kw">let</span> family <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">marry</span>(<span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-12" title="12">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-13" title="13"><span class="op">},</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-14" title="14">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;Ann&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb379-15" title="15"><span class="op">}</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Function <code>marry</code> ‚Äúmarries‚Äù two objects by giving them references to each other and returns a new object that contains them both.</p>
<p>The resulting memory structure:</p>
<p><img src="family.svg" /></p>
<p>As of now, all objects are reachable.</p>
<p>Now let‚Äôs remove two references:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb380"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb380-1" title="1"><span class="kw">delete</span> <span class="va">family</span>.<span class="at">father</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb380-2" title="2"><span class="kw">delete</span> <span class="va">family</span>.<span class="va">mother</span>.<span class="at">husband</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p><img src="family-delete-refs.svg" /></p>
<p>It‚Äôs not enough to delete only one of these two references, because all objects would still be reachable.</p>
<p>But if we delete both, then we can see that John has no incoming reference any more:</p>
<p><img src="family-no-father.svg" /></p>
<p>Outgoing references do not matter. Only incoming ones can make an object reachable. So, John is now unreachable and will be removed from the memory with all its data that also became unaccessible.</p>
<p>After garbage collection:</p>
<p><img src="family-no-father-2.svg" /></p>
<h2 id="unreachable-island">Unreachable island</h2>
<p>It is possible that the whole island of interlinked objects becomes unreachable and is removed from the memory.</p>
<p>The source object is the same as above. Then:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb381"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb381-1" title="1">family <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">null</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The in-memory picture becomes:</p>
<p><img src="family-no-family.svg" /></p>
<p>This example demonstrates how important the concept of reachability is.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs obvious that John and Ann are still linked, both have incoming references. But that‚Äôs not enough.</p>
<p>The former <code>"family"</code> object has been unlinked from the root, there‚Äôs no reference to it any more, so the whole island becomes unreachable and will be removed.</p>
<h2 id="internal-algorithms">Internal algorithms</h2>
<p>The basic garbage collection algorithm is called ‚Äúmark-and-sweep‚Äù.</p>
<p>The following ‚Äúgarbage collection‚Äù steps are regularly performed:</p>
<ul>
<li>The garbage collector takes roots and ‚Äúmarks‚Äù (remembers) them.</li>
<li>Then it visits and ‚Äúmarks‚Äù all references from them.</li>
<li>Then it visits marked objects and marks <em>their</em> references. All visited objects are remembered, so as not to visit the same object twice in the future.</li>
<li>‚Ä¶And so on until every reachable (from the roots) references are visited.</li>
<li>All objects except marked ones are removed.</li>
</ul>
<p>For instance, let our object structure look like this:</p>
<p><img src="garbage-collection-1.svg" /></p>
<p>We can clearly see an ‚Äúunreachable island‚Äù to the right side. Now let‚Äôs see how ‚Äúmark-and-sweep‚Äù garbage collector deals with it.</p>
<p>The first step marks the roots:</p>
<p><img src="garbage-collection-2.svg" /></p>
<p>Then their references are marked:</p>
<p><img src="garbage-collection-3.svg" /></p>
<p>‚Ä¶And their references, while possible:</p>
<p><img src="garbage-collection-4.svg" /></p>
<p>Now the objects that could not be visited in the process are considered unreachable and will be removed:</p>
<p><img src="garbage-collection-5.svg" /></p>
<p>We can also imagine the process as spilling a huge bucket of paint from the roots, that flows through all references and marks all reachable objects. The unmarked ones are then removed.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs the concept of how garbage collection works. JavaScript engines apply many optimizations to make it run faster and not affect the execution.</p>
<p>Some of the optimizations:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Generational collection</strong> ‚Äì objects are split into two sets: ‚Äúnew ones‚Äù and ‚Äúold ones‚Äù. Many objects appear, do their job and die fast, they can be cleaned up aggressively. Those that survive for long enough, become ‚Äúold‚Äù and are examined less often.</li>
<li><strong>Incremental collection</strong> ‚Äì if there are many objects, and we try to walk and mark the whole object set at once, it may take some time and introduce visible delays in the execution. So the engine tries to split the garbage collection into pieces. Then the pieces are executed one by one, separately. That requires some extra bookkeeping between them to track changes, but we have many tiny delays instead of a big one.</li>
<li><strong>Idle-time collection</strong> ‚Äì the garbage collector tries to run only while the CPU is idle, to reduce the possible effect on the execution.</li>
</ul>
<p>There exist other optimizations and flavours of garbage collection algorithms. As much as I‚Äôd like to describe them here, I have to hold off, because different engines implement different tweaks and techniques. And, what‚Äôs even more important, things change as engines develop, so studying deeper ‚Äúin advance‚Äù, without a real need is probably not worth that. Unless, of course, it is a matter of pure interest, then there will be some links for you below.</p>
<h2 id="summary-48">Summary</h2>
<p>The main things to know:</p>
<ul>
<li>Garbage collection is performed automatically. We cannot force or prevent it.</li>
<li>Objects are retained in memory while they are reachable.</li>
<li>Being referenced is not the same as being reachable (from a root): a pack of interlinked objects can become unreachable as a whole.</li>
</ul>
<p>Modern engines implement advanced algorithms of garbage collection.</p>
<p>A general book ‚ÄúThe Garbage Collection Handbook: The Art of Automatic Memory Management‚Äù (R. Jones et al) covers some of them.</p>
<p>If you are familiar with low-level programming, the more detailed information about V8 garbage collector is in the article <a href="http://jayconrod.com/posts/55/a-tour-of-v8-garbage-collection">A tour of V8: Garbage Collection</a>.</p>
<p><a href="https://v8.dev/">V8 blog</a> also publishes articles about changes in memory management from time to time. Naturally, to learn the garbage collection, you‚Äôd better prepare by learning about V8 internals in general and read the blog of <a href="http://mrale.ph">Vyacheslav Egorov</a> who worked as one of V8 engineers. I‚Äôm saying: ‚ÄúV8‚Äù, because it is best covered with articles in the internet. For other engines, many approaches are similar, but garbage collection differs in many aspects.</p>
<p>In-depth knowledge of engines is good when you need low-level optimizations. It would be wise to plan that as the next step after you‚Äôre familiar with the language.<br />
# Object methods, ‚Äúthis‚Äù</p>
<p>Objects are usually created to represent entities of the real world, like users, orders and so on:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb382"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb382-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb382-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb382-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb382-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>And, in the real world, a user can <em>act</em>: select something from the shopping cart, login, logout etc.</p>
<p>Actions are represented in JavaScript by functions in properties.</p>
<h2 id="method-examples">Method examples</h2>
<p>For a start, let‚Äôs teach the <code>user</code> to say hello:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30 };</p>
<p><em>!</em> user.sayHi = function() { alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù); }; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>user.sayHi(); // Hello! ```</p>
<p>Here we‚Äôve just used a Function Expression to create a function and assign it to the property <code>user.sayHi</code> of the object.</p>
<p>Then we can call it as <code>user.sayHi()</code>. The user can now speak!</p>
<p>A function that is a property of an object is called its <em>method</em>.</p>
<p>So, here we‚Äôve got a method <code>sayHi</code> of the object <code>user</code>.</p>
<p>Of course, we could use a pre-declared function as a method, like this:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { // ‚Ä¶ };</p>
<p><em>!</em> // first, declare function sayHi() { alert(‚ÄúHello!‚Äù); };</p>
<p>// then add as a method user.sayHi = sayHi; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>user.sayHi(); // Hello! ```</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúObject-oriented programming‚Äù When we write our code using objects to represent entities, that‚Äôs called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming">object-oriented programming</a>, in short: ‚ÄúOOP‚Äù.</p>
<p>OOP is a big thing, an interesting science of its own. How to choose the right entities? How to organize the interaction between them? That‚Äôs architecture, and there are great books on that topic, like ‚ÄúDesign Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software‚Äù by E. Gamma, R. Helm, R. Johnson, J. Vissides or ‚ÄúObject-Oriented Analysis and Design with Applications‚Äù by G. Booch, and more. ``` ### Method shorthand</p>
<p>There exists a shorter syntax for methods in an object literal:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb383"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-1" title="1"><span class="co">// these objects do the same</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-3" title="3">user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-4" title="4">  <span class="dt">sayHi</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-5" title="5">    <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="st">&quot;Hello&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-6" title="6">  <span class="op">}</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-7" title="7"><span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-8" title="8"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-9" title="9"><span class="co">// method shorthand looks better, right?</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-10" title="10">user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-11" title="11"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-12" title="12">  <span class="at">sayHi</span>() <span class="op">{</span> <span class="co">// same as &quot;sayHi: function(){...}&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-13" title="13"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-14" title="14"><span class="ss">    alert</span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">&quot;Hello&quot;</span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-15" title="15"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb383-16" title="16"><span class="ss">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>As demonstrated, we can omit <code>"function"</code> and just write <code>sayHi()</code>.</p>
<p>To tell the truth, the notations are not fully identical. There are subtle differences related to object inheritance (to be covered later), but for now they do not matter. In almost all cases the shorter syntax is preferred.</p>
<h2 id="this-in-methods">‚Äúthis‚Äù in methods</h2>
<p>It‚Äôs common that an object method needs to access the information stored in the object to do its job.</p>
<p>For instance, the code inside <code>user.sayHi()</code> may need the name of the <code>user</code>.</p>
<p><strong>To access the object, a method can use the <code>this</code> keyword.</strong></p>
<p>The value of <code>this</code> is the object ‚Äúbefore dot‚Äù, the one used to call the method.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30,</p>
<p>sayHi() { <em>!</em> // ‚Äúthis‚Äù is the ‚Äúcurrent object‚Äù alert(this.name); <em>/!</em> }</p>
<p>};</p>
<p>user.sayHi(); // John ```</p>
<p>Here during the execution of <code>user.sayHi()</code>, the value of <code>this</code> will be <code>user</code>.</p>
<p>Technically, it‚Äôs also possible to access the object without <code>this</code>, by referencing it via the outer variable:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb384"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">age</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">30</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-5" title="5">  <span class="at">sayHi</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-6" title="6"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-7" title="7">    <span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">name</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// &quot;user&quot; instead of &quot;this&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-8" title="8"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-9" title="9"><span class="ss">  }</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-10" title="10"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb384-11" title="11"><span class="ss">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>‚Ä¶But such code is unreliable. If we decide to copy <code>user</code> to another variable, e.g.¬†<code>admin = user</code> and overwrite <code>user</code> with something else, then it will access the wrong object.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs demonstrated below:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30,</p>
<p>sayHi() { <em>!</em> alert( user.name ); // leads to an error <em>/!</em> }</p>
<p>};</p>
<p>let admin = user; user = null; // overwrite to make things obvious</p>
<p><em>!</em> admin.sayHi(); // TypeError: Cannot read property ‚Äòname‚Äô of null <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>If we used <code>this.name</code> instead of <code>user.name</code> inside the <code>alert</code>, then the code would work.</p>
<h2 id="this-is-not-bound">‚Äúthis‚Äù is not bound</h2>
<p>In JavaScript, keyword <code>this</code> behaves unlike most other programming languages. It can be used in any function, even if it‚Äôs not a method of an object.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs no syntax error in the following example:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb385"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb385-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">sayHi</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb385-2" title="2">  <span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="op">*!*</span><span class="kw">this</span><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">.name </span><span class="sc">)</span><span class="ss">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb385-3" title="3"><span class="ss">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The value of <code>this</code> is evaluated during the run-time, depending on the context.</p>
<p>For instance, here the same function is assigned to two different objects and has different ‚Äúthis‚Äù in the calls:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù }; let admin = { name: ‚ÄúAdmin‚Äù };</p>
<p>function sayHi() { alert( this.name ); }</p>
<p><em>!</em> // use the same function in two objects user.f = sayHi; admin.f = sayHi; <em>/!</em></p>
<p>// these calls have different this // ‚Äúthis‚Äù inside the function is the object ‚Äúbefore the dot‚Äù user.f(); // John (this == user) admin.f(); // Admin (this == admin)</p>
<p>admin<a href="">‚Äòf‚Äô</a>; // Admin (dot or square brackets access the method ‚Äì doesn‚Äôt matter) ```</p>
<p>The rule is simple: if <code>obj.f()</code> is called, then <code>this</code> is <code>obj</code> during the call of <code>f</code>. So it‚Äôs either <code>user</code> or <code>admin</code> in the example above.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="Calling without an object:</code>this == undefined`" We can even call the function without an object at all:</p>
<p>```js run function sayHi() { alert(this); }</p>
<p>sayHi(); // undefined</p>
<pre><code>
In this case `this` is `undefined` in strict mode. If we try to access `this.name`, there will be an error.

In non-strict mode the value of `this` in such case will be the *global object* (`window` in a browser, we&#39;ll get to it later in the chapter [](info:global-object)). This is a historical behavior that `&quot;use strict&quot;` fixes.

Usually such call is a programming error. If there&#39;s `this` inside a function, it expects to be called in an object context.</code></pre>
<p>``<code>smart header="The consequences of unbound</code>this<code>" If you come from another programming language, then you are probably used to the idea of a "bound</code>this<code>", where methods defined in an object always have</code>this` referencing that object.</p>
<p>In JavaScript <code>this</code> is ‚Äúfree‚Äù, its value is evaluated at call-time and does not depend on where the method was declared, but rather on what object is ‚Äúbefore the dot‚Äù.</p>
<p>The concept of run-time evaluated <code>this</code> has both pluses and minuses. On the one hand, a function can be reused for different objects. On the other hand, the greater flexibility creates more possibilities for mistakes.</p>
<p>Here our position is not to judge whether this language design decision is good or bad. We‚Äôll understand how to work with it, how to get benefits and avoid problems. ```</p>
<h2 id="arrow-functions-have-no-this">Arrow functions have no ‚Äúthis‚Äù</h2>
<p>Arrow functions are special: they don‚Äôt have their ‚Äúown‚Äù <code>this</code>. If we reference <code>this</code> from such a function, it‚Äôs taken from the outer ‚Äúnormal‚Äù function.</p>
<p>For instance, here <code>arrow()</code> uses <code>this</code> from the outer <code>user.sayHi()</code> method:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { firstName: ‚ÄúIlya‚Äù, sayHi() { let arrow = () =&gt; alert(this.firstName); arrow(); } };</p>
<p>user.sayHi(); // Ilya ```</p>
<p>That‚Äôs a special feature of arrow functions, it‚Äôs useful when we actually do not want to have a separate <code>this</code>, but rather to take it from the outer context. Later in the chapter <a href="info:arrow-functions" class="uri">info:arrow-functions</a> we‚Äôll go more deeply into arrow functions.</p>
<h2 id="summary-49">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>Functions that are stored in object properties are called ‚Äúmethods‚Äù.</li>
<li>Methods allow objects to ‚Äúact‚Äù like <code>object.doSomething()</code>.</li>
<li>Methods can reference the object as <code>this</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>The value of <code>this</code> is defined at run-time. - When a function is declared, it may use <code>this</code>, but that <code>this</code> has no value until the function is called. - A function can be copied between objects. - When a function is called in the ‚Äúmethod‚Äù syntax: <code>object.method()</code>, the value of <code>this</code> during the call is <code>object</code>.</p>
<p>Please note that arrow functions are special: they have no <code>this</code>. When <code>this</code> is accessed inside an arrow function, it is taken from outside. # Constructor, operator ‚Äúnew‚Äù</p>
<p>The regular <code>{...}</code> syntax allows to create one object. But often we need to create many similar objects, like multiple users or menu items and so on.</p>
<p>That can be done using constructor functions and the <code>"new"</code> operator.</p>
<h2 id="constructor-function">Constructor function</h2>
<p>Constructor functions technically are regular functions. There are two conventions though:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>They are named with capital letter first.</li>
<li>They should be executed only with <code>"new"</code> operator.</li>
</ol>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run function User(name) { this.name = name; this.isAdmin = false; }</p>
<p><em>!</em> let user = new User(‚ÄúJack‚Äù); <em>/!</em></p>
<p>alert(user.name); // Jack alert(user.isAdmin); // false ```</p>
<p>When a function is executed with <code>new</code>, it does the following steps:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>A new empty object is created and assigned to <code>this</code>.</li>
<li>The function body executes. Usually it modifies <code>this</code>, adds new properties to it.</li>
<li>The value of <code>this</code> is returned.</li>
</ol>
<p>In other words, <code>new User(...)</code> does something like:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb387"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-1" title="1"><span class="kw">function</span> <span class="at">User</span>(name) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-2" title="2"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// this = {};  (implicitly)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-4" title="4"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-6" title="6"><span class="ss">  // add properties to this</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-7" title="7"><span class="ss">  this.name = name;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-8" title="8"><span class="ss">  this.isAdmin = false;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-9" title="9"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-10" title="10"><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-11" title="11"><span class="ss">  // return this;  </span><span class="sc">(</span><span class="ss">implicitly</span><span class="sc">)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-12" title="12"><span class="sc">*</span><span class="ss">/</span><span class="op">!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb387-13" title="13"><span class="op">}</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>So <code>let user = new User("Jack")</code> gives the same result as:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb388"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb388-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb388-2" title="2">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;Jack&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb388-3" title="3">  <span class="dt">isAdmin</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="kw">false</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb388-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now if we want to create other users, we can call <code>new User("Ann")</code>, <code>new User("Alice")</code> and so on. Much shorter than using literals every time, and also easy to read.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs the main purpose of constructors ‚Äì to implement reusable object creation code.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs note once again ‚Äì technically, any function can be used as a constructor. That is: any function can be run with <code>new</code>, and it will execute the algorithm above. The ‚Äúcapital letter first‚Äù is a common agreement, to make it clear that a function is to be run with <code>new</code>.</p>
<p>````smart header=‚Äúnew function() { ‚Ä¶ }‚Äù If we have many lines of code all about creation of a single complex object, we can wrap them in constructor function, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb389"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="kw">function</span>() <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-2" title="2">  <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="at">name</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-3" title="3">  <span class="kw">this</span>.<span class="at">isAdmin</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">false</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-4" title="4"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-5" title="5">  <span class="co">// ...other code for user creation</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-6" title="6">  <span class="co">// maybe complex logic and statements</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-7" title="7">  <span class="co">// local variables etc</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb389-8" title="8"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The constructor can‚Äôt be called again, because it is not saved anywhere, just created and called. So this trick aims to encapsulate the code that constructs the single object, without future reuse. ````</p>
<h2 id="constructor-mode-test-new.target">Constructor mode test: new.target</h2>
<p><code>smart header="Advanced stuff" The syntax from this section is rarely used, skip it unless you want to know everything.</code></p>
<p>Inside a function, we can check whether it was called with <code>new</code> or without it, using a special <code>new.target</code> property.</p>
<p>It is undefined for regular calls and equals the function if called with <code>new</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function User() { alert(new.target); }</p>
<p>// without ‚Äúnew‚Äù: <em>!</em> User(); // undefined <em>/!</em></p>
<p>// with ‚Äúnew‚Äù: <em>!</em> new User(); // function User { ‚Ä¶ } <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>That can be used inside the function to know whether it was called with <code>new</code>, ‚Äúin constructor mode‚Äù, or without it, ‚Äúin regular mode‚Äù.</p>
<p>We can also make both <code>new</code> and regular calls to do the same, like this:</p>
<p>```js run function User(name) { if (!new.target) { // if you run me without new return new User(name); // ‚Ä¶I will add new for you }</p>
<p>this.name = name; }</p>
<p>let john = User(‚ÄúJohn‚Äù); // redirects call to new User alert(john.name); // John ```</p>
<p>This approach is sometimes used in libraries to make the syntax more flexible. So that people may call the function with or without <code>new</code>, and it still works.</p>
<p>Probably not a good thing to use everywhere though, because omitting <code>new</code> makes it a bit less obvious what‚Äôs going on. With <code>new</code> we all know that the new object is being created.</p>
<h2 id="return-from-constructors">Return from constructors</h2>
<p>Usually, constructors do not have a <code>return</code> statement. Their task is to write all necessary stuff into <code>this</code>, and it automatically becomes the result.</p>
<p>But if there is a <code>return</code> statement, then the rule is simple:</p>
<ul>
<li>If <code>return</code> is called with an object, then the object is returned instead of <code>this</code>.</li>
<li>If <code>return</code> is called with a primitive, it‚Äôs ignored.</li>
</ul>
<p>In other words, <code>return</code> with an object returns that object, in all other cases <code>this</code> is returned.</p>
<p>For instance, here <code>return</code> overrides <code>this</code> by returning an object:</p>
<p>```js run function BigUser() {</p>
<p>this.name = ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù;</p>
<p>return { name: ‚ÄúGodzilla‚Äù }; // &lt;‚Äì returns this object }</p>
<p>alert( new BigUser().name ); // Godzilla, got that object ```</p>
<p>And here‚Äôs an example with an empty <code>return</code> (or we could place a primitive after it, doesn‚Äôt matter):</p>
<p>```js run function SmallUser() {</p>
<p>this.name = ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù;</p>
<p>return; // &lt;‚Äì returns this }</p>
<p>alert( new SmallUser().name ); // John ```</p>
<p>Usually constructors don‚Äôt have a <code>return</code> statement. Here we mention the special behavior with returning objects mainly for the sake of completeness.</p>
<p>```<code>smart header="Omitting parentheses" By the way, we can omit parentheses after</code>new`, if it has no arguments:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb390"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb390-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> User<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// &lt;-- no parentheses</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb390-2" title="2"><span class="co">// same as</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb390-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">new</span> <span class="at">User</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Omitting parentheses here is not considered a ‚Äúgood style‚Äù, but the syntax is permitted by specification. ````</p>
<h2 id="methods-in-constructor">Methods in constructor</h2>
<p>Using constructor functions to create objects gives a great deal of flexibility. The constructor function may have parameters that define how to construct the object, and what to put in it.</p>
<p>Of course, we can add to <code>this</code> not only properties, but methods as well.</p>
<p>For instance, <code>new User(name)</code> below creates an object with the given <code>name</code> and the method <code>sayHi</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function User(name) { this.name = name;</p>
<p>this.sayHi = function() { alert( ‚ÄúMy name is:‚Äù + this.name ); }; }</p>
<p><em>!</em> let john = new User(‚ÄúJohn‚Äù);</p>
<p>john.sayHi(); // My name is: John <em>/!</em></p>
<p>/<em> john = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, sayHi: function() { ‚Ä¶ } } </em>/ ```</p>
<p>To create complex objects, there‚Äôs a more advanced syntax, <a href="info:classes">classes</a>, that we‚Äôll cover later.</p>
<h2 id="summary-50">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>Constructor functions or, briefly, constructors, are regular functions, but there‚Äôs a common agreement to name them with capital letter first.</li>
<li>Constructor functions should only be called using <code>new</code>. Such a call implies a creation of empty <code>this</code> at the start and returning the populated one at the end.</li>
</ul>
<p>We can use constructor functions to make multiple similar objects.</p>
<p>JavaScript provides constructor functions for many built-in language objects: like <code>Date</code> for dates, <code>Set</code> for sets and others that we plan to study.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúObjects, we‚Äôll be back!‚Äù In this chapter we only cover the basics about objects and constructors. They are essential for learning more about data types and functions in the next chapters.</p>
<p>After we learn that, we return to objects and cover them in-depth in the chapters <a href="info:prototypes" class="uri">info:prototypes</a> and <a href="info:classes" class="uri">info:classes</a>. ```</p>
<h1 id="optional-chaining-.">Optional chaining ‚Äò?.‚Äô</h1>
<p>[recent browser=‚Äúnew‚Äù]</p>
<p>The optional chaining <code>?.</code> is a safe way to access nested object properties, even if an intermediate property doesn‚Äôt exist.</p>
<h2 id="the-non-existing-property-problem">The ‚Äúnon-existing property‚Äù problem</h2>
<p>If you‚Äôve just started to read the tutorial and learn JavaScript, maybe the problem hasn‚Äôt touched you yet, but it‚Äôs quite common.</p>
<p>As an example, let‚Äôs say we have <code>user</code> objects that hold the information about our users.</p>
<p>Most of our users have addresses in <code>user.address</code> property, with the street <code>user.address.street</code>, but some did not provide them.</p>
<p>In such case, when we attempt to get <code>user.address.street</code>, and the user happens to be without an address, we get an error:</p>
<p>```js run let user = {}; // a user without ‚Äúaddress‚Äù property</p>
<p>alert(user.address.street); // Error! ```</p>
<p>That‚Äôs the expected result. JavaScript works like this. As <code>user.address</code> is <code>undefined</code>, an attempt to get <code>user.address.street</code> fails with an error.</p>
<p>In many practical cases we‚Äôd prefer to get <code>undefined</code> instead of an error here (meaning ‚Äúno street‚Äù).</p>
<p>‚Ä¶And another example. In the web development, we can get an object that corresponds to a web page element using a special method call, such as <code>document.querySelector('.elem')</code>, and it returns <code>null</code> when there‚Äôs no such element.</p>
<p><code>js run // document.querySelector('.elem') is null if there's no element let html = document.querySelector('.elem').innerHTML; // error if it's null</code></p>
<p>Once again, if the element doesn‚Äôt exist, we‚Äôll get an error accessing <code>.innerHTML</code> of <code>null</code>. And in some cases, when the absence of the element is normal, we‚Äôd like to avoid the error and just accept <code>html = null</code> as the result.</p>
<p>How can we do this?</p>
<p>The obvious solution would be to check the value using <code>if</code> or the conditional operator <code>?</code>, before accessing its property, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb391"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb391-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb391-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb391-3" title="3"><span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">address</span> <span class="op">?</span> <span class="va">user</span>.<span class="va">address</span>.<span class="at">street</span> : <span class="kw">undefined</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>It works, there‚Äôs no error‚Ä¶ But it‚Äôs quite inelegant. As you can see, the <code>"user.address"</code> appears twice in the code. For more deeply nested properties, that becomes a problem as more repetitions are required.</p>
<p>E.g. let‚Äôs try getting <code>user.address.street.name</code>.</p>
<p>We need to check both <code>user.address</code> and <code>user.address.street</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb392"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb392-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{};</span> <span class="co">// user has no address</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb392-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb392-3" title="3"><span class="at">alert</span>(<span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">address</span> <span class="op">?</span> <span class="va">user</span>.<span class="va">address</span>.<span class="at">street</span> <span class="op">?</span> <span class="va">user</span>.<span class="va">address</span>.<span class="va">street</span>.<span class="at">name</span> : <span class="kw">null</span> : <span class="kw">null</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>That‚Äôs just awful, one may even have problems understanding such code.</p>
<p>Don‚Äôt even care to, as there‚Äôs a better way to write it, using the <code>&amp;&amp;</code> operator:</p>
<p>```js run let user = {}; // user has no address</p>
<p>alert( user.address &amp;&amp; user.address.street &amp;&amp; user.address.street.name ); // undefined (no error) ```</p>
<p>AND‚Äôing the whole path to the property ensures that all components exist (if not, the evaluation stops), but also isn‚Äôt ideal.</p>
<p>As you can see, property names are still duplicated in the code. E.g. in the code above, <code>user.address</code> appears three times.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs why the optional chaining <code>?.</code> was added to the language. To solve this problem once and for all!</p>
<h2 id="optional-chaining">Optional chaining</h2>
<p>The optional chaining <code>?.</code> stops the evaluation if the value before <code>?.</code> is <code>undefined</code> or <code>null</code> and returns <code>undefined</code>.</p>
<p><strong>Further in this article, for brevity, we‚Äôll be saying that something ‚Äúexists‚Äù if it‚Äôs not <code>null</code> and not <code>undefined</code>.</strong></p>
<p>In other words, <code>value?.prop</code>: - works as <code>value.prop</code>, if <code>value</code> exists, - otherwise (when <code>value</code> is <code>undefined/null</code>) it returns <code>undefined</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the safe way to access <code>user.address.street</code> using <code>?.</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let user = {}; // user has no address</p>
<p>alert( user?.address?.street ); // undefined (no error) ```</p>
<p>The code is short and clean, there‚Äôs no duplication at all.</p>
<p>Reading the address with <code>user?.address</code> works even if <code>user</code> object doesn‚Äôt exist:</p>
<p>```js run let user = null;</p>
<p>alert( user?.address ); // undefined alert( user?.address.street ); // undefined ```</p>
<p>Please note: the <code>?.</code> syntax makes optional the value before it, but not any further.</p>
<p>E.g. in <code>user?.address.street.name</code> the <code>?.</code> allows <code>user</code> to safely be <code>null/undefined</code> (and returns <code>undefined</code> in that case), but that‚Äôs only for <code>user</code>. Further properties are accessed in a regular way. If we want some of them to be optional, then we‚Äôll need to replace more <code>.</code> with <code>?.</code>.</p>
<p>``<code>warn header="Don't overuse the optional chaining" We should use</code>?.` only where it‚Äôs ok that something doesn‚Äôt exist.</p>
<p>For example, if according to our coding logic <code>user</code> object must exist, but <code>address</code> is optional, then we should write <code>user.address?.street</code>, but not <code>user?.address?.street</code>.</p>
<p>So, if <code>user</code> happens to be undefined due to a mistake, we‚Äôll see a programming error about it and fix it. Otherwise, coding errors can be silenced where not appropriate, and become more difficult to debug. ```</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="The variable before</code>?.<code>must be declared" If there's no variable</code>user<code>at all, then</code>user?.anything` triggers an error:</p>
<p><code>js run // ReferenceError: user is not defined user?.address;</code> The variable must be declared (e.g.¬†<code>let/const/var user</code> or as a function parameter). The optional chaining works only for declared variables. ````</p>
<h2 id="short-circuiting">Short-circuiting</h2>
<p>As it was said before, the <code>?.</code> immediately stops (‚Äúshort-circuits‚Äù) the evaluation if the left part doesn‚Äôt exist.</p>
<p>So, if there are any further function calls or side effects, they don‚Äôt occur.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let user = null; let x = 0;</p>
<p>user?.sayHi(x++); // no ‚ÄúsayHi‚Äù, so the execution doesn‚Äôt reach x++</p>
<p>alert(x); // 0, value not incremented ```</p>
<h2 id="other-variants-.-.">Other variants: ?.(), ?.[]</h2>
<p>The optional chaining <code>?.</code> is not an operator, but a special syntax construct, that also works with functions and square brackets.</p>
<p>For example, <code>?.()</code> is used to call a function that may not exist.</p>
<p>In the code below, some of our users have <code>admin</code> method, and some don‚Äôt:</p>
<p>```js run let userAdmin = { admin() { alert(‚ÄúI am admin‚Äù); } };</p>
<p>let userGuest = {};</p>
<p><em>!</em> userAdmin.admin?.(); // I am admin <em>/!</em></p>
<p><em>!</em> userGuest.admin?.(); // nothing (no such method) <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>Here, in both lines we first use the dot (<code>userAdmin.admin</code>) to get <code>admin</code> property, because we assume that the user object exists, so it‚Äôs safe read from it.</p>
<p>Then <code>?.()</code> checks the left part: if the admin function exists, then it runs (that‚Äôs so for <code>userAdmin</code>). Otherwise (for <code>userGuest</code>) the evaluation stops without errors.</p>
<p>The <code>?.[]</code> syntax also works, if we‚Äôd like to use brackets <code>[]</code> to access properties instead of dot <code>.</code>. Similar to previous cases, it allows to safely read a property from an object that may not exist.</p>
<p>```js run let key = ‚ÄúfirstName‚Äù;</p>
<p>let user1 = { firstName: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù };</p>
<p>let user2 = null;</p>
<p>alert( user1?.[key] ); // John alert( user2?.[key] ); // undefined ```</p>
<p>Also we can use <code>?.</code> with <code>delete</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run delete user?.name; // delete user.name if user exists</code></p>
<p>```<code>warn header="We can use</code>?.<code>for safe reading and deleting, but not writing" The optional chaining</code>?.` has no use at the left side of an assignment.</p>
<p>For example: ```js run let user = null;</p>
<p>user?.name = ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù; // Error, doesn‚Äôt work // because it evaluates to undefined = ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù</p>
<pre><code>
It&#39;s just not that smart.</code></pre>
<h2 id="summary-51">Summary</h2>
<p>The optional chaining <code>?.</code> syntax has three forms:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><code>obj?.prop</code> ‚Äì returns <code>obj.prop</code> if <code>obj</code> exists, otherwise <code>undefined</code>.</li>
<li><code>obj?.[prop]</code> ‚Äì returns <code>obj[prop]</code> if <code>obj</code> exists, otherwise <code>undefined</code>.</li>
<li><code>obj.method?.()</code> ‚Äì calls <code>obj.method()</code> if <code>obj.method</code> exists, otherwise returns <code>undefined</code>.</li>
</ol>
<p>As we can see, all of them are straightforward and simple to use. The <code>?.</code> checks the left part for <code>null/undefined</code> and allows the evaluation to proceed if it‚Äôs not so.</p>
<p>A chain of <code>?.</code> allows to safely access nested properties.</p>
<p>Still, we should apply <code>?.</code> carefully, only where it‚Äôs acceptable that the left part doesn‚Äôt exist. So that it won‚Äôt hide programming errors from us, if they occur.</p>
<h1 id="symbol-type">Symbol type</h1>
<p>By specification, object property keys may be either of string type, or of symbol type. Not numbers, not booleans, only strings or symbols, these two types.</p>
<p>Till now we‚Äôve been using only strings. Now let‚Äôs see the benefits that symbols can give us.</p>
<h2 id="symbols">Symbols</h2>
<p>A ‚Äúsymbol‚Äù represents a unique identifier.</p>
<p>A value of this type can be created using <code>Symbol()</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb394"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb394-1" title="1"><span class="co">// id is a new symbol</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb394-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> id <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">Symbol</span>()<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Upon creation, we can give symbol a description (also called a symbol name), mostly useful for debugging purposes:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb395"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb395-1" title="1"><span class="co">// id is a symbol with the description &quot;id&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb395-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> id <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">Symbol</span>(<span class="st">&quot;id&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Symbols are guaranteed to be unique. Even if we create many symbols with the same description, they are different values. The description is just a label that doesn‚Äôt affect anything.</p>
<p>For instance, here are two symbols with the same description ‚Äì they are not equal:</p>
<p>```js run let id1 = Symbol(‚Äúid‚Äù); let id2 = Symbol(‚Äúid‚Äù);</p>
<p><em>!</em> alert(id1 == id2); // false <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>If you are familiar with Ruby or another language that also has some sort of ‚Äúsymbols‚Äù ‚Äì please don‚Äôt be misguided. JavaScript symbols are different.</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Symbols don't auto-convert to a string" Most values in JavaScript support implicit conversion to a string. For instance, we can</code>alert` almost any value, and it will work. Symbols are special. They don‚Äôt auto-convert.</p>
<p>For instance, this <code>alert</code> will show an error:</p>
<p><code>js run let id = Symbol("id"); *!* alert(id); // TypeError: Cannot convert a Symbol value to a string */!*</code></p>
<p>That‚Äôs a ‚Äúlanguage guard‚Äù against messing up, because strings and symbols are fundamentally different and should not accidentally convert one into another.</p>
<p>If we really want to show a symbol, we need to explicitly call <code>.toString()</code> on it, like here: <code>js run let id = Symbol("id"); *!* alert(id.toString()); // Symbol(id), now it works */!*</code></p>
<p>Or get <code>symbol.description</code> property to show the description only: <code>js run let id = Symbol("id"); *!* alert(id.description); // id */!*</code></p>
<p>````</p>
<h2 id="hidden-properties">‚ÄúHidden‚Äù properties</h2>
<p>Symbols allow us to create ‚Äúhidden‚Äù properties of an object, that no other part of code can accidentally access or overwrite.</p>
<p>For instance, if we‚Äôre working with <code>user</code> objects, that belong to a third-party code. We‚Äôd like to add identifiers to them.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs use a symbol key for it:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { // belongs to another code name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù };</p>
<p>let id = Symbol(‚Äúid‚Äù);</p>
<p>user[id] = 1;</p>
<p>alert( user[id] ); // we can access the data using the symbol as the key ```</p>
<p>What‚Äôs the benefit of using <code>Symbol("id")</code> over a string <code>"id"</code>?</p>
<p>As <code>user</code> objects belongs to another code, and that code also works with them, we shouldn‚Äôt just add any fields to it. That‚Äôs unsafe. But a symbol cannot be accessed accidentally, the third-party code probably won‚Äôt even see it, so it‚Äôs probably all right to do.</p>
<p>Also, imagine that another script wants to have its own identifier inside <code>user</code>, for its own purposes. That may be another JavaScript library, so that the scripts are completely unaware of each other.</p>
<p>Then that script can create its own <code>Symbol("id")</code>, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb396"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb396-1" title="1"><span class="co">// ...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb396-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> id <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">Symbol</span>(<span class="st">&quot;id&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb396-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb396-4" title="4">user[id] <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;Their id value&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>There will be no conflict between our and their identifiers, because symbols are always different, even if they have the same name.</p>
<p>‚Ä¶But if we used a string <code>"id"</code> instead of a symbol for the same purpose, then there <em>would</em> be a conflict:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb397"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span> <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span> <span class="op">};</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-3" title="3"><span class="co">// Our script uses &quot;id&quot; property</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-4" title="4"><span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">id</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;Our id value&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-5" title="5"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-6" title="6"><span class="co">// ...Another script also wants &quot;id&quot; for its purposes...</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-8" title="8"><span class="va">user</span>.<span class="at">id</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;Their id value&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb397-9" title="9"><span class="co">// Boom! overwritten by another script!</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="symbols-in-an-object-literal">Symbols in an object literal</h3>
<p>If we want to use a symbol in an object literal <code>{...}</code>, we need square brackets around it.</p>
<p>Like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb398"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> id <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">Symbol</span>(<span class="st">&quot;id&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-2" title="2"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-3" title="3"><span class="kw">let</span> user <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-4" title="4">  <span class="dt">name</span><span class="op">:</span> <span class="st">&quot;John&quot;</span><span class="op">,</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-5" title="5"><span class="op">*!*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-6" title="6">  [id]<span class="op">:</span> <span class="dv">123</span> <span class="co">// not &quot;id&quot;: 123</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-7" title="7"><span class="op">*</span><span class="ss">/!</span><span class="sc">*</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb398-8" title="8"><span class="ss">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>That‚Äôs because we need the value from the variable <code>id</code> as the key, not the string ‚Äúid‚Äù.</p>
<h3 id="symbols-are-skipped-by-for..in">Symbols are skipped by for..in</h3>
<p>Symbolic properties do not participate in <code>for..in</code> loop.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let id = Symbol(‚Äúid‚Äù); let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, age: 30, [id]: 123 };</p>
<p><em>!</em> for (let key in user) alert(key); // name, age (no symbols) <em>/!</em></p>
<p>// the direct access by the symbol works alert( ‚ÄúDirect:‚Äù + user[id] ); ```</p>
<p><code>Object.keys(user)</code> also ignores them. That‚Äôs a part of the general ‚Äúhiding symbolic properties‚Äù principle. If another script or a library loops over our object, it won‚Äôt unexpectedly access a symbolic property.</p>
<p>In contrast, <a href="mdn:js/Object/assign">Object.assign</a> copies both string and symbol properties:</p>
<p>```js run let id = Symbol(‚Äúid‚Äù); let user = { [id]: 123 };</p>
<p>let clone = Object.assign({}, user);</p>
<p>alert( clone[id] ); // 123 ```</p>
