<p>There‚Äôs no paradox here. That‚Äôs by design. The idea is that when we clone an object or merge objects, we usually want <em>all</em> properties to be copied (including symbols like <code>id</code>).</p>
<h2 id="global-symbols">Global symbols</h2>
<p>As we‚Äôve seen, usually all symbols are different, even if they have the same name. But sometimes we want same-named symbols to be same entities. For instance, different parts of our application want to access symbol <code>"id"</code> meaning exactly the same property.</p>
<p>To achieve that, there exists a <em>global symbol registry</em>. We can create symbols in it and access them later, and it guarantees that repeated accesses by the same name return exactly the same symbol.</p>
<p>In order to read (create if absent) a symbol from the registry, use <code>Symbol.for(key)</code>.</p>
<p>That call checks the global registry, and if there‚Äôs a symbol described as <code>key</code>, then returns it, otherwise creates a new symbol <code>Symbol(key)</code> and stores it in the registry by the given <code>key</code>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run // read from the global registry let id = Symbol.for(‚Äúid‚Äù); // if the symbol did not exist, it is created</p>
<p>// read it again (maybe from another part of the code) let idAgain = Symbol.for(‚Äúid‚Äù);</p>
<p>// the same symbol alert( id === idAgain ); // true ```</p>
<p>Symbols inside the registry are called <em>global symbols</em>. If we want an application-wide symbol, accessible everywhere in the code ‚Äì that‚Äôs what they are for.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúThat sounds like Ruby‚Äù In some programming languages, like Ruby, there‚Äôs a single symbol per name.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, as we can see, that‚Äôs right for global symbols. ```</p>
<h3 id="symbol.keyfor">Symbol.keyFor</h3>
<p>For global symbols, not only <code>Symbol.for(key)</code> returns a symbol by name, but there‚Äôs a reverse call: <code>Symbol.keyFor(sym)</code>, that does the reverse: returns a name by a global symbol.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run // get symbol by name let sym = Symbol.for(‚Äúname‚Äù); let sym2 = Symbol.for(‚Äúid‚Äù);</p>
<p>// get name by symbol alert( Symbol.keyFor(sym) ); // name alert( Symbol.keyFor(sym2) ); // id ```</p>
<p>The <code>Symbol.keyFor</code> internally uses the global symbol registry to look up the key for the symbol. So it doesn‚Äôt work for non-global symbols. If the symbol is not global, it won‚Äôt be able to find it and returns <code>undefined</code>.</p>
<p>That said, any symbols have <code>description</code> property.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let globalSymbol = Symbol.for(‚Äúname‚Äù); let localSymbol = Symbol(‚Äúname‚Äù);</p>
<p>alert( Symbol.keyFor(globalSymbol) ); // name, global symbol alert( Symbol.keyFor(localSymbol) ); // undefined, not global</p>
<p>alert( localSymbol.description ); // name ```</p>
<h2 id="system-symbols">System symbols</h2>
<p>There exist many ‚Äúsystem‚Äù symbols that JavaScript uses internally, and we can use them to fine-tune various aspects of our objects.</p>
<p>They are listed in the specification in the <a href="https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/#sec-well-known-symbols">Well-known symbols</a> table:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Symbol.hasInstance</code></li>
<li><code>Symbol.isConcatSpreadable</code></li>
<li><code>Symbol.iterator</code></li>
<li><code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code></li>
<li>‚Ä¶and so on.</li>
</ul>
<p>For instance, <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> allows us to describe object to primitive conversion. We‚Äôll see its use very soon.</p>
<p>Other symbols will also become familiar when we study the corresponding language features.</p>
<h2 id="summary-52">Summary</h2>
<p><code>Symbol</code> is a primitive type for unique identifiers.</p>
<p>Symbols are created with <code>Symbol()</code> call with an optional description (name).</p>
<p>Symbols are always different values, even if they have the same name. If we want same-named symbols to be equal, then we should use the global registry: <code>Symbol.for(key)</code> returns (creates if needed) a global symbol with <code>key</code> as the name. Multiple calls of <code>Symbol.for</code> with the same <code>key</code> return exactly the same symbol.</p>
<p>Symbols have two main use cases:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>‚ÄúHidden‚Äù object properties. If we want to add a property into an object that ‚Äúbelongs‚Äù to another script or a library, we can create a symbol and use it as a property key. A symbolic property does not appear in <code>for..in</code>, so it won‚Äôt be accidentally processed together with other properties. Also it won‚Äôt be accessed directly, because another script does not have our symbol. So the property will be protected from accidental use or overwrite.</p>
<p>So we can ‚Äúcovertly‚Äù hide something into objects that we need, but others should not see, using symbolic properties.</p></li>
<li><p>There are many system symbols used by JavaScript which are accessible as <code>Symbol.*</code>. We can use them to alter some built-in behaviors. For instance, later in the tutorial we‚Äôll use <code>Symbol.iterator</code> for <a href="info:iterable">iterables</a>, <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> to setup <a href="info:object-toprimitive">object-to-primitive conversion</a> and so on.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>Technically, symbols are not 100% hidden. There is a built-in method <a href="mdn:js/Object/getOwnPropertySymbols">Object.getOwnPropertySymbols(obj)</a> that allows us to get all symbols. Also there is a method named <a href="mdn:js/Reflect/ownKeys">Reflect.ownKeys(obj)</a> that returns <em>all</em> keys of an object including symbolic ones. So they are not really hidden. But most libraries, built-in functions and syntax constructs don‚Äôt use these methods.</p>
<h1 id="object-to-primitive-conversion">Object to primitive conversion</h1>
<p>What happens when objects are added <code>obj1 + obj2</code>, subtracted <code>obj1 - obj2</code> or printed using <code>alert(obj)</code>?</p>
<p>In that case, objects are auto-converted to primitives, and then the operation is carried out.</p>
<p>In the chapter <a href="info:type-conversions" class="uri">info:type-conversions</a> we‚Äôve seen the rules for numeric, string and boolean conversions of primitives. But we left a gap for objects. Now, as we know about methods and symbols it becomes possible to fill it.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>All objects are <code>true</code> in a boolean context. There are only numeric and string conversions.</li>
<li>The numeric conversion happens when we subtract objects or apply mathematical functions. For instance, <code>Date</code> objects (to be covered in the chapter <a href="info:date" class="uri">info:date</a>) can be subtracted, and the result of <code>date1 - date2</code> is the time difference between two dates.</li>
<li>As for the string conversion ‚Äì it usually happens when we output an object like <code>alert(obj)</code> and in similar contexts.</li>
</ol>
<h2 id="toprimitive">ToPrimitive</h2>
<p>We can fine-tune string and numeric conversion, using special object methods.</p>
<p>There are three variants of type conversion, so-called ‚Äúhints‚Äù, described in the <a href="https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/#sec-toprimitive">specification</a>:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>"string"</code></dt>
<dd><p>For an object-to-string conversion, when we‚Äôre doing an operation on an object that expects a string, like <code>alert</code>:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb399"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb399-1" title="1"><span class="co">// output</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb399-2" title="2"><span class="at">alert</span>(obj)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb399-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb399-4" title="4"><span class="co">// using object as a property key</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb399-5" title="5">anotherObj[obj] <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">123</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
</dd>
<dt><code>"number"</code></dt>
<dd><p>For an object-to-number conversion, like when we‚Äôre doing maths:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb400"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-1" title="1"><span class="co">// explicit conversion</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> num <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">Number</span>(obj)<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-4" title="4"><span class="co">// maths (except binary plus)</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-5" title="5"><span class="kw">let</span> n <span class="op">=</span> <span class="op">+</span>obj<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// unary plus</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-6" title="6"><span class="kw">let</span> delta <span class="op">=</span> date1 <span class="op">-</span> date2<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-7" title="7"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-8" title="8"><span class="co">// less/greater comparison</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb400-9" title="9"><span class="kw">let</span> greater <span class="op">=</span> user1 <span class="op">&gt;</span> user2<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
</dd>
<dt><code>"default"</code></dt>
<dd><p>Occurs in rare cases when the operator is ‚Äúnot sure‚Äù what type to expect.</p>
<p>For instance, binary plus <code>+</code> can work both with strings (concatenates them) and numbers (adds them), so both strings and numbers would do. So if a binary plus gets an object as an argument, it uses the <code>"default"</code> hint to convert it.</p>
<p>Also, if an object is compared using <code>==</code> with a string, number or a symbol, it‚Äôs also unclear which conversion should be done, so the <code>"default"</code> hint is used.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb401"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb401-1" title="1"><span class="co">// binary plus uses the &quot;default&quot; hint</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb401-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> total <span class="op">=</span> obj1 <span class="op">+</span> obj2<span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb401-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb401-4" title="4"><span class="co">// obj == number uses the &quot;default&quot; hint</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb401-5" title="5"><span class="cf">if</span> (user <span class="op">==</span> <span class="dv">1</span>) <span class="op">{</span> ... <span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>The greater and less comparison operators, such as <code>&lt;</code> <code>&gt;</code>, can work with both strings and numbers too. Still, they use the <code>"number"</code> hint, not <code>"default"</code>. That‚Äôs for historical reasons.</p>
<p>In practice though, we don‚Äôt need to remember these peculiar details, because all built-in objects except for one case (<code>Date</code> object, we‚Äôll learn it later) implement <code>"default"</code> conversion the same way as <code>"number"</code>. And we can do the same.</p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>``<code>smart header="No</code>"boolean"` hint" Please note ‚Äì there are only three hints. It‚Äôs that simple.</p>
<p>There is no ‚Äúboolean‚Äù hint (all objects are <code>true</code> in boolean context) or anything else. And if we treat <code>"default"</code> and <code>"number"</code> the same, like most built-ins do, then there are only two conversions. ```</p>
<p><strong>To do the conversion, JavaScript tries to find and call three object methods:</strong></p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Call <code>obj[Symbol.toPrimitive](hint)</code> - the method with the symbolic key <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> (system symbol), if such method exists,</li>
<li>Otherwise if hint is <code>"string"</code>
<ul>
<li>try <code>obj.toString()</code> and <code>obj.valueOf()</code>, whatever exists.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Otherwise if hint is <code>"number"</code> or <code>"default"</code>
<ul>
<li>try <code>obj.valueOf()</code> and <code>obj.toString()</code>, whatever exists.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="symbol.toprimitive">Symbol.toPrimitive</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs start from the first method. There‚Äôs a built-in symbol named <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> that should be used to name the conversion method, like this:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb402"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb402-1" title="1">obj[<span class="va">Symbol</span>.<span class="at">toPrimitive</span>] <span class="op">=</span> <span class="kw">function</span>(hint) <span class="op">{</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb402-2" title="2">  <span class="co">// must return a primitive value</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb402-3" title="3">  <span class="co">// hint = one of &quot;string&quot;, &quot;number&quot;, &quot;default&quot;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb402-4" title="4"><span class="op">};</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>For instance, here <code>user</code> object implements it:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, money: 1000,</p>
<p><a href="hint">Symbol.toPrimitive</a> { alert(<code>hint: ${hint}</code>); return hint == ‚Äústring‚Äù ? <code>{name: "${this.name}"}</code> : this.money; } };</p>
<p>// conversions demo: alert(user); // hint: string -&gt; {name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù} alert(+user); // hint: number -&gt; 1000 alert(user + 500); // hint: default -&gt; 1500 ```</p>
<p>As we can see from the code, <code>user</code> becomes a self-descriptive string or a money amount depending on the conversion. The single method <code>user[Symbol.toPrimitive]</code> handles all conversion cases.</p>
<h2 id="tostringvalueof">toString/valueOf</h2>
<p>Methods <code>toString</code> and <code>valueOf</code> come from ancient times. They are not symbols (symbols did not exist that long ago), but rather ‚Äúregular‚Äù string-named methods. They provide an alternative ‚Äúold-style‚Äù way to implement the conversion.</p>
<p>If there‚Äôs no <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> then JavaScript tries to find them and try in the order:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>toString -&gt; valueOf</code> for ‚Äústring‚Äù hint.</li>
<li><code>valueOf -&gt; toString</code> otherwise.</li>
</ul>
<p>These methods must return a primitive value. If <code>toString</code> or <code>valueOf</code> returns an object, then it‚Äôs ignored (same as if there were no method).</p>
<p>By default, a plain object has following <code>toString</code> and <code>valueOf</code> methods:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <code>toString</code> method returns a string <code>"[object Object]"</code>.</li>
<li>The <code>valueOf</code> method returns the object itself.</li>
</ul>
<p>Here‚Äôs the demo:</p>
<p>```js run let user = {name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù};</p>
<p>alert(user); // [object Object] alert(user.valueOf() === user); // true ```</p>
<p>So if we try to use an object as a string, like in an <code>alert</code> or so, then by default we see <code>[object Object]</code>.</p>
<p>And the default <code>valueOf</code> is mentioned here only for the sake of completeness, to avoid any confusion. As you can see, it returns the object itself, and so is ignored. Don‚Äôt ask me why, that‚Äôs for historical reasons. So we can assume it doesn‚Äôt exist.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs implement these methods.</p>
<p>For instance, here <code>user</code> does the same as above using a combination of <code>toString</code> and <code>valueOf</code> instead of <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, money: 1000,</p>
<p>// for hint=‚Äústring‚Äù toString() { return <code>{name: "${this.name}"}</code>; },</p>
<p>// for hint=‚Äúnumber‚Äù or ‚Äúdefault‚Äù valueOf() { return this.money; }</p>
<p>};</p>
<p>alert(user); // toString -&gt; {name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù} alert(+user); // valueOf -&gt; 1000 alert(user + 500); // valueOf -&gt; 1500 ```</p>
<p>As we can see, the behavior is the same as the previous example with <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code>.</p>
<p>Often we want a single ‚Äúcatch-all‚Äù place to handle all primitive conversions. In this case, we can implement <code>toString</code> only, like this:</p>
<p>```js run let user = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù,</p>
<p>toString() { return this.name; } };</p>
<p>alert(user); // toString -&gt; John alert(user + 500); // toString -&gt; John500 ```</p>
<p>In the absence of <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> and <code>valueOf</code>, <code>toString</code> will handle all primitive conversions.</p>
<h2 id="return-types">Return types</h2>
<p>The important thing to know about all primitive-conversion methods is that they do not necessarily return the ‚Äúhinted‚Äù primitive.</p>
<p>There is no control whether <code>toString</code> returns exactly a string, or whether <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> method returns a number for a hint <code>"number"</code>.</p>
<p>The only mandatory thing: these methods must return a primitive, not an object.</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Historical notes" For historical reasons, if</code>toString<code>or</code>valueOf` returns an object, there‚Äôs no error, but such value is ignored (like if the method didn‚Äôt exist). That‚Äôs because in ancient times there was no good ‚Äúerror‚Äù concept in JavaScript.</p>
<p>In contrast, <code>Symbol.toPrimitive</code> <em>must</em> return a primitive, otherwise there will be an error. ```</p>
<h2 id="further-conversions">Further conversions</h2>
<p>As we know already, many operators and functions perform type conversions, e.g.¬†multiplication <code>*</code> converts operands to numbers.</p>
<p>If we pass an object as an argument, then there are two stages: 1. The object is converted to a primitive (using the rules described above). 2. If the resulting primitive isn‚Äôt of the right type, it‚Äôs converted.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let obj = { // toString handles all conversions in the absence of other methods toString() { return ‚Äú2‚Äù; } };</p>
<p>alert(obj * 2); // 4, object converted to primitive ‚Äú2‚Äù, then multiplication made it a number ```</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The multiplication <code>obj * 2</code> first converts the object to primitive (that‚Äôs a string <code>"2"</code>).</li>
<li>Then <code>"2" * 2</code> becomes <code>2 * 2</code> (the string is converted to number).</li>
</ol>
<p>Binary plus will concatenate strings in the same situation, as it gladly accepts a string:</p>
<p>```js run let obj = { toString() { return ‚Äú2‚Äù; } };</p>
<p>alert(obj + 2); // 22 (‚Äú2‚Äù + 2), conversion to primitive returned a string =&gt; concatenation ```</p>
<h2 id="summary-53">Summary</h2>
<p>The object-to-primitive conversion is called automatically by many built-in functions and operators that expect a primitive as a value.</p>
<p>There are 3 types (hints) of it: - <code>"string"</code> (for <code>alert</code> and other operations that need a string) - <code>"number"</code> (for maths) - <code>"default"</code> (few operators)</p>
<p>The specification describes explicitly which operator uses which hint. There are very few operators that ‚Äúdon‚Äôt know what to expect‚Äù and use the <code>"default"</code> hint. Usually for built-in objects <code>"default"</code> hint is handled the same way as <code>"number"</code>, so in practice the last two are often merged together.</p>
<p>The conversion algorithm is:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Call <code>obj[Symbol.toPrimitive](hint)</code> if the method exists,</li>
<li>Otherwise if hint is <code>"string"</code>
<ul>
<li>try <code>obj.toString()</code> and <code>obj.valueOf()</code>, whatever exists.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Otherwise if hint is <code>"number"</code> or <code>"default"</code>
<ul>
<li>try <code>obj.valueOf()</code> and <code>obj.toString()</code>, whatever exists.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol>
<p>In practice, it‚Äôs often enough to implement only <code>obj.toString()</code> as a ‚Äúcatch-all‚Äù method for all conversions that return a ‚Äúhuman-readable‚Äù representation of an object, for logging or debugging purposes.<br />
# Methods of primitives</p>
<p>JavaScript allows us to work with primitives (strings, numbers, etc.) as if they were objects. They also provide methods to call as such. We will study those soon, but first we‚Äôll see how it works because, of course, primitives are not objects (and here we will make it even clearer).</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs look at the key distinctions between primitives and objects.</p>
<p>A primitive</p>
<ul>
<li>Is a value of a primitive type.</li>
<li>There are 7 primitive types: <code>string</code>, <code>number</code>, <code>bigint</code>, <code>boolean</code>, <code>symbol</code>, <code>null</code> and <code>undefined</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>An object</p>
<ul>
<li>Is capable of storing multiple values as properties.</li>
<li>Can be created with <code>{}</code>, for instance: <code>{name: "John", age: 30}</code>. There are other kinds of objects in JavaScript: functions, for example, are objects.</li>
</ul>
<p>One of the best things about objects is that we can store a function as one of its properties.</p>
<p>```js run let john = { name: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù, sayHi: function() { alert(‚ÄúHi buddy!‚Äù); } };</p>
<p>john.sayHi(); // Hi buddy! ```</p>
<p>So here we‚Äôve made an object <code>john</code> with the method <code>sayHi</code>.</p>
<p>Many built-in objects already exist, such as those that work with dates, errors, HTML elements, etc. They have different properties and methods.</p>
<p>But, these features come with a cost!</p>
<p>Objects are ‚Äúheavier‚Äù than primitives. They require additional resources to support the internal machinery.</p>
<h2 id="a-primitive-as-an-object">A primitive as an object</h2>
<p>Here‚Äôs the paradox faced by the creator of JavaScript:</p>
<ul>
<li>There are many things one would want to do with a primitive like a string or a number. It would be great to access them as methods.</li>
<li>Primitives must be as fast and lightweight as possible.</li>
</ul>
<p>The solution looks a little bit awkward, but here it is:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>Primitives are still primitive. A single value, as desired.</li>
<li>The language allows access to methods and properties of strings, numbers, booleans and symbols.</li>
<li>In order for that to work, a special ‚Äúobject wrapper‚Äù that provides the extra functionality is created, and then is destroyed.</li>
</ol>
<p>The ‚Äúobject wrappers‚Äù are different for each primitive type and are called: <code>String</code>, <code>Number</code>, <code>Boolean</code> and <code>Symbol</code>. Thus, they provide different sets of methods.</p>
<p>For instance, there exists a string method <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/toUpperCase">str.toUpperCase()</a> that returns a capitalized <code>str</code>.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs how it works:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúHello‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert( str.toUpperCase() ); // HELLO ```</p>
<p>Simple, right? Here‚Äôs what actually happens in <code>str.toUpperCase()</code>:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>The string <code>str</code> is a primitive. So in the moment of accessing its property, a special object is created that knows the value of the string, and has useful methods, like <code>toUpperCase()</code>.</li>
<li>That method runs and returns a new string (shown by <code>alert</code>).</li>
<li>The special object is destroyed, leaving the primitive <code>str</code> alone.</li>
</ol>
<p>So primitives can provide methods, but they still remain lightweight.</p>
<p>The JavaScript engine highly optimizes this process. It may even skip the creation of the extra object at all. But it must still adhere to the specification and behave as if it creates one.</p>
<p>A number has methods of its own, for instance, <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number/toFixed">toFixed(n)</a> rounds the number to the given precision:</p>
<p>```js run let n = 1.23456;</p>
<p>alert( n.toFixed(2) ); // 1.23 ```</p>
<p>We‚Äôll see more specific methods in chapters <a href="info:number" class="uri">info:number</a> and <a href="info:string" class="uri">info:string</a>.</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="Constructors</code>String/Number/Boolean<code>are for internal use only" Some languages like Java allow us to explicitly create "wrapper objects" for primitives using a syntax like</code>new Number(1)<code>or</code>new Boolean(false)`.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, that‚Äôs also possible for historical reasons, but highly <strong>unrecommended</strong>. Things will go crazy in several places.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run alert( typeof 0 ); // ‚Äúnumber‚Äù</p>
<p>alert( typeof new Number(0) ); // ‚Äúobject‚Äù! ```</p>
<p>Objects are always truthy in <code>if</code>, so here the alert will show up:</p>
<p>```js run let zero = new Number(0);</p>
<p>if (zero) { // zero is true, because it‚Äôs an object alert( ‚Äúzero is truthy!?!‚Äù ); } ```</p>
<p>On the other hand, using the same functions <code>String/Number/Boolean</code> without <code>new</code> is a totally sane and useful thing. They convert a value to the corresponding type: to a string, a number, or a boolean (primitive).</p>
<p>For example, this is entirely valid:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb403"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb403-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> num <span class="op">=</span> <span class="at">Number</span>(<span class="st">&quot;123&quot;</span>)<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// convert a string to number</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>````</p>
<p>```<code>warn header="null/undefined have no methods" The special primitives</code>null<code>and</code>undefined` are exceptions. They have no corresponding ‚Äúwrapper objects‚Äù and provide no methods. In a sense, they are ‚Äúthe most primitive‚Äù.</p>
<p>An attempt to access a property of such value would give the error:</p>
<p>```js run alert(null.test); // error ````</p>
<h2 id="summary-54">Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>Primitives except <code>null</code> and <code>undefined</code> provide many helpful methods. We will study those in the upcoming chapters.</li>
<li>Formally, these methods work via temporary objects, but JavaScript engines are well tuned to optimize that internally, so they are not expensive to call. # Numbers</li>
</ul>
<p>In modern JavaScript, there are two types of numbers:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>Regular numbers in JavaScript are stored in 64-bit format <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_754-2008_revision">IEEE-754</a>, also known as ‚Äúdouble precision floating point numbers‚Äù. These are numbers that we‚Äôre using most of the time, and we‚Äôll talk about them in this chapter.</p></li>
<li><p>BigInt numbers, to represent integers of arbitrary length. They are sometimes needed, because a regular number can‚Äôt exceed <code>2<sup>53</sup></code> or be less than <code>-2<sup>53</sup></code>. As bigints are used in few special areas, we devote them a special chapter <a href="info:bigint" class="uri">info:bigint</a>.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>So here we‚Äôll talk about regular numbers. Let‚Äôs expand our knowledge of them.</p>
<h2 id="more-ways-to-write-a-number">More ways to write a number</h2>
<p>Imagine we need to write 1 billion. The obvious way is:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb404"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb404-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> billion <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1000000000</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>We also can use underscore <code>_</code> as the separator:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb405"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb405-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> billion <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span>_000_000_000<span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Here the underscore <code>_</code> plays the role of the ‚Äúsyntactic sugar‚Äù, it makes the number more readable. The JavaScript engine simply ignores <code>_</code> between digits, so it‚Äôs exactly the same one billion as above.</p>
<p>In real life though, we try to avoid writing long sequences of zeroes. We‚Äôre too lazy for that. We‚Äôll try to write something like <code>"1bn"</code> for a billion or <code>"7.3bn"</code> for 7 billion 300 million. The same is true for most large numbers.</p>
<p>In JavaScript, we can shorten a number by appending the letter <code>"e"</code> to it and specifying the zeroes count:</p>
<p>```js run let billion = 1e9; // 1 billion, literally: 1 and 9 zeroes</p>
<p>alert( 7.3e9 ); // 7.3 billions (same as 7300000000 or 7_300_000_000) ```</p>
<p>In other words, <code>e</code> multiplies the number by <code>1</code> with the given zeroes count.</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb406"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb406-1" title="1"><span class="fl">1e3</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span> <span class="op">*</span> <span class="dv">1000</span> <span class="co">// e3 means *1000</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb406-2" title="2"><span class="fl">1.23e6</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="fl">1.23</span> <span class="op">*</span> <span class="dv">1000000</span> <span class="co">// e6 means *1000000</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Now let‚Äôs write something very small. Say, 1 microsecond (one millionth of a second):</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb407"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb407-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> ms <span class="op">=</span> <span class="fl">0.000001</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Just like before, using <code>"e"</code> can help. If we‚Äôd like to avoid writing the zeroes explicitly, we could say the same as:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb408"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb408-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> ms <span class="op">=</span> <span class="fl">1e-6</span><span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// six zeroes to the left from 1</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>If we count the zeroes in <code>0.000001</code>, there are 6 of them. So naturally it‚Äôs <code>1e-6</code>.</p>
<p>In other words, a negative number after <code>"e"</code> means a division by 1 with the given number of zeroes:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb409"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb409-1" title="1"><span class="co">// -3 divides by 1 with 3 zeroes</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb409-2" title="2"><span class="fl">1e-3</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="dv">1</span> / <span class="dv">1000</span> (<span class="op">=</span><span class="fl">0.001</span>)</a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb409-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb409-4" title="4"><span class="co">// -6 divides by 1 with 6 zeroes</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb409-5" title="5"><span class="fl">1.23e-6</span> <span class="op">=</span> <span class="fl">1.23</span> / <span class="dv">1000000</span> (<span class="op">=</span><span class="fl">0.00000123</span>)</a></code></pre></div>
<h3 id="hex-binary-and-octal-numbers">Hex, binary and octal numbers</h3>
<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexadecimal">Hexadecimal</a> numbers are widely used in JavaScript to represent colors, encode characters, and for many other things. So naturally, there exists a shorter way to write them: <code>0x</code> and then the number.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 0xff ); // 255 alert( 0xFF ); // 255 (the same, case doesn't matter)</code></p>
<p>Binary and octal numeral systems are rarely used, but also supported using the <code>0b</code> and <code>0o</code> prefixes:</p>
<p>```js run let a = 0b11111111; // binary form of 255 let b = 0o377; // octal form of 255</p>
<p>alert( a == b ); // true, the same number 255 at both sides ```</p>
<p>There are only 3 numeral systems with such support. For other numeral systems, we should use the function <code>parseInt</code> (which we will see later in this chapter).</p>
<h2 id="tostringbase">toString(base)</h2>
<p>The method <code>num.toString(base)</code> returns a string representation of <code>num</code> in the numeral system with the given <code>base</code>.</p>
<p>For example: ```js run let num = 255;</p>
<p>alert( num.toString(16) ); // ff alert( num.toString(2) ); // 11111111 ```</p>
<p>The <code>base</code> can vary from <code>2</code> to <code>36</code>. By default it‚Äôs <code>10</code>.</p>
<p>Common use cases for this are:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>base=16</strong> is used for hex colors, character encodings etc, digits can be <code>0..9</code> or <code>A..F</code>.</li>
<li><strong>base=2</strong> is mostly for debugging bitwise operations, digits can be <code>0</code> or <code>1</code>.</li>
<li><p><strong>base=36</strong> is the maximum, digits can be <code>0..9</code> or <code>A..Z</code>. The whole latin alphabet is used to represent a number. A funny, but useful case for <code>36</code> is when we need to turn a long numeric identifier into something shorter, for example to make a short url. Can simply represent it in the numeral system with base <code>36</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run   alert( 123456..toString(36) ); // 2n9c</code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>``<code>warn header="Two dots to call a method" Please note that two dots in</code>123456..toString(36)<code>is not a typo. If we want to call a method directly on a number, like</code>toString<code>in the example above, then we need to place two dots</code>..` after it.</p>
<p>If we placed a single dot: <code>123456.toString(36)</code>, then there would be an error, because JavaScript syntax implies the decimal part after the first dot. And if we place one more dot, then JavaScript knows that the decimal part is empty and now goes the method.</p>
<p>Also could write <code>(123456).toString(36)</code>. ```</p>
<h2 id="rounding">Rounding</h2>
<p>One of the most used operations when working with numbers is rounding.</p>
<p>There are several built-in functions for rounding:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>Math.floor</code></dt>
<dd>Rounds down: <code>3.1</code> becomes <code>3</code>, and <code>-1.1</code> becomes <code>-2</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>Math.ceil</code></dt>
<dd>Rounds up: <code>3.1</code> becomes <code>4</code>, and <code>-1.1</code> becomes <code>-1</code>.
</dd>
<dt><code>Math.round</code></dt>
<dd>Rounds to the nearest integer: <code>3.1</code> becomes <code>3</code>, <code>3.6</code> becomes <code>4</code>, the middle case: <code>3.5</code> rounds up to <code>4</code> too.
</dd>
<dt><code>Math.trunc</code> (not supported by Internet Explorer)</dt>
<dd>Removes anything after the decimal point without rounding: <code>3.1</code> becomes <code>3</code>, <code>-1.1</code> becomes <code>-1</code>.
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Here‚Äôs the table to summarize the differences between them:</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th></th>
<th><code>Math.floor</code></th>
<th><code>Math.ceil</code></th>
<th><code>Math.round</code></th>
<th><code>Math.trunc</code></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>3.1</code></td>
<td><code>3</code></td>
<td><code>4</code></td>
<td><code>3</code></td>
<td><code>3</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>3.6</code></td>
<td><code>3</code></td>
<td><code>4</code></td>
<td><code>4</code></td>
<td><code>3</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>-1.1</code></td>
<td><code>-2</code></td>
<td><code>-1</code></td>
<td><code>-1</code></td>
<td><code>-1</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>-1.6</code></td>
<td><code>-2</code></td>
<td><code>-1</code></td>
<td><code>-2</code></td>
<td><code>-1</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>These functions cover all of the possible ways to deal with the decimal part of a number. But what if we‚Äôd like to round the number to <code>n-th</code> digit after the decimal?</p>
<p>For instance, we have <code>1.2345</code> and want to round it to 2 digits, getting only <code>1.23</code>.</p>
<p>There are two ways to do so:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>Multiply-and-divide.</p>
<p>For example, to round the number to the 2nd digit after the decimal, we can multiply the number by <code>100</code> (or a bigger power of 10), call the rounding function and then divide it back. ```js run let num = 1.23456;</p>
<p>alert( Math.round(num * 100) / 100 ); // 1.23456 -&gt; 123.456 -&gt; 123 -&gt; 1.23 ```</p></li>
<li><p>The method <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number/toFixed">toFixed(n)</a> rounds the number to <code>n</code> digits after the point and returns a string representation of the result.</p>
<p><code>js run  let num = 12.34;  alert( num.toFixed(1) ); // "12.3"</code></p>
<p>This rounds up or down to the nearest value, similar to <code>Math.round</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run  let num = 12.36;  alert( num.toFixed(1) ); // "12.4"</code></p>
<p>Please note that result of <code>toFixed</code> is a string. If the decimal part is shorter than required, zeroes are appended to the end:</p>
<p><code>js run  let num = 12.34;  alert( num.toFixed(5) ); // "12.34000", added zeroes to make exactly 5 digits</code></p>
<p>We can convert it to a number using the unary plus or a <code>Number()</code> call: <code>+num.toFixed(5)</code>.</p></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="imprecise-calculations">Imprecise calculations</h2>
<p>Internally, a number is represented in 64-bit format <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_754-2008_revision">IEEE-754</a>, so there are exactly 64 bits to store a number: 52 of them are used to store the digits, 11 of them store the position of the decimal point (they are zero for integer numbers), and 1 bit is for the sign.</p>
<p>If a number is too big, it would overflow the 64-bit storage, potentially giving an infinity:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 1e500 ); // Infinity</code></p>
<p>What may be a little less obvious, but happens quite often, is the loss of precision.</p>
<p>Consider this (falsy!) test:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3 ); // *!*false*/!*</code></p>
<p>That‚Äôs right, if we check whether the sum of <code>0.1</code> and <code>0.2</code> is <code>0.3</code>, we get <code>false</code>.</p>
<p>Strange! What is it then if not <code>0.3</code>?</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 0.1 + 0.2 ); // 0.30000000000000004</code></p>
<p>Ouch! There are more consequences than an incorrect comparison here. Imagine you‚Äôre making an e-shopping site and the visitor puts <code>$0.10</code> and <code>$0.20</code> goods into their cart. The order total will be <code>$0.30000000000000004</code>. That would surprise anyone.</p>
<p>But why does this happen?</p>
<p>A number is stored in memory in its binary form, a sequence of bits - ones and zeroes. But fractions like <code>0.1</code>, <code>0.2</code> that look simple in the decimal numeric system are actually unending fractions in their binary form.</p>
<p>In other words, what is <code>0.1</code>? It is one divided by ten <code>1/10</code>, one-tenth. In decimal numeral system such numbers are easily representable. Compare it to one-third: <code>1/3</code>. It becomes an endless fraction <code>0.33333(3)</code>.</p>
<p>So, division by powers <code>10</code> is guaranteed to work well in the decimal system, but division by <code>3</code> is not. For the same reason, in the binary numeral system, the division by powers of <code>2</code> is guaranteed to work, but <code>1/10</code> becomes an endless binary fraction.</p>
<p>There‚Äôs just no way to store <em>exactly 0.1</em> or <em>exactly 0.2</em> using the binary system, just like there is no way to store one-third as a decimal fraction.</p>
<p>The numeric format IEEE-754 solves this by rounding to the nearest possible number. These rounding rules normally don‚Äôt allow us to see that ‚Äútiny precision loss‚Äù, but it exists.</p>
<p>We can see this in action: <code>js run alert( 0.1.toFixed(20) ); // 0.10000000000000000555</code></p>
<p>And when we sum two numbers, their ‚Äúprecision losses‚Äù add up.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs why <code>0.1 + 0.2</code> is not exactly <code>0.3</code>.</p>
<p>```smart header=‚ÄúNot only JavaScript‚Äù The same issue exists in many other programming languages.</p>
<p>PHP, Java, C, Perl, Ruby give exactly the same result, because they are based on the same numeric format. ```</p>
<p>Can we work around the problem? Sure, the most reliable method is to round the result with the help of a method <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Number/toFixed">toFixed(n)</a>:</p>
<p><code>js run let sum = 0.1 + 0.2; alert( sum.toFixed(2) ); // 0.30</code></p>
<p>Please note that <code>toFixed</code> always returns a string. It ensures that it has 2 digits after the decimal point. That‚Äôs actually convenient if we have an e-shopping and need to show <code>$0.30</code>. For other cases, we can use the unary plus to coerce it into a number:</p>
<p><code>js run let sum = 0.1 + 0.2; alert( +sum.toFixed(2) ); // 0.3</code></p>
<p>We also can temporarily multiply the numbers by 100 (or a bigger number) to turn them into integers, do the maths, and then divide back. Then, as we‚Äôre doing maths with integers, the error somewhat decreases, but we still get it on division:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( (0.1 * 10 + 0.2 * 10) / 10 ); // 0.3 alert( (0.28 * 100 + 0.14 * 100) / 100); // 0.4200000000000001</code></p>
<p>So, multiply/divide approach reduces the error, but doesn‚Äôt remove it totally.</p>
<p>Sometimes we could try to evade fractions at all. Like if we‚Äôre dealing with a shop, then we can store prices in cents instead of dollars. But what if we apply a discount of 30%? In practice, totally evading fractions is rarely possible. Just round them to cut ‚Äútails‚Äù when needed.</p>
<p>````smart header=‚ÄúThe funny thing‚Äù Try running this:</p>
<p><code>js run // Hello! I'm a self-increasing number! alert( 9999999999999999 ); // shows 10000000000000000</code></p>
<p>This suffers from the same issue: a loss of precision. There are 64 bits for the number, 52 of them can be used to store digits, but that‚Äôs not enough. So the least significant digits disappear.</p>
<p>JavaScript doesn‚Äôt trigger an error in such events. It does its best to fit the number into the desired format, but unfortunately, this format is not big enough. ````</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Two zeroes" Another funny consequence of the internal representation of numbers is the existence of two zeroes:</code>0<code>and</code>-0`.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs because a sign is represented by a single bit, so it can be set or not set for any number including a zero.</p>
<p>In most cases the distinction is unnoticeable, because operators are suited to treat them as the same. ```</p>
<h2 id="tests-isfinite-and-isnan">Tests: isFinite and isNaN</h2>
<p>Remember these two special numeric values?</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Infinity</code> (and <code>-Infinity</code>) is a special numeric value that is greater (less) than anything.</li>
<li><code>NaN</code> represents an error.</li>
</ul>
<p>They belong to the type <code>number</code>, but are not ‚Äúnormal‚Äù numbers, so there are special functions to check for them:</p>
<ul>
<li><p><code>isNaN(value)</code> converts its argument to a number and then tests it for being <code>NaN</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run   alert( isNaN(NaN) ); // true   alert( isNaN("str") ); // true</code></p>
<p>But do we need this function? Can‚Äôt we just use the comparison <code>=== NaN</code>? Sorry, but the answer is no. The value <code>NaN</code> is unique in that it does not equal anything, including itself:</p>
<p><code>js run   alert( NaN === NaN ); // false</code></p></li>
<li><p><code>isFinite(value)</code> converts its argument to a number and returns <code>true</code> if it‚Äôs a regular number, not <code>NaN/Infinity/-Infinity</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run   alert( isFinite("15") ); // true   alert( isFinite("str") ); // false, because a special value: NaN   alert( isFinite(Infinity) ); // false, because a special value: Infinity</code></p></li>
</ul>
<p>Sometimes <code>isFinite</code> is used to validate whether a string value is a regular number:</p>
<p>```js run let num = +prompt(‚ÄúEnter a number‚Äù, ‚Äô‚Äô);</p>
<p>// will be true unless you enter Infinity, -Infinity or not a number alert( isFinite(num) ); ```</p>
<p>Please note that an empty or a space-only string is treated as <code>0</code> in all numeric functions including <code>isFinite</code>.</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="Compare with</code>Object.is`"</p>
<p>There is a special built-in method <a href="mdn:js/Object/is"><code>Object.is</code></a> that compares values like <code>===</code>, but is more reliable for two edge cases:</p>
<ol type="1">
<li>It works with <code>NaN</code>: <code>Object.is(NaN, NaN) === true</code>, that‚Äôs a good thing.</li>
<li>Values <code>0</code> and <code>-0</code> are different: <code>Object.is(0, -0) === false</code>, technically that‚Äôs true, because internally the number has a sign bit that may be different even if all other bits are zeroes.</li>
</ol>
<p>In all other cases, <code>Object.is(a, b)</code> is the same as <code>a === b</code>.</p>
<p>This way of comparison is often used in JavaScript specification. When an internal algorithm needs to compare two values for being exactly the same, it uses <code>Object.is</code> (internally called <a href="https://tc39.github.io/ecma262/#sec-samevalue">SameValue</a>). ```</p>
<h2 id="parseint-and-parsefloat">parseInt and parseFloat</h2>
<p>Numeric conversion using a plus <code>+</code> or <code>Number()</code> is strict. If a value is not exactly a number, it fails:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( +"100px" ); // NaN</code></p>
<p>The sole exception is spaces at the beginning or at the end of the string, as they are ignored.</p>
<p>But in real life we often have values in units, like <code>"100px"</code> or <code>"12pt"</code> in CSS. Also in many countries the currency symbol goes after the amount, so we have <code>"19‚Ç¨"</code> and would like to extract a numeric value out of that.</p>
<p>That‚Äôs what <code>parseInt</code> and <code>parseFloat</code> are for.</p>
<p>They ‚Äúread‚Äù a number from a string until they can‚Äôt. In case of an error, the gathered number is returned. The function <code>parseInt</code> returns an integer, whilst <code>parseFloat</code> will return a floating-point number:</p>
<p>```js run alert( parseInt(‚Äò100px‚Äô) ); // 100 alert( parseFloat(‚Äò12.5em‚Äô) ); // 12.5</p>
<p>alert( parseInt(‚Äò12.3‚Äô) ); // 12, only the integer part is returned alert( parseFloat(‚Äò12.3.4‚Äô) ); // 12.3, the second point stops the reading ```</p>
<p>There are situations when <code>parseInt/parseFloat</code> will return <code>NaN</code>. It happens when no digits could be read:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( parseInt('a123') ); // NaN, the first symbol stops the process</code></p>
<p>```<code>smart header="The second argument of</code>parseInt(str, radix)<code>" The</code>parseInt()<code>function has an optional second parameter. It specifies the base of the numeral system, so</code>parseInt` can also parse strings of hex numbers, binary numbers and so on:</p>
<p>```js run alert( parseInt(‚Äò0xff‚Äô, 16) ); // 255 alert( parseInt(‚Äòff‚Äô, 16) ); // 255, without 0x also works</p>
<p>alert( parseInt(‚Äò2n9c‚Äô, 36) ); // 123456</p>
<pre><code></code></pre>
<h2 id="other-math-functions">Other math functions</h2>
<p>JavaScript has a built-in <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math">Math</a> object which contains a small library of mathematical functions and constants.</p>
<p>A few examples:</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>Math.random()</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns a random number from 0 to 1 (not including 1).</p>
<p><code>js run alert( Math.random() ); // 0.1234567894322 alert( Math.random() ); // 0.5435252343232 alert( Math.random() ); // ... (any random numbers)</code></p>
</dd>
<dt><code>Math.max(a, b, c...)</code> / <code>Math.min(a, b, c...)</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns the greatest/smallest from the arbitrary number of arguments.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( Math.max(3, 5, -10, 0, 1) ); // 5 alert( Math.min(1, 2) ); // 1</code></p>
</dd>
<dt><code>Math.pow(n, power)</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns <code>n</code> raised to the given power.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( Math.pow(2, 10) ); // 2 in power 10 = 1024</code></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>There are more functions and constants in <code>Math</code> object, including trigonometry, which you can find in the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math">docs for the Math object</a>.</p>
<h2 id="summary-55">Summary</h2>
<p>To write numbers with many zeroes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Append <code>"e"</code> with the zeroes count to the number. Like: <code>123e6</code> is the same as <code>123</code> with 6 zeroes <code>123000000</code>.</li>
<li>A negative number after <code>"e"</code> causes the number to be divided by 1 with given zeroes. E.g. <code>123e-6</code> means <code>0.000123</code> (<code>123</code> millionths).</li>
</ul>
<p>For different numeral systems:</p>
<ul>
<li>Can write numbers directly in hex (<code>0x</code>), octal (<code>0o</code>) and binary (<code>0b</code>) systems.</li>
<li><code>parseInt(str, base)</code> parses the string <code>str</code> into an integer in numeral system with given <code>base</code>, <code>2 ‚â§ base ‚â§ 36</code>.</li>
<li><code>num.toString(base)</code> converts a number to a string in the numeral system with the given <code>base</code>.</li>
</ul>
<p>For converting values like <code>12pt</code> and <code>100px</code> to a number:</p>
<ul>
<li>Use <code>parseInt/parseFloat</code> for the ‚Äúsoft‚Äù conversion, which reads a number from a string and then returns the value they could read before the error.</li>
</ul>
<p>For fractions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Round using <code>Math.floor</code>, <code>Math.ceil</code>, <code>Math.trunc</code>, <code>Math.round</code> or <code>num.toFixed(precision)</code>.</li>
<li>Make sure to remember there‚Äôs a loss of precision when working with fractions.</li>
</ul>
<p>More mathematical functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>See the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math">Math</a> object when you need them. The library is very small, but can cover basic needs. # Strings</li>
</ul>
<p>In JavaScript, the textual data is stored as strings. There is no separate type for a single character.</p>
<p>The internal format for strings is always <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-16">UTF-16</a>, it is not tied to the page encoding.</p>
<h2 id="quotes">Quotes</h2>
<p>Let‚Äôs recall the kinds of quotes.</p>
<p>Strings can be enclosed within either single quotes, double quotes or backticks:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb411"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb411-1" title="1"><span class="kw">let</span> single <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&#39;single-quoted&#39;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb411-2" title="2"><span class="kw">let</span> double <span class="op">=</span> <span class="st">&quot;double-quoted&quot;</span><span class="op">;</span></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb411-3" title="3"></a>
<a class="sourceLine" id="cb411-4" title="4"><span class="kw">let</span> backticks <span class="op">=</span> <span class="vs">`backticks`</span><span class="op">;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<p>Single and double quotes are essentially the same. Backticks, however, allow us to embed any expression into the string, by wrapping it in <code>${‚Ä¶}</code>:</p>
<p>```js run function sum(a, b) { return a + b; }</p>
<p>alert(<code>1 + 2 = ${sum(1, 2)}.</code>); // 1 + 2 = 3. ```</p>
<p>Another advantage of using backticks is that they allow a string to span multiple lines:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let guestList =</code>Guests: * John * Pete * Mary `;</p>
<p>alert(guestList); // a list of guests, multiple lines ```</p>
<p>Looks natural, right? But single or double quotes do not work this way.</p>
<p>If we use them and try to use multiple lines, there‚Äôll be an error:</p>
<p><code>js run let guestList = "Guests: // Error: Unexpected token ILLEGAL   * John";</code></p>
<p>Single and double quotes come from ancient times of language creation when the need for multiline strings was not taken into account. Backticks appeared much later and thus are more versatile.</p>
<p>Backticks also allow us to specify a ‚Äútemplate function‚Äù before the first backtick. The syntax is: <code>func`string`</code>. The function <code>func</code> is called automatically, receives the string and embedded expressions and can process them. This is called ‚Äútagged templates‚Äù. This feature makes it easier to implement custom templating, but is rarely used in practice. You can read more about it in the <a href="mdn:/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals#Tagged_templates">manual</a>.</p>
<h2 id="special-characters">Special characters</h2>
<p>It is still possible to create multiline strings with single and double quotes by using a so-called ‚Äúnewline character‚Äù, written as <code>\n</code>, which denotes a line break:</p>
<p>```js run let guestList = ‚ÄúGuests:JohnPeteMary‚Äù;</p>
<p>alert(guestList); // a multiline list of guests ```</p>
<p>For example, these two lines are equal, just written differently:</p>
<p>```js run let str1 = ‚ÄúHello‚Äù; // two lines using a ‚Äúnewline symbol‚Äù</p>
<p>// two lines using a normal newline and backticks let str2 = <code>Hello World</code>;</p>
<p>alert(str1 == str2); // true ```</p>
<p>There are other, less common ‚Äúspecial‚Äù characters.</p>
<p>Here‚Äôs the full list:</p>
<table>
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 45%" />
<col style="width: 54%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>Character</th>
<th>Description</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>\n</code></td>
<td>New line</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>\r</code></td>
<td>Carriage return: not used alone. Windows text files use a combination of two characters <code>\r\n</code> to represent a line break.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>\'</code>, <code>\"</code></td>
<td>Quotes</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>\\</code></td>
<td>Backslash</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>\t</code></td>
<td>Tab</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>\b</code>, <code>\f</code>, <code>\v</code></td>
<td>Backspace, Form Feed, Vertical Tab ‚Äì kept for compatibility, not used nowadays.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>\xXX</code></td>
<td>Unicode character with the given hexadecimal Unicode <code>XX</code>, e.g.¬†<code>'\x7A'</code> is the same as <code>'z'</code>.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>\uXXXX</code></td>
<td>A Unicode symbol with the hex code <code>XXXX</code> in UTF-16 encoding, for instance <code>\u00A9</code> ‚Äì is a Unicode for the copyright symbol <code>¬©</code>. It must be exactly 4 hex digits.</td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>\u{X‚Ä¶XXXXXX}</code> (1 to 6 hex characters)</td>
<td>A Unicode symbol with the given UTF-32 encoding. Some rare characters are encoded with two Unicode symbols, taking 4 bytes. This way we can insert long codes.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>Examples with Unicode:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "\u00A9" ); // ¬© alert( "\u{20331}" ); // ‰Ω´, a rare Chinese hieroglyph (long Unicode) alert( "\u{1F60D}" ); // üòç, a smiling face symbol (another long Unicode)</code></p>
<p>All special characters start with a backslash character <code>\</code>. It is also called an ‚Äúescape character‚Äù.</p>
<p>We might also use it if we wanted to insert a quote into the string.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'I*!*\'*/!*m the Walrus!' ); // *!*I'm*/!* the Walrus!</code></p>
<p>As you can see, we have to prepend the inner quote by the backslash <code>\'</code>, because otherwise it would indicate the string end.</p>
<p>Of course, only the quotes that are the same as the enclosing ones need to be escaped. So, as a more elegant solution, we could switch to double quotes or backticks instead:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( `I'm the Walrus!` ); // I'm the Walrus!</code></p>
<p>Note that the backslash <code>\</code> serves for the correct reading of the string by JavaScript, then disappears. The in-memory string has no <code>\</code>. You can clearly see that in <code>alert</code> from the examples above.</p>
<p>But what if we need to show an actual backslash <code>\</code> within the string?</p>
<p>That‚Äôs possible, but we need to double it like <code>\\</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( `The backslash: \\` ); // The backslash: \</code></p>
<h2 id="string-length">String length</h2>
<p>The <code>length</code> property has the string length:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( `My\n`.length ); // 3</code></p>
<p>Note that <code>\n</code> is a single ‚Äúspecial‚Äù character, so the length is indeed <code>3</code>.</p>
<p>``<code>warn header="</code>length<code>is a property" People with a background in some other languages sometimes mistype by calling</code>str.length()<code>instead of just</code>str.length`. That doesn‚Äôt work.</p>
<p>Please note that <code>str.length</code> is a numeric property, not a function. There is no need to add parenthesis after it. ```</p>
<h2 id="accessing-characters">Accessing characters</h2>
<p>To get a character at position <code>pos</code>, use square brackets <code>[pos]</code> or call the method <a href="mdn:js/String/charAt">str.charAt(pos)</a>. The first character starts from the zero position:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>Hello`;</p>
<p>// the first character alert( str[0] ); // H alert( str.charAt(0) ); // H</p>
<p>// the last character alert( str[str.length - 1] ); // o ```</p>
<p>The square brackets are a modern way of getting a character, while <code>charAt</code> exists mostly for historical reasons.</p>
<p>The only difference between them is that if no character is found, <code>[]</code> returns <code>undefined</code>, and <code>charAt</code> returns an empty string:</p>
<p>``<code>js run let str =</code>Hello`;</p>
<p>alert( str[1000] ); // undefined alert( str.charAt(1000) ); // ‚Äô‚Äô (an empty string) ```</p>
<p>We can also iterate over characters using <code>for..of</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run for (let char of "Hello") {   alert(char); // H,e,l,l,o (char becomes "H", then "e", then "l" etc) }</code></p>
<h2 id="strings-are-immutable">Strings are immutable</h2>
<p>Strings can‚Äôt be changed in JavaScript. It is impossible to change a character.</p>
<p>Let‚Äôs try it to show that it doesn‚Äôt work:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòHi‚Äô;</p>
<p>str[0] = ‚Äòh‚Äô; // error alert( str[0] ); // doesn‚Äôt work ```</p>
<p>The usual workaround is to create a whole new string and assign it to <code>str</code> instead of the old one.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòHi‚Äô;</p>
<p>str = ‚Äòh‚Äô + str[1]; // replace the string</p>
<p>alert( str ); // hi ```</p>
<p>In the following sections we‚Äôll see more examples of this.</p>
<h2 id="changing-the-case">Changing the case</h2>
<p>Methods <a href="mdn:js/String/toLowerCase">toLowerCase()</a> and <a href="mdn:js/String/toUpperCase">toUpperCase()</a> change the case:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'Interface'.toUpperCase() ); // INTERFACE alert( 'Interface'.toLowerCase() ); // interface</code></p>
<p>Or, if we want a single character lowercased:</p>
<div class="sourceCode" id="cb412"><pre class="sourceCode js"><code class="sourceCode javascript"><a class="sourceLine" id="cb412-1" title="1"><span class="at">alert</span>( <span class="st">&#39;Interface&#39;</span>[<span class="dv">0</span>].<span class="at">toLowerCase</span>() )<span class="op">;</span> <span class="co">// &#39;i&#39;</span></a></code></pre></div>
<h2 id="searching-for-a-substring">Searching for a substring</h2>
<p>There are multiple ways to look for a substring within a string.</p>
<h3 id="str.indexof">str.indexOf</h3>
<p>The first method is <a href="mdn:js/String/indexOf">str.indexOf(substr, pos)</a>.</p>
<p>It looks for the <code>substr</code> in <code>str</code>, starting from the given position <code>pos</code>, and returns the position where the match was found or <code>-1</code> if nothing can be found.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòWidget with id‚Äô;</p>
<p>alert( str.indexOf(‚ÄòWidget‚Äô) ); // 0, because ‚ÄòWidget‚Äô is found at the beginning alert( str.indexOf(‚Äòwidget‚Äô) ); // -1, not found, the search is case-sensitive</p>
<p>alert( str.indexOf(‚Äúid‚Äù) ); // 1, ‚Äúid‚Äù is found at the position 1 (..idget with id) ```</p>
<p>The optional second parameter allows us to start searching from a given position.</p>
<p>For instance, the first occurrence of <code>"id"</code> is at position <code>1</code>. To look for the next occurrence, let‚Äôs start the search from position <code>2</code>:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòWidget with id‚Äô;</p>
<p>alert( str.indexOf(‚Äòid‚Äô, 2) ) // 12 ```</p>
<p>If we‚Äôre interested in all occurrences, we can run <code>indexOf</code> in a loop. Every new call is made with the position after the previous match:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄòAs sly as a fox, as strong as an ox‚Äô;</p>
<p>let target = ‚Äòas‚Äô; // let‚Äôs look for it</p>
<p>let pos = 0; while (true) { let foundPos = str.indexOf(target, pos); if (foundPos == -1) break;</p>
<p>alert( <code>Found at ${foundPos}</code> ); pos = foundPos + 1; // continue the search from the next position } ```</p>
<p>The same algorithm can be layed out shorter:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúAs sly as a fox, as strong as an ox‚Äù; let target = ‚Äúas‚Äù;</p>
<p><em>!</em> let pos = -1; while ((pos = str.indexOf(target, pos + 1)) != -1) { alert( pos ); } <em>/!</em> ```</p>
<p>``<code>smart header="</code>str.lastIndexOf(substr, position)`" There is also a similar method <a href="mdn:js/String/lastIndexOf">str.lastIndexOf(substr, position)</a> that searches from the end of a string to its beginning.</p>
<p>It would list the occurrences in the reverse order. ```</p>
<p>There is a slight inconvenience with <code>indexOf</code> in the <code>if</code> test. We can‚Äôt put it in the <code>if</code> like this:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúWidget with id‚Äù;</p>
<p>if (str.indexOf(‚ÄúWidget‚Äù)) { alert(‚ÄúWe found it‚Äù); // doesn‚Äôt work! } ```</p>
<p>The <code>alert</code> in the example above doesn‚Äôt show because <code>str.indexOf("Widget")</code> returns <code>0</code> (meaning that it found the match at the starting position). Right, but <code>if</code> considers <code>0</code> to be <code>false</code>.</p>
<p>So, we should actually check for <code>-1</code>, like this:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúWidget with id‚Äù;</p>
<p><em>!</em> if (str.indexOf(‚ÄúWidget‚Äù) != -1) { <em>/!</em> alert(‚ÄúWe found it‚Äù); // works now! } ```</p>
<h4 id="the-bitwise-not-trick">The bitwise NOT trick</h4>
<p>One of the old tricks used here is the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Bitwise_NOT">bitwise NOT</a> <code>~</code> operator. It converts the number to a 32-bit integer (removes the decimal part if exists) and then reverses all bits in its binary representation.</p>
<p>In practice, that means a simple thing: for 32-bit integers <code>~n</code> equals <code>-(n+1)</code>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( ~2 ); // -3, the same as -(2+1) alert( ~1 ); // -2, the same as -(1+1) alert( ~0 ); // -1, the same as -(0+1) *!* alert( ~-1 ); // 0, the same as -(-1+1) */!*</code></p>
<p>As we can see, <code>~n</code> is zero only if <code>n == -1</code> (that‚Äôs for any 32-bit signed integer <code>n</code>).</p>
<p>So, the test <code>if ( ~str.indexOf("...") )</code> is truthy only if the result of <code>indexOf</code> is not <code>-1</code>. In other words, when there is a match.</p>
<p>People use it to shorten <code>indexOf</code> checks:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚ÄúWidget‚Äù;</p>
<p>if (~str.indexOf(‚ÄúWidget‚Äù)) { alert( ‚ÄòFound it!‚Äô ); // works } ```</p>
<p>It is usually not recommended to use language features in a non-obvious way, but this particular trick is widely used in old code, so we should understand it.</p>
<p>Just remember: <code>if (~str.indexOf(...))</code> reads as ‚Äúif found‚Äù.</p>
<p>To be precise though, as big numbers are truncated to 32 bits by <code>~</code> operator, there exist other numbers that give <code>0</code>, the smallest is <code>~4294967295=0</code>. That makes such check correct only if a string is not that long.</p>
<p>Right now we can see this trick only in the old code, as modern JavaScript provides <code>.includes</code> method (see below).</p>
<h3 id="includes-startswith-endswith">includes, startsWith, endsWith</h3>
<p>The more modern method <a href="mdn:js/String/includes">str.includes(substr, pos)</a> returns <code>true/false</code> depending on whether <code>str</code> contains <code>substr</code> within.</p>
<p>It‚Äôs the right choice if we need to test for the match, but don‚Äôt need its position:</p>
<p>```js run alert( ‚ÄúWidget with id‚Äù.includes(‚ÄúWidget‚Äù) ); // true</p>
<p>alert( ‚ÄúHello‚Äù.includes(‚ÄúBye‚Äù) ); // false ```</p>
<p>The optional second argument of <code>str.includes</code> is the position to start searching from:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "Widget".includes("id") ); // true alert( "Widget".includes("id", 3) ); // false, from position 3 there is no "id"</code></p>
<p>The methods <a href="mdn:js/String/startsWith">str.startsWith</a> and <a href="mdn:js/String/endsWith">str.endsWith</a> do exactly what they say:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( "Widget".startsWith("Wid") ); // true, "Widget" starts with "Wid" alert( "Widget".endsWith("get") ); // true, "Widget" ends with "get"</code></p>
<h2 id="getting-a-substring">Getting a substring</h2>
<p>There are 3 methods in JavaScript to get a substring: <code>substring</code>, <code>substr</code> and <code>slice</code>.</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>str.slice(start [, end])</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns the part of the string from <code>start</code> to (but not including) <code>end</code>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run let str = "stringify"; alert( str.slice(0, 5) ); // 'strin', the substring from 0 to 5 (not including 5) alert( str.slice(0, 1) ); // 's', from 0 to 1, but not including 1, so only character at 0</code></p>
<p>If there is no second argument, then <code>slice</code> goes till the end of the string:</p>
<p><code>js run let str = "st*!*ringify*/!*"; alert( str.slice(2) ); // 'ringify', from the 2nd position till the end</code></p>
<p>Negative values for <code>start/end</code> are also possible. They mean the position is counted from the string end:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äústrin<em>!</em>gif<em>/!</em>y‚Äù;</p>
<p>// start at the 4th position from the right, end at the 1st from the right alert( str.slice(-4, -1) ); // ‚Äògif‚Äô ```</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>str.substring(start [, end])</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns the part of the string <em>between</em> <code>start</code> and <code>end</code>.</p>
<p>This is almost the same as <code>slice</code>, but it allows <code>start</code> to be greater than <code>end</code>.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äúst<em>!</em>ring<em>/!</em>ify‚Äù;</p>
<p>// these are same for substring alert( str.substring(2, 6) ); // ‚Äúring‚Äù alert( str.substring(6, 2) ); // ‚Äúring‚Äù</p>
<p>// ‚Ä¶but not for slice: alert( str.slice(2, 6) ); // ‚Äúring‚Äù (the same) alert( str.slice(6, 2) ); // "" (an empty string)</p>
<p>```</p>
<p>Negative arguments are (unlike slice) not supported, they are treated as <code>0</code>.</p>
</dd>
<dt><code>str.substr(start [, length])</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns the part of the string from <code>start</code>, with the given <code>length</code>.</p>
<p>In contrast with the previous methods, this one allows us to specify the <code>length</code> instead of the ending position:</p>
<p><code>js run let str = "st*!*ring*/!*ify"; alert( str.substr(2, 4) ); // 'ring', from the 2nd position get 4 characters</code></p>
<p>The first argument may be negative, to count from the end:</p>
<p><code>js run let str = "strin*!*gi*/!*fy"; alert( str.substr(-4, 2) ); // 'gi', from the 4th position get 2 characters</code></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Let‚Äôs recap these methods to avoid any confusion:</p>
<table>
<colgroup>
<col style="width: 26%" />
<col style="width: 36%" />
<col style="width: 36%" />
</colgroup>
<thead>
<tr class="header">
<th>method</th>
<th>selects‚Ä¶</th>
<th>negatives</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>slice(start, end)</code></td>
<td>from <code>start</code> to <code>end</code> (not including <code>end</code>)</td>
<td>allows negatives</td>
</tr>
<tr class="even">
<td><code>substring(start, end)</code></td>
<td>between <code>start</code> and <code>end</code></td>
<td>negative values mean <code>0</code></td>
</tr>
<tr class="odd">
<td><code>substr(start, length)</code></td>
<td>from <code>start</code> get <code>length</code> characters</td>
<td>allows negative <code>start</code></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>``<code>smart header="Which one to choose?" All of them can do the job. Formally,</code>substr` has a minor drawback: it is described not in the core JavaScript specification, but in Annex B, which covers browser-only features that exist mainly for historical reasons. So, non-browser environments may fail to support it. But in practice it works everywhere.</p>
<p>Of the other two variants, <code>slice</code> is a little bit more flexible, it allows negative arguments and shorter to write. So, it‚Äôs enough to remember solely <code>slice</code> of these three methods. ```</p>
<h2 id="comparing-strings">Comparing strings</h2>
<p>As we know from the chapter <a href="info:comparison" class="uri">info:comparison</a>, strings are compared character-by-character in alphabetical order.</p>
<p>Although, there are some oddities.</p>
<ol type="1">
<li><p>A lowercase letter is always greater than the uppercase:</p>
<p><code>js run  alert( 'a' &gt; 'Z' ); // true</code></p></li>
<li><p>Letters with diacritical marks are ‚Äúout of order‚Äù:</p>
<p><code>js run  alert( '√ñsterreich' &gt; 'Zealand' ); // true</code></p>
<p>This may lead to strange results if we sort these country names. Usually people would expect <code>Zealand</code> to come after <code>√ñsterreich</code> in the list.</p></li>
</ol>
<p>To understand what happens, let‚Äôs review the internal representation of strings in JavaScript.</p>
<p>All strings are encoded using <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-16">UTF-16</a>. That is: each character has a corresponding numeric code. There are special methods that allow to get the character for the code and back.</p>
<dl>
<dt><code>str.codePointAt(pos)</code></dt>
<dd><p>Returns the code for the character at position <code>pos</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run // different case letters have different codes alert( "z".codePointAt(0) ); // 122 alert( "Z".codePointAt(0) ); // 90</code></p>
</dd>
<dt><code>String.fromCodePoint(code)</code></dt>
<dd><p>Creates a character by its numeric <code>code</code></p>
<p><code>js run alert( String.fromCodePoint(90) ); // Z</code></p>
<p>We can also add Unicode characters by their codes using <code>\u</code> followed by the hex code:</p>
<p><code>js run // 90 is 5a in hexadecimal system alert( '\u005a' ); // Z</code></p>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>Now let‚Äôs see the characters with codes <code>65..220</code> (the latin alphabet and a little bit extra) by making a string of them:</p>
<p>```js run let str = ‚Äô‚Äô;</p>
<p>for (let i = 65; i &lt;= 220; i++) { str += String.fromCodePoint(i); } alert( str ); // ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ[]^_`abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz{|}~¬Ä¬Å¬Ç¬É¬Ñ // ¬°¬¢¬£¬§¬•¬¶¬ß¬®¬©¬™¬´¬¨¬≠¬Æ¬Ø¬∞¬±¬≤¬≥¬¥¬µ¬∂¬∑¬∏¬π¬∫¬ª¬º¬Ω¬æ¬ø√Ä√Å√Ç√É√Ñ√Ö√Ü√á√à√â√ä√ã√å√ç√é√è√ê√ë√í√ì√î√ï√ñ√ó√ò√ô√ö√õ√ú ```</p>
<p>See? Capital characters go first, then a few special ones, then lowercase characters, and <code>√ñ</code> near the end of the output.</p>
<p>Now it becomes obvious why <code>a &gt; Z</code>.</p>
<p>The characters are compared by their numeric code. The greater code means that the character is greater. The code for <code>a</code> (97) is greater than the code for <code>Z</code> (90).</p>
<ul>
<li>All lowercase letters go after uppercase letters because their codes are greater.</li>
<li>Some letters like <code>√ñ</code> stand apart from the main alphabet. Here, it‚Äôs code is greater than anything from <code>a</code> to <code>z</code>.</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="correct-comparisons-correct-comparisons">Correct comparisons [#correct-comparisons]</h3>
<p>The ‚Äúright‚Äù algorithm to do string comparisons is more complex than it may seem, because alphabets are different for different languages.</p>
<p>So, the browser needs to know the language to compare.</p>
<p>Luckily, all modern browsers (IE10- requires the additional library <a href="https://github.com/andyearnshaw/Intl.js/">Intl.js</a>) support the internationalization standard <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-402/1.0/ECMA-402.pdf">ECMA-402</a>.</p>
<p>It provides a special method to compare strings in different languages, following their rules.</p>
<p>The call <a href="mdn:js/String/localeCompare">str.localeCompare(str2)</a> returns an integer indicating whether <code>str</code> is less, equal or greater than <code>str2</code> according to the language rules:</p>
<ul>
<li>Returns a negative number if <code>str</code> is less than <code>str2</code>.</li>
<li>Returns a positive number if <code>str</code> is greater than <code>str2</code>.</li>
<li>Returns <code>0</code> if they are equivalent.</li>
</ul>
<p>For instance:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( '√ñsterreich'.localeCompare('Zealand') ); // -1</code></p>
<p>This method actually has two additional arguments specified in <a href="mdn:js/String/localeCompare">the documentation</a>, which allows it to specify the language (by default taken from the environment, letter order depends on the language) and setup additional rules like case sensitivity or should <code>"a"</code> and <code>"aÃÅ"</code> be treated as the same etc.</p>
<h2 id="internals-unicode">Internals, Unicode</h2>
<p>```warn header=‚ÄúAdvanced knowledge‚Äù The section goes deeper into string internals. This knowledge will be useful for you if you plan to deal with emoji, rare mathematical or hieroglyphic characters or other rare symbols.</p>
<p>You can skip the section if you don‚Äôt plan to support them. ```</p>
<h3 id="surrogate-pairs">Surrogate pairs</h3>
<p>All frequently used characters have 2-byte codes. Letters in most european languages, numbers, and even most hieroglyphs, have a 2-byte representation.</p>
<p>But 2 bytes only allow 65536 combinations and that‚Äôs not enough for every possible symbol. So rare symbols are encoded with a pair of 2-byte characters called ‚Äúa surrogate pair‚Äù.</p>
<p>The length of such symbols is <code>2</code>:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'ùí≥'.length ); // 2, MATHEMATICAL SCRIPT CAPITAL X alert( 'üòÇ'.length ); // 2, FACE WITH TEARS OF JOY alert( '©∑∂'.length ); // 2, a rare Chinese hieroglyph</code></p>
<p>Note that surrogate pairs did not exist at the time when JavaScript was created, and thus are not correctly processed by the language!</p>
<p>We actually have a single symbol in each of the strings above, but the <code>length</code> shows a length of <code>2</code>.</p>
<p><code>String.fromCodePoint</code> and <code>str.codePointAt</code> are few rare methods that deal with surrogate pairs right. They recently appeared in the language. Before them, there were only <a href="mdn:js/String/fromCharCode">String.fromCharCode</a> and <a href="mdn:js/String/charCodeAt">str.charCodeAt</a>. These methods are actually the same as <code>fromCodePoint/codePointAt</code>, but don‚Äôt work with surrogate pairs.</p>
<p>Getting a symbol can be tricky, because surrogate pairs are treated as two characters:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'ùí≥'[0] ); // strange symbols... alert( 'ùí≥'[1] ); // ...pieces of the surrogate pair</code></p>
<p>Note that pieces of the surrogate pair have no meaning without each other. So the alerts in the example above actually display garbage.</p>
<p>Technically, surrogate pairs are also detectable by their codes: if a character has the code in the interval of <code>0xd800..0xdbff</code>, then it is the first part of the surrogate pair. The next character (second part) must have the code in interval <code>0xdc00..0xdfff</code>. These intervals are reserved exclusively for surrogate pairs by the standard.</p>
<p>In the case above:</p>
<p>```js run // charCodeAt is not surrogate-pair aware, so it gives codes for parts</p>
<p>alert( ‚Äòùí≥‚Äô.charCodeAt(0).toString(16) ); // d835, between 0xd800 and 0xdbff alert( ‚Äòùí≥‚Äô.charCodeAt(1).toString(16) ); // dcb3, between 0xdc00 and 0xdfff ```</p>
<p>You will find more ways to deal with surrogate pairs later in the chapter <a href="info:iterable" class="uri">info:iterable</a>. There are probably special libraries for that too, but nothing famous enough to suggest here.</p>
<h3 id="diacritical-marks-and-normalization">Diacritical marks and normalization</h3>
<p>In many languages there are symbols that are composed of the base character with a mark above/under it.</p>
<p>For instance, the letter <code>a</code> can be the base character for: <code>√†√°√¢√§√£√•ƒÅ</code>. Most common ‚Äúcomposite‚Äù character have their own code in the UTF-16 table. But not all of them, because there are too many possible combinations.</p>
<p>To support arbitrary compositions, UTF-16 allows us to use several Unicode characters: the base character followed by one or many ‚Äúmark‚Äù characters that ‚Äúdecorate‚Äù it.</p>
<p>For instance, if we have <code>S</code> followed by the special ‚Äúdot above‚Äù character (code <code>\u0307</code>), it is shown as SÃá.</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'S\u0307' ); // SÃá</code></p>
<p>If we need an additional mark above the letter (or below it) ‚Äì no problem, just add the necessary mark character.</p>
<p>For instance, if we append a character ‚Äúdot below‚Äù (code <code>\u0323</code>), then we‚Äôll have ‚ÄúS with dots above and below‚Äù: <code>SÃáÃ£</code>.</p>
<p>For example:</p>
<p><code>js run alert( 'S\u0307\u0323' ); // SÃáÃ£</code></p>
<p>This provides great flexibility, but also an interesting problem: two characters may visually look the same, but be represented with different Unicode compositions.</p>
<p>For instance:</p>
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/prism/1.23.0/prism.min.js" integrity="sha512-YBk7HhgDZvBxmtOfUdvX0z8IH2d10Hp3aEygaMNhtF8fSOvBZ16D/1bXZTJV6ndk/L/DlXxYStP8jrF77v2MIg==" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>
